A special programme has been designed for the Small Christian Community (SCC), a group of “doers” in every parish, who takes up different responsibilities given to them by their respective priests.

The programme has been christened ‘Live the Faith’, where SCCs will be told to identify the helpless and sick of all communities in the neighbourhood irrespective of religion and stand by them. On Tuesday, the first training will be given at Church Of Christ the King at Park Circus. There will be a sermon where the priest will pick up teachings from the gospels and tell parishioners how to transform them into real life situations. The church feels that too many differences in the name of religion are cropping up these days and they need serious ironing out. The parishioners will be encouraged to intermingle outside their community because tendencies to limit oneself to one’s own religious boundaries are creating barriers.

“The circumstances are changed today and only if we are able to encourage people to forget religious divides and come together as one humanity, problems will be solved. The efforts should start at the micro level so that the rhetoric of understanding, love and mercy replaces that of intolerance and hatred,” said Dominic Gomes, vicar general of the Archdiocese of Kolkata, who heads the SCC programme of the Roman Catholic Church.

The next two trainings will happen at Queen of Peace church at Tollygunge and Holy Family Church at Kestopur. There are 65 parishes that are within the purview of the archdiocese of Kolkata and 470 SCCs that will get trained under the programme. “We are doing this to revitalise our SCCs. Till the time different religious communities in every neighbourhood are able to intermingle freely, problems will irk us. I am trying to re-energise the SCCs to the best of my ability,” the vicar general said.

Every SCC will be encouraged to come back to the church and discuss the pressing issues of the neighbourhood with the priest, who will then take leadership in sending help wherever required across religions. “I think basic human interactions can do magic. We hope after we are able to fully translate what we learn in the scriptures to “doing them” or “living them”, we will be able to see the differences ourselves,” the vicar general said.

Title: SPCA gets functional after delay of 19 years
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Nagpur: Almost over 19 years after central government’s order, the Society for Prevention of Cruelty to Animals (SPCA) has started functioning in the district.

On top agenda are effective implementation of sterilization of strays, curbing illegal breeding of dogs, mandatory licensing of pet shops and creating mass awareness on animal welfare.

Two years back, TOI reported that in 2001, the union government had directed all states to establish SPCA in each district within six months from the date of commencement of rules. The society’s main intention is to prevent cruelty to animals and execute welfare schemes of Animal Welfare Board of India (AWBI). However, Nagpur district had failed in doing so.

Following pressure from citizens and animal welfare groups, the district administration finally formed the society which consists of 11 government and non-government members each. Nagpur is now among the few districts of the state to have a registered society.

In a recently held workshop, state commissionerate of animal husbandry Laxminarayan Mishra directed the society members to initiate action against illegal pet shops operating in the city.

Non-government member and animal activist Karishma Galani highlighted that illegal breeding of dogs is getting rampant in the city. “We will be creating public awareness on buying pets only from licensed shops,” she said.

Apart from this, the society also aims to implement better animal birth control (ABC) programme in the city.

TOI has been repeatedly reporting about the increasing menace of stray dogs in the city. In August, 2017, the Maharashtra Navnirman Sena (MNS) had filed a complaint with state chief minister Devendra Fadnavis stating that there were over 90,000 dogs in the city.

In October last year, a pack of five stray dogs brutally injured a seven-year-old boy at Bhange layout in Jaitala. In the last few months, TOI received many complaints regarding increasing stray population in many areas.

While a sterilization programme is being carried out, activists pointed out that it was not done in a scientific manner. “ABC operations should be carried out ward-wise, keeping in mind proper relocation of the operated dogs. Apart from this, a city like Nagpur should have at least four operation centres,” said Galani.

As per the Centre’s norms, the state government has to provide adequate land and other facilities for constructing infirmaries and animal shelters to the society. The members need to submit its annual report to the Animal Welfare Board of India (AWBI) incorporating the activities undertaken by it.

Title: Two, including a 16-year-old, raped in city
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Rajkot: Two rape cases , one involving a 16-year-old minor , were reported in Rajkot on Sunday.

In the first case, the 16-year-old survivor was befriended by accused Satyajeetsinh Zala on Instagram. According to the police, Zala forced the minor to accompany him to Madhapar Chowkadi and Morbi Road bypass on January 22 evening.

“Zala allegedly forced himself on the girl and tried to assault her sexually. He then allegedly threatened to kill her, if she complained about the incident to anyone. The survivor studies in Class XI,” said N B Dodia, sub-inspector with Rajkot mahila police station.

In the second case, accused Jaideep Dav, raped a 23-year-old woman after lying about his marital status.

According to police, Dav and the survivor became friends in 2019. He allegedly kept his marital status hidden from the survivor, and told her that he was divorcee and also developed physical relationship with her. He signed a registration form declaring himself to be married to the survivor before having physical relationship.

“When the survivor learnt about the deception and confronted him, Dav allegedly beat her up in an inebriated state,” said H J Barwadia of University police station.

Apart from Dav, the survivor has accused Ajay Bhadarka, Darshan Dhranga and Anil Badhia of aiding Dav in the crime. Following this, the trio, too, has been booked.

Title: Man stabbed to death over financial dispute
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

The accused in police custody

Rajkot: A man was stabbed to death over a financial dispute in Jesingpara locality of Amreli district on Saturday night. The accused Karsan Ajani (37), was arrested early on Sunday morning for stabbing Praful Mandora (35) to death, said cops.

Ajani had accosted Mandora near a paan shop at Ramapeer Temple on Rangpur Road and stabbed him four times on the chest and back. Mandora had gone to the paan shop after having his dinner.

Mandora was rushed to Amreli Civil Hospital and later was shifted to a private hospital where he died during treatment shortly after admission.

Ajani was nabbed from the spot soon after the incident. During interrogation, Ajani told the cops that he and Mandora had some ongoing financial dispute after they had parted ways from a joint transportation business for which they had even bought a truck.

“Duo had some dispute over partnership money. Nursing a grudge against Mandora, Ajani decided to kill him,” said R K Karmata, inspector with Amreli local crime branch.

Title: Two arrested for vehicle loot, extortion
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Two accused in police custody

Rajkot: Two persons were arrested for a vehicle loot and extortion in Nilambaug locality of Bhavnagar on Sunday.

Police said the accused, identified as Mohsin Rafai and Avesh Sheikh had allegedly robbed Hussein Jivani of his two-wheeler and also extorted Rs 25,000 from him on Saturday night.

“We acted on Jivani’s complaint and after getting a tip-off about Sheikh being at Matawa Chowk in Arabvad locality of Bhavnagar, we arrested him from the area. Similarly, Rafai was nabbed from Kumbharpara Chowk near Sharda School,” said S N Barot, inspector with Bhavnagar special operation group.

Rafai and Sheikh had allegedly accosted Jivani asking him to pay Rs 50,000 as protection money. When Jivani said he did not have that much amount with him, the accused allegedly took Rs 25,000 from him in cash and also took away his two-wheeler.

Title: Night temperature to remain below 10 degrees C in Patna this week
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Minimum temperatures are likely to be in the range of 9 to 13 degrees C till February 13

PATNA: Sunny days notwithstanding, night temperature is likely to remain below 10 degrees C in Patna and most parts of the state this week as well.

Patna Meteorological Centre claimed that though weather is expected to remain dry, cold westerly winds coming from the snow-laden Himalayan peaks will keep the mercury in night and early morning hours below 10 degrees C at least till February 13. The daily weather bulletin issued by Patna Meteorological Centre on Sunday afternoon stated that fall in night temperature is expected by two to four notches over Bihar during the next 24 hours.

An extended weather bulletin on February 6 stated that minimum temperatures are likely to be in the range of 9 to 13 degrees C till February 13.

Even on Sunday, the minimum temperature at Patna stood at 8.4 degrees C, which was three notches lower than the corresponding normal. Gaya remained the coldest place in the state in the morning with minimum temperature at 6.8 digress C.

“The cold northwesterly winds will continue to blow in the region, keeping a check on rise in minimum temperature till February 15. Maximum temperature is, however, expected to be in the range of 23-25 degrees C till then owing to the clear skies allowing warming up of lower level of atmosphere due to direct solar rays,” an official at Patna Meteorological Centre said.

He said dry weather prevailed and shallow fog was observed at one or two places over the state during last 24 hours.

Meanwhile, a western disturbance is very likely to affect western Himalayan region from February 11 onwards. Met officials, however, ruled out any significant impact of the upcoming western disturbance on the prevailing weather in Bihar.

“Any western disturbance henceforth will not have much impact on weather in Bihar, in terms of significant rainfall or variation in temperature,” the meteorologist said.

The western disturbances are low pressure area or extra-tropical storms originating from Mediterranean Sea, Red Sea and Caspian Sea, which cause snow and winter rainfall in north-western Indian subcontinent. Normally, there are six to seven western disturbances in January, but meteorologists claimed this time there were around 10 such weather systems and most of them affected Bihar.

Title: Bihar: 4.5 lakh teachers firm on strike from February 17
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Representative image

PATNA: Despite the education department’s warning, around 4.5 lakh contractual teachers have decided to go on an indefinite strike from February 17 in support of their 8-point demands, including equal pay for equal work and old pension scheme.

Niyojit (contractual) teachers of government and government-aided schools will not join the teaching and invigilation duty of matriculation examination to be conducted by Bihar School Examination Board from February 17.

The teachers will protest under the banner of Bihar Rajya Shikshak Sangharsh Samanvay Samiti (BRSSSS).

Bihar State Primary Teachers’ Association president and convener of the samiti, Brajnandan Sharma, said, “Through videoconferencing, we have asked all the teachers to support the strike. We will not get scared of ‘tughlaqi farman’ of education department. This time, we will fight for our rights and the state government has to compromise with us,” he said and added: “We will lock the gates of the schools and there will be no classes. The teachers will also boycott invigilation duty.”

Education minister Krishna Nandan Prasad Verma told this newspaper on Sunday that the teachers’ protest may cause inconvenience to department and the examinees. “We are trying to sort out the issues with the teachers by holding dialogues. The department cannot fulfil their demands. Even the Supreme Court has rejected their demand,” he said.

He added: “By holding protests, the teachers are blackmailing the department. They should do their duty diligently. However, the department will not let the teachers cause inconvenience to the teachers. We will make alternate arrangements in their absence from duty.”

Additional chief secretary of education department, RK Mahajan, on Friday directed the DMs, district education officers and deputy development commissioner to obtain a written declaration from such teachers, who have been deputed for the invigilation of matriculation examination but want to join the indefinite strike.

“Accordingly, special arrangements should be made, so that the Class X board exams should not get affected. The protesting teachers will be marked absent and their salary will be deducted on the principle of ‘no work no pay’. if the teachers tried to cause hindrance during the examination, strict action would be taken against them, including suspension,” says the notification.

Title: ECR: Old and abandoned coach now a canteen for railway staff
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

PATNA: The Danapur division of the East Central Railway ( ECR ) has started using an old and abandoned railway coach as a canteen for its staff.

According to Danapur divisional railway manager (DRM) Sunil Kumar, the railways had declared a 1994 Integral Coach Factory coach (ECG 94504) “unfit” for running on tracks in September last year.

“The innovative idea of renovating the abandoned coach and converting it into a canteen came to the minds of some senior railway officials of the division. A team was formed that gave a facelift to the coach at the Danapur depot yard and made all kinds of facilities available,” Kumar told this newspaper and added the personnel department of the division was running the canteen.

ECR’s chief public relations officer (CPRO) Rajesh Kumar claimed that the concept of converting a coach into a canteen had been hailed in other zones of the railways. “The canteen, which can accommodate 40 people at a time, is likely to serve the needs of around 400 railway employees, who work around the clock. They can eat snacks and light meals and also drink tea,” he said.

The CPRO added, “The railways is trying to ensure that fresh and hygienic meals are served to the staff inside the canteen. Depending on their response, Bihari delicacies will also be added to the menu in future. Besides, more such canteens or cafeterias are likely to be developed at other places under the five divisions of the ECR.”

The Danapur railway canteen was recently inaugurated by the president of ECR’s women welfare organization, Kaumudi Trivedi.

Title: Shantibagh anti-CAA dharna enters 43rd day
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

GAYA: The ongoing dharna in Shantibagh locality of the town entered 43rd day on Sunday and the protest continues with patriotic songs, frequent recital of the Constitution’s preamble, speeches by activists with non-right background and a resolve to take the fight to its logical end.

Teenagers try to emulate Kanhaiyya through his high decibel ‘azadi’ slogans. Every now and then full throated slogans are raised. “Kanhaiyya and not Owaisi is my role model,” said Danish, who got a soar throat via Kanhaiyya’s favourite slogan. During his January 21 visit to the dharna site, organisers got scared as selfie-seeking youngsters came close to crushing the JNU students union former president.

According to Satish Das, an Ambedkarite and co-convener of the Samvidhan Bachao Morcha, besides staging dharnas, Morcha activists, in smaller groups have launched an outreach programme to create awareness about the overall implication of the CAA-NPR-NRC on undocumented population irrespective of its religious affiliations. “CAA route to citizenship was available only for non-Muslims coming to India from Pakistan, Bangladesh and Afghanistan,” Das tells people during the outreach programme.

“Undocumented Indians remain vulnerable to exploitation by the lower bureaucracy,” Das and other members of the group tell people. The Morcha co-convener claimed that the group visits 3-4 villages everyday and returns to the dharna site in the afternoon. They have so far visited villages located in Manpur, Bodh Gaya , Bela, Paraiyya and Sherghati blocks. All these blocks except Sherghati are within a 15 km radius from the dharna site located in the northwestern part of the town.

Asked about the criteria for selecting villages, Das said that they pick up villages with a mixed population of Dalits, Muslims, OBCs and EBCs. Besides the Muslims, a large number of Dalits realise the consequences of CAA-NRP-NRC. The activist admitted that convincing the OBCs and EBCs was somewhat difficult. “Ultimately, the OBCs and EBCs too will see through the RSS game,” hoped Satish Das.

Asked about how long the dharna will continue, Omair Khan @Tikka Khan, convener of the Morcha said that they were waiting for the SC response. He was very hopeful about a positive outcome from the SC. The dharna issue will be reviewed in the light of the SC response and also the outcome of similar protest in Shaheenbagh and elsewhere in the country. He favoured coordination among protesters across the country.

Mushtari, a domestic help who regularly sits on dharna after doing her part time job in several households in the neighbourhood, says that the dharna inconvenience is nothing as compared to jail.

Title: Youth arrested in teenager's murder in Udhna
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Surat: Police arrested an 18-year-old boy on Sunday for allegedly murdering a 17-year-old Class XII student in limits of Udhna police station on Friday. The accused was caught from Dindoli area based on specific information.

“The accused youth has been arrested and police will share more details after preliminary questioning. He was caught from Dindoli area,” said a senior police officer.

Police earlier booked, Mukesh Pimple, a resident of Nagsen Nagar, for allegedly killing Rohit Baviskar. The complaint was lodged by Dashrath, father of the deceased. Pimple suspected that Baviskar met his sister often during the past couple of years. The duo had heated heated arguments in the past over this suspicion, police said.

On Saturday, a group of over 100 including family and friends of Baviskar sat on dharna at New Civil Hospital and refused to accept his body after postmortem. They later arrived at police commissioner's office and brought the body in morgue van to the campus. They demanded quick action and immediate arrest of the accused.

On Friday, when Baviskar came out of tuition classes at Vishnu Nagar 1 in Udhna, the accused stopped and stabbed him multiple times. The victim was stabbed five times in the back, head, near the ear and twice in the chest. His heart got punctured due stabbing, said police.

Title: BJP worker shares obscene videos in group, warned
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Surat: The city BJP unit was in for some embarassment after a party worker reportedly shared some obscene videos in the Whatsapp group of Limbayat ward 24.

As soon as the party worker, Kishore Solanki, uploaded the videos, women members of the group were left fuming and demanded that he be removed from the group. Even as Solanki deleted the videos after the uproar, the screen shots of the group chat also went viral on various other social media platforms.

City BJP leaders have not taken Solanki’s action kindly and have warned him of strict action if he repeats such an act. The issue reached city BJP president Nitin Bhajiyawala who asked Solanki to come in person and give a clarification.

"I had called Solanki to find out the truth and found that he shared the videos. I warned him of suspension from the party if he repeats. Solanki is not an office bearer in the party but a worker," said Bhajiyawala.

The incident comes days after videos of BJP municipal councillor Piyush Shivshaktiwala dancing while being in an inebriated condition near Nargol beach of Valsad.

Title: Patna zoo to spend Rs 2.2 crore on enclosures for its new inmates
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

The zoo director said a separate enclosure would be made adjacent to Reptile House for rhino iguana

PATNA: The officials at Sanjay Gandhi Biological Park, aka Patna zoo , are busy developing new enclosures and modifying some existing ones for the new inmates likely to arrive from abroad by April and June.

Officials said the zoo is to spend estimated Rs2.2 crore on the modification and development of new enclosures to be ready by March-end.

Patna zoo will get a pair of two-horned rhinos from Vietnam in lieu of pair of one-horned rhinos under the animal exchange programme of the Central Zoo Authority (CZA) by April first week.

The city zoo will also get a pair each of green anaconda, Nile crocodile, royal python and rhino iguana from Denmark in exchange of one male and seven female gharials.

Amit Kumar, Patna zoo director, told this newspaper on Saturday that enclosures are being modified as per the requirement of new guests. “We have to consider the geological, psychological and basking requirements of the new inmates. Fountains and green cover will be prepared for the snakes. In Reptile House, two snake enclosures are undergoing modification to house green anaconda and royal python,” Amit said.

He further said that the natural habitat and diet of the new snakes — anaconda and royal python — is different from the snakes at Patna zoo. The coming snakes need a bigger enclosure measuring 40X30 feet because they can easily grow up to 1,500mm, he said.

“Besides glass terrariums, they require wooden chips, bulbs and warm basking area inside the enclosure. For diet, these reptiles eat chicken, rodents, fish and lizards,” he explained.

The zoo director said a separate enclosure would be made adjacent to Reptile House for rhino iguana. “They need space to climb, hide and bask. Iguana eats fruits, vegetables, leaves and insects. They need natural surroundings. Strong well-fixed branches or logs, fountain and rocks add a more naturalistic look to the enclosure along with some foliage,” Amit said.

The zoo administration is also creating a small pond of fresh water near the Rhino Breeding Centre for the pair of Nile crocodile. The pair will get beef, chicken and fish in their diet. The inmates from Danish zoo will be here by June.

“For two-horned rhinos, we are making few modifications in the existing enclosure of one-horned rhinos. We will keep the new inmates at display, while the one-horned rhinos will be kept in Rhino Breeding Centre, which will be ready by March. A bigger night house is being prepared for two-horned rhinos and as they prefer less swampy area. They will be here by first week of April,” he said.

The breeding facility under construction for one-horned rhinoceroses is spread over an area of 2.5 acres between new lake and jungle trail area on the zoo premises. It is being developed with an estimated outlay of Rs4.11 crore. The centre would have facility of a night house, a shaded area and an open area. The breeding area would also have a lake and grassland to stimulate natural habitat for rhinos and help in mating.

Title: Bihar: FIR lodged for attack on Abadpur police station
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Representative image

PATNA: An FIR was lodged against 50 named and 500 unknown persons for the attack on Abadpur police station in Katihar district late on Saturday evening, a day after a man suspected to be involved in a motorbike theft case was brutally assaulted in police custody.

Katihar SP Aditya Kumar said that 14 accused were arrested by the police during raids on Sunday. “Raids have been intensified to arrest the remaining culprits at the earliest,” he said adding that senior police and administrative officials were camping at the site.

The SP said that police fired five rounds in the air to disperse the unruly mob, which had indulged in stone pelting and setting the building of the police station on fire. Documents and furniture were damaged, he said.

Katihar DM Poonam, who visited the spot on Sunday, ordered a detailed investigation into public outrage over rumours spread in the area over the death of a suspect in police custody due to alleged police accesses. The suspect was detained for interrogation in connection with a motorbike theft case.

Title: ‘70 per cent of water bodies vanished in three decades in Bihar’
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Representative image

PATNA: Unnatural death of thousands of water bodies and considerable decline in the area of wetlands during the past few decades have led to the present drinking water crisis in different parts of the state.

Experts point out that almost 70% water bodies in the state have vanished during the last three decades. There were more than 2.50 lakh ponds in the state till the late eighties, but the number has reportedly declined to less than one lakh today. All these ponds, which were essential to store rainwater during the eight dry months of the year, have disappeared across the state owing to the alleged government apathy and increasing real estate activities. These ponds and wetlands have been encroached upon by the vested interests for construction purposes, they alleged.

There were nearly 1,000 lakes in Patna but their numbers have come down to a little over 200. Several residential localities have been developed after big ponds were filled. Patna’s ponds, including Kachchi Talaab, Sachivalay Talaab, Manikchand Talaab and Adalatgannj Talaab may not survive for long.

Expressing serious concern at the neglect of most water bodies, Patna University geology teacher and JD (U) MLC Ranbir Nandan told this newspaper that almost 90% of the drinking water requirement of the people, particularly of urban area, is met through groundwater. “The groundwater is recharged by ponds, canals and all other wetlands, but with the disappearing of water bodies the groundwater level at most places has gone down to greater depths,” Nandan said, adding consequently, dug wells, hand pumps and shallow tube wells have dried at many places.

Nandan, who has done extensive work on the groundwater resources of Bihar , further pointed out that satellite data indicate the presence of as many as 27,931 water bodies having an area above 0.5 hectares in the state. “However, only 14% of them are perennial. Small water bodies are mostly seasonal and contribute very little to the sustainable water resource development,” he said.

In 2016, the state revenue and land reforms department had undertaken a project to make all water bodies encroachment free and renovate them so that they are fit for rainwater harvesting and water conservation. It had also directed the officials concerned to lodge cases against those who have encroached upon ponds, lakes and rivers in the state.

Under the water bodies' conservation project, which is part of the disaster risk reduction road map (2015-30) of the state government, the department was first supposed to identify all community water bodies in the state and then remove encroachments, if any. Finally, all water bodies were to be renovated under various schemes of the government and made fit to conserve water. The department sources said, this was also supposed to help in groundwater conservation.

Nandan, however, asserted that the ‘Jal-Jivan-Hariyali Abhiyan’ launched recently by chief minister Nitish Kumar would go a long way in reclaiming most of the encroached ponds and other water bodies, thereby, enhancing the groundwater level. Besides, it would also take care of all other problems related to climate change, he added.

Title: B2B e-commerce company Udaan backs PetPooja
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

(Representative image)

BENGALURU: Udaan , the online business-to-business (B2B) commerce platform valued at $2.8 billion, has made its first startup investment in Ahmedabad-based restaurant billing platform PetPooja , according to regulatory documents sourced by TOI.

Udaan’s investment in the two-year-old startup indicates its aspiration to build a larger fresh foods and vegetables supply business to small and medium enterprises, or restaurants in this case. This further intensifies Udaan’s competition with Walmart and Tiger Global-backed Ninjacart and online wholesale marketplace Jumbotail as it has been building the ‘Fresh’ vertical for the foods and vegetables supply business.

“More than the capital investment, PetPooja’s data will help Udaan to understand the fresh supplies business better. They (Udaan) have been looking to scale up that line of business,” a source aware of the goings-on said. PetPooja has over 12,000 restaurants on its platform, another person aware of the matter added.

The Bengaluru-based B2B unicorn’s Singapore-based arm Trustroot Payments invested around $2 million in PetPooja, started by Parthiv Patel and Apurv Patel. The investment was made in December, the documents showed. This investment will help China’s Tencent-backed Udaan to get a closer look at the data on what restaurant order cycles look like and build its Fresh business accordingly.

Both Udaan and PetPooja confirmed the development to TOI.

“PetPooja team has done a great job of empowering restaurant owners across India. As strong believers in the power of our country’s unique B2B ecosystem, we’re happy and proud to support them in their journey,” said Udaan co-founder Amod Malviya.

Patel said he will use Udaan’s investment to scale up operations. “Our mission is to digitise restaurants by building technology to streamline their operations to scale and make them more productive,” he added.

Title: Kolkata: Thousands take over Red Road to run for clean air at inaugural edition of Times Half Marathon
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

The build-up to the event, which included planning, registering and practising for several days, culminated in... Read More

KOLKATA: Thousands in the city braved the early morning chill and gathered on Red Road to run for a cause in the inaugural edition of the Apollo Gleneagles Times Half Marathon on Sunday. The build-up to the event, which included planning, registering and practising for several days, culminated in a morning filled with enthusiasm and excitement.

More than 5,000 people participated in the event and there were a lot of non-runners who turned up to cheer their friends and family on. “I woke up at 4am so I could be here by 5.15am. I have been preparing for the half marathon for nearly a week by going for morning walks to build up my endurance level. I even made my friends register for the run,” said Kriti Pachisia, a college student from Lake Town who finished the 10k run in a little over two hours.

The 21k event, which was flagged off at 6.30am, had several marathon veterans as participants . For those who were not experienced, but registered to give it a try, the cool weather kept the discomfort index in control. “It feels great to run at the Times Half Marathon. I was not sure I would be able to complete the 10k run, but the weather was good and I did not sweat much. And the organizers were always at hand to offer help,” said Rajan Thapa, a retired para-military personnel who completed the 21k run in less than three hours.

Before the events started, fitness instructors at warm-up stations shared tips with participants on how to keep injuries at bay. There was an Apollo Gleneagles zone in the activity area with 10 beds and three tables, and three ambulances were kept on stand-by.

The 3k run, which witnessed the maximum participation, was flagged off by actor-MP Nusrat Jahan, and actors Prosenjit Chatterjee and Ritabhari Chakraborty at 8.30am.

Many participants appeared to have forgotten they were there to run as they crowded around the stage where the actors stood, clicking photographs and selfies on their phones. The space around the stage became so crowded at one point that the cops and volunteers had to intervene to urge the runners forward.

“It is very encouraging to see that so many people have turned up early on Sunday morning to be a part of a noble cause. This shows we are aware and alert,” said Chatterjee.

Rajender Singh Lahauria, general manager (ATC), Kolkata airport, completed the 10k run in 58 minutes. “The message of the Times Half Marathon is to keep our city clean so we can breathe fresh air every time we step out of our homes. Running is the best and most affordable exercise.”

Title: Kolkata Airport: The Authorities at Kolkata airport,airlines officials to discuss roll-out of inline baggage scan
Content:
Inline baggage screening through a CTX machine

KOLKATA: The authorities at Kolkata airport will meet airlines’ representatives next week to discuss the preparedness for the roll-out of the much-awaited inline baggage screening (ILBS) system. Once it is introduced, passengers will be able to drop their checked-in bags directly at the check-in counter instead of first getting them scanned at standalone X-Ray machines.While Airports Authority of India (AAI) officials in Kolkata are keen to introduce ILBS at the earliest following the nod from Bureau of Civil Aviation Security (BCAS), airport director Kaushik Bhattacharjee said the roll-out could happen in phases between October 20 and 28, with portals dedicated to airlines being commissioned one at a time. In the international wing, though, all portals — F, G and H — will be commissioned at one go since they follow dynamic allocation and are not dedicated to any carrier.“We know there is a lot of interest in the introduction of ILBS as it will eliminate one queue and save flyers 5-15 minutes. But we have to consult the airline and find out if they have any concerns or issues before finalising the commissioning schedule. Of the five portals in the domestic wing, four will get ILBS while all three portals in the international wing will get the facility,” said Bhattacharjee.Portal A, used by GoAir and AirAsia, will get the system at a later date as it will require the Spanish baggage handling system supplier to rework the software. The other seven portals — B to H — are managed by German firm Siemens.According to airport officials, portal D, which caters to SpiceJet and Vistara, and portal E, which has Air India, could be commissioned separately. But portals B and C, which cater to IndiGo, will have to be commissioned at the same time.The migration to the new system will be tricky as it requires baggage handling discipline by airline staff and rigorous screening by AAI’s baggage screeners. Airlines will have to ensure a minimum separation between two bags placed on the belt and put small bags, duffel bags and rucksacks that have belts in trays for the system to work seamlessly.Of the 80-plus screeners, 50 have received certification by BCAS. The rest are expected to be certified before ILBS is commissioned. While they have been trained to detect explosives and other dangerous materials, a security expert warned that the initial baggage rejection rate could be high as the system could flag innocuous items, like pickle.“The CTX registered baggage explosive detection system will flag many suspicious items. Most of them will be harmless stuff, primarily edible items typical to Indian cuisine. Screeners will learn what to override through experience. Till that happens, there will be higher rejections, requiring passengers to be summoned to the basement to explain what the suspect item is or to open the bag for inspection,” the security expert said.In airports that have ILBS, passengers are required to sign a declaration that they do not have prohibited items, including lithium-ion batteries or wet cell batteries that could explode in the air due to heat build-up. “While the bag rejection should happen within 10 minutes of it being dropped at the check-in counter, if there are too many rejections, airlines could get harried and decide to leave the bag at the airport instead of summoning passengers and delay flights. Thus, it is important that passengers get educated on what they should not carry in registered bags,” said an airline official.

Title: Madhya Pradesh: 4.5 lakh ‘paper toilets’ vanish in Rs 540 crore scam
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Representative image

BHOPAL: Call it the vanishing-toilet scam. More than 4.5 lakh Swachh loos have been flushed into oblivion in Madhya Pradesh , along with the Rs 540 crore it took to build them.

The toilets may never be found — though the administration has GPS-tagged photographs of each of them — but the government aims to recover every paisa spent on them. It’s a reminder of the toilet door scam unearthed in Guna district in 2017, where the iron doors of 42,000 toilets were built 10kg lighter, leading to siphoning of crores.

The ‘vanishing’ toilets were supposed to have been built — at least on paper — between 2012 and October 2018. But they don’t exist. Officials believe that the photographs submitted as proof of Swachh toilet construction were actually clicked elsewhere, perhaps at neighbours’ homes as proof of money spent.

Some villagers blew the whistle in Betul’s tribal Lakkadjam panchayat and complained to officials. A probe quickly found that four Swachh beneficiaries — Chaitram, Ram Kishore, Kansraj and Shambhudayal — were not even aware that toilets have been built in their name. On government records, not only do their homes have toilets but the government portal has pictures of them before loos as well. Officials found that all four were photographed in front of a neighbour’s toilet.

“A detailed probe was conducted in Lakkadjam panchayat, and the complaints were found to be true. For these toilets and other similar anomalies, a recovery of Rs 7 lakh was imposed on the accused. They appealed against the recovery order, but the penalty was upheld. Once recovery is done, we will initiate action under IPC. I have ordered investigation of all the other work done in the panchayat,” chief executive officer (CEO) of Betul panchayat ML Tyagi told TOI.

It set alarm bells ringing and the panchayat and rural development department has since identified 4.5 lakh such missing ‘ paper toilets ’ across the state. In monetary terms, toilets worth Rs 540 crores are missing, said an official.

“In 2012, a baseline survey was conducted and 62 lakh above-poverty-line households without toilets were identified in the state. On October 2, 2018, construction of all these toilets was complete. But to ensure that these toilets are actually present and 100% complete, we conducted a survey and physical verification using 21,000 volunteers. During this survey, around 4.5 lakh toilets were found to be missing,” deputy director of Swachh Bharat Mission (Rural) Madhya Pradesh, Ajit Tiwari, told TOI.

A second physical verification is under way. “It is being conducted by district-level officers. We hope it will be complete in a couple of months. Then, we will have a cleaner picture of the numbers of Swachh mission toilets. Our objective is to ensure that the toilets or assets built by the government are actually present,” said Tiwari. The data will be put in public domain so that the beneficiaries can check for any anomaly, he added.

“There were two processes of making payments. Panchayats were provided money upon completion of toilets in households, or the government transferred Rs 12,000 to beneficiaries’ accounts once they built the toilets. In both cases, it is clear where the money went. So, people responsible for the missing toilets will have to build them for real, or the face music. The sole objective is to ensure 100% completion of the target identified in 2012,” Tiwari said.

Asked how the scamsters beat technology since Swachh toilet photographs are geo-mapped, Tiwari said: “The GPS is accurate up to 6 metres. Most probably, pictures of toilets within 6 metres were uploaded in the name of the beneficiaries or pictures of toilets built prior to 2012 were uploaded. Things will be clear once the second survey is complete.”

Title: Sales execs quit companies to log onto gig economy
Content:
(Representative image)

MUMBAI: The perennially high demand for sales talent has made these jobs ‘recession-proof’. Frontline sales jobs have always been in demand, given the high attrition levels.Earlier, sales people were largely rotating between traditional industries like banking, financial services & insurance (BFSI), FMCG and pharmaceuticals companies every year or two. However, today, a significant chunk is said to be moving out of traditional jobs to operate in gig roles.Other than the growing opportunities in sales within the traditional sectors, multiple avenues have opened up in the new-age economy as well. In an internal survey of Axis Bank, it was found that 45% of employees who had quit the sales function a year ago were not engaged in any major job and were instead doing multiple gigs.Axis Bank HR head Rajkamal Vempati said, “The psychology of a job seeker has moved from a scarcity mindset to that of abundance. The young talent is willing to take risks with small organisations and make money doing different kinds of jobs. This is the talent that falls under Rs 3-lakh earning bracket and it’s difficult to retain them.”The BFSI industry is hiring a slew of people in sales to compensate for the high attrition levels. However, given the trend of talent moving to gig jobs, Axis Bank has made a shift in its policy. Around 60% of its frontline sales hires are now experienced sales professionals instead of freshers.PNB MetLife director & HR head Shishir Agarwal said, “Alternative jobs are emerging and people are seen shifting out of sales. However, I believe 80% of the people who exit remain within the same ship. Around 20% would be jumping to the gig roles.”In pharma, the scenario is not very different. RPG Life Sciences MD Yugal Sikri said, “The shift in trend is about the kind of talent that is getting into sales. Earlier, we used to get science and pharmacy graduates, hailing from middle-class, relatively well-off family backgrounds. Now we get talent from humble backgrounds as well, and this is the talent that stays on with us for longer as they value the job more. The talent with science/pharmacy and management background stays for 1-1.5 years, but moves to product management role or even to FMCG.”According to the company’s findings, 10% of the people who move out do so to other jobs/industries. “Earlier, it used to be the BPO industry that attracted sales talent. Today, new-age gig economy is the new BPO,” said Sikri.With capabilities that cut across industries, TeamLease Services executive VP & co-founder Rituparna Chakraborty said sales people are the ones who can ride a two-wheeler, they are outbound and have good capability of interacting with customers. Substitutable roles for sales include e-commerce delivery boys.“They are happy with the pay package and they are in control of the hours they keep. These roles did not exist earlier. For the 20-29-year-olds, it’s an itch they need to scratch. The divide emerges only later when they feel the need for developing career paths,” said Chakraborty.A key reason why sales professionals stay with a company is salary and compensation, and the variable pay is usually greater than the fixed salary. Chakraborty said companies should invest in apprenticeship schemes to fill frontline jobs, as these have a lower risk and higher returns than the costly lateral hires.Interestingly, while organisations are going all out to build their employer brand, the younger generation of sales talent does not appear to be convinced. “Good amount of disposable income with minimal responsibilities gives them the confidence of not worrying about continuity in the job. They are not afraid to quit and try something different. Thus, working in an organisation that understands their needs and provides flexibility of working is higher in the pecking order over brand,” said Agarwal.A TeamLease Services report said the sales domain in India has the potential to create more than 2 million jobs over a few years, without any major structural reforms. The potential could be realised through a combination of macro-economic, strategic and technological factors that would give further growth impetus to enterprises in India, while boosting domestic consumption.

Title: Turkey’s Koc eyes Indian consumer durables market
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

(Representative image)

MUMBAI: Turkey’s largest business house, Koc Group , is betting on the Indian market, which is being seen as one of the bright spots in the world despite the current slump.

Koc, owner of consumer durable brands like Grundig and Beko, will roll out made-in-India refrigerators, washing machines, microwave ovens and dishwashers to take on the well-entrenched Samsung, LG and Whirlpool in the country. Controlled by Istanbul’s wealthiest family, Koc is hoping to replicate its European success in India.

Though Koc has a diversified portfolio such as financial services, energy and tourism, it will begin in India with consumer durable brands Beko and later Grundig. The Turkish business house has partnered with the Tata Group for the home appliances business in India. The 50:50 partnership, however, does not cover air conditioners (ACs) as Tata has its own play in that space.

The joint venture has invested $180 million in setting up a manufacturing facility in Sanand, Gujarat, to manufacture washing machines and microwaves, among other products.

India is a rare market where Koc has a joint venture for consumer durables, said one of its top executives. The home appliances arm of Koc — Arcelik — is a leading player in Europe, the heartland of kitchen appliances. And in the UK, one in five appliances sold is a Beko. India, however, is a difficult market to foray into without a local partner, said the company’s CEO Hakan Bulgurlu.

Koc identified India as a growth-potential geography in 2010, following which it started gauging the size of the market and meeting prospective partners. In 2017, Arcelik inked an agreement with Tata Group company Voltas. Arcelik’s greenfield factory in Sanand follows its refrigerator plant in Thailand.

For Voltas, the joint venture marks a re-entry into kitchen appliances, a segment it has visited multiple times in the past. A couple of years after India’s economic liberalisation in 1991, Voltas had acquired Allwyn refrigerators. In 1998, it sold Allwyn to Sweden’s Electrolux.

Title: CII: Fear of criminal tag among companies
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

(Representative image)

MUMBAI: The Confederation of Indian Industry ( CII ) has said that there is a fear factor among directors, young entrepreneurs and foreign investors over increasing incidents where commercial and civil disputes are being treated as criminal complaints. The industry body has petitioned the Prime Minister and the finance minister, calling for steps to decriminalise provisions in several business-facing laws and Acts to improve investor confidence.

CII’s recommendations cover 37 laws and Acts, ranging from the Partnership Act of 1932 to the Insolvency & Bankruptcy Code of 2016. It has said that offences that are technical or those that do not affect public interest prejudicially should be decriminalised. The confederation has said that there are 23 offences under the Companies Act that could be shifted to an adjudication mechanism, and seven offences where penalties can be omitted as they pertain to orders of the National Company Law Tribunal (NCLT). “The NCLT may use its contempt power in such cases,” the representation said.

During the Union Budget 2020-21 speech, finance minister Nirmala Sitharaman had emphasised that criminal liabilities for civil Acts will be amended in the Companies Act and other laws would also be examined. In this context, the CII has identified many of these Acts where criminal provisions exist.

For instance, under the Sebi Act, the maximum punishment for non-compliance is imprisonment up to 10 years, or fine of Rs 25 crore, or both. “Mere errors of non-disclosure or late disclosure, which are not significant in nature, may be made punishable with penalties that are not substantial in monetary terms or do not include the possibility of imprisonment,” the CII said. The confederation has recommended 12 alternative ways to work towards decriminalisation of laws and amend legislation to change criminal penalties to civil penalties.

“A change in the nature of penalty provisions in business and economic laws represents the next stage of reforms in ease of doing business. Divesting criminal penalties from business laws — unless well-defined criminal actions are found — will strengthen confidence among young entrepreneurs and investors in doing business,” CII president Vikram Kirloskar said.

Besides these laws, CII has highlighted sections of competition law, partnership Act, labour laws, environment laws and FMCG laws that required amendment. “Inadvertent errors or technical deviations may not be tried as criminal offences, and the director of the company not to be tried before the remote magistrate courts but by the respective controller of legal metrology where the registered office of the company is situated,” the representation said.

Earlier, the government had sought to criminalise failure to meet targets for spending toward corporate social responsibility. However, following protests from industry, the government said that it is not going ahead with the provision.

Title: Chandigarh’s second medical college to be on 15 Sarangpur acres
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Representative image

CHANDIGARH: Finally, the city will have a second medical college, for which administrator V P Singh Badnore has consented to allot 15 acres in Sarangpur’s Education City. Government Multi-Specialty Hospital (GMSH), Sector 16, will run this affiliate institute of Panjab University .

The college’s estimated annual expenditure on salary and related components is Rs 13 crore. Its 50 seats will be expanded to 100, later. For the first two years, Government Medical College and Hospital (GMCH), Sector 32, will conduct the classes, and when the new building is ready, GMSH-16 will take over from the third and fourth years. The new college will follow the GMCH’s admission and reservation policy.

The urban planning department wanted a site in Sector 53 of south Chandigarh but the administrator, highest authority, found Sarangpur more suitable. The land approval, a copy of which is with TOI, says: “The case is submitted to the UT administrator with reference to a demi-official letter from Union health minster Dr Harsh Vardhan and a meeting held in the UT secretariat. Held under the chairmanship of the administrator and attended by the UT adviser, the meeting was to seek administrative approval for 10 to 15 acres, keeping in view the future expansion and increase in the MBBS (bachelor of medicine and bachelor of surgery) seats, so that a DPR (detailed project report) can be submitted at the earliest.”

Besides the creation of teaching posts for the new college, members of the clinical faculty and the resident doctors of GMSH can be adjusted for clinical subjects, if they fulfil the MCI (Medical Council of India) norms. Since it is UT’s own project, the authority won’t have to bear the cost of land, which is about Rs 750 crore. The engineering department is yet to prepare the financial component but sources said the construction cost will be Rs 400-500 crore.

Box:

Minister wrote to Badnore in 2019

In December 2019, Union health minster Dr Harsh Vardhan wrote to UT administrator V P Singh Badnore for building a medical college in the city. The letter reads: “My ministry is implementing a centrally sponsored scheme, namely ‘establishment of new medical colleges attached with existing/referral hospital’. Phase III of the scheme has been approved in August 2019 to build 75 more medical colleges, with preference to aspirational districts. All states and UTs were required to identify the district/referral hospital… for the scheme… and submit proposal along with detailed project report (DPR). The ministry intends to make the college functional by the session 2022-23. Kindly look into the matter personally and arrange to expedite submission of proposal along with DPR.”

Title: Kashmir nursery student’s art shares space with MF Hussain
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Chandigarh: A national obsession with big names and VIPs has not spared public displays of Indian art. But a novel art exhibition, Innovative Vibes-II, broke the “monopoly of big names” by allowing a nursery school student of Kashmir, Thyaim Akira, to showcase her painting in a space shared with the works of legends such as MF Hussain, Dhanraj Bhagat, Kishan Khanna and Jatin Das. The authentic works of the masters were largely unknown to the public, were created in Kashmir and held in the private collection of the Gayoor Art Foundation Trust, Kashmir.

As many as 45 artists from Kashmir displayed their paintings, sculptures and photographs at the Artspace Gallery, Mohali. The refreshing content, style and sparks of originality displayed by budding artists and students are reflected in the fact that some of them hail from lesser-known areas of the Valley such as Kulgam, Salaam Charar-e-Sharief, Handwara, Dalwan, Wahpora Budgam, Harwan, Mattan Anantnag, among others. “In contrast to some of our students from urban centres, students from rural areas and mofussil towns display a great eagerness to learn when they come to study at the Institute of Music and Fine Arts, Kashmir University. Kashmir has been a favourite destination for artists across India. In the mid-twentieth century, SH Raza’s frequent sojourns in Kashmir and later Ghulam Rasool Santosh’s idea to host art camps brought reputed modern artists in direct contact with aspiring local artists. These early interactions shaped the modern art practices of local artists,” Naushad Gayoor told the TOI.

Innovative Vibes-II has been curated by Gayoor and Bengaluru-based Jeetin Rangher, the latter having worked for 10 years in Kashmir promoting local artists. Innovative Vibes-II was staged under the aegis of the Gayoor Foundation and Master Sansar Chand Memorable Charitable Trust. “The exhibition allowed Kashmiri artists to merge with those from all over India and from nations such as Tunisia, UK, China and South Africa. There are a total of 141 artists participating in Innovative Vibes-II. Such an exposure to audiences outside Kashmir allows us to promote and nurture fresh artistic talent from the troubled Valley,” Rangher told the TOI.

One of the Kashmiri artists, Azhar Rafiq, painted a man collecting fish from the waters flowing into the Dal Lake. “Recently there was an episode of fish having died in the lake due to a toxic spillover. I also heard that human bodies were dumped in the lake. I merged the two into a painting that symbolises blood flowing in the waters and a man collecting fish in a red bowl that depicts unnatural death,” Rafiq told the TOI.

Mehak Mubeen’s two-part painting has her poetry and a vivid depiction of barbed wire strung with chinar leaves encircling a beautiful Kashmiri girl like an eerie necklace. “I created this painting in the three months following the abrogation of Article 370 on August 5, 2019. Curfew meant we were bound down to our homes. But I do not only depict a life of barbed wires in Kashmir but also my personal struggles and a resilient spirit to rise from the ruins and hopelessness,” said Mubeen.

Innovative Vibes-II is dedicated to the memory of Naushad’s late father, Gayoor Hassan, whose contribution to the development of modern art in Kashmir, both as an artist and academician, is peerless. Hassan took charge as principal of the Institute of Music and Fine Arts when the Valley was witnessing the worst period of violence. It is difficult to imagine a functional art institute in the midst of insurgency. His contribution lies in his unflinching and unwavering determination to run the institute and maintain a prolific artistic engagement.

Title: IOCL’s Mathura refinery starts producing 100% BS-VI fuel ahead of deadline
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Agra: Indian Oil Corporation’s Mathura refinery completed the revamp of its all units to produce BS-VI level fuels ahead of the deadline for the roll-out of newer emission norms from April 2020.

The refinery had undertaken projects to upgrade its diesel and gasoline units for bringing down sulphur level by nearly 80%, said Mathura Refinery executive director Arvind Kumar. He added that this would make environment substantially cleaner.

With the commissioning of these facilities, Mathura Refinery is now supplying 100% of its MS (petrol) and HSD (diesel), meeting BS-VI norms, said Kumar. IOCL’s Mathura Refinery has achieved the distinction of becoming first refinery in the country to supply BS-VI compliant fuels, containing less than 10 ppm sulphur with existing units, well ahead of deadline set by the government, he said.

According to officials, Bharat stage emission standards (BSES) are standards instituted by the central government to regulate the emission of air pollutants from motor vehicles. The standards and the timeline for implementation are set by the Central Pollution Control Board under the ministry of environment, forest and climate change.

Kumar told media that since October 2010, Bharat Stage (BS) III emission norms have been enforced across the country which allowed sulphur content in MS (petrol) and HSD (diesel) up to 150 parts per million and 350 ppm respectively. He said, emission norms were further tightened in the subsequent step in the form of BS-IV emission norms which were made effective from April 2017. These norms allowed sulphur in MS (petrol) & HSD (diesel) u pto 50 ppm level.

At a time when all the Indian refineries were producing BS-IV compliant fuels, IOCL’s Mathura Refinery was the first refinery to take up the challenge to meet the requirement of supplying NCT region with BS-VI compliant fuels (sulphur less than 10 ppm) with its existing facilities.

Kumar further said that as a major step towards reducing air pollution, in January 2016, Government of India (GOI), through a historic decision announced not only to skip the BS-V emissions norms but also decided to implement BS-VI norms on Pan-India basis wef April 1, 2020. “A deadline was also set for rolling out cleaner (BS-VI compliant) fuel across the National Capital Territory (NCT) by April 18 & National Capital Region (NCR) by April 19,” he added.

Title: Sri Lankan PM Mahinda Rajapaksa offers prayers at Kashi Vishwanath temple, visits Sarnath
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Sri Lankan prime minister Mahinda Rajapaksa offers prayers at the Kashi Vishwanath temple

VARANASI: Sri Lankan Prime Minister Mahinda Rajapaksa offered prayers at the Kashi Vishwanath Temple in Varanasi before heading to pay a visit to Buddhist shrines in Sarnath on Sunday. Rajapaksa’s is on a fiveday visit to India.

Rajapaksa reached Kashi Vishwanath temple and performed the ‘ shodashopchar pujan’ in the sanctum sanctorum as priests chanted Vedic mantras. He then went to the ‘mandap’ of the neighbouring Tarkeshwar Mahadev Temple, where UP tourism minister Neelkanth Tiwari felicitated him. Divisional commissioner Deepak Agrawal and district magistrate Kaushal Raj Sharma showed the Sri Lanka PM a map of the ongoing Kashi Vishwanath Dham (corridor) project and apprised him about the worldclass facilities which will be on offer for pilgrims once the project is completed.

After spending 40 minutes at the two temples, Rajapaksa reached Kaal Bhairo temple and performed various rituals. After a brief halt at a hotel, the Sri Lankan PM and his team set out for Sarnath. He was greeted by people waving flags of the two countries on the roadside.

Rajapaksa lit a lamp at the Moolgandha Kuti Vihara and performed the circumambulation of the Bodhi Tree, where Gautam Buddha had given his first sermon. He then visited temple of Mahabodhi Society of India, where Buddhist priests blessed him with Buddha’s relics. Bhikshu Medhankar Thero also performed a ‘paritran deshna path’ for him.

In the visitors’ book of Moolgandha Kuti Vihara, Rajapaksa wrote, “I am happy to visit the pilgrimage site of the followers of Lord Buddha. I feel fortunate. I got inner peace.” He also went to Dhamekh Stupa and performed various religious rituals. He also toured the Archaeological Survey of India (ASI) museum in Sarnath. ASI officials showed him the ruins excavated from the site between 1835 and 1929.

Title: Solar storage tariff spells trouble for coal
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Representative image

NEW DELHI: When solar power tariff dropped to Rs 2.44 per unit for the first time in May 2017, it set a record for cheapest electricity, busted the myth of renewable power being unaffordable and opened a Pandora’s box for conventional power plants by challenging coal’s dominance as the primary source of energy.

In an eerie feeling of deja-vu some 20 months on, the latest auction of storage-based solar project with assured peak-hour supply may have driven another nail into the coffin for coal by setting a world record for cheapest solar storage power — with the added commitment of almost round-the-clock supply costing 8% less than thermal power to break the affordability barrier for storage-based energy solutions. In the latest instance, Hyderabad-based GreenKo won 900MW of the 1,200MW solar storage project auction by SECI Ltd.

In the latest instance, Hyderabad-based GreenKo won 900MW of the 1,200MW solar storage project auction by SECI Ltd, the entity under the renewable energy ministry implementing the Modi government’s solar 175 GW renewable capacity plan. Goldman Sachs-funded ReNew Power bagged 300 MW.

GreenKo quoted a peak tariff of Rs 6.12 per unit and average tariff of Rs 3.89 for 100MW and Rs 3.93 for 800MW. ReNew offered a peak tariff of Rs 6.85 a unit and average tariff of Rs 4.07. A SECI executive said ReNew was opting for battery-storage and GreenKo for pump-storage backup in Andhra Pradesh , Madhya Pradesh , Karnataka and Rajasthan .

SECI will pay peak power at the average of the quoted tariff of the total bids and a trading margin. This works out to an effective peak tariff of Rs 6.37 per unit and off-peak rate of Rs 2.95. The average tariff of both peak and non-peak hours will work out to Rs 4.04, including trading margin.

These compare well with the Rs 4.24 per unit tariff discovered at a recent auction of stressed thermal capacity auctioned for a tenure of three years by PFC and Rs 4.34 in a bidding round conducted by NHPC earlier. In peak hours, discoms pay up to Rs 6.5 to buy power from the open market or peaking sources, mostly gas-fired plants, to meet demand.

“This tender brings storage-based renewable power within reach and allows India to plan giga watt-size projects. The tariffs for storage-based solar power is within touching distance of the average pooled cost of power purchased by various discoms,” a SECI executive said.

Indeed, it is the assured tariff at a reasonably affordable rate that can really spell trouble for coal in the coming days. The auction makes it mandatory for winners to meet six hours of peak demand as per choice of time windows allowed to discoms. This feature of the solar storage project removes a key hurdle — intermittency and ability to supply peaking power — in making solar mainstream.

This provides discoms a financially viable alternative for meeting renewable energy obligation. They can tap solar storage for meeting peak demand, especially in the evening hours, and also fulfil the green commitment.

In addition, solar tariff is levelised for 25 years, while thermal power tariff is for 3-5 years and becomes costlier every time coal prices rise. “This project also has assured supply commitment, including peaking power. These factors give it a huge advantage over conventional power,” the SECI executive said.

Title: Hyderabad: Cops get tweet against TV anchor removed
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Photo for representative purpose only

HYDERABAD: After a popular TV anchor complained about an abusive post against her on a social media platform, Cyber Crime police of Hyderabad acted swiftly and got the post removed. In another case, Kukatpally police registered a cheating case against a film distributor for allegedly duping a TV anchor.

Abusive content was posted from a Twitter handle about Telugu television anchor Anasuya Bharadwaj on Monday. One of her followers tagged Hyderabad cyber crime police and the anchor. “We have sent notices to Twitter and got the abusive content about the anchor and another actress removed. We also sought details of the twitter handle to identify the person posting abusive content,” ACP, cyber crime, KVM Prasad said.

In another case, anchor Ravi Kiran of Moosapet lodged a complaint with Kukatpally police on Sunday alleging that film distributor Sandeep had duped him. “He had asked me money for film distribution work. In September 2018, I gave Rs 45 lakh. After a few days, Sandeep returned Rs 3.75 lakh. When I asked him for the rest of the amount, Sandeep started threatening me,” Ravi Kiran said.

Police registered a case, but no arrests have been made yet.

Title: Dist jail abuzz with activities
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Director general of prisons & correctional services Rishi Raj Singh launches the sale of ready-made clothes at... Read More

Kochi: There are 450 aloe vera saplings here, said an inmate of the district prison dressed as a farmer, as he pointed to the garden in the jail compound.

Farming is now a common task assigned to inmates to help them earn while in prison and as a training module for a vocation they can take up when they are released. However, the district jail has taken the mission a notch higher by making inmates try out different farming methods.

“We will install about 30 beehive boxes on the premises. There is a rubber plantation near the prison so we expect it to facilitate apiculture. Aloe vera plants have already been planted. We had been farming fish like tilapia and nutter. Now, we are planning to farm pearl spot fish,” said K V Jagadeeshan, superintendent of the district prison.

The event on Monday saw the launch of the sale of ready-made clothes made by women inmates, Milma products, beekeeping , aloe vera farming, second phase of fish farming and sale of stationery items made by inmates. Well-wishers donated a refrigerator, five sewing machines, a water purifier, 25 chairs and clothes.

Rishi Raj Singh, head of the prisons department, launched the initiatives.

The event also felicitated Jagadeeshan who received the President’s medal for meritorious service this year. A logo of the band, Correctional Voices, was launched.

Title: Narendra Modi: PM condoles death of Parameswaran
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

paying homage: Ambulance carrying mortal remains of P Parameswaran at RSS Karyalayam in Kochi on Sunday

Kochi: Prime Minister Narendra Modi in two separate tweets condoled the death of RSS ideologue and director of Bharatheeya Vichara Kendram P Parameswaran , who passed away on Saturday. “An institution builder, Parameswaran Ji nurtured eminent institutions such as the Bharatheeya Vichara Kendram, Vivekananda Kendra and others. I am fortunate to have interacted with him many times. He was a towering intellectual. Anguished by his demise. Om Shanti,” the PM tweeted.

In another tweet, Modi said, “Shri P Parameswaran was a proud and dedicated son of Bharat Mata. His was a life devoted to India’s cultural awakening, spiritual regeneration and serving the poorest of the poor. Parameswaran Ji’s thoughts were prolific and his writings were outstanding. He was indomitable!.”

Parameswaran, 93, popularly known as Parameswarji, was undergoing treatment at an ayurvedic hospital at Ottappalam. Death came while he was at the house of K Sasikumar, secretary of Nila Seva Samithi, around midnight. His body was kept at the RSS state karyalaya in Kochi from 6am to 4pm for the public to pay homage. Later, the body was taken to Thiruvananthapuram where his mortal remains will be kept at Samskrithi Bhavan Bharatheeya Vichara Kendram for public to pay last respects. Funeral will be held at his home in Muhamma in Alappuzha on Monday afternoon.

Governor Arif Mohammed Khan in his condolence tweet said, “Deeply grieved by the sad demise of P Parameswar-Ji, Director, Bharatiya Vichara Kendram. With endearing politeness and accomplished scholarship, he inspired society through insightful speeches and writings on Indian thought. My heartfelt condolences.”

“Parameswaran was a philosopher who dedicated his life to the ideology he believed in,” said chief minister Pinarayi Vijayan in his condolence message.

BJP leaders, including P K Krishnadas, Congress leader K V Thomas, CPI Rajya Sabha member Binoy Viswam, Vypeen MLA S Sarma and others paid homage to Parameswaran.

Born to Parameswaran Elayath and Savithri Antharjanam at Thamarassery Illam in 1927, Parameswaran was attracted to religious affairs and became an RSS pracharak. His primary education was in Luther Mission L P School in Muhamma. He passed out Honours degree with gold medal from University College, Thiruvananthapuram. He became the disciple of Swami Agamananda of Sri Ramakrishna Mission. Later, he became an RSS pracharak in Thiruvananthapuram. Parameswaran was jailed for two years under Maintenance of Internal Security Act (MISA) for protesting against the Emergency.

In 1957, he was entrusted with the task of building Bharatiya Jan Sangh in Kerala and was named its organizing secretary. In 1968, he became the all-India general secretary and later the vice-president of Jan Sangh. He was the director of Deendayal Research Institute from 1977 to 82. Parameswaran founded Bharatheeya Vichara Kendram in Thiruvananthapuram in 1982. He has penned a number of books, including Sree Narayana Guru the Prophet of Renaissance, Marx and Vivekananda and From Marx to Maharshi.

He was awarded Padma Shri in 2004 and Padma Vibhushan in 2018.

Title: Power tariff for small industries will go up by 40%: VIA
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Nagpur: Vidarbha Industries Association (VIA) has strongly opposed MSEDCL’s power tariff hike petition claiming that the tariff hike for some type of industries will be very high and will lead to their closure. In its submission before Maharashtra Electricity Regulatory Commission (MERC), VIA has claimed that the hike for low tension (LT) having load below 20kW will be more than 40%. The public hearing on the petition will be held on Tuesday.

VIA power expert RB Goenka told TOI that the present tariff for such industries was Rs6.30 per unit. “It will go up to Rs8.98 per unit if MERC accepts MSEDCL’s petition. This translates into a hike of 42.55%,” he said.

VIA has objected to several aspects of MSEDCL’s petition. One of them is the proposal to introduce KVAH billing. Goenka pointed out that despite strong opposition from consumers, MSEDCL wants to introduce this type of billing without providing any reason. “MSEDCL purchases power in kWh but wants to bill its consumer on KVAH basis. This makes no sense,” he said.

The Association has objected to the methodology of calculation of fuel adjustment cost (FAC). It has demanded that MSEDCL levy FAC on the basis of the extra cost incurred that month and not pertaining to three months ago. This upsets the economics of industries.

MSEDCL has proposed sharp hike in demand charges. VIA has pointed out that this will sharply increase the tariff of industries working in one or two shifts. Ideally, MSEDCL should reduce fixed cost component instead of increasing it. A consumer should be billed only for the power he consumes.

MSEDCL’s proposal to levy astronomical grid support charge (GSC) on solar rooftop consumers has been strongly opposed. VIA has pointed out that if proposed GSC rates are levied solar power will become costlier than MSEDCL power. This is against the central government’s policy of promoting renewable energy.

VIA pointed out that such consumers are captive generators, who produce power for their own consumption and hence cross subsidy surcharge (CSS) can’t be levied on them. MSEDCL has also not taken into account the renewal purchase obligation (RPO) benefit due to solar rooftop.

Goenka has calculated that if all norms are followed GSC for residential consumers having consumption above 500 units should be 57 paise per unit instead of the proposed Rs8.33 per unit.

On schedule of charges, VIA has contended that MSEDCL wants to recover the cost of infrastructure under the name of premium service. This is nothing but service line charge (SLC), which was abolished by MERC many years ago.

The Association pointed out that only the residential, commercial and industrial (RCI) consumers of MSEDCL bear the burden of supplying cheap power to farmers. This should not be the case and consumers of other licensees like BEST, BSES and Tata should also bear the burden. This can be possible if a separate distribution company is created for supplying farmers and its deficit is loaded on all licensees in the state.

Title: Panchkula: Two fighting bulls kill 22-year-old Samaritan
Content:
Shahbaj Khan

PANCHKULA: Two raging bulls caused the death of a 22-year-old Ramgarh resident near Nada Sahib Gurdwara late on Saturday night.Shahbaj Khan, a private firm employee, was on way home on his motorcycle when the accident took place.“When he reached near Nada Sahib Gurdwara around 11.30pm, two bulls fighting on the roadside came in the middle of the lane and hit his motorcycle,” said an eyewitness.Shahbaj fell on the road and suffered a head injury. He was rushed to a nearby private hospital, from where he was referred to PGIMER, Chandigarh. But he succumbed during treatment.His friends informed his family about the incident.On Sunday morning, the body was taken to the Sector 6 civil hospital.His last rites were conducted before sunset on Sunday.Shahbaj is survived by two younger sisters, mother and father.His friends said he was a social worker, a member of a local blood donation group and had donated blood and platelets to many needy persons. His friend Gurdian Singh, also a member of the blood donation group, said, “Shahbaj was very helpful and involved in various social works.”Even as his friends protested against the municipal corporation, his family did not file any complaint.MC executive officer Jarnail Singh said, “At present, all cowsheds are full. Three new ones are under construction. Their work will be completed soon. The work of catching stray cattle and dogs will be started after that.”

Title: In times of hatred, Sant Ravidas’ beliefs most relevant today: Priyanka Gandhi Vadra
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Congress leader Priyanka Gandhi Vadra offers prayers at Ravidas temple in Varanasi’s Seer Gowardhanpur area on... Read More

VARANASI: Congress general secretary Priyanka Gandhi Vadra said the teachings of 14th century saint Ravidas and his dream of a society without any discrimination on basis of caste and religion are most relevant and needed today when hatred and violence are being fanned.

Attending the 643rd birth anniversary celebration of Sant Ravidas at his birthplace in Seer Gowardhanpur area on Sunday afternoon, Priyanka utilised the opportunity to target the government without making a mention.

“Sant Ravidas dreamt of a society where everyone is equal and honoured. Our Constitution is also based on the same philosophy and this should be the practice in country. No differences should be created on religion or caste basis,” she said in her brief address.

“Sant Ravidas taught that Ram and Rahim are not different. We all are creation of one god and hence there should be no difference on basis of caste and creed. He dreamt of a place like Begumpura where everyone is honoured and live without any discrimination,” she said adding that his teachings should be spread in society today when hatred and violence are being fanned.

Earlier, Priyanka reached Ravidas temple amid tight security and was felicitated by Mahant Sant Niranjan Das on the dais. She garlanded the statue of Sant Ravidas at his birthplace and then visited main lobby of the temple. She also joined seers and dignitaries for ‘prasad’ at the langar (community kitchen) and left for airport after spending an hour at the temple. The Seer Gowardhanpur area was flooded with followers of Sant Ravidas.

Earlier, Priyanka was accorded a warm welcome by UP Congress president Ajay Singh Lallu, former minister Ajay Rai, party’s city unit chief Raghvendra Chaubey at LBS International airport.

The temple of Sant Ravidas has been attracting many politicians. In 2016, Prime Minister Narendra Modi and Delhi chief minister Arvind Kejriwal attended Ravidas Jayanti celebrations.

Former Congress president Rahul Gandhi also visited the temple in November 2011. Bahujan Samaj Party chief Mayawati had addressed a huge gathering on Ravidas Jayanti in 2008 in the capacity of chief minister.

Sant Ravidas, born in Varanasi, was a leading figure of the Bhakti Movement and is revered in Buddhism, Sikhism and Hinduism. He left behind a great legacy and a 21st century cult called Ravidassia follows his teachings.

Title: BJP MLA demands separate Vindhya state, threatens stir
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Bhopal: Controversial BJP legislator Narayan Tripathi has on Sunday advocated for a separate Vindhya state, a demand pending since 1956, alleging poor development in the region. The MLA represents Maihar assembly constituency.

Tripathi, had kicked a political storm by defying BJP diktat and voted in favour of Kamal Nath led-Congress government in the Madhya Pradesh assembly during an amendment bill and shocked BJP leaders by speaking out against Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA).

The BJP legislator has urged that Congress government should moot a proposal for statehood to Vindhya region in the budget session of the state assembly scheduled next month and forward the same to the Centre.

Meanwhile, minister Kamleshwar Patel rejected the demand, saying Vindhya region has witnessed a significant development during the Congress rule.

“I have written letters to Prime Minister, chief minister and all public representatives of Vindhya region to take up the proposal for a separate Vindhya state. We will soon launch an agitation from Vindhya to Bhopal to press for our demand. We will talk to all leaders to raise above party politics and support this move,” said Tripathi on Sunday.
