The BJP MLA who had been praising chief minister Kamal Nath for his commitment towards public, attended a meeting of Vindhya Mahotsava preparations here, along with public relations minister PC Sharma, panchayat minister Kamleshwar Patel, former deputy speaker Rajendra Singh and BJP MLA Vishwas Sarang among others.

Justifying the statehood demand, Tripathi said, "Those who support the formation of a new Vindhya state, public will support them. Who do not support the demand, public will boycott them. After the formation of Madhya Pradesh, Vindhya region has remained undeveloped. "

The BJP has however, distanced itself from Tripathi's statement. Sources said BJP leadership is surprised as Tripathi did not discuss the issue of dividing MP on the party forum before raising it in public. Former minister and MLA Vishwas Sarang said, "Demand for a separate Vindhya state is an old issue. In Congress rule, Vindhya has been left undeveloped. The ministers of Vindhya region should come clear on these allegations."

Title: A towering presence and inspiration for many
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Amit Shah, President of Bharatiya Janata Party being offered an "onavillu" by Bharateeya Vichara Kendram direc... Read More

Thiruvananthapuram: The road to Samskrithi Bhavan in GPO Lane, where one of the noted institutions ‘ Bharatheeya Vichara Kendram ’ established by veteran RSS pracharak P Parameswaran functions, wore a deserted look on Sunday morning. Many representatives of the institute had left for Palakkad after they came to know about the demise of Parameswaran and a few who left behind were busy with preparations to accord a final reception to their leader at the institution, which he established in 1982.

Friends and followers of Parameswaran recollected their association him. “Even during his last days, he was very much active in the programmes of Vichara Kendram. He had visited the institution in January and had recently participated in a convention held in Kannur, after which he fell ill. I started associating with Parameswarji after I joined the city unit of Vichara Kendram. It is his simple yet powerful words that inspired everyone. An example for his dedication towards a cause would be the Bhagavad Gita campaign, through which he wanted to spread the message of Gita to the masses,” said Rajan Pillai, treasurer of Vichara Kendram.

His demise came when Parameswaran, who frequently travelled to various branches of Vichara Kendram, was scheduled to visit the centre in the city on February 14.

K C Ajayakumar, writer and translator, who has a 30-year association with Vichara Kendram, became an active member in 2012 after he met Parameswaran. “Parameswaranji had once asked me to translate a speech by Mohan Bhagwat. Not only in public conventions, even during causal talks, he discussed only social issues. Parameswaranji had an extensive plan for research work at Vichara Kendram, which he wanted to upgrade as an international institute of research,” said Ajayakumar, who is the state committee member of Vichara Kendram.

A recipient of the Padma Vibhushan award, Parameswaran has over 20 books ranging from philosophy, essays and poems to his credit.

Pointing at the collection of books authored by Parameswaran, BVK representative Ajayykumar R S recalled Parameswaran’s creative talent to pen poems at any moment of inspiration. “I had travelled with Parameswaranji for around four years. I remember one day when we were going for a morning walk, after observing the place, Parameswaranji wrote a poem then and there. He was always open to our suggestions like changing some words in his poems while we were editing his works. It is his poems that we sing at the Vichara Kendram units every day,” said Ajayykumar.

Title: Bhim Army chief Chandrashekhar Azad warns of massive anti-CAA stir in Uttar Pradesh
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Chandrashekhar Azad

VARANASI: Bhim Army chief Chandrashekhar Azad , aka Ravan , on Sunday said he would soon launch a massive agitation in Uttar Pradesh against the Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA) and the proposed National Register of Citizens (NRC).

“No court has barred me from holding agitation. In a democratic set-up, I am free to go anywhere I want. I am frequenting Shaheen Bagh (in Delhi) and Bhim Army volunteers are there for the security of women protesters,” Azad, who was in Seer Gowardhanpur to attend Ravidas Jayanti celebrations, said.

Talking to reporters after offering obeisance at the temple, he said, “We are ready to launch a massive agitation against CAA and NRC in UP. The chief minister who threatens to speak not with words, but bullets, must know that those sworn to save the Constitution are not afraid of bullets.”

Azad said he wished for a government of ‘Bahujans’ in the state. “I promise you that in 2022, the state will get a CM from Bahujan society,” he said.

On the purpose of his visit, he said it was unfair to say that he had come to take political mileage. “Those thinking that way are insulting over 30 crore followers of Sant Ravidas. I have come to seek blessings of Sant Ravidas for peace, prosperity and harmony in the country,” he added.

Title: CP allots mayor Joshi’s shooting case to dedicated team
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Nagpur: City police chief BK Upadhyay has created a special team under Senior PI Satyavan Mane to probe the firing on mayor Sandip Joshi on December 17, 2019. Mane was earlier leading the probe as the in-charge of Unit 4 of crime branch.

The firing on Joshi, while on way back home in his official car after attending his anniversary party, has become a major challenge for the cops. The incident, which created ripples, had left the city police red-faced during the winter assembly session. Despite several teams being pressed into action, the probe did not move further.

Around a fortnight ago, Upadhyay shifted the responsibility of Unit 4 from Mane and handed it over to Senior PI Ashok Meshram. Mane was given the sole responsibility of probing the firing on Joshi. He is conducting the probe under the supervision of DCP, detection, Gajanan Rajmane.

Mane has been reporting the progress of the case to top cops, Upadhyay and Joint CP Ravindra Kadam, on a regular basis. Apart from city, the special teams have so far visited other states too in connection with the probe. Special cyber cops, under experts, have also been working on the case to support Mane and his special team.

Title: Uttar Pradesh: Two kalpwasis killed in car accident
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Representative image

ALLAHABAD: An elderly couple returning after completing a month-long kalpwas at Magh Mela ground were among the three killed when their car rammed a bicycle and then a parked truck near Alauddin-Johapur Bazaar Road on Allahabad-Pratapgrah highway, under Mauaima police station, on Sunday.

The deceased were identified as Radhy Shyam Tiwari (65), his wife Kevla Devi (60), and Panna Lal Patel (45). The couple were residents of Amethi and Lal was native to Makramau.

Mauaima police said the accident occurred around 9am, when the couple were returning to their native village Hirapur in Amethi district after completing a month-long stay at the Magh Mela ground.

The couple’s nephew Shrawan Kumar told the police, “After taking a dip in Sangam on Magh Purnima, we were returning to our native village.”

“My uncle Radhay Shyam and his wife were travelling in a car, while I was following them in another vehicle,” he added.

When the couple’s car reached Jogamau Block Bazar, a cyclist suddenly started crossing the road. “My uncle tried to avoid ramming into the bicycle and he ended up colliding his car into a parked truck,” Kumar said.

Eyewitnesses told the police that Tiwari lost control over the car and first collided into another car and then into a stationed truck. The couple died on the spot, while the man the man riding the bicycle breathed his last on way to hospital.

Police have sent the bodies for postmortem examination.

Title: Kerala: 4 of a family found dead at home near Kodungallur
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Thiaparampath Vinod

THRISSUR: Four of a family were found dead at their home in Pulloot near Kodungallur on Sunday.

The deceased have been identified as Thiaparampath Vinod (44), his wife Rema (38), daughter Nayana (17) and son Neeraj (9).

Vinod, who was a worker at a firm manufacturing cement blocks, was absent from work for the last four days. On Sunday, the owner of the firm reached Vinod’s home to enquire and found that the front door was locked and a foul smell was emanating from the house.

Then, locals also reached the spot and informed Kodungallur police. “The police broke the door and found the bodies hanging in four rooms of the house. A suicide note also was found. The bodies will be shifted for postmortem only on Monday morning after a forensic team collects scientific evidence,” Kodungallur CI P K Padmarajan said.

“The body of Vinod was found hanging from a ceiling fan while the others were found hanging from window grills in different rooms,” the officer said.

“The bodies have started decomposing. We suspect that the deaths happened on last Thursday night. Newspapers from Friday onwards were found lying outside the house,” said the CI.

Rema was working in a private firm at Vadakenada in Kodungallur. Nayana was a Class XII student of Karuppadana Government Higher Secondary School and Neeraj was a Class 4 student of Chappara Little Flower School.

Title: Delhi assembly polls: Candidates de-stress after voting ends
Content:
While some of the political bigwigs spent time with their family, others went out to meet friends and well-wis... Read More

Getting 8 hours of sleep, catching up on newspapers and reading a spy thriller recommended by my 12-year old niece!… https://t.co/CkbUIBUngH — Atishi (@AtishiAAP) 1581241612000

NEW DELHI: After a high-decibel high-stake election, politicians took a much-needed breather on Sunday to relax and make preparations for Tuesday when votes would be counted. While some of the political bigwigs spent time with their family, others went out to meet friends and well-wishers.Complete coverage on Delhi electionsTo find out how they were unwinding after whirlwind campaigning for weeks, TOI interacted with a few prominent functionaries of all parties.AAP Kalkaji candidate Atishi said that it was time to read books, apart from catching up on some much-needed sleep. “Getting eight hours of sleep, catching up on newspapers and reading a spy thriller recommended by my 12-year-old niece! The day after election was such a contrast to insanity of the election campaign,” tweeted Atishi on Sunday.Manish Sisodia, AAP’s Patparganj candidate, also preferred to relax at home on Sunday and tweeted photographs in which he could be seen playing with children. He also tweeted that someone had asked him what he was doing after polling. His reply was what could be a better alternative then listening to the innocent giggle of children.In contrast, BJP’s Vijender Gupta decided to go shopping after having lunch. “I decided to visit the market after a long day at home. I didn’t miss the opportunity to chat with my friends and others in the market,” he said.Congress heavyweight Haroon Yusuf decided to have a lavish lunch with his three sons and wife at home. The Ballimaran candidate said, “Instead of going out, my sons and I decided to order food of our choice. Later, I took a nap. It has been over a month since I slept for more than 4-5 hours. In the morning, I had tea with my close friends.”For Saurabh Bharadwaj, the AAP candidate from Greater Kailash, Sunday was time to visit his newborn nephew. “He was born on Election Day. Because of my hectic schedule, I couldn’t visit my sister. On Sunday, I visited her and her son at Sant Parmanand Hospital in Civil lines in the morning and then went to the CM house,” he said.Delhi BJP general secretary and Matia Mahal candidate Ravinder Gupta had an entertaining Sunday. He said, “I watched comedy movies, ate golgappas and decided to stay home. People came at my house to give their wishes for counting day.”Arvinder Singh Lovely, the Congress Gandhi Nagar candidate, decided to lie in bed the entire day and stream movies. “Frankly, I avoided going out and had no political discussion the entire day,” he said.

Title: It’s like a journey from one home to another: Kalpwasis
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Devotees offer prayers on Magh Purnima on the Magh Mela ground on Sunday

Allahabad: For Madhukar and his wife Archana, the commute from Magh Mela ground to their home in Pratapgarh was a journey from one home to another. The couple were among the hundreds of kalpwasis who headed back home on Sunday after living frugally along the banks of Ganga on the Magh Mela ground for a month.

“It’s like leaving one home for another. We met many devotees here and we got along just like a family. We are taking back soil from the Ganga’s banks and intend to return next year too,” said Madhukar, who is in his 40s.

As per tradition, kalpwasis give up comforts to lead an austere lifestyle for a month and camp along the banks of Ganga to gain salvation. Their period of penance comes to an end with the Hindu month of Magh. Kalpwasis, who had put up tents on Kali Marg, said they are taking back cheerful memories and stories to share with their family members.

One of the kalpwasis Ghanshyam (35) touched the feet of his elderly neighbour Dashrath before leaving the Magh Mela ground. “I assured him that we will meet again during next year’s Magh Mela. We didn’t just share our joys and problems, but also sat together to perform rituals and attended religious discourses. As we spent more time together, we started treated each other as extended family.”

“In the past one month, we developed special bonds with other devotees, despite the fact that they belonged to different districts and states,” said Mamta, a kalpwasi from Mirzapur.

“Most of us had tears in our eyes while leaving the Magh Mela ground,’ she added. The women among the kalpwasis claimed that spending month together makes people come closer, irrespective of age and class.

“When the weather was cold, we used to take care of each other. If a devotee fell ill, one of us would be tending to him/her round the clock,” said another kalpwasi.

Title: Andhra Pradesh government suspends DGP rank officer on charges of treason
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

AB Venkateswara Rao

VIJAYAWADA: The Andhra Pradesh government suspended former chief of Intelligence AB Venkateswara Rao on charges of treason and misconduct while discharging his duties.

Authorities said the DGP-rank officer colluded with a foreign defence manufacturer by disclosing security protocols and put national security and police personnel at risk by trying to procure sub-standard equipment from Israel in a multi-crore contract for a firm owned by his son in 2017. Rao, in his defence said the allegations were baseless. “I am exploring all legal options and soon people would know the truth,” he said.

AP chief secretary Nilam Sawhney issued orders placing Rao under suspension pending an inquiry into the allegations. The orders came after DGP Gautam Sawang submitted a letter with details of preliminary inquiry that established prima facie evidence against Rao.

He has also been barred from leaving Vijayawada without permission.

According to government sources, Rao colluded with M/s RT Inflatables Private Limited, an Israeli defence equipment manufacturer, to illegally award critical intelligence and surveillance contract to M/s Akasam Advanced Systems Private Limited owned by his son Chetan Sai Krishna. Akasam Advanced Systems was the primary bidder on behalf of RT Inflatables in the contract that was worth Rs 25 crore.

“This is grave misconduct and irregularities were wilfully committed by Rao resulting out of a conscious and premeditated act of treason towards the state and nation,” a source in the government said.

Sources in the police department told TOI that follow-up action would be initiated in accordance with law.

“In view of the gravity of the case, it is yet to be decided whether the case will be handled by the state police or it would be transferred to a central agency. The decision will be taken after consulting with home and defence ministry, DGCA and other central government agencies,” the source added.

A senior cop probing the case said disciplinary action would also be taken according to All India Service (AIS) rules as Rao is alleged to have disclosed intelligence protocols and procedures of police to a foreign defence manufacturing firm without acquiring necessary permissions.

It has been alleged that Rao ignored the clarification sought by the then additional director general of police (ADGP) for operations Nalin Prabhat over technical, financial, licensing and procedural aspects.

As the intelligence protocols are standard throughout the police force in the country, the actions of Rao were a direct threat to national security, a source said.

Rao faced severe criticism from the then opposition YSRC and present ruling party for snooping on their functionaries and helping the then ruling TDP by going out of the way. They have also alleged that Rao played a key role in horse-trading of YSRC MLAs during the TDP regime. As many as 23 YSRC MLAs switched loyalties and Rao was in the middle of the political controversy.

Title: 15 inmates of hostel for socially backward extort funds from food contractor, go on jaunt to hill stations
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Nagpur: Around 15 students belonging to the socially backward categories are under investigation by the state social welfare department for taking around Rs85,000 from their hostel mess contractor and spending it on vacation in hill stations of Kullu, Manali besides undertaking expeditions such as river rafting in January.

Speaking to TOI, the students said two different issues — food quality complaint and the tour — are being clubbed to malign them while their tour was a lifetime opportunity to seek inspiration and learn new things which they may not be able to afford for years. “Our family income is below Rs40,000 per annum. None of us would be able to afford to visit these places. Our aim is to see Indian culture, landscape and people from whom we can draw inspiration,” said the inmate who arranged the tour.

A law student living at the hostel admitted that the picnic was uncalled for but it has been a trend at all such hostels. “This is a much-needed break after exams. We don’t get money for tour directly from the government so this is a mutual agreement between the warden, contractor and students,” he said.

Students alleged the contractor is conspiring now when they complained of poor quality and contaminated food being served them. “We never suspected he would use the letter he sought and the cheques in such a manner,” they said.

The mess contractor M/s Tiger Saoji Caterers complained among several other issues about money being frequently demanded by inmates on some or other pretext. An inquiry panel was set up by the social justice and special assistance department after over 100 students from its Manish Nagar hostel staged a protest demanding removal of the contractor on January 31.

Those on-tour had posted their photographs enjoying in picturque destinations on social media which led to discontent among others who started demanding money from the contractor and agitated when he refused.

The proprietor in his submission before the inquiry panel stated that the students had made a written application seeking the cash for which they were ready to forego non-veg food from January 4 to January 25.

In their letter dated December 24 last year, all the inmates had asked the mess contractor to hand them over Rs135 per student for a period of 21 days so that they could fund their tour after winter exams. The government allocates a monthly Rs4,800 per socially backward student towards mess expenses in addition to a monthly Rs800 stipend.

Propritier Prashant Irkhade said he incurs around Rs12,000 to Rs15,000 on one time non-veg meal. He issued a sum of Rs85,000 vide two cheques that was saved on chicken and mutton served on Wednesdays and Sundays, respectively. Irkhade attached his bank account statement showing the name of student who withdrew it on January 1 and 10. The tour commenced from January 11 for next seven days.

The student said the inmate who coordinated the tour furnished all the expenditures and bills after returning before the hostel committee. The same inmate had withdrawn the Rs85,000.

Contrary to Irkhade’s complaint, the law student said 35 students had preferred the tour to Kullu, Manali and Delhi. “Rest didn’t go as we were busy with further studies,” he said.

The tour coordinator inmate said 50% of the expenses were borne by the students.

The panel is likely to submit its report to the divisional commissioner of the department Siddharth Gaikwad this week.

Title: 2 tigers from city zoo to be sent to Mumbai on Tuesday
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Aurangabad: Two tigers from the Siddharth Garden Zoo, which is run by the Aurangabad Municipal Corporation (AMC), will be sent to Mumbai’s Veer Mata Jijabai Bhosale Zoo on Tuesday.

In return, the AMC zoo will get a pair of cheetahs, zoo director B S Naikwade said. After tigeress Samruddhi gave birth to four cubs in April, the total number of tigers in the Siddharth Garden Zoo had gone up to 12.

However, according to the Central Zoo Authority (CZA), a maximum of nine tigers can be kept at the zoo at a time. Earlier, the Brihanmumbai Municipal Corporation (BMC) had asked for two tigers from the AMC. Solapur had also sought tigers from it.

The proposal to send the tigers to the Mumbai zoo was placed before the AMC general body and former municipal commissioner had sent two AMC officials to check whether the BMC zoo in Mumbai had adequate infrastructure to house the big cats. All the necessary background work was completed in January.

Naikwade said the AMC has received the permission from the forest department to transport the tigers to Mumbai. The tigers — named Veer and Karishma — are aged 4 and 6 respectively. The pair were born in the Siddharth Garden Zoo. The zoo director stated that the AMC will receive a pair of cheetahs, but the process may take some time.

The earlier plan to bring colourful birds from the Mumbai zoo may also take time, he added. The AMC is planning to bring 10 colourful exotic birds from Mumbai’s zoo. However, it has not yet received the approval from the CZA.

Title: Workers seek easing of welfare board registry rules
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Aurangabad: The state-level body of building workers will hold a protest on Monday at the divisional commissionerate to push for their demands which include relaxing terms and conditions for online registration for the workers welfare board.

Maharashtra Rajya Sanyukt Kamgar Mahasangh has called for the protest, which will beheld at 10am. Ganesh Bhonsle, the president of the workers' body said that the criteria for one to register as a construction worker in Maharashtra Building & Other Construction Workers Welfare Board is too stringent. The state government had formed the board in 2011 as per the Maharashtra Building and Other Construction Workers (Employment Regulation and Conditions of Service) Rules, 2007.

According to the 2011 Census, the population of construction workers in the state are expected to be 17.50 lakh. The welfare board aims to provide improved service for the workers and seeks benefits under government schemes.

“For example, the workers have to produce a certificate to show they have worked for a particular contractor for 10 days and the contractor has to be registered with the board. The contractor is not liable to give the workers a certificate nor do the workers have a choice. This condition is unfair,” Bhonsle said.

The workers’ body demands the removal of mandatory ration card condition. They said that many of them do not have a ration card or do not have it updated. There is a one-time password that is delivered on the registered mobile number during the registration process but since many people have changed their mobile numbers, they cannot complete the registration.

The workers’ body has also said as 80% of the workers are illiterate, they are unable to handle the online system. In addition, to that the workers have to register afresh as the board office has been shifted from the previous location.

Title: How Shaheen Bagh is teaching its children
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

New Delhi: Kehkeshan Riyaz helps a five-year-old hold a crayon on a sheet of paper, one among about 40 who come to a new ‘ school ’ at the Shaheen Bagh protest site — a space set aside for children of protesters, adding to the library that was started on January 17 near the main tent.

As the women’s resistance to the revised citizenship law completes 57 days at the Shaheen Bagh sit-in, the presence of children has invited both criticism and acclaim. However, women at the protest are at peace when their children are with them. With the new ‘school’, women are confident children will not be exposed to negativity. Here, children sing, play, read books, wait for storytelling sessions, draw — all activities coordinated by mothers and volunteers.

Joan, a teacher, came to the capital from Bengaluru about two weeks ago and helped set up the ‘school’ for the youngest kids who come with their mothers from poorer neighbourhoods. “We teach poems, songs, tables and sounds. Even lessons about sharing and hygeine are important,” she said. Razia Shaheen, who also helps manage it, said mothers sign a register when they drop their kids and sign again when they collect them at 4pm, when the ‘school’ closes.

A new worry is a plea in court to ban children from the site. Earlier, the national child rights body NCPCR had cautioned against “trauma” to children at the site, throwing mothers in a dilemma. Some left their children home against instincts, but soon changed their mind.

“I came home one day to hear my twins chanting a hateful slogan, asking me what gaddar means. I know what taleem (education) I want to impart to them instead of hate,” said Riyaz.

This taleem also caught the attention of educationist Poonam Batra from Delhi University’s department of education. “A Class IV student at the site informed me that the Constituent assembly of India went on for 2 years, 11 months and 17 days. The kids’ curiosity and questions show they’re far more engaged wanting to know about the Constitution than a child would usually be,” said Batra.

The makeshift library called Read for Revolution was set up by Usama Zakir, a research scholar at Jamia. Alina, 9, visits it every day after school and draws whatever she likes, which usually involves a tricolour. A 13-year-old visits for the stories. Zakir said it's important to give children activities they enjoy, adding that drawing and storytelling resonate, the national flag a top choice to draw. “Questions are being asked about the presence of children at the sit-in. So, we started the library to provide a safe space,” Zakir said.

On a discussion about children in the resistance, Dr Amit Sen, a child psychiatrist said that children would likely feel the mothers’ anxiety about the protest as they can sense discord. “But what can be a safer place for a child than by the mother’s side, especially when the resistance is a nurturing space,” said Farah Faruqui, faculty at Jamia Millia Islamia. Joan added the ‘school’ helps ease any anxiety children may feel with police around.

On NCPCR’s earlier caution, its former chairperson Shanta Sinha said children also have a right to be heard, which is the core of all child rights. “The commission should have first listened to the children. Yet, the body acted on a mere complaint without even visiting the site,” she said.

Sinha also refers to police questioning 85 children in a Karnataka school five times over nine days. “In both places, children are expressing themselves. In one, it is misunderstood as trauma, while in Bidar, the situation traumatised the children,” she said.

(Inputs by Anam Ajmal, Shreyas HS and Nandita Sengupta)

Title: Uttar Pradesh: Suspended constable held minutes after crook son’s arrest
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Representative image

ALLAHABAD: A suspended head constable and his son, who is a history sheeter, were sent behind bars in Pratapgarh on Saturday night. Inspector (Jethwara) Vinod Kumar Yadav said, “The arrested history sheeter, Abhishek Singh, had as many as 10 criminal cases pending against him in different police stations of Pratapgarh.”

“A .315 bore country-made pistol and two live cartridges were recovered from his possession near Raja Ram Bagh road while he was planning a crime,” Yadav added. Abhishek’s father Amarpal Singh, was posted in Ayodhya , but was suspended for dereliction of duty. hE immediately rushed to Katra Gulab Singh police outpost when he learnt about his son’s arrest. There, he had an altercation with sub-inspector Hari Bhajan. Amarpal lost his cool and manhandled the sub-inspector. But, he was soon overpowered by other policemen of the outpost.

“Following the incident, the errant head constable was charged of disturbing government proceedings and attacking a police official,” Yadav said. tnn

Title: Tankers stop supply to ‘no pipeline’ areas over dues
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Aurangabad: The tanker service provided by the Aurangabad Municipal Corporation (AMC) to areas without piped water supply has been shut for the past four days because of non-payment of dues to the operators.

Residents of Jai Bhawani Nagar, Mukundwadi, Chikalthana, Satara, Deolai, Harsul, Jatwada and certain areas in Padegaon that are in AMC jurisdiction are still not linked to a water pipeline. Similarly, many other areas have been waiting for water from the Jayakwadi reservoir for many years now. These are the neighbourhoods that the AMC supplies water to using tankers. The vehicles are hired via a contractor.

A set of 20 families pool the money required for an AMC tanker in their lane. Each family pays Rs 1,100 (in advance) for three months. Tankers supply about 200 litres of water to each family on alternate days. Sometimes, the supply gap increases by more than a day.

Sarika Samendre, a resident of Vishanti Nagar, said there has been no supply for the past four days. “Our calls to the AMC staff have not helped. We earn a daily wage. We cannot afford to skip a day of work to fetch water,” she said.

When asked, the tanker contractor said because of outstanding dues of Rs 80-90 lakh, the fuel pump is not allowing credit. “The AMC has to pay us Rs 3.7 crore, which has been pending for the past seven months,” the contractor said. The AMC has outsourced 80 tankers for its supply service.

Incidentally, the AMC had recently recorded a healthy tax recovery. So its delay in payments to the tanker operator is questionable. According to Rahul Ingle, a resident of Shahar Parivartan Aghadi, nearly 2.5 lakh people rely on the tanker service for water.

“The AMC is charging these people, who are mostly daily wage workers, higher charges compared to the tap water supply. The AMC charges Rs 4,400 annually for the tanker supply while the water tax for a pipeline supply is Rs 4,050. The municipal commissioner should ensure these marginalised people do not suffer because of administrative apathy,” Ingle said.

When asked, Raju Sandha, who heads the waterworks department of the AMC, said all outstanding dues to the tanker operators will be cleared soon. “The tanker service will begin in two days,” he said.

Title: Test quality of water used in parks, Delhi Jal Board told
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

A NGT-appointed panel said an independent agency should test the water quality

NEW DELHI: Allay public fear regarding the quality and odour of the treated water, a National Green Tribunal-appointed expert panel has told Delhi Jal Board (DJB).

Mentioning this in a report submitted to the tribunal on Wednesday, the Yamuna monitoring committee has pointed out that “the bad odour from the treated waste water, high mineral content and presence of faecal coliforms, which are harmful to plant growth and human health, become the bone of contention”. Asking DJB to address public fear properly through the district magistrates and the municipal corporations, which are in charge of conservancy, the panel said a direction was essential as “this becomes no man’s land and results in the park-owning agencies refusing to use the water”.

The panel said an independent agency should test the water quality, which would remove public resistance and end the disputes about the quality of water being supplied to the parks.

The report stressed on installation of de-centralised modular sewage treatment plants near parks and gardens, as has been done by South Delhi Municipal Corporation in Vasant Kunj and a few other areas.

Title: Study: Just 9% women know of Domestic Violence Act
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Aurangabad: A survey carried out in four districts of Marathwada by five non-government organinsations (NGOs) found that 26.7% of the women participants experienced domestic violence in the last 12 months.

As many as 2,360 women in the age group of 13 to 49 from 100 villages in Beed, Hingoli, Latur and Osmanabad districts participated in the survey.

It also came to the fore that only 9.2% women were aware of the Protection of Women from Domestic Violence Act, 2005. And few were aware of the role of the court and the protection officer in helping rehabilitation of the victim.

Switzerland-based NGO Swissaid facilitated the survey with the help of four local NGOs — Ugam Sanstha (Hingoli), Gramin Mahila Vikas Sanstha (Deoni-Nagpur), Manavlok Sanstha (Ambajogai) and Halo Medical Foundation (HMF) (Osmanabad).

The result of the survey was shared by during a programme held at Mahatma Gandhi Mission (MGM). According to Swissaid, the study collected baseline information for an intervention to address domestic violence experienced by women.

Kashinath Ahinkari, president of HMF, in his introductory speech said that for gender equality in society men need to get rid of their ego. The survey result was presented by HMF trustee Kranti Rayamane and researcher Gopal Kulkarni.

As per the findings, 38.3% women said they have experienced domestic violence at least once. Of this, 33.9% encountered physical violence, 24.1% faced emotional violence and 12.2% faced sexual violence.

The survey defines emotional violence as being insulted or made to feel bad about oneself, being belittled in front of others or being intimidated for a purpose.

Early marriage, low literacy, poor economic status, marginalised social status, substance addiction, polygamy and financial or health problems emerged as the key factors that were associated with domestic violence.

Title: Light rain kicks up a stench storm in Jawaharnagar belt
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Secunderabad: Barely 30 mm of rainfall on Saturday evening reinvigorated the stench originating from Jawaharnagar dumpyard. Within an hour after the rainfall, the stench engulfed areas up to Sainikpuri, forcing residents to keep their doors and windows shut.

Several areas of the northern-eastern corridors of the city received light rainfall during the weekend. The stench from the dumping yard worsened after the rainfall with residents living in areas within 10 kms of radius such as Malkajgiri, Yapral, Kapra among others gagging during night time.

“While rainfall brought relief from dry and hot weather conditions, we could not enjoy the pleasant weather due to the acrid stench that emanates from the dumping yard,” said Geeta Kalukuri, a resident of Chandrapuri Colony in Kapra.

Residents claim that while the stench from Jawaharnagar dump yard has reduced substantially in the last few weeks following Greater Hyderabad Municipal Corporation’s ( GHMC ) capping work, it only worsens after a brief spell of rainfall. With the India Meteorological Department, Hyderabad forecasting rainfall to continue for the next few days, residents are worried over the unbearable stench that is likely to engulfs areas surrounding the dumpyard .

“Even two centimetres of rainfall is enough for the stench to engulf areas up to 10 kms of radius. It’s high time the GHMC finds a permanent solution to this issue for which residents have been fighting and protesting for the last one decade,” said T Raghunath, a resident of Malkajgiri.

The city generates close to 7,000 metric tons of waste every day which is transported to Jawaharnagar, that has been the only dumpyard for years. However, the dumpyard can only process 5,500 metric tons a day with excess garbage being stacked up.

It may be noted that the a petition by aggrieved residents of Sainikpuri, Kapra and other nearby areas seeking solution on Jawaharnagar dumping yard issue is pending in the High Court.

Title: Delhi: Teenager rapes three-year-old, sent to correction centre

This story is from February 10, 2020

Title: Illusion museum leaves citizens awestruck
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Aurangabad: A room where an individual becomes taller as well as shorter within a moment and anti-gravity room that defies the laws of physics are some of the key attractions one can enjoy at the illusion museum that has been set up at the APJ Abdul Kalam Astrospace Science Centre here.

The first-of-its-kind science lab in the country has around 21 different entities that offer a peek into the fascinating world of illusions.

Centre director Shriniwas Aundhkar said there are illusion museums built at 16 places in the world.

“Illusion can be defined as the perception that occurs when a sensory stimulus is present, but is incorrectly perceived and misinterpreted by the brain. The scientific principle of illusion can be aptly used for entertainment and educative purposes,” he said.

Ames room, where a person walking back or forth either grows or shrinks due to illusions and it seem like a person’s head is on a platter, as the body is hidden

Mirrors have also been used to bring out the illusion. Such exhibits include ‘anti-gravity mirror’ which feels like flying or swimming through the air and crawling on the wall like a lizard, ‘self-centred mirror’ which involves an arrangement of 28 vertical panes of the mirror provides reflection on 14 panes and ‘swap mirror’ which creates a false impression of different movement of two halves of the human body.

Rotating room gives a perception of a tilt of almost 90 degrees. The vortex tunnel in motion makes it really difficult to take a step forward through a rotating cylinder on a stable and flat surface. It also has pyramids, cubes and paintings which offer different illusions along with a ‘shadow room’ based on the spectrum principle of light.

The museum has been developed as a part of ‘Mamacha Gaon’, a dream project by Ankushrao Kadam, secretary of Mahatman Gandhi Mission (MGM) which is the parent body of APJ Abdul Kalam Astrospace Science Centre. Aundhkar, centre coordinator Dhanashree Kasar – Akkar and the construction department at MGM has been credited for the successful experiment of the illusion lab. It has open to all on weekdays except Monday during office hours.

Title: Lucknow: IIT-Kanpur signs MoU with TurboTech at DefExpo
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

IIT-Kanpur

KANPUR: IIT-Kanpur and TurboTech Precision Engineering Private Limited (TurboTech), an aerospace and defence company entered into an MoU at DefExpo 2020 in Lucknow on Saturday.

A team of researchers from IIT-Kanpur, including Prof Santanu De as principal investigator and Prof Shantanu Bhattacharya as one of the co-investigators, is developing an upscaled version of Micro Gas Turbine (MGT), which is envisaged to fuel the automotive and aerospace sectors in addition to the power generation.

While IIT-Kanpur will work on designing the sub-sections of the projects, TurboTech will be responsible for physical realisation of the designs and a complete assembly of the envisioned technology.

Group captain and chief operations officer Prakash Angadi VSM (Retd) signed the MoU on behalf of TurboTech. The project will be financially supported through a project under the IMPRINT scheme of the ministry of human resources development (MHRD) and the ministry of power, said IIT-Kanpur’s media cell.

According to IIT-K , Micro gas turbine (MGT) is a leap towards decentralisation of power generation and distribution strategy, which is an important need for the current power scenario. Also, it is a step towards eco-friendly, green energy production.

Title: Centre to generate whole-genome sequences of selected bird species
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Aurangabad: The environment, forest and climate change ministry has decided to generate the whole-genome sequences of selected bird species in India.

Some of the birds categorized under rare, endangered and threatened (RET) species will be covered under the initiative, which is a part of the draft visionary perspective plan (VPP) for 2020-2030. Around 270 species (21%) of Indian avifauna fall under the ‘rare’ category and these include raptors, pheasants, bustards, hornbills, cranes, storks and others — together called RET bird species.

The draft also mentions the development of a state-of-the-art genome resource banking facility at the Salim Ali Centre for Ornithology and Natural History for cryobanking biomaterial from RET species as a long-term measure.

Cryobanking — the process of storing cells, tissues or organs at very low/freezing temperatures — is considered an important conservation tool. Of the 1,317 bird species recorded in India, 72 are endemic. As per an assessment of the International Union for Conservation of Nature 2018, 100 Indian species are classified as ‘threatened’, of which 17 are ‘critically endangered’, 20 are ‘endangered’ and 63 are ‘vulnerable’.

The draft calls for identifying and prioritising RET species that need conservation intervention and asks for conducting population, habitat and threat assessments. The environment ministry said birds perform various ecosystem services such as control of insect pests in agriculture and forestry, rodent control, pollination, seed dispersal, forest regeneration, scavenging services etc.

The VPP has envisaged 15 major programmes and various thrust areas for implementation over the next 10years. These are to be implemented over short-term (2020-2024), medium-term (2024-2027) and long-term (2027-2030) periods and extended beyond 2030 based on the evaluation.

Environmentalist Kishor Pathak, talking about the draft, said: “The document is very well-drafted and takes care of challenges encountered in conservation of varied and rich bird population in India. We hope all words get translated into action and render tangible benefits to birds.”

There are 870 protected areas (national parks, wildlife sanctuaries, community reserves and conservation reserves) in India, many with avian diversity; 554 sites have also been designated as “important bird and biodiversity areas (IBAs)” of which 219 are outside the protected areas network and under anthropogenic pressure. There are 2,01,503 wetlands (above 2.25 hectare) in the country, most of which are under stress due to urbanization, agricultural runoffs which require specific management plans, VPP says while underling the need of conservation.

Title: Two, including woman held for thefts
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Vadodara: Laxmipura police on Sunday arrested a resident of Gotri for stealing a laptop and other valuables from a car. Manoj Padhiyar, who stays in Mali Faliyu, had broken window glasses of a car parked in Gorwa and stolen the laptop worth Rs 35,000, passbook and LIC premium receipt.

Police had received information that a man was moving suspiciously near Gayatri Party Plot in Laxmipura on Sunday. When they caught and questioned him, Manoj admitted to have committed the theft.

In another incident, the detection of crime branch (DCB) has arrested a woman with a stolen gold chain. Crime branch sleuths said that they received tip-off about the woman Laxmi Thakor, a resident of Kheda district. She was booked by the Navapura police some time ago for stealing a gold chain worth Rs 24,300 from the victim.

Thakor has been handed over to the Navapura police that is now investigating if she had committed any other crimes.

Title: Delhi: Jobless man kills two kids, jumps in front of metro
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

NEW DELHI: An unemployed man allegedly killed his six-year-old son and 14-year-old daughter at their residence in northwest Delhi’s Shalimar Bagh on Sunday. The accused, identified as Madhur Malaani (44), then jumped to his death in front of a metro train at Haiderpur Badli Mor station.

The cops said, prima facie, it appeared that the man was depressed.

According to police, they received a call around 7pm on Sunday from the mother of the kids, informing them about the murders. The deceased were identified as Siransh and Sumiksha.

While Sumiksha’s body — found on the bed — had froth coming out of her mouth and blood near her face, Siransh’s body was found in another room.

Malaani’s wife, Rupali, told the cops that she had left home around 3.30pm for some work. “Both the children were alone with their father,” she said. When Rupali returned, she found the house locked. After knocking on the door and receiving no response, she asked the house owner to provide her the spare keys and opened the door.

Rupali told police that she suspected her husband of killing their kids. The cops formed a team to track the accused. They received information that Malaani was seen moving towards Haiderpur station.

Around 6pm, Malaani jumped in front of a metro train at Haiderpur Badli Mor station on the Yellow Line. Probe revealed that he was under depression and had been jobless for months.

“We have registered a case of murder and investigations are going on,” said DCP (northwest) Vijayanta Arya.

Title: Kolkata: New Town to get unique art street
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

The stretch near Eco Park where the art street will come up

KOLKATA: The city will soon have a unique art street in New Town . A stretch of road adjacent to Gate No. 1 of Eco Park is being developed where artisans and artists will be able to showcase their creations and sell them. The initiative is likely to start next month.

Housing Infrastructure Development Corporation (Hidco) has initiated the process to empanel artists and allied organisations who would display their works.

An official said, “There are such streets in many European nations where artists showcase their works. Some artists have shown interest in such streets where they can show their creations, like paintings, drawings, handicrafts and sculptures, to the people.”

Initially, artists will be able to showcase their products only on weekends as the Eco Park opens. A token payment of Rs 1,000 will be charged. The art street will be divided into two zones. The empanelled artists and organisations will be allocated display rights by rotation in either of the two zones every few months.

Hidco had earlier organised a design hackathon and a number of street art furniture were installed on important traffic intersections on the Main Arterial Road. As part of this, two owl sculptures were fixed on the Main Arterial Road near Eco Park. Now, it is known as Pnechar More (the Owl Crossing).

Title: Kolkata: Book fair ends with chaos, crowd and bumper sales
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Protest in front of the VHP pavillion on the last day of the International Kolkata Book Fair on Sunday

KOLKATA: Distribution of Hanuman Chalisa by the Vishva Hindu Parishad (VHP) on book fair grounds led to an altercation, which snowballed into a high-decibel fight late on Sunday afternoon. This zone, the foyer outside the BJP mouthpiece “Jana Barta” stall, had become a battle zone for the past few days as BJP workers were seen clashing with anti-CAA/NRC protesters comprising of students and some Left-backed citizen’s forums. Interestingly, on Sunday, the face-off was between the Bidhannagar Police and the VHP workers.

In the afternoon, when VHP workers started distributing Hanuman Chalisa outside the “Jana Barta” stall, some senior police officers tried to stop them. This led to trouble as VHP workers challenged the cops and dared them to stop the free distribution of a prayer book. They argued that if Koran and Bible could be distributed inside the fair, why should the cops stop the distribution of Hanuman Chalisa. “This is unfair and so we challenged the police. We said come what may, we will go on with our distribution, which we did despite police interference,” said Amitabha Roy, a VHP spokesperson.

Students and anti-CAA protesters, on the other hand, sat on the ground near the Subhas Mukhopadhyay Mancha to write posters and participate in silent and peaceful demonstrations. They moved out in a file once in the afternoon, following the ring road, but were guided back by the police soon. “We were instructed to keep peace at the fair and not to allow any kind of protests. So we guided them back,” said a police officer. Unlike on Saturday, when 10 persons were arrested, no one was even detained on Sunday.

Addressing the media, the president of the Publishers and Booksellers Guild, Tridib Chatterjee, said everyone is free to have his/her political opinions, but no one will be allowed to use the book fair as a platform for disrup-tive activities.

The fair otherwise ended on a high note. At least 3,00,000 people visited the fair on Sunday itself, taking the total number of visitors to 25 lakh, up by 2,00,000 from last year. “This number would have been higher, but rain played spoilsport at the beginning,” said general secretary of the guild, Sudhangshu Dey. The sales have approximately touched Rs 23 crore this year, up from Rs 21 crore last year.

Next year, the book fair will celebrate the centenary of Sheikh Mujibur Rehman and the theme country would be Bangladesh. Several ministers from Bangladesh were present at the closing ceremony.

Title: Engineering student ends life in hostel
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

VADODARA: A 17-year-old student of diploma engineering of a private college at Savli ended his life at his hostel on Saturday afternoon.

Deceased Ronak Vashi , a native of Dahod, studying in the mechanical branch at a private college was staying at the college hostel. On Saturday, sometime between 2 pm and 5 pm Vashi went to the neighbouring room of the hostel and hanged himself from the ceiling fan using a nylon rope.

Vashi’s room partner learnt about the suicide when he went to the neighbouring room to hunt for him.

The friend then alerted the college management which informed the police . The institute also called Vashi’s parents to inform about his extreme step. But as the family members asked the cops to keep the hostel room sealed till they arrived, cops could not take possession of the body.

It was only after the kin reached Savli late in the evening, that the cops could bring down the body and send it for post-mortem. The police have registered a case of accidental death, while the kin suspect wrongdoing. “It is unbelievable that he killed himself. He was not someone who would take such a step. The police should conduct an in-depth investigation,” said a relative, Dilip Baman.

Title: Members of wedding party vandalize GSRTC bus after minor accident
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Members of a wedding procession pelted stones at the GSRTC bus

Vadodara: Violence erupted at Eral village in Panchmahal on Sunday evening as a Gujarat State Road Transport Corporation (GSRTC) bus brushed against a tractor carrying DJ and loudspeakers in a wedding procession.

Members of the wedding procession argued with the bus conductor and later resorted to pelting stones on the bus injuring two passengers.

According to the police, the bus brushed against the tractor when the driver was trying to bypass the wedding procession. While the bus was going to Kadwal in Chhota Udepur from Vejalpur in Panchmahal, the wedding procession was entering Eral village. As the revellers were dancing on the DJ’s tunes blocking the road, the bus driver stopped the bus on the side of the road. However, when the procession failed to move forward for a long time, the driver tried to bypass it by taking the bus from the side of the road.

In this attempt, the bus brushed against the tractor and the baraatis got into an argument with the bus conductor and driver. they even pelted stones on the bus, breaking the windshield, rear glass and a window glass. Two passengers also suffered minor injuries in the stone pelting, and had to be taken to a private hospital.

Soon, police including senior officials reached the village and controlled the situation. Later at night, the police initiated registration of offence at Vejalpur police station and also called in the groom’s father to identify all those who had pelted stones at the bus. All members of the procession were from Baska village of Halol taluka.

“We will be registering an offence of rioting, injuring a public servant and causing hurt,” said superintendent of Panchmahal police Dr Leena Patil.

“I have driven the bus on this route several times but never experienced this kind of a situation,” said the bus driver Karamsinh Zala.

Title: More hits than misses for innovative city corpn
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Trichy: Trichy City Corporation has earned the applause of many for being a pioneer in implementing many innovative projects, though it has of late been receiving brickbats for a few projects that have turned out to be a damp squib.

While projects such as ‘the wall of happiness’ and ‘street library’ earned much acclaim for the corporation, initiatives including food bank and e-waste centre have failed to yield any desired results. Here is a list of hits and misses, the civic body pioneered in recent years.

The innovation started with ‘the wall of happiness’ initiative in December 2017, which has been successfully operating on the Allithurai Road. While other cities including Tirunelveli had failed to implement the initiative, Trichy is successful in its attempt due to the choice of location, near the government hospital. The success story pushed the civic body to emulate the initiative at Srirangam to help the economically weeker sections of the society.

The street library initiative is another such successful project. Launched at Officers Colony, Puthur in December 2018, the library caters to the needs of 30-35 people every day. It serves as an exchange point for residents to hand over books they read and collect new books. "While the habit of reading books is taking a dip due to the penetration of smartphones, such libraries are the need of the hour," 64-year-old K Manoharan from Puthur told TOI. The street library, which functions on a vacant space along a walking track, was expanded to Ariyamangalam in March 2019.

Plogging, a physical activity combining litter collection and walking, is another novel initiative launched by the civic body in April 2018. Subsequently, it was emulated by other civic bodies. Latest to join the list was Miyawaki forest, a Japanese method of raising dense forest in the city. Around 10,000 saplings of native trees were planted in a day at Srirangam to encourage afforestation.

Though the corporation can take the credit for the innovations, there are also a few projects that fell flat. E-waste (electronic waste) collection centre is one of the expensive projects that failed to take shape. An e-waste collection centre was established at Thennur at an estimated cost of Rs 20 lakh to collect electrical and electronic waste separately from residents. However, the centre still awaits clearance from Tamil Nadu Pollution Control Board (TNPCB) to become operational. "TNPCB says that segregating electronic waste should not happen inside the centre, it is difficult to oblige," a corporation official said.

Another innovative project that has flopped is QR (Quick Response) code enable waste collection. The ambitious project launched in October 2018 at a cost of Rs 3-5 lakh per ward distributed custom QR code cards to all households and shops. To ensure day-to-day waste collection, the QR code cards should be scanned by sanitary workers while collecting waste. The initiative failed as those engaged in the work rarely scan the QR code.

The food bank initiative launched in September 2019 remains an underutilized initiative. Since cooked food was not allowed in the bank, the racks of refrigerators remain empty. Residents have urged the civic body to handover the food bank to voluntary organisations for better handling.

Title: Over 10,000 participate in 25-km rally for Pathri’s devpt
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Aurangabad: A special rally organised on Sunday between Selu and Pathri towns of the Parbhani district, to press for the demand of speedy development of Saibaba’s birthplace in Marathwada, witnessed huge response.

Over 10,000 people took part in the rally which was deliberately organized on Sunday to ensure maximum participation.

While Pathri is revered as the birthplace of Saibaba, Selu has a temple of Keshavraj Babasaheb Maharaj, who is hailed as Saibaba’s spiritual guru. The rally began after performing an aarti at Selu temple in the morning and reached Pathri by evening where similar rituals were performed at the local Saibaba temple.

BJP MLA Meghana Bordikar, who led the rally, said it was crystal clear that Pathri is the birthplace of Saibaba and the town must be developed on the lines of other pilgrim sites in the state.

“The temple trust and scholars have proof and piece of evidence to substantiate the fact that Saibaba was born in Pathri. His spiritual guru Keshavraj Babasaheb Maharaj was from Selu, and many evidence exist to prove this fact. Therefore, the government must not make any inordinate delay in releasing the funds for development of Pathri,” she said.

Baba Jani Durani, NCP MLC and president of the action committee for Pathri temple development, said the government must not test the patience of devotees.

“Chief minister Udhhav Thackeray had announced funds for developing Pathri and we demand release of the same at the earliest. The government must not halt development of Pathri due to opposition from certain elements in Shirdi,” he said.

Thackeray, on January 9, had announced Rs 100 crore for development of Pathri referring that the Marathwada town as the birthplace of Saibaba. The statement did not go down well with a section of residents and political elements in Shirdi.

One month after the announcement, the state government has not released any money for the development of Pathri.

Title: After 2 months, sanitary pads return to Jan Aushadhi Kendras
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Surge in demand: In a bid to boost use of hygienic sanitary pads, the government had slashed the price of the ... Read More

Mangaluru: Two months after subsidised sanitary pads went off the shelves of PM Jan Aushadhi Kendras, fresh stock has arrived and is being distributed to the centres. The biodegradable Suvidha napkins cost just Rs 1 apiece and are available in a pack of four.

Six of the 24 Jan Aushadi Kendras in Dakshina Kannada, which are recognised as A+ performers, said supplies have been trickling in over the past 15 days.

In a bid to boost use of hygienic sanitary pads, the government had slashed the price of the Suvidha pack from Rs 10 to Rs 4 in August last year. This led to a five-fold increase in demand across the country, says one estimate. “It came to our notice that the Kendras started getting bulk orders from individuals and non-governmental organisations,” said Anila Kumari, senior marketing officer of Jan Aushadhi Kendra and nodal officer for Karnataka. “Some people were also donating these napkins in large numbers to slums and government schools. We have now requested Kendras not to supply bulk orders.”

The surge wiped off stocks in November and the Union government is now gradually regularising supply. Dhiraj Sharma, general manager of marketing of Jan Aushadhi Kendra, who is based in New Delhi, said the jump in demand was much more than expected, causing an upset. “The regional warehouse in Chennai and distributors of Bengaluru and Mysuru have enough stock now. The gap is about reaching the stock to locations. We have instructed store owners to keep 100-1,000 units available,” he said.

Jan Aushadhi Kendras in the district are receiving supplies in batches. “I was told on Friday that the sanitary pad stock has arrived. I will be placing an order soon” said Chandra Mohan K of Attavar Jan Aushadi Kendra. Kiran of the Officials of the Mallikatte centre said they received adequate stock about 10 days ago. Shivaranjan of Puttur said his unit was fully stocked now.

“We received 60,000 packets about 15 days ago,” said Abhishek, managing director of Bengaluru-based Mahaveer Drugs Plus which is an authorised distributor for Jan Aushadi Kendras, said There was a deficit about two months ago, it is being rectified now,” he said.

BOX

Pads vending machine at bus stand

KSRTC has installed a sanitary pad vending machine and incinerator at the ladies’ toilet of the city bus stand. Each pad costs Rs 5.

Title: 16 farmers booked for stealing water from dam
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Aurangabad: A day after a group of 16 farmers were caught lifting water from Jayakwadi dam and its backwater in an unauthorized manner, mixed reactions started pouring from all quarters in connection with the unusual crackdown on Sunday.

Acting on a complaint from the Water Resources Department, the Paithan police on Saturday registered offences against a group of farmers for illegally stealing water.

Nathsagar, the dam reservoir has scores of unauthorized electric pumps that are used to lift water without due permission.

While water management experts and activists have welcomed the crackdown, the farmer activists and political elements have expressed dissent against such action.

“Jayakwadi dam was built for irrigation purposes originally and therefore farmers have a legitimate right over its water. However, the water must be drawn legitimately by following a due procedure. We are against encouraging farmers to opt for illegal means for drawing water,” said water activist Abhijit Dhanorkar.

Notably, the issue of rampant illegal lifting of water from the Jayakwadi dam was raised before the Supreme Court by stakeholders from Ahmednagar and Nashik in recent past through petitions related to the release of water in downstream areas from upstream areas.

Farmer activist Jayaji Surywanshi said such crackdown against farmers was something uncalled for. “The farmers are forced to lift water from the Jayakwadi dam in an unauthorized manner. The process of allowing the water-lifting must be made farmer-centric,” he said.

Title: Delhi assembly elections: Polling went on till late, says EC
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Ranbir Singh

NEW DELHI: The final turnout for the assembly polls was 62.59%. Sources said while the figure was around 46% at 3pm, it went up by 16% by the time the last person voted.

Complete coverage on Delhi elections

On why turnout figures were released almost 25 hours after end of poll at 6 pm on Saturday, Delhi chief electoral officer Ranbir Singh told TOI that polling did not really conclude at 6 pm but went on till 7-8 pm in many booths. As per convention, all voters queued up at the polling station at scheduled time for end of poll are allowed to cast their vote.

“Even after the polling ends, it takes time to wind up. EVMs have to be sealed, signed and counter-signed. All these processes continued till Sunday wee hours. Then the EVMs needed to be moved to the strongrooms as per the laid down security protocol. All this is top priority after end of polling and the returning officers and the entire poll machinery were busy with the necessary processes and procedures. While voting turnout figures too must be compiled side by side, there has been some delay in order to ensure that the final figure when put out is accurate,” said Singh.
