Title: Narol Fire: Death toll in Narol fire reaches seven, three held
Content:
Police officials are yet to get forensic science laboratory (FSL) report to identify origin of the fire

TimesView The message that the Narol denim factory fire sends out to industrial workers in Gujarat is chilling: that their lives do not matter. Across industrial estates in the state, licences are granted to factories without adequate inspection of their safety measures. This problem only aggravates by a shortage of inspection staff with the industrial safety and health department. For too long now, Gujarat’s industries have been lax about following safety norms. Neither the government nor the public have held them adequately accountable for the loss of lives. The problem will only worsen if the government sleeps over implementing compulsory safety audits for its economic power engines.

AHMEDABAD: Bags of humans bones, skulls and ash. This was what 150 firemen salvaged from the charred remains of a denim factory in Narol which was till a few hours ago a burning cauldron. The worst Ahmedabad has seen in last 15 years, in which seven people lost their lives. It took the firemen of Ahmedabad Fire and Emergency Services (AFES) 15 hours to douse the fire but could not save these precious seven lives who struggled to get out of this three-floor factory made of metal shed with only a single entry and exit. The ordeal for the relatives of the dead was even more. They now wait for DNA tests to be carried out on the charred remains so that they can carry back with them their loved ones in bags of bones.The fire incident at Nandan Denim Ltd on Narol-Pirana Road at Piplaj is a story of neglect, apathy on the part of the industrial safety and health department of the state government besides the civic body. How such a dangerous set up was allowed to come up that employed 200 people in a hazardous environment? The bodies were trapped underneath rows of large metal racks that had twisted under heat and fell on the victims. The bodies — four of them were recovered on Saturday and three on Sunday — were sent to the VS Hospital for postmortem.Narol police on Sunday afternoon filed an FIR against six promoters and employees of the firm under IPC Section 304 (culpable homicide not amounting to murder. Those included in the FIR included Jyoti Chiripal, MD; Dipak Chiripal, CEO; P K Sharma, full-time director; B C Patel, general manager of shirting division; H M Patel, deputy general manager; and Ravikant Sinha, fire safety officer. R B Rana, ACP J Division, told media on Sunday evening that three of the accused including B C Patel, H M Patel and Ravikant Sinha, were apprehended in this connection.Police officials are yet to get forensic science laboratory (FSL) report to identify origin of the fire. “It’s likely that it started from the ceiling of the shirting division of production department on the first floor and spread to other parts of the building. The spread was very quick. Several of the employees managed to make a dash to safety, those on the first floor could not make it.Investigators said that as there was no other way to identify the deceased, they would get their DNA sampling done with help of their relatives. The relatives refused to accept the bodies till the management of the firm approaches them. They accused the officials of evading their responsibility of ensuring safety of the employees.

Title: Man molests 14-year-old niece in Padra, arrested
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Vadodara: A 14-year-old girl in Padra was sexually harassed by a distant relative near her home on Saturday night. The accused was arrested on Sunday after the girl and her family lodged a complaint with Vadu police station on Saturday midnight.

The minor told the police that the man caught her when she had gone to relieve herself in a dark spot in an open space opposite her house. The distant uncle pinned her down to the ground and gagged her before attempting to disrobe her.

She struggled to loosen the grip and managed to push his hand away and started shouting before he could proceed further.

The Class IX girl said that her shouts attracted her parents and grandparents who were seating near a bonfire at the house and rushed to her help. Seeing the people, the accused fled away.

The girl narrated the incident to her family members who took her to Vadu police station to lodge a complaint.

An offence of sexual harassment and under Protection of Children from Sexual Offences (POCSO) Act was registered.

On Sunday, the police arrested the accused from his house.

Title: Gadchiroli frontline staff gets lessons in wildlife management
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Nagpur: Perhaps for the first time, frontline staff in Gadchiroli got lessons in wildlife management with an aim to equip them with biodiversity knowledge, camera trapping, signs, surveys, animal behavior and tracking.

Though Gadchiroli forest circle is more in the news for wrong reasons, the tribal-dominated district has huge potential to restore wildlife and tigers. The Sironcha division is already known for its presence of vultures and pure breed of wild buffaloes. The Allapalli division has most number of giant squirrels in the state. The district was in news for recent dispersal of tiger K7 from neighbouring Telangana.

To ensure capacity-building of the frontline staff, Wildlife Trust of India (WTI), one of the leading NGOs in Central India, along with Maharashtra forest department conducted a two-day training workshop for the staff in Gadchiroli.

The two-day workshop was held at Sironcha and Allapalli recently. A concluding function of the workshop was held on Sunday at Repanpalli in Pranhita range. In this function at least 80 staffers who were trained were distributed kits by the NGO, which included jackets, torches and water bottles.

“The workshop gave lessons in importance of biodiversity and forest management, animal behaviour and monitoring, sign surveys and tracking, camera trap monitoring, use of GPS and mobile applications in monitoring,” said Shrikant Pawar, assistant conservator of forests (ACF).

“The staff learnt basics of human-wildlife conflict and how various types of cases can be handled. Staff was also told about snakes and their identification, and myths related to reptiles. As Gadchiroli is known for snakes, training was given on dos and don’ts about snake bites and safe rescue methods,” said Pawar.

“With wire snares emerging as one of the biggest threats, the staff was told about types of snares and importance of anti-snare walks. The staff was introduced to these topics through a detailed power point session. A field session was also held where the staff was given first-hand experience of GPS, sign surveys and identification and basics of camera trapping,” said WTI’s regional head Prafulla Bhamburkar.

“Gadchiroli recently experienced tiger movement followed by livestock depredation and also keeping in mind that most of the staff will now be a part of Pranhita sanctuary, understanding the basics of animal signs, tracking and monitoring is absolutely important,” says ACF Suhas Badekar, Sironcha.

“It proved to be a good platform for frontline staff to discuss their problems in animal tracking and learning camera trapping following the recent movement of tiger in this area,” said Amrut Dagade, RFO, Pranhita.

The workshop was attended by 47 staff from Sironcha and 40 from Allapalli. Those who attended included round officers and forest guards of six ranges. WTI’s field biologist Nikhil Dandekar conducted indoor as well as field sessions.

The workshop was attended by ACFs Shrikant Pawar and Suhas Badekar, RFO Amrut Dagade, WTI field officer & sociologist Mahendra Raut, and field assistant Noor Ali and assistant field officer Vibhor Choudhary.

Title: Your work is a pain in the neck
Content:
Representative image

AHMEDABAD: Stooped shoulders, the neck thrust forward, and the back hunched. If these are your postures while working on your computers, chronic back and neck pains loom for you. Recently, a public hospital in the city analyzed neck and back pains of 512 patients to record the causes.Among reasons for the nagging neck pain were prolonged computer usage, chairs whose backrest did not fit the the natural back curve of the individual, and unsuitable height of chairs. The researchers were V R Dave, H J Khanpara , R P Shukla, K N Sonaliya, J Tolani, and R Patel of GCS Medical College Hospital and Research Centre. They found that 50 (9.8%) patients used computers at their workplace for more than four hours. The researchers gave a ‘pain score’ on the scale of 1 to 10 to patients while conducting detailed interviews on their postures. Of the total, 89 (17.4%) patients were included in the mild (1 to 3) pain score category; and 286 (55.9%) and 137 (26.7%) were included in the moderate (4 to 6) and severe (7 to 10) categories.When probed further about neck positions during work (more than four hours without rest), about 114 (22.3%) said that their necks were flexed, 72 (14.1%) said that they were straight, 312 (61.0%) said that they were either flexed or straight most of the time, 5 (1.0%) said they were extended, while 9 (1.6%) said that they were flexed or rotated most of the time. “On being asked about maintaining the ideal body posture of forward head and shoulder position at work, 67 (13.1%) patients said that they were able to follow the ideal posture,” the research paper said.In the case of the body mass index, the severity of pain was higher among obese people compared to other two groups, which is statistically significant. This supports various studies showing that spine problems affect more obese people compared to normal or overweight people.

Title: Defence ministry gives Rs 6.5cr service charges to cantt board
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Pune: The cash-strapped Pune Cantonment Board (PCB) got a shot in the arm from the defence ministry, in the form of service charges of Rs6.5 crore as services charges from the Ministry of Defence recently.

PCB officials said these funds would allow them to pay salaries and pension bills for the month of March, which would have been difficult otherwise.

“The ministry has released service charges to five financially weak cantonments. This ‘help’, albeit a small one, was much needed,” a senior PCB official, who did not wish to be named, said.

The board has monthly expenses amounting to Rs7 crore, which comes to about Rs84 crore per annum. According to board officials, PCB earns only around Rs45 crore, placing it in a precarious position.

“Apart from basic civic amenities, such as garbage collection, road repairs, water, etc, we incur spend on health care and education. We cannot afford to compromise on any of these things,” PCB CEO Amit Kumar told TOI on Sunday, adding, “Unless we get our Goods and Services Tax (GST) share from the government, our fiscal health will not improve.”

The Ministry of Defence is supposed to release Rs97 per crore per annum to PCB. Also, the state government collects about Rs1,000 crore in GST from traders and businesses in cantonment limits. About 15% of this share was to come to PCB. However, apart from Rs3 crore in 2017 and the current Rs6.5 crore, the MoD has not released the rest of the money, while the PCB has not received GST share since it was implemented. This amounts to a revenue loss of close to Rs250 crore per annum, a board official said.

A section of PCB officials and elected members called the disbursed amount “paltry”. “Service charges worth Rs590 crore are pending with the ministry for the past few years. If we get this money even in phases or instalments, it would be a big relief. We can at least meet the board’s monthly expenses. But the ministry has been ignoring this demand over the years. Unless the ministry earmarks a special budget to cantonments, the situation across the country would remain grim,” a senior Director General Defence Estates (DGDE) official said.

The official added that thanks to the reduced budget this year, cantonments will have to fend for themselves. The boards in Maharashtra — Pune, Khadki, Dehu Road, Ahmednagar, Aurangabad, Deolali and Kamptee — will be worse hit because cantonments are not recognized as urban local bodies under the state’s tax laws.

“The ministry could merge facilities like hospitals and schools with municipal corporations to reduce the burden on cantonment boards,” another DGDE official suggested.

Title: Students clean up waste & plant saplings in Kharadi
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Pune: Four students from Victorious Kidss Educares cleaned up parts of Kharadi near Fountain Road within two months and planted saplings in the area.

The school is affiliated to the International Baccalaureate (IB) board. The four eighth grade students Aadi Karnavat, Aaryan Dharani, Neel Jain and Yuvraj Bhosale said they had noticed filth covering open plots in the middle of residential areas while going to school everyday. So, they decided to clean it up, as part of their community project.

Karnavat said, “We found a resolution to tackle garbage dumping spots in various parts of the city and started working towards converting this land into a beautiful park.”

Dharani said their objective was to reduce the waste dumping and make the area garbage-free so that it could be utilized by kids and adults. Jain said the group created a proposal for the beautification of the area, which included a 3D model on plantation, created a beautiful walkway, added benches and some garbage bins.

“We met with Sushma Mundhe, the health and sanitation inspector for Kharadi, and sought her guidance and support. The area was cleaned up and an awareness drive was carried out on waste segregation for residents and local shopkeepers,” Jain said.

The students took commitment from a local nursery to donate 55 plants. They reached out to the Pune Municipal Corporation’s garden department to deliver soil for the project. Simultaneously, they sent messages on a Kharadi Swachhata group to seek help of volunteers and support for the first plantation drive, which was conducted in December.

Bhosale said, “The second plantation drive was in January, for which Vimannagar biodiversity park donated around 35 herbal plants. We also conducted a fundraiser at school by selling shakes, sandwiches, soft drinks and managed to collect about Rs8,000. We even reached out to Adar Poonawalla foundation to get their commitment for installing trash bins.”

Robbin Ghosh, the president of Victorious Kidss Educares, said, “The teaching and learning pedagogy of our school is coupled with the IB curriculum and Vedanta. These students become strong leaders of family, community and the world through these teachings.”

Title: 2 die after tanker and car collide
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Mangaluru: Two people, including an ayurveda practitioner , were killed in a head-on collision between a car and a tanker at Bedrodi , in Puttur traffic police station limits on Sunday morning.

Police said the victims are Dr Jaini Shaji , 43, and Jithin, 27. Shaini Shaji, who is grievously injured, is being treated at a private hospital in Mangaluru. The victims were residents of Nelyadi.

The incident took place around 6.45am, when a tanker plying towards Kolar from Mangaluru met with a head-on collision with a multi-utility vehicle with the three victims in it, who were going towards Uppinangady from Nelyadi. Locals removed the victims from the car and rushed them to a nearby hospital. Police said Jaini and Jithin were declared brought dead to hospital. Police have seized the tanker.

Title: Coronavirus scare: Chinese nationals in Bavla screened, test ‘normal’
Content:
Authorities said that if needed, the Chinese nationals will be screened again

AHMEDABAD: A resident of Bavla approached the local mamlatdar over four Chinese nationals living in a housing society after scare of coronavirus . The local administration carried out a test right at their residences, declaring them ‘normal’ but still the locals are apprehensive about the viral spread.Atul Thakor, associated with a socio-political organization, had written a letter to the mamlatdar on February 5. ‘In Alok City of Bavla, a family of four to five persons has arrived recently from China. The country is affected by coronavirus and the virus is spreading fast. There is no treatment available except awareness,’ mentioned the letter.‘Thus, I request you to immediately test these families as the housing scheme has 250-odd families and they are feeling unsafe. The Chinese should be declared safe after due medical procedure or they should be relocated.’ mentioned Thakor’s letter.When approached, Thakor told TOI on Sunday that a medical team did test the four Chinese nationals. “The primary test has showed no signs of coronavirus. But we need more assurance,” he said. “I have also written to the health secretary about the same issue.”Bavla administration said that the Chinese nationals, who came to India on February 2, were duly tested at the airport and had showed no signs of viral infection. They however pointed at the heightened awareness about coronavirus that led to apprehension among locals. Authorities said that if needed, the Chinese nationals will be screened again. They currently have no fever or respiratory distress, added officials.

Title: Cops return empty-handed from liquor raid
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Vadodara: A raid by Vadodara Taluka police at a bungalow in Ampad village near the city late on Saturday night turned out to be a false alarm.

Police received information that a group of people were partying at the bungalow of a businessman, where liquor was being served to guests.

Police searched the entire premises for booze but no liquor was found. Around 20 persons had come for a social gathering. Police also conducted breath analysis test of all.

“We called material witnesses from Ampad village and conducted all legal procedures in front of them. No one had consumed alcohol. We made a report of it and submitted an entry in the station diary,” said sub-inspector P J Kharsan. No offence was registered by the police.

Title: HC recognizes victim’s right to appeal under amended criminal law
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Pune: The Bombay high court has held that a victim’s right to appeal against any order of acquittal of the accused, whether passed by the trial or appellate court, is absolute and unfettered as per amended provision of Section 372 of the Code of Criminal Procedure (CrPC).

Justice Sadhana Shinde and justice N B Suryawanshi recently admitted for final hearing an appeal by Pune resident Ramdas Nivrutti More against a Pune sessions court’s order that acquitted five persons on the latter’s appeal against a magisterial court’s order convicting them for unlawful assembly and causing grievous hurt to him with deadly weapons.

More’s lawyer Aniket Ujjwal Nikam told TOI, “Before the amendment to CrPC Section 372, the remedy of appeal was provided under CrPC Section 378 and the same could be filed on a police report only at the instance of district magistrate or state government. The aggrieved victim or complainant had no right to appeal and he could only prefer a revision.”

Nikam said, “The revision would be a cumbersome process as the revision court has no powers to convict an accused in case it finds that the latter has been wrongly acquitted. At the most, it could remand the case back to the trial court. This involved wastage of time and money _ as has been observed by the Law Commission on whose recommendation an exception was added to CrPC Section 372, providing right of appeal to the victim against any order passed by the court acquitting the accused or conviction for a lesser offence or an inadequate compensation.”

On More’s appeal in the HC, the lawyer representing the five acquitted men challenged the maintainability of the appeal on the grounds that Section 372 CrPC did not provide a right of appeal to the victim. Moreover, the victim’s right of appeal co-existed with a similar right of the accused, who filed the first appeal before the sessions court and the same resulted in their acquittal. The lawyer argued that More could have at the most gone for a revision of the acquittal order.

The bench, however, held, “We are unable to accept the interpretation canvassed by the counsel for the original accused as the said interpretation would defeat the very object, with which the said (amended) provision was introduced. The right which is granted to the victim to file an appeal against any order would be rendered nugatory, if the interpretation.....is accepted.” It further noted that the legislature had introduced the said proviso to carve out an exception to the main provision to CrPC Section 372. It relied on a 2019 ruling by the Supreme Court in support of its conclusion.

Title: Corinthians Club in Undri was a hub of fun & creativity on Sunday
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Pune: The Corinthians Club in Undri hosted Happy Streets this Sunday after it completed three weeks in Kharadi.

The atmosphere was electric on a cool Sunday morning filled with dancing, art, fitness and creativity for participants of various ages.

Happy Streets is set to be held at Undri this week onwards.

At the front lawn and activity space just off the entrance of the sprawling Corinthians Club, people of all age group joined in on the fun.

The activities structured and planned for the day were well-designed, particularly for the younger crowd.

A flat, rectangular surface allotted for roller-skating and skateboarding was ideal for enthusiasts. A substantial number of children utilized the space to practise and strengthen their skill.

There were plenty of bicycles available for non-skaters to enjoy a ride along the course. This was a free service available for all, similar to last week.

An arts and creativity corner was set up mainly for children. Artists taught them how to make pinwheels using simple stationary such as paper, glue and sticks.

On the grassy bank, children assiduously followed instructions, and happily returned home with working pinwheels.

"I brought my brother here to indulge in some fun after I came to know that Happy Streets was coming to our area. Not only did my brother have fun with arts and Zumba, even I enjoyed myself a lot. I rode around the course on a bicycle and followed it with a visit to the open-air gym," said Aparna Tiwari, who drove to the venue from her NIBM Road residence.

The Zumba was a fast-paced exercise which drew all kinds of people to break a sweat with upbeat and energetic music.

The Zumba exercise, conducted at a consistently high tempo for nearly three hours by Raahil Chouhan, remained a top draw for people of all ages, as was the case with the adjacent open-air gym.

The gym was well equipped with weights and others instruments ideal for people seeking some early morning exercise.

Happy Streets is an initiative of The Times of India, in association with the Pune police and the Pune Municipal Corporation, powered by Nyati.

Title: Gujarat realtor given kidnap threat by former business partner
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Representative image

AHMEDABAD: Kaushik Patel 42, of Vaishnavdevi Park in Khoraj has lodged a complaint at Vastrapur police station alleging that his former business partner Tarun Patel, and 10 others, had come to his office near Rajpath Club and threatened to kidnap him if over dues.

However, the complaint mentions that it is Tarun Patel who owes the company Rs 7 crore and interest.

Vastrapur police said they have registered a case under sections 294 (b), 506 (1) and 114 and are verifying the details of the FIR. Police said they will soon act against the accused.

According to the FIR, among other accused besides Tarun there were Krutarth Desai, Ullas Chaku, Dashrath Chaku, Pragnesh Patel, Mahendra Patel, Prahlad Patel and three other unknown persons.

The complainant owns an office Pacifica Developers Pvt. Ltd near Rajpath Club. The FIR mentions that about seven years ago, Tarun Patel was also a partner of the company, but he opted out.

The company is to recover Rs 7 crore from Tarun and has frequently asked him to pay the amount with interest the FIR states, but he never accepted their accounts. On February 7 the accused came to the complainant’s office and sat at the reception for a long time.

The next day, the same accused came at about 10.30am and sat at the reception for about six hours. “They started abusing the complainant and said that if their owner don’t pay him money he would come with 50 persons on Monday and kidnap him. Saying this they went away,” the FIR states.

Meanwhile, some of the staff members called up the police control room. “They came with us and have lodged a complaint against the accused. We are probing the case “ said senior official of Vastrapur police station.

Title: Woman held for stealing gold rings in Pune
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Representative image

PUNE: The crime branch of the Pune police on Saturday arrested a 25-year-old woman, a resident of Kothrud, for stealing two gold finger rings from a jewellery store on Centre Street in Camp.

The woman has acted in a few movies and some television serials.

A team headed by inspector Mahendra Jagtap arrested the woman from a mall on NIBM Road in Kondhwa on Saturday after receiving a tip-off about her presence.

Police recovered the two gold rings worth Rs 50,000 from her.

Deputy commissioner of police (Crime) Bachchan Singh told TOI that she played a few minor roles in the films.

According to the police, the theft took place about two weeks ago.

“The theft was recorded by the CCTV cameras installed in the shop. We first established her identity and then began our search for her,” they said.

A case against the actress has been registered with the Cantonment police station.

Title: Three held with Ecstasy
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Mangaluru: The Mangaluru city police , who have continued their crackdown against the drug menace , have arrested three people and seized MDMA , commonly known as Ecstasy , valued at Rs 87,560, a BMW car and three cellphones, totally valued at Rs 51.1 lakh. They were arrested on Sunday.

The arrested are Mohammed Shareef Siddique,40, a resident of Chokkabettu; Mohammed Shafi , 33, a resident of Katipalla and Mohammed Anas , 27, a resident of Katipalla Kaikamba.

Police said that acting on credible information, personnel of the city crime branch and economic and narcotic police station, arrested the trio on the Mangaluru-Udupi Highway. They were procuring Ecstasy from Mumbai and selling the same in Mangaluru.

Mohammed Shareef is a habitual drug peddler and a case has been registered against him at Surathkal police station. Shafi is booked in an attempt-to-murder case at Surathkal police station and drug peddling at Kankanady town police station. Mohammed Anas is accused in a murder that took place in Surathkal.

Title: Kazhakoottam-Mukkola NH work enters the final stage
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: KNR Constructions is gearing up to wind up construction work of the Kazhakoottam-Mukkola national highway in 10 days. The contractor has informed that it will complete all pending work within the stipulated time.

Construction of a slip road to Chackai flyover is to be completed to facilitate two-way traffic. The contractor has informed the National Highways Authority of India ( NHAI ) that traffic diversion on Chackai-Enchakkal stretch is necessary to complete the work.

NHAI has asked traffic department to allow diversion for one or two days in the area to complete the work. Once it is completed, NHAI will open the flyover to two-way traffic. Currently, traffic is allowed only from Enchakkal-Chackai side of the flyover.

After opening the flyover for two-way traffic, NHAI will start work on the service road under the flyover. It also plans to utilise the area under the flyover for paid parking.

“There is concern in allotting the area for parking as drains are located close to the area. However, there is a proposal for a paid parking slot under the flyover,” sources said.

Another pending work – construction of the service road and drain at Gurunagar near Infosys – is stuck due to opposition of local people, who have sought a pedestrian underpass in the area. NHAI officials said that they would restart construction in the area within a week. Local people led by Poundukadavu councillor Medayil Vikraman has stopped work in the past demanding a pedestrian underpass. Currently the area is a major road safety concern, as vehicles have direct access to the national highway due to the absence of a retaining wall.

NHAI sources said that they could divert buses along the service road after completing construction. Currently movement of buses is causing traffic congestion in the national highway.

NHAI has to complete some work near Kovalam which was disrupted following demand to provide direct access to the NH. Construction of a vehicular underpass at one end of Akkulam bridge is progressing. The authority is now constructing drains in the area.

KNR Constructions began work in June 2015 with completion set for July 2017. Following various hurdles, NHAI revised the date of completion to August 2018. By that time, KNR submitted completion report for 22km out of the total 26km of the Kazhakoottam-Mukkola stretch.

Title: Mop in belly: Doctor ordered to pay Rs 6.85 lakh
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Representative image

AHMEDABAD: The Gujarat State Consumer Dispute Redressal Commission has ordered a Surat-based gynaecologist to pay Rs 6.85 lakh to a woman for forgetting a mop in her abdomen after her C-section surgery.

Dr Meena Vankawala will be paying the amount to one Bhavi Mehta, who was admitted to her hospital in March 2012. She delivered a son after undergoing surgery. She complained that her baby swallowed fluid during birth and hence suffered various health problems. The baby’s treatment lasted long at different hospitals.

After C-section surgery, the woman continued to feel pain in her abdomen. She consulted other doctors, but did not get any relief. Finally, on May 14, 2012, she was hospitalized and sonography reflected a foreign body in her abdomen. She was operated upon and a mop of the size of 15x12 mm was found in her stomach.

Mehta sued Dr Vankawala, her hospital and the insurance company in the consumer commission for medical negligence.

She also supplied a medical report saying that Dr Vankawala did not remove the mop during the surgery. The case lasted for seven years and the commission accepted the patient’s claim that it was a case of medical negligence.

The commission said, “This is a case of medical negligence which is highly difficult to establish... There is no dispute that the cotton mop was left during the operation in the body of complainant No. 1 (Mehta)... doctor had not taken any care to remove the mop from the body of the complainant, otherwise, she might not have suffered such severe and unbearable pain for long. This itself suggests to conclude that doctor was careless and negligent at the time of performing the operation on her.”

The complainant had sought ha efty amount of over Rs 90 lakh towards compensation for the trouble she and her son had undergone. But the consumer commission said that she was entitled to get Rs 5 lakh towards compensation, and Rs 1.5 lakh for the medical expenses she had incurred. The doctor and her insurance company were also ordered to pay Rs 25,000 to the patient for mental agony caused to them besides Rs 10,000 towards legal expenditure.

Title: Woman booked for drunken driving
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Representative image

AHMEDABAD: Two couples in inebriated condition were caught by Sola police at about 2am on Sunday from near Nirma University on SG Road.

One of the women, aged around 25 years, was driving their car in a very dangerous manner and was booked for drunken driving, said inspector Manoharsinh Jadeja , who is in charge of Sola police station. The other three were booked under prohibition act.

A team from Sola police station was checking vehicles near Nirma University, when the policemen saw a white car moving oddly in a zigzag manner.

“We stopped the car and told the woman driver to park it on the side of the road and asked all inside to come out,” said a police official.

Police sources said that on checking all four, including the two men — Nayan Thakkar and Ravi Prajapati — seemed heavily drunk. All four were arrested.

Title: ‘Develop infrastructure to attract agro-tourists’
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Agro-tourism workshop organized by Vidarbha Economic Development Council, on Saturday

Nagpur: Agro-tourism is limited to day trips and does not have scope for overnight stays. It is about observing how agriculture is done and an ordinary day in a farmer’s life, said Prachiti Bagade, assistant professor at the department of geology, LAD College, on Saturday.

She was speaking at a workshop organized by the Vidarbha Economic Development Council (VD) and Smart Welfare Foundation. The daylong workshop was on ‘Opportunities and challenges in agro-tourism’.

Speaking on the problems faced by agro-tourism industry, she said, “Infrastructure is not properly developed at some agro tourism centres (ATC) because of lack of adequate capital. Labour management, lack of awareness among tourists, extreme weather conditions and conversion of ATCs into overcrowded resorts are some of the main problems.”

Bagade stated that agro-tourism aids in generation of rural employment . “Using waste water from swimming pools and rain dance for farms at a few ATCs is a good environment initiative.”

Prasanna Shembekar, associate professor, Tirpude Institute of Management Education, spoke on hospitality and marketing in agro-tourism industry. “Most people don’t know the difference between a farmhouse and an ATC. Agro-tourism is done on a working and functional farm.”

Shembekar pointed out that observation, demonstration, participation and recreation are the main ingredients for a proper agro-tourism destination. According to him, one should figure out how to make customer come to you, make him turn up again and to ensure that he spreads the word.

He said 15% of people don’t know what agro-tourism is. Over 85% think that it means visit to a farmhouse. Using digital marketing can be used as a tool to promote ATCs, Shembekar said.

Amol Khante of CAC-AllRounder and Roshan Daga, Ranwara, shared their success stories about agro-tourism. Prashant Sawai, director of MTDC, spoke about investment opportunities and services in agro-tourism while Anup Ghumare, CEO, Cenin Tours and Travels, highlighted the role and support from tours and travel agencies to agro-tourism.

Sunil Mankikar, president of Smart Welfare Foundation, spoke on how to start new ATCs with minimum investment.

Title: Solar energy to power AMC head office
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Agra: To save power and promote use of green energy, Agra Municipal Corporation (AMC) administration is planning to set up a high capacity solar plant at its head office on MG Road. The installation of the 325-kilowatt capacity plant is estimated to cost Rs 15 crore. The contract for the solar plant has been awarded to a private company.

With this move, AMC also hopes to cut down on its power bill which is around Rs 1 lakh per month. In addition, Rs 50,000 is spent on operating generators. The solar power besides cutting down on electricity bills will also provide relief from power cuts that affects official work.

Municipal commissioner Arun Prakash said, “We are planning to use solar power as the main source of electricity at the head office. For this. a 325-Kw solar power plant will be set up. Following tender process, a private company has been assigned the task for setting up the plant. The company will also look after the maintenance of the plant for 25 years.”

After installing the solar power plant at its head office, AMC administration plans to switch to green energy at the zone offices as well. The Hariparwat zone office is located in the AMC head office. It is proposed to set up solar power plants at the zonal offices in Chatta, Lohamandi and Tajganj in the second phase.

In Agra, the Dayalbagh Educational Institute (DEI) has already set an example of harnessing solar energy and saving power. The university has been successful in meeting a major part of its electricity demand on its own and also succeeded in distributing surplus energy to colonies in Dayalbagh.

On a daily basis, DEI produces up to 2,500 to 2,800 units of electricity. The varsity has a grid tie-up with Dakshinanchal Vidyut Vitran Nigam (DVVNL) to whom it sells its surplus power.

Title: ADA fails to set up facilities around Inner Ring Road
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Agra: The Agra Development Authority (ADA) administration has not been able to set up the proposed facilities around the Inner Ring Road even after much delay. However, toll tax is being charged. The Inner Ring Road has no restroom, restaurant, petrol pump or a parking space. ADA’s plan to make a selfie point also remains on papers.

The Inner Ring Road is planned to connect National Highway-2, Agra-Lucknow expressway and the Agra-Noida Yamuna expressway with the Gwalior road. Work on the project was started in 2015.

Proposed to be 24 km, the road will be completed in three phases. The idea behind construction of the highway is to streamline traffic movement towards the Taj Mahal.

The first phase of Inner Ring Road which is 11km has been completed. Work on the second phase is in progress. So far, a detailed project report for the third phase has not been prepared.

Construction of the third phase of the Inner Ring Road will be done by the National Highway Authority of India (NHAI).

The first phase of the Inner Ring Road was made operational on December 14, 2017. ADA was supposed to make arrangements for the required facilities within two years. Despite the ADA getting Rs 18 crore toll tax per year, these facilities are yet to come up.

ADA vice-chairman Devendra Singh said, “The required facilities will come up very soon. A detailed plan will be prepared in this regard.”

Meanwhile, a kilometer of the service road of the first phase has not been completed as the ADA has not been able to acquire the required piece of land.

Title: Door-to-door trash collection yet to cover 30-40 wards in city
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Bareilly: Garbage continues to be piled up on city roads as most of the municipal wards are yet to be covered under the door-to-door trash collection service launched by Bareilly Municipal Corporation (BMC). Of the total 80 wards of BMC, the service is available in only 30-40 wards. Among the worst-affected areas are Nekpur, Jagatpur, Old City, Madinath and other pockets, where garbage continues to be littered on the roads.

Residents allege that despite repeated complaints to the civic authorities regarding garbage, nothing much has been done to address the problems they face every day.

According to BMC sources, the door-to-door garbage collection is currently functional in a limited number of wards such as Indira Nagar, Janakpuri, Awas Vikas and Civil Lines. But it is yet to begin in most of the wards. including Gulab Nagar, Gadhaiya, Alamgiriganj, Jagatpur and Old City.

Shameem Ahmed, a resident of Nekpur, said, “Piles of garbage are a common sight here. In the absence of proper garbage disposal system, it is difficult to walk through the streets.”

Usha Misra, a resident Jagatpur, Gautiya, said, “Almost every lane and by-lane is littered with stinking garbage,”

Anees, a resident in Old City, said, “With insufficient garbage bins in the area, the trash from the existing ones spills on the roads. These are not being cleared by sanitation workers regularly.”

Bareilly municipal commissioner Abhishek Anand said, “We have been receiving complaints about garbage and we have taken cognizance of the issue. Soon, door-to-door garbage collection will be started in the affected wards and it will be ensured that maximum city wards are covered under the service at the earliest.”

Title: Woman gets 6 years in jail for perjury
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Representative image

AHMEDABAD: Jyoti Joshi ’s desperate efforts to get more maintenance from her husband have landed her in jail for six years. A court in Amreli punished her for giving false evidence and making a false statement before the court, during proceedings on her plea seeking more maintenance money.

Last month, a magisterial court in Amreli sentenced her to three years’ rigorous imprisonment for supplying false evidence in court under Section 193 of the IPC. It punished her with equal jail term under Section 199 of the IPC, for giving a false statement in declaration which is by law receivable as evidence. The court ordered her to undergo both terms consecutively.

While Joshi got six years in jail, she succeeded in her bid to increase the maintenance amount – from Rs 2,000 to Rs 6,000 in December 2013. However, seven months before she got this relief from the court, the court ordered registration of a complaint against her under Sections 193, 199 and 200 of IPC.

In this case, Jyoti married Yogesh Joshi in 1987 and the couple lived in Chalala town. After matrimonial discord, Jyoti approached the court in 2003 and secured monthly maintenance of Rs 1,100 by way of a settlement in 2004. The maintenance amount was later increased to Rs 2,000.

In 2007, Jyoti filed an application for enhancement in maintenance to Rs 6,000, claiming that her husband was an accountant with the animal husbandry department in Rajkot drawing a salary of Rs 12,000. To show that she needed more money due to her dire financial status, Joshi claimed that she was living in her aunt Saguna Madhak ’s house by paying Rs 2,000 rent. She thus needed more than Rs 2,000 maintenance from the husband.

The husband, on the other hand, complained before the court that his wife was lying on oath. The court ordered an inquiry and found substance to the husband’s claim. The judge ordered the court registrar to file a complaint against Jyoti for supplying false evidence in court.

In 2014, the trial against Jyoti began. Last month, the court delivered its verdict holding her guilty of telling a lie to the court because it was established that she was not paying any rent to her aunt, because the aunt did not own any property at all.

Title: 85 corporates participate in industry-academic meet
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Delegates at the meet in Changa

Vadodara/ Anand: The university industry interaction cell (UIIC) of Changa-based Charotar University of Science and Technology (CHARUSAT) and the Gujarat Council on Science and Technology (GUJCOST) jointly organized third gala industry-academia meet on Saturday.

The meet was organized on ‘synergetic approach towards industry 4.0’ in which more than 70 innovative projects were displayed before 85-odd representatives from the corporate world.

The university has already filed 22 patents.

“The meet encouraged the industries to join hands with the innovative projects of the university and commercializing them for the benefits of society,” said a CHARUSAT official, adding that the university’s faculty members also interacted with experts from industries during the meet.

An MoU between CHARUSAT’s Space Research and Technology Centre and J K Laxmi Cement (JKLC) was also signed in presence of Habib Shah, senior general manager of grinding unit and Sanjeev Shroff, deputy general manager – both from JKLC and Ashok Patel, vice-president of Kelavani Mandal from CHARUSAT.

The university has established UIIC with an aim to design curriculum based on demand from the industry and provide a platform to students, faculty members and industries .

Title: Oscars 2020: Priyanka Chopra shares pictures of her at the red carpet of past Academy Award ceremonies
Content: Recently, Kareena Kapoor Khan announced the big breaking news of her second pregnancy with hubby Saif Ali Khan. While fans, friends, and family of the gorgeous diva seem to be growing impatient for the upcoming little bundle of joy who’s expected to arrive by late February to March 2021, one must also recall Bebo’s first pregnancy days when she was carrying her munchkin, Taimur Ali Khan. No doubt, she was a complete stunner in her first pregnancy glow, meanwhile, if the actress is looking for some inspiration for her second round, here’s a list of five celebrities from whom Bebo can take fashion inspirations to ace her maternity look once again.
