Title: Dudhwa’s Jhadi Tal to be developed as Sarus habitat
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Bareilly: Jhadi Tal which is situated in Chhairasi beat under Bhira range of buffer area of Dudhwa Tiger Reserve (DTR) will be developed as a Sarus habitat for conservation of the bird. The state bird of Uttar Pradesh, Sarus crane is considered vulnerable in theInternational Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN) Red list.

The Sarus Conservation Society recently approved the project of developing Jhadi Tal site as Sarus habitat. The society also sanctioned a budget of Rs 17 lakh for the same.

It may be noted that Jhadi Tal, which is proposed to be developed as Sarus habitat, should not be confused with another wetland of the same name located in Kishanpur Wildlife Sanctuary of DTR.

Forest officials said nearly five Sarus cranes were spotted at the site in the past. After developing the site as Sarus habitat, the forest department will try to increase the number of birds here as it is an ideal place for birding.

“The site, spread across 25 hectares, is ideal for conservation of the bird because it is surrounded by forest on three sides while one side is agricultural land and it also has a small wetland. The site is a mosaic of woodland, grassland and wetland. As paddy and wheat is mostly grown on the agriculture land, it is an ideal foraging site for the Sarus,” said Anil Patel, deputy director, DTR (buffer areas).

Though Jhadi Tal is located in the buffer areas of DTR, the way to reach the site from entry gate is after crossing dense forest of sal, teak and other trees for nearly 5 km. “We believe that environmentalists, tourists and children will enjoy the route to reach Jhadi Tal and also the Sarus crane. Developing the site will create awareness among people about the need for conservation of Sarus and other birds,” said Patel.

Forest officials have proposed setting up of two wooden watch towers, wooden benches and view shades at the site for facilitating the tourists here.

According to experts, the Sarus crane is considered the tallest flying bird in the world. Its height when standing is approximately 156 cm (5’2”). They are usually found in pairs. The bird lives in open wetlands and marshes, foraging for roots, tubers, insects and small prey. The Sarus crane is easily distinguished from other cranes in the region by its overall grey colour and contrasting red head and upper neck. The crane builds its nest in June-July in marshy areas by using paddy straw, leaves and twigs. The breeding period is August-September, and the female crane usually lays two eggs at a time.

Title: Temporary ban on trekking to Meenmutty
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: Following the drowning death of a 25-year-old physiotherapist at Meenmutty waterfalls in Neyyar forest range, the forest department authorities have temporarily stopped the Meenmutty trekking package. The department will also install more warning boards at vulnerable spots.

Neyyar forest range officer J Suresh said that all bookings for the next two weeks have been cancelled. No new bookings are being allowed either. The move will result in huge monetary loss as the department charges Rs 965 per head for one-day trek and Rs 1,100 per head for trek with one-night camping in the jungle.

“We are not much bothered about the financial loss as the safety of trekkers is more important,” said the forest range officer. During the two-week break when trekking won’t be allowed, the officials will inspect the route, identify dangerous spots and install new warning signs. It has also been decided to increase the number of guides provided to each trekking group based on the strength of the group.

“Henceforth, we will provide one guide for each five persons in a group,” Suresh said. On Saturday, there were nine members in the group that went to Meenmutty, but, they only had one guide.

The range officer added that entering the waterfall was not part of the trekking package offered by the department. If there were more guides to manage the group, perhaps the tragedy could have been averted, he said.

Anandhu M S, a physiotherapist hailing from Pirappancode, had drowned in the Meenmutty waterfalls on Saturday afternoon. A week ago, an NRI from the United Kingdom had drowned in the Kallar River on the foot of Ponmudi hills.

Divisional forest officer K I Pradeep Kumar said that as the number of domestic tourists to waterfalls inside forest area is expected to increase in the wake of ensuing summer season, all tourist guides have been directed to intensify their vigil.

Rural SP B Ashok said that police personnel in such tourist destinations have been told to check the tourists thoroughly to prevent them from taking liquor to the water bodies as consumption of liquor was a reason for most drowning cases reported in the forests.

Title: PG law dept merger with NU college sparks row
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Nagpur: The Nagpur University (NU) plans to merge its postgraduate department of law with its Babasaheb Ambedkar College of Law has courted a major controversy.

Vice-chancellor SP Kane has made a U-turn after issuing directives in September last year and forming a committee led by himself and college principal Shrikant Komawar as member-secretary following objections from a section of NU as well as former statutory bodies.

While the committee members are viewing the move as beneficial for students, the opponents have expressed concern over loss of jobs to teachers at the PG department and disturbance to the roster. The formation of committee and the directives too have come under scanner.

Opponents called the committee and Direction 40 of 2019 as “illegal” and “arbitrary”.

VC Kane didn’t respond to TOI’s calls. Acting pro-VC Vinayak Deshpande said no decision has been taken so far regarding merger issue. “A committee under my chairmanship is constituted to study the issue. We will be seeking opinion of stakeholders, social thinkers, etc. It is a proposal. Legal issues if any will also be taken into account,” he said.

In September last year, the committee ‘RTMNU Dr Babasaheb Ambedkar College of Law Management Committee for Management and Maintenance of the College’ was formed. Besides Kane and Komawar, the committee comprises two management council members, a retired judge of SC or HC within NU jurisdiction, a senior advocate, one full-time teacher of the college, joint director and internal quality cell officer.

Among the key functions of the committee is to suggest amalgamation take over or merger of the college with any other postgraduate teaching department of the university to create a new teaching and research institution with new suitable names. Also, it has been mandated to prepare an overall comprehensive plan for the growth and development of the college, covering infrastructure, and academic programmes.

Ex-management council member Mahendra Nimbarte said NU has no powers to form such a committee as per the Maharashtra Public Universities Act, 2016. “It is illegal. Every one was kept in the dark. If this merger happens, then teachers will lose jobs. When we spoke to the VC, he denied having any knowledge of the direction. It suggests he signed it without reading or maybe he was misled,” Nimbarte said.

Title: Travel bookings hit after GSHSEB realigns academic schedule
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Ahmedabad: With the state education board announcing alignment of its academic schedule with that of the Central Board of Secondary Education (CBSE), travel bookings are expected to take a hit. Tour operators said that as families align their holiday plans with their kids’ vacations and international tours are booked in advance, the last-minute change in academic schedules may disrupt plans. Estimates by travel agents indicate that bookings may be affected by at least 15% this summer.

“Leisure travel bookings for summer are usually made by December and January. With the recent announcement by government of Gujarat, there is serious confusion among parents, who are inquiring about cancellations and rescheduling of their trips. This may impact bookings by at least 15% if the schedule remains unchanged for the upcoming academic year,” said Anuj Pathak, secretary, Tour Operators and Travel Agents’ Association of Gujarat (TAG).Since visa processing takes time, tourists for both leisure travel as well as those who are visiting their kin abroad tend to make bookings in advance, said tour operators, as they get cheaper deals. Apart from international tour bookings, even in domestic tourism, many tourists travel to hill stations in April. “Prices of hotels and tickets shoot up tremendously in May, owing to tourist rush. Besides, availing cancellation for peak season travel will mean customers not getting refund and rescheduling coming at a dearer cost,” Pathak further added.

Tour operators also said that due to recession and financial crisis, the inquiries for both international as well as domestic bookings are down by 20-25%. “Such last-minute decisions by the state government have disrupted travel plans of holidayers. The government must take into consideration these finer aspects and not announce any decision overnight. At a time when bookings are already in low gear, such an abrupt decision will mean further denting of tour bookings,” said Manish Sharma, secretary, Travel Agents’ Federation of India (TAFI).

Title: TN man, two sons drown in temple pond
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: A father and two sons drowned in a temple pond at Kadakkal in Kollam district on Sunday. Selvaraj, 49, of Kariyamonickapuram near Nagercoil in Tamil Nadu’s Kanyakumari district, and his sons Sunder Raj, 22, and Sounder Raj, 17, had stepped into the pond for a swim.

According to Kadakkal police, the tragedy occurred around 6.30pm. Selvaraj and family had arrived at Kadakkal to attend a relative’s wedding, which was scheduled to take place on Monday.

They were staying with Selvaraj’s cousin Murukesh here. On Sunday evening, both families set out to visit the Kadakkal Devi temple nearby. The father and two sons entered the pond for a swim while the others, including his wife Subbalakshmi and Murukesh’s family stood on the bank to feed the fish in the pond.

According to the statement given by Murukesh before the police, they stood on the west bank of the pond while Selvaraj and sons stepped into the pond through the eastern bank, which has a bathing ghat. The exact circumstance under which the three drowned are not known. They saw the three struggling to stay afloat and heard them screaming for help.

By the time they reached the east bank, the three had sunk to the bottom of the pond. The bodies were fished out by personnel of the Kadakkal fire and rescue station. Though they were rushed to the government taluk hospital at Kadakkal, the doctors declared them dead on arrival.

The police said the pond was relatively very deep. Three years ago, temple authorities had cleaned the pond, removing silt and slush deposits, which made the pond deeper.

The bodies of the deceased were shifted to the mortuary. They will be released to the family on Monday after postmortem. tnn

Title: BCA expects to get Rs 100 crore grant from BCCI
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

BCA management claims it has got 23.78 crore for the project

VADODARA: Decks will soon clear for building an international cricket stadium in the city. The Baroda Cricket Association (BCA) is expecting to get Rs 100 crore grant from the Board of Control of Cricket in India (BCCI) this year. BCA management said that it has already got Rs 23.78 crores from the BCCI recently.

“We got Rs 18.66 crores towards ad hoc grant from the BCCI for the 2014-15 AGM and Rs 1.83 crores that was pending since 2013-14 AGM apart from Rs 3.69 crore goods and services tax (GST),” said Satyajit Gaekwad, chairman of press and publicity committee, BCA.

The BCA management said that it is soon going to organize the three pending AGMs including 2016-17, 2017-18 and 2018-19. “Once we organize these AGMs, we will get another Rs 100 crore from the BCCI. We will then have Rs 175 crores in our kitty. This will help us kickstart our international cricket stadium project,” Gaekwad told TOI.

The BCA had been facing stinging criticism over last few years due to pending AGMs as the association couldn’t avail of the grants worth hundreds of crores. The association has been promising an international cricket stadium to Barodians for the past two decades. But the project never took off due to land issues and internal bickering in the association.

BCA president, Pranav Amin , however, has promised to take up the stadium project on priority. A piece of land has already been bought in Kotambi and Amin has said that the project will be executed in different phases.

Title: No love lost between VNSGU & literature
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Sursinhji Takhatsinhji Gohil, popularly known as Kalapi

SURAT: Love is in the air with the countdown to Valentine Day beginning. But there is no love lost between Veer Narmad South Gujarat University (VNSGU) and some of the greatest literary works.

In a move that has enraged littérateurs, VNSGU has decided to chuck out an entire book of poetries of Kavi Kalapi, one of Gujarati’s most celebrated poets known for this romanticism, from BA syllabus. Further, the university has also removed the Gujarati translation of Bhisham Sahani’s ‘Tamas’ from the first-year MA course.

Kalapi’s 25 poems ‘Aapni Yadi’ compiled by Harikrushan Pathak has been replaced with poetries of Harischandra Bhatt. Tamas’ translation by Narayan Desai has been replaced with ‘Arogya Niketan’ by Tarashankar Bandopadhyay.

The decision was taken in a meeting of Board of Studies (BoS) late last month with majority of the members supporting it.

And, the reason for this is even more shocking. An assistant professor in Gujarati department reportedly felt Kalapi’s poems were just full of “love, love, love”.

“I am not against any poet, but Kalapi poems were being taught for many years. It was discussed in the meeting that works of other poets should also be taught. Equally good books are included in the syllabus and all the members agreed except one,” said assistant professor Bharat Thakore, who was nominated by VNSGU vice-chancellor Shivendra Gupta to attend the meeting.

Language academicians vented their anger at the move on social media. MSU’s Gujarati department professor Bharat Mehta said the decision was as encroachment on freedom of expression and thoughts.

“These two books which are in UGC’s list of textbooks were included during the previous BoS meeting,. But they are removing it under some kind of pressure. VNSGU’s Gujarat department head Sharifa Vijlivala was the only member who objected to this decision,” Mehta told TOI.

Chairperson of Gujarati BoS, Rujuta Gandhi, said, “VC and others asked me to make changes in the syllabus as per outcome of Gyan Sangam and government’s guidelines. So I suggested them to bring it in BoS. I was against some changes but I also believe that both sides have their reservations and ultimately it is the loss of students. Both sides are trying to play politics.”

A BoS member added, “They called the meeting specifically to make these changes and many members were not from Gujarati subject in BoS of Gujarati. They took the decisions by majority and there is no one to stop them.”

Ketan Desai, a professor of science and VNSGU syndicate member, said, “It was discussed in Gyan Sangam an event held in university few months ago to revise existing syllabus. I was sent by VNSGU V-C to convey the outcome of Gyan Sangam in the BoS. Some books are being taught for many years, so we proposed that new Gujarati writers should be included.”

Sursinhji Takhatsinhji Gohil (1974-1900), popularly known as Kalapi, was ruler of Lathi state currently in Amreli district of Gujarat. In a short life, his creations are considered as greatest contribution to Gujarati literature .

Tamas is a novel on backdrop of communal violence during India-Pakistan partition.

Title: Family of six suffers burns in LPG blast at Warasiguda
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Secunderabad: A family of six, including a three-month-old girl, suffered burn injuries in a cylinder blast on Sunday morning at Warasiguda .

Chilkalguda police said that Mohammed Ghouse, who runs a marble business, his wife Shabana Begum, and their four daughters- Afiya, 9, Shifa, 6, Misbha, 3, and three-month-old Umema were injured in the mishap and are undergoing treatment at Gandhi hospital .

Ghouse and his wife suffered 70 per cent burn injuries while their four children suffered 30 per cent burns.

The incident took place at 6.30 am on Sunday when the family members were asleep. Waking up to a foul smell, the Ghouse household went to the kitchen.

“It is possible that the gas was leaking from the cylinder since Saturday night. By Sunday morning, the gas had diffused to all parts of their house. Immediately after the light was turned on, the mishap took place,” Chilkalguda Inspector AC Balagangi Reddy said. Police said the couple are in serious condition. The children are under observation .

Title: Gujarat schools set for new academic calendar
Content:
Schools will have limited time to declare results if the session commences from April 20

AHMEDABAD: Though the academic fraternity is confused about the implementation of the new academic calendar, the state government said it is prepared to ensure smooth implementation. Secretary, primary and secondary education, Vinod Rao, said that elaborate planning is in place. “There will be no dearth of textbooks,” Rao said. “The printing of textbooks for Classes IX to XII is complete and they will be distributed in March. Almost 70% of printing of textbooks for Classes VI to VIII is complete. The printing for Classes I to VIII will finish by mid-March.” The state education department has printed almost 50% extra books to meet the demand.However, confusion still prevails following the announcement of change in the academic session to April-March from June-May. Educators say that the circular lacks clarity on multiple fronts. Moreover, parents have had to cancel their vacation plans. In the circular, the education department has asked schools to start the new academic session from April 20 this year and from the first week of April from 2020-21. The circular also says that to reduce the stress, there will be only two exams — in October and March.Most schools say the change should have been introduced as a pilot project this year and across state next year as it will be tough for schools in rural areas to make the switch. The biggest challenge is that exams conclude in the second week of April. Schools will have limited time to declare results if the session commences from April 20. Besides, teachers will have to deal with invigilation of exams, checking of papers, and teaching. “The students fail to get books till June,” an educator said. “How will they arrange for them in April?”Citing the scorching heat of April, Prutha Desai, the mother of a Class V student, said: “My daughter is in the afternoon shift. How will she endure the heat?” However, some in the education fraternity see the positive side. Preeta Pillai, another educator, said: “The move will bring us on a par with the Central Board of Secondary Education (CBSE). With only two exams, the stress on students will be reduced.”“Vacations have not been curtailed,” Rao said. “Schools were functioning, and we have now included teaching.” As for cancelled vacations, he said: “The academic calendar was declared last year.”

Title: Will win Delhi polls: Kishan
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Hyderabad: Union minister G Kishan Reddy , talking to the media on Sunday, said BJP will win Delhi elections. He also said that there was no fear of Coronavirus in the country. “The Union government is trying to get Indian passengers stranded aboard a ship near Japan, back home,” he said. tnn

Title: Telangana farmers’ wait to get turmeric minimum support price may get longer
Content:
Representative image

HYDERABAD: The long-pending demand of Telangana farmers of getting minimum support price ( MSP ) for turmeric may be delayed further as nine other states have also joined the spice bandwagon.The National Task Force, constituted after Nizamabad farmers took up an agitation, is assessing prices quoted by different states and the highest was sought by Tamil Nadu at Rs 12, 500. The variation, in prices quoted by the states, might delay any announcement on MSP, highly-placed sources said.Apart from Telangana, Karnataka, Tamil Nadu, Andhra Pradesh, Maharashtra, Gujarat and a few north eastern states were involved in consultations with the Task Force committee. Farmers, various stake-holders and state governments had represented before the panel. Sources in the Union agriculture ministry told TOI that the Telangana government reportedly recommended Rs 9,000 per quintal as the MSP. Curiously, the state government has given three different prices before three different central teams.Apart from the Task Force committee, two central teams from the ministries of commerce and agriculture also visited the turmeric-growing states. The state government had recommended between Rs 6,500 and Rs 12,000 before the central teams. The sources said the farmers of Andhra Pradesh, Telangana, Karnataka and Maharashtra expressed satisfaction with the Rs 9,000 per quintal, but Tamil Nadu farmers wanted Rs 12, 500 per quintal as the production cost was high in their state.Though turmeric was part of the spice board along with 57 other crops, it was not included in the list of crops for which MSP was being declared, as it was considered a perishable crop. “The final decision will be delayed though getting MSP for turmeric is most likely,” the official said.Meanwhile, the TRS government refused to send any letter as sought by Union commerce minister Piyush Goyal on MSP recommendation.

Title: Smokers must go for screening to detect lung cancer early: Doctors
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Nagpur: Most people are aware cigarette smoking can cause lung cancer. Still, not many are ready or able to quit smoking. Doctors advise that such people should at least get themselves screened regularly for lung cancer to ensure early detection.

“No doubt treatments are getting better but lung cancer still kills more men and women than any other type of cancer,” said Dr Subhrajit Dasgupta, director of Rashtrasant Tukdoji Cancer Hospital and Research Centre, on Sunday.

“Lungs are internal organs and there are no visible symptoms like lumps in case of lung cancer. Still, smokers must understand that they are at risk. They must not ignore any cough that stays more than three weeks even after taking medicines,” he said.

He was speaking at ‘Update on lung cancer’, organized by RST Cancer Hospital and Indian Medical Association (IMA) Nagpur branch. Expert pulmonologists, medical oncologists, pathologists, and surgeons discussed various aspects of lung cancer which has highest rate of mortality in all cancers.

According to pulmonologist Dr Rajesh Swarnakar, majority of patients with lung cancer die within a year of diagnosis and only 17% of them can survive for five years. “This is because lung cancer patient report at advanced stage,” he said.

Doctors also said that there is no screening programme for lung cancer in India so far. “A person who is smoking from a significant period should meet doctors and go for CT Scan. Early detection and quitting smoking may add some more years to your life,” said pulmonologist Dr Sushant Meshram.

Dr Deepak Muthreja spoke about endobronchial ultrasound trans-bronchial needle aspiration (EBUS-TBNA) which is initial diagnostic and staging procedure in patients suspected with lung cancer. “This technique is faster, cheaper and effective than CT or PET scan. It provides real-time imaging of the surface of the airways, blood vessels, lungs, and lymph nodes,” he said.

Histopathologist Dr Kamayani Deshpande spoke on challenges in diagnosis of lung cancer. Dr Vaibhav Chaudhary and Dr Parag Ingle elaborated on current trends. Joint director of RST Hospital Dr Prasanna Joshi coordinated the interactive session while Dr B K Sharma conducted the proceedings.

Lung cancer: Who needs screening

Lung cancer is deadly because it usually does not show any symptoms

It gets diagnosed mostly in advanced stage when it is difficult to cure

People above 50 years of age who currently smoke should be screened for lung cancer once a year

Even those who have quit smoking need to be screened once in a year up to 15 years

Smokers should go for screening even if they are not experiencing clinical signs or symptoms

Screening includes a low dose CT scan and a clinical evaluation which is painless and fast

Title: Prisoner among 4 booked for murder of Doon property dealer in Meerut
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Muzaffarnagar: A day after the body of Dehradun-based property dealer Pankaj Sharma was recovered from an SUV in Khatauli area, an FIR against four was registered on the complaint of the deceased’s wife.

According to the complainant, her husband was being threatened for extortion by one of the accused Jitender Rawat, who is currently in jail. Police said the deceased Sharma also has criminal antecedents, which is being looked into it.

“On Saturday late evening, a case under section 302 (punishment for murder) of the Indian Penal Code was registered against four people at Khatauli police station after the deceased wife filed a complaint,” said station house officer of the Khatauli police station, Santosh Kumar Tyagi.

The deceased’s wife has alleged that four people, including Rawat who is currently lodged in Tehri, Uttrakhand, are responsible for her husban’s murder. Meanwhile, police sources said the deceased and the accused knew each other.

According to the investigation done by the police, Pankaj Sharma is resident of Adarsh colony in Dehradun. Police said a country-made firearm and several bullets were recovered from the vehicle.

Title: Accused wanted in two murder cases arrested during encounter
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Muzaffarnagar: A criminal accused of two murders was arrested during a police encounter near Bharat inter-college Muzzafarnagar on Sunday morning.

Police had received a tip-off that accused Arya Kant was hiding in Bharat inter-college, following which Chhapar police laid a trap. But as the police tried to capture him he fired at the police team.

Police also retaliated during which he sustained bullet injury in his leg and was subsequently, arrested.

Police have seized one country-made weapon and some cartridges from his possession.

Arya Kant was charged after killing a man in October. Police said he was on the run ever since.

“He was carrying Rs 20,000 bounty and was wanted in two murder cases,” superintendent of police (City) Satpal Antil said.

Giving details on the status of the accused who was shot at, station house officer of the Chhapar police station Pawan Kumar Sharma said, “He is admitted at the hospital and will be sent to jail.”

Title: Govt executing ‘unparalleled’ dvpt work in T’puram: Minister
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: Dismissing allegations that the state budget failed to give due consideration to the needs of the state capital, Kadakampally Surendran, the only minister representing the district, said the government was implementing ‘unparalleled’ development works in Thiruvananthapuram.

“It’s been a deliberate campaign which began on social-media platforms, where the BJP now has a big influence. However, the people are convinced about ongoing developmental activities in Thiruvananthapuram,” the cooperation and devaswom minister told reporters here on Sunday.

Elaborating on various ongoing and proposed works in the state capital, Surendran said the only shortcoming was the procedural delay, which needs to be addressed efficiently. “The government has adopted a comprehensive development policy for the capital district considering its future possibilities.”

The 2020-21 budget has proposed PWD works worth an estimated Rs 1,696 crore in the district for which Rs 42 crore has been earmarked as token advance, Surendran said. “An amount of Rs 3,008.20 crore has been sanctioned by KIIFB for implementing 96 projects, which can change the face of the state capital,” the minister asserted.

A major project approved in the budget is the development of Kattakkada Junction, for which Rs 100 crore has been earmarked, while a total of 48 projects , estimated between Rs 10 crore and Rs 50 crore, have been allocated Rs 969 crore for this year alone, Surendran said. This is apart from the Rs 350 crore set apart this year for Vizhinjam seaport, besides Rs 21.5 crore for Travancore Titanium, Rs 13.6 crore for Kerala Automobiles, Rs 6 crore for Thiruvananthapuram Spinning Mill and Rs 5 crore for Handicrafts Development Corporation in the industry sector.

“At least half of the Rs 153 crore announced for the handloom sector is for Thiruvananthapuram, besides the Rs 1,000 crore earmarked for the coastal zone package. The district will also have a good share in the west coast canal and coastal and hill highway projects,” he said.

Under KIIFB projects, a total of Rs 1,133.63 crore has been sanctioned for 24 roads, Rs 65 crore for five bridges and Rs 316 crore for four flyovers including Ulloor, Pattom and Sreekaryam, the minister said. Thiruvananthapuram has been sanctioned Rs 209 crore under the hill highway project, Rs 544 crore for drinking water projects, Rs 141 crore for development of hospitals and Rs 100 crore for IT Park at Techno City, he added.

Surendran, who also holds the tourism portfolio, said tourism projects worth Rs 450 crore were being implemented in the district. “An amount of Rs 317 crore is being spent for development of destinations including Kovalam, Shankumugham, Veli, Akkulam, Varkala and Kappil. The first phase cleaning work of the Kovalam-Varkala stretch of the Kovalam-Bakel national waterway is nearing completion,” he said.

Referring to BJP workers burning effigies of the chief minister, the finance minister and himself on Saturday, Surendran said, they (the BJP workers) should have burnt effigies of Prime Minister Modi and other representatives of the central government instead for ‘the anti-Kerala stand’ they have adopted.

Title: New community hall at Tarnaka
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Secunderabad: The Greater Hyderabad Municipal Corporation (GHMC) will soon construct a new community hall at Chintal Basti in Tarnaka .

Following requests from the residents, T Padma Rao, deputy speaker of Telangana legislative assembly instructed officials to take necessary measures. A RCC nala wall will also be constructed in the place of a collapsed wall in Seethaphalmandi division.

The deputy speaker also conducted a review meeting with GHMC engineering officials on pending civic works pertaining to Secunderabad Assembly Constituency. TNN

Title: Toxic waste in stream: Firm gets closure notice
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: Kerala water authority (KWA) temporarily stopped pumping from its Kundamankadavu pump house following chemical contamination in a stream near its source. The health wing of the city corporation has slapped closure notice on an electroplating unit in Vayalikkada in this regard. The action was taken after finding that employees of the unit dumped chemical waste in a drain leading to the stream.

KWA officials said that they have resumed pumping by Sunday night after finding that samples taken from near the KWA source were not contaminated.

Residents had noticed floating dead fish in the stream that leads to Karamana River at Vayalikara, around 2-3km away from the pump house on Sunday morning. Following the complaint, corporation officials visited the area and found that a local firm – Matha Industries, which is engaging in electroplating works – has dumped chemical waste into the drain on Saturday evening.

Health standing committee chairman I P Binu said that a team of officials from corporation, including three health inspectors, reached the spot on Sunday morning. He said that samples collected will be sent for testing on Monday.

“We got complaints that people spotted dead fish in the stream near Haritha Nagar at Vayalikkada, Vazhottukonam. In the preliminary investigation, we found that the staff had dumped a chemical named ‘Surfolin sk 40’, an alkaline soak cleaner, into the drain, which seem to have caused the contamination. We have collected samples from the firm, drain and the stream,” he said. Binu said that people depending on KWA water should use only boiled water for drinking purpose.

“The firm has been asked to arrange three tanks to purify water. It has been directed to release water to drain only after purification,” said health inspector S S Minu.

The Vattiyoorkavu police have registered a case suo motu in connection with the incident, invoking relevant sections for polluting water sources of the public. “The health department officials have collected samples from the stream to find out the nature of toxic material dumped into the stream,” said Vattiyoorkavu sub-inspector D Suvarnakumar.

As KWA stopped pumping for several hours, water supply was disrupted in areas such as Vattiyoorkavu, Thirumala, Poojappura, Karamana, Valiyavila and Vellayambalam. KWA officials said that water supply will be normalized in these areas only by Monday noon.

Title: High court restores pension for widow, 80
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Madurai: Madras high court has directed officials to continue paying monthly pension to an elderly woman from Theni district saying the reasons cited in the order to stop the pension are not sustainable.

Petitioner Lakshmi, 80, who lives separately from her two sons and daughter was sanctioned monthly pension by the special tahsildar for social security scheme under the Indira Gandhi National old age pension scheme at Andipatti on March 13, 2012. However, it was withdrawn suddenly from October 2013. Since there was no response to her petitions, she moved HC Madurai bench in 2019 following which the court directed the officials to consider her representation and pass orders on merit. Thereafter, the special tahsildar passed an order dated July 30, 2019, stopping monthly pension to the petitioner. Lakshmi moved the court again this year seeking to quash the order. Justice Pushpa Sathyanarayana observed that the rejection order passed by the officials stated that the petitioner is the owner of two acres of land and has two sons. The order also says that the sons who are 62 and 58 years have no jobs and the land has been partitioned among the two. The petitioner is also hearing impaired and unable to do any work by herself. The judge noted that the special government pleader submitted that they are willing to continue paying pension of Rs 1,000 considering the petitioner’s age. The judge observed that there is no reason for withdrawal of the monthly pension from October 2013 and the officials are dutybound to pay the arrears to the petitioner. Though the special government pleader submitted that it would be difficult to heed the request as it will lead to many petitions claiming arrears, she submitted that arrears would be paid to the petitioner for 2019 by treating it as a special case. With the petitioner’s counsel also agreeing, the judge directed payment of Rs 12,000 arrears to the petitioner for 2019 in four weeks.

The special tahsildar was also asked to pay monthly pension of Rs 1,000 from January 2020 throughout her lifetime.

Title: Stray bull kills farmer, 40, in Shahjahanpur
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Bareilly: A 40-year-old farmer was gored to death by a stray bull in Tilhar area of Shahjahanpur district on Sunday afternoon. The victim was keeping his crop when a herd of stray cattle barged into his farm. When he was trying to shoo them away, a giant bull charged at him and gored him to death.

After the incident, locals gathered and caught the bull and handed it over to nagar panchayat officials. Police sent the body for autopsy.

Victim Virendrapal was the eldest among his five brothers and used to live in a joint family.

Virendrapal’s father said Virendra had died before farmers came to his rescue.

Tilhar police station SHO Sanjay Rai said, “A team of the administration will visit the bereaved family and initiative the process for granting ex gratia in accordance with law.”

Title: University of Hyderabad fails to conduct audit for admissions
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

University of Hyderabad

HYDERABAD: Despite the 84th Academic Council (AC) of University of Hyderabad ( UoH ) passing a resolution to audit all admissions at the university to find discrepancies in seat allotment, the varsity failed to conduct an audit in the past year.

The decision to audit was taken after students alleged that the varsity was discriminating against reserved category students, especially at Doctor of Philosophy (PhD) level.

“ In the last AC meet, it was resolved that UoH would initiate an audit of admission in all departments to ensure that seat allotments are happening as per regulations. However, for some reason the audit did not happen,” said a senior professor of UoH, who was part of the meet in March, 2019.

Teaching faculty said that the issue cropped in only after the University Grants Commission (UGC) came up with a limit on number of research scholars a professor, associate professor, or assistant professor can have. “Earlier, a professor could guide unlimited students. But later, UGC said a professor can guide a maximum of eight students. Soon students started alleging about discrepancies,” a professor said.

Vinod Pavarala, chair of the admission grievance committee 2019-20, who inquired into the issue during the August 2019 session after students submitted a petition, said that at least seven students benefited after the committee redirected department heads to reconsider recommendations.

“In some cases there were no candidates in a category and in other cases even when students were available, a department did not fill seats. That is when we asked them to reconsider their decision,” Vinod said.

“Had they done the audit it would have given us a clear picture,” said Iniyavan M, president, Ambedkar Students Association.

Title: Send sexual harassment plaint to police: HC to MSU
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Madurai: Madras high court has directed the registrar of Manonmaniam Sundaranar University (MSU), Tirunelveli, to forward a sexual harassment complaint against an assistant professor to the police. Justice G R Swaminathan passed the order while hearing the plea filed by a victim seeking a direction to the university to lodge a complaint with the police.

The petitioner said that Vinod Vincent Rajesh, an assistant professor in the history department, committed acts of sexual harassment when she was a student of the university. Based on the complaint lodged by her and other victims, an inquiry committee was constituted. The judge noted that the petitioner’s counsel submitted that the committee found the assistant professor guilty of acts alleged against him. The university syndicate also passed a resolution in 2016 accepting the committee’s report and resolved to treat his period of suspension as punishment and stoppage of two increments with cumulative effect was also ordered.

However, the grievance of the petitioner is that the action taken by the university is wholly insufficient. The petitioner’s counsel drew the court’s attention to section 11 of Sexual Harassment of Women at Workplace (Prevention, Prohibition and Redressal) Act, 2013, which mandates the committee to forward the complaint to police for registration of case under IPC section 509 (word, gesture or act intended to insult the modesty of a woman) or any other provisions within seven days if a prima facie case exists. The judge noted that the university has failed to forward the complaint to the jurisdictional police in this case. Though the standing counsel for the university stated that he would get instructions as to whether such action is taken, the court said it is of the view that it is not necessary to adjourn the case for the purpose.

It is seen that the cause of action arose in 2015 and the complaint was made in July 2016. The judge observed that though the petition was filed way back in February 2016, the case had been taken up for final disposal only in January 2020. “It is seen that the offence under IPC section 509 is punishable only up to three years. Therefore, neither the police nor the jurisdictional magistrate will close the complaint on the ground of infraction of the statutory mandate under Section 468 Cr.P.C. This is because, the petition filed by the petitioner has been pending before this court for four full years,” observed the judge.

Hence the judge directed the registrar to forward the complaint along with the committee’s report dated August 14, 2015 to the police in three weeks. The judge further directed the inspector of police of Pettai police station to register FIR on receiving the complaint and conclude the investigation in three months.

Title: Music lovers relish popular Hindi songs
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Nagpur: It was time for music lovers to relish popular Hindi songs at a programme titled ‘Kabhi hoti nahin jiski haar, woh toh hai pyar’, organized jointly by Rajnigandha and District Bar Association at Dr Vasantrao Deshpande Hall on Saturday.

Eighteen singers presented 32 romantic and entertaining songs much to the delight of the audience.

‘Ab mujhe raat din tumhara hi’ was the first song presented by Abhimanyu Samarth, followed by ‘Neele neele ambar par’ by Praveen Manpe, which received repeated applause.

‘Aaja aaja main hoon pyar tera’, an entertaining number, was sung by Vinod Khobre and Kiran Barapatre. ‘Saathiya tune kya kiya’ was yet another duet presented by Prakash Jaiswal and Simran Naidu.

Singers Priya Gupta, Deepak Sutavne, Pramod Pekde, Prashant Mankar, MV Pardhe, Jitendra Rajkumar, Girish Sharma, Dinkar Pande, Deepak Tambekar, Chintan Deopujari, JM Gandhi and Parinita Maturkar kept music lovers engrossed.

Hits like ‘Dekha na hai re socha na’, ‘Arey deewano mujhe pehchano’, ‘Chahe koi mujhe junglee kahe’, ‘O mere sona re sona’, ‘Sara zamana haseeno ka deewana’ and other songs were presented energetically.

Romantic songs ‘Tum mile dil khile’, ‘Pyar karne wale’, ‘Chalo ek baar firse ajnabi baan jaye hum dono’, ‘Chahunga main tujhe saanjh savere’, ‘Yeh mera dil pyar ka deewana’, ‘Sochenge tumhe pyar’ and ‘Jab mohabbat jawan hoti hai’ were relaxing.

District and sessions judge VB Kulkarni, commissioner of police Bhushan Kumar Upadhyay, president of DBA Kamal Satuja, secretary Nitin Deshmukh, senior police officer Raghvendra Kshirsagar and Rajesh and Rani Rokde were the guests of honour. Members of DBA were present.

Anchor Manoj Salpekar kept the audience engaged by narrating the anecdotes behind songs and making of movies.

The programme was conceptualized by Parinita Maturkar and Simran Naidu, in coordination with Tushar Vighne, who also looked after music arrangement.

Title: CAA Protest in Mumbai: Hyderabad cops crack down on flash protests
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Representative image

HYDERABAD: City police on Sunday slapped a case of rioting against several people for holding flash protests against CAA in Mallepally area during night time.

Police invoked stringent sections under the Prevention of Damage to Public Property (PDPP) Act against the agitators in order to curb the increasing number of flash protests being held at night.

Mild tension prevailed near Riyan Hotel under Habeeb Nagar police station limits on Saturday night after a large group of protesters, including women activists Khaleda parveen and Sheeba Minai, staged a flash protest against the CAA, NRC and NPR.

Sleuths from the police commissioner’s task force, quick reaction team and local police were pressed into service. As many as 34 protesters, including 22 men and 12 women, were arrested from the protest site. Most of them were detained at Goshamahal police stadium while the women were taken to the women’s police station at CCS.

“They pushed us and obstructed us in carrying out our legitimate duties. When we told them to get into the police van, they broke the side mirror of the police vehicle,” said inspector P Shiva Chandra of Habeeb Nagar police

Title: Thiruvananthapuram: Central station expands 4-wheeler parking facility
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram Central railway station

THIRUVANANTHAPURAM: Addressing the demand for additional parking space in Thampanoor, the railways has expanded parking facilities at Thiruvananthapuram Central railway station. The area near Thampanoor flyover has been cleared for parking four-wheelers.

Central station director Ajay Kaushik said the extended parking area can accommodate 70 cars.

"Passengers have been demanding additional car parking facilities and the available space was proving inadequate. The land near the flyover had become a dumping ground for construction debris and other waste. An authorised agency was handed over the construction material and plastic bottles collected from the area were sent to a shredding unit. Some vehicles were found parked or abandoned in the area, which will be auctioned as per procedure. A 2,000 sqm area has been cleared and made available for four-wheeler parking at the entry to the station," said Kaushik.

Normal parking fees will be charged in the extended area.

The Central station only had parking space for 75 cars. There is space for 20 cars in the premium parking area. Parking at the Power House Road entry can take 30 cars. Also, 500-odd two-wheelers can be parked next to the main entry and around 400 two-wheelers on the Power House Road side.

Railway also proposes to close the staff parking space under the flyover. “Illegal parking is rampant here and this affects the revenue of the railways. So, it has been decided to relocate staff parking to the main parking yard and make it a people-entry gate,” Kaushik said.

Around 400 parking passes have been issued to railway employees working at the station.

Title: Locust attack: UP farmers told to be alert, inform authorities about insects
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Bijnor: After a spurt in locust attacks in Punjab, Rajasthan, Haryana, Gujarat and other states recently, Uttar Pradesh agriculture department has issued a high alert in the state in this regard. Locally called ‘Tiddi Dal’, locusts are known to attack healthy crop on farmlands. According to experts, this time of the year is highly sensitive because locusts reproduce during this month. All the village pradhans and farmers have been alerted about the locust attacks and have been asked to inform the district authorities if they spot any such incident.

The state government has issued advisory to all district magistrates, especially districts bordering Haryana where advent of locust swarms was reported.

Bijnor DM Ramakant Pandey said, “We have sounded alert among all farmers, revenue staff and village heads about potential invasion of locust swarms here. Locusts have been wreaking havoc in Punjab, Gujarat, Rajasthan and now Haryana too, which borders west UP.”

“Spring season has begun which is conducive to locusts for breeding and reproduction. Locusts thrive and flourish in loam soil. Farmers should regularly plough such type of farmland. If villagers spot swarms of locusts, they should immediately inform the administration, so that appropriate steps could be taken,” Pandey said.

Deputy director, agriculture, JP Chaudhary said, “Farmers can scare away locusts by beating the drum. Besides, they can take chlorpyrifos 20% EC insecticide from us and spray it on their crop. Grasshopper swarms can cause an epidemic if farmers show negligence and do not take measures at earliest. Locusts subsist on green leaves and are able to destroy crops very fast, particularly potato, wheat, mustard and sugarcane crops. In Punjab, fire brigade was used to curb locusts. We can also apply that method here.”

More than 1.68 lakh hectares of farmland in the country has been affected by locusts with Rajasthan and Gujarat taking the worst hit. Union agriculture minister Narendra Singh Tomar had recently told Rajya Sabha that 88% of total 1,68,548 hectares of affected farmland witnessed severe crop loss of more than 33%.

Title: Protection of temple jewels, ornaments: HC seeks response
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Madurai: Madras high court has sought a counter from the state government on a petition seeking to safeguard the ornaments of Adikesava Perumal temple in Kanyakumari district. In his petition, N Thangappan, the president of Sree Adikesava Seva Trust, stated that the temple situated at Thiruvattar is one of the 108 divya desams. Though it is under the control of HR & CE department since 1960, no proper records have been maintained by the officials about the jewels and ornaments of the deities.

Due to this, the temple employees including archakars started to loot the ornaments. After the people staged a protest and submitted complaints repeatedly in 1992, CB-CID officials from Tirunelveli conducted an inquiry and subsequently several people including three archakars were convicted. He stated that though archakars of the temple were convicted for looting the ornaments of the temple, their successors are still allowed to perform pujas at the temple.

It was in this context that the petitioner moved the HC Madurai bench seeking to publish the list of ornaments and also display them to the public by adorning the deities with them. He further sought to remove such archakars whose family have bad antecedents from the temple. To this, a division bench of Justice M Duraiswamy and Justice T Ravindran directed the state government to file a counter and adjourned the case to a further date for hearing.

Title: Plastic industry is expanding rapidly: Experts
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Hyderabad: The plastic industry in the state is expanding, say experts who feel the region is well on the way to developing into a plastic manufacturing hub. Industries secretary Jayesh Ranjan said, “We have a 1,500-unit strong industry, located in and around the city.”

Vimalesh Gupta, president, Telangana and Andhra Pradesh Plastic Manufacturer’s association, said that in the past five years, an equal number of new units have been established in Telangana. Both said the figures are conservative estimates as the unorganised sector is largely unmapped. Ranjan said several big players are setting up shop in the state at the proposed plastic park. Addressing the issue of single-use plastics, Ranjan said though 60-65% of plastics produced are the single-use variety, he said efforts were being made to phase out their production.

Gupta said, “Rs 1,500 crore investment has been made in single-use plastic sector in five years. The average turnover from single-use plastics Rs 40-45 crore per day.” While Kattedan sill remains a hub for plastics, Gupta said newer areas were emerging such as Chandrayangutta and the area around Zoo park. tnn

Title: Ganja peddler arrested from Thampanoor bus station
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Illustration used for representational purpose.

THIRUVANANTHAPURAM: The excise special squad here on Sunday arrested a habitual offender with over 1kg of ganja . The officials identified the accused as Ayyappan (32) a resident of Bismi Nagar near Karamana.

He was booked under section 20 (b) (ii) (B) of Narcotic Drugs and Psychotropic Substances (NDPS) Act.

The excise special squad officials said that the accused was held from KSRTC Terminal at Thampanoor , where he regularly sold ganja. He was held when he arrived here to hand over ganja to a customer. The catch was made by a team led by excise special squad inspector T R Mukeshkumar.

According to Mukeshkumar, Ayyappan was a habitual offender involved in numerous crimes in the past. He was mostly involved in pickpocketing and chain snatching cases. His modus was to purchase large quantities of ganja from Madhurai in Tamil Nadu and sell it here in small packets. The squad had been monitoring his activities for the past one week.

Title: Single-use plastic sector growing in Hyderabad despite rising ecological concerns
Content:
Representative image

HYDERABAD: Several businessmen are making a foray into the single-use plastic (SUP) sector in the state, in spite of rising environmental concerns. They say, their interest is fuelled by the demand, but also because there is no genuine alternative to it.While there is a ban on manufacturing products below 50 microns, there is no ban on production of single-use plastic above that grade.Experts said the talk of further restrictions on sale is leading to greater growth in the unorganised space. The sector is thriving with large number of unregistered units being set up.A single unit can be set up at a cost of few lakh rupees. The cost of setting up a unit can run from Rs 3-4 lakh to crores, said Vimalesh Gupta, president, Telangana and Andhra Pradesh plastic Manufacturer’s association.Thota Sripadh, who launched a throw-away glasses factory in Warangal in 2015, said: “The alternative proposed for plastic glasses is paper cups, but no one takes into account how many trees and the amount of water needed for these.” Plastic is completely recyclable when its above specified thickness. He says he took a Rs 1.5 crore loan to float his unit.Sudhakar M, who set up Radha Ramana Polymers, in RR district with an investment of Rs 10 crore. The company produces thin-walled containers used for food packaging. Asked why he decided to foray into this industry when there is growing sentiment against plastics, he says, “Only late last year did the Prime Minister speak about the ban, by that time I had already established my unit.”A city-based manufacturer, who has invested a Rs 200 crore in the past two years, but preferred anonymity, rubbished the talk about reducing use of plastic. He said genuine manufacturers are being targeted. “Why not impose restrictions on packaging of food items? Can that be done? And why not ban IT in the state? The carbon footprint of this industry has not even been calculated.”He said “demonisation of plastics will kill jobs and recycling industry”. He put the figure of jobs provided by the sector at 40,000-50,000, and said over a lakh ragpickers indirectly make a living through the plastic industry.Arguing in favour for plastics, Anil Reddy Vennam, V-P, South All India Plastic Manufacturers Association said, “Plastics can easily be recycled for multiple-uses including to create roads, tiles, clothes among other items. We have made a representation to the government regarding the uses that the material can be out to.”

Title: Bihar gang may be behind baby’s theft at LLRM College
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Meerut: Nearly a week after a newborn was stolen from Lala Lajpat Rai Memorial Medical (LLRM) College here, police are yet to trace the woman who was seen allegedly fleeing with the baby boy by his father.

Police have set up several teams to crack the case and various angles are being probed. Sources say a Bihar gang may be behind kidnapping the baby.

Akhilesh Singh, Meerut SP city, said, “We have got inputs from reliable sources that the accused might be a part of a Bihar-based gang. However, we are yet to confirm these facts and are investigating all angles.”

Earllier, TOI had reported how a newborn boy was stolen allegedly by a woman in her forties from LLRM College on February 3. The baby’s family mistook the woman as hospital staff when she started helping them. She allegedly stole the baby by asking his father to dispose of a diaper. As soon as the man went near the dustbin, the woman fled with the baby. He tried to chase her but she melted into the crowd.

The baby was stolen from outside the nursery. However, the CCTV cameras were not working near the spot. It was only after hospital authorities checked other cameras in the vicinity that the woman could be spotted.

“We have set up different police teams and have also pasted pamphlets with the picture of the woman at different spots. Efforts are being made to arrest the accused at the earliest,” said Kulveer Singh, station house officer, Medical College police station. An FIR has also been filed in the matter.

The patient, Sumaiya, was admitted to LLRM Medical College when she went into labour. She had a caesarean section and delivered a baby boy on February 3 afternoon. The baby was kept in the nursery for observation for two hours. During this time, a mysterious woman struck up a conversation with Sumaiya’s husband, Asif. She helped him as men were not allowed in the ward where his wife was admitted. Later, she accompanied him to the nursery when he went to take the baby. The woman then volunteered to change the baby’s diaper and asked Asif to throw away the used one in the dustbin. According to the inquiry, it has been found that in the few seconds that he turned away to throw the waste in the bin, the woman fled with the baby. He even tried to follow her but failed.

Title: NU PG law dept merger with its law college sparks row
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Nagpur: The Nagpur University (NU) plans to merge its postgraduate department of law with its Babasaheb Ambedkar College of Law has courted a major controversy.

Vice-chancellor SP Kane has made a U-turn after issuing directives in September last year and forming a committee led by himself and college principal Shrikant Komawar as member-secretary following objections from a section of NU as well as former statutory bodies.

While the committee members are viewing the move as beneficial for students, the opponents have expressed concern over loss of jobs to teachers at the PG department and disturbance to the roster. The formation of committee and the directives too have come under scanner.

The opponents have called the committee and the Direction 40 of 2019 as “illegal” and “arbitrary”.

VC Kane didn’t respond to TOI’s calls. Acting pro-VC Vinayak Deshpande said no decision has been taken so far regarding merger issue. “A committee under my chairmanship is constituted to study the issue. We will be seeking opinion of stakeholders, social thinkers, etc. It is a proposal. Legal issues if any will also be taken into account,” he said.

In September last year, the committee ‘RTMNU Dr Babasaheb Ambedkar College of Law Management Committee for Management and Maintenance of the College’ was formed. Besides Kane and Komawar, the committee comprises two management council members, a retired judge of SC or HC within NU jurisdiction, a senior advocate, one full-time teacher of the college, joint director and internal quality cell officer.

Among the key functions of the committee is to suggest amalgamation take over or merger of the college with any other postgraduate teaching department of the university to create a new teaching and research institution with new suitable names. Also, it has been mandated to prepare an overall comprehensive plan for the growth and development of the college, covering infrastructure, and academic programmes.

Former management council member Mahendra Nimbarte said the university has no powers to form such a committee as per the Maharashtra Public Universities Act, 2016. “It is an illegal committee. Every one was kept in the dark. If this merger happens, then teachers will lose jobs while the roster will get disturbed. When we spoke to the VC, he denied having any knowledge of the direction. It suggests he signed it without reading or maybe he was misled,” Nimbarte said.

Title: BJP wants temple officer suspended
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Madurai: The BJP has demanded the suspension of the executive officer of the Thanjavur Peruvudaiyar temple, for allegedly acting against rules and permitting Naam Tamilar Katchi leader Seeman and Muslims in to the temple. Speaking to reporters in Madurai on Sunday, BJP National Secretary H Raja said DMK and its allies were trying to create unrest in Tamil Nadu in the name of religion. “Will these parties which are demanding that rituals be performed in Tamil in temples also demand that it be followed in mosques, instead of Arabic?” he said.

He said that the protest in Neyveli was held because filming had been banned there following an accident that occurred previously at the site during the shooting of another movie. “The protest was not against the actor, but filming in a sensitive region,” he said.Raja added that the Tamil Nadu BJP chief would be appointed soon and that the BJP was not a party which went back on its promises. He also condemned the attack on Theni MP P Ravindranath Kumar for his pro-CAA stand. He said that the exit polls should not to be taken seriously.tnn

Title: Reduction in use only way ahead: Greens
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Hyderabad: Though the industry is batting for single-use plastic, environmentalists feel that reduction of plastic use and consumption is the only way ahead.

“The restrictions put on sale of plastic below 50 microns is not enough. Users can’t judge how thick their bags are. The government should at least have a colour code to help distinguish between different grades of plastic,” said Subba Rao, green activist.

Environmentalist Kajal Maheswari said, “While we can go on debating whether paper cups are better or plastic ones, one needs to understand that the solution lies in reduce of consumption.”

Title: Giving third genders’ lives a glam makeover
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Dishit Rajput (L) training the others

VADODARA: It’s her daily morning routine — get up at dawn and get ready to visit residential colonies in Gotri with her group seeking alms — a ritual that Aradhyaa, a eunuch , has been doing for years now. But that’s about to change. Aradhyaa will soon see a new dawn in her life after she completes her beautician course and starts her own business. All that she now begs from life is to give her the strength to fulfil her dream.

Thanks to 30-year-old Dishit Rajput, a transgender, many more like Aradhyaa will soon see a sea change in their ‘socially excluded’ lives. Rajput’s mission is to take these eunuchs off the street and give them a chance to eke a decent living.

Rajput, who has done diploma in fine arts from Vidyanagar, told TOI, “Since childhood, I have seen eunuchs begging for alms to survive. With ‘them’ being ‘unacceptable’ in society, I wanted to usher in a change in societal perception by including eunuchs in mainstream society. And what can be a better way than to train them with skills that will help them earn self-respect and money too?” After pursuing a beauticians course about 19 years ago, Rajput today runs two salons – one in Wadi and the other in Waghodia — where he employees 45 women.

He has decided to enrol people from the third gender in beautician’s course, teaching them basic skills in facial, manicure, pedicure and applying mehendi — sans payment of any fees or other charges!

He will impart the training at his new parlour in Waghodia. “With some hard work and focus, they will soon pick up the skills and start their own business,” he said. He has already received inquiries from 25 transgenders and 10 have already begun their training in the course which has been kept completely professional, replete with identity cards and parlour rules.

An ebullient Aradhyaa exuded: “I am very excited to learn the new skills and to change my life forever. I am sure people will support me.”

Title: After 7 yrs, Dalits take out yatra on Ravidas Jayanti
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Bijnor: Following threats of conversion by hundreds of Dalit residents of Shyamiwala village in UP's Bijnor district, local administration conceded to their demand for taking out a procession on the occasion of Ravidas Jayanti on Sunday. The procession was stopped by the district administration in 2013 after people of the minority community, who account for 70% population of the village, objected to it.

The ‘shobha yatra’ in honour of Sant Ravidas was taken out on Sunday afternoon amid tight security at Shyamiwala village, 40 km from the district headquarters. Later, cultural programmes depicting Sant Ravidas were held.

Before permitting the procession, police held a meeting with villagers and warned against attempts to disrupt peace. Before the ‘shobha yatra’, police personnel also took out a march through the route to be taken by the procession. Drones were deployed to keep an aerial vigil over the procession.

Lakshmi Nivas Mishra, city’s superintendent of police, said, “We held several meetings with villagers here. The procession was taken out unanimously. Two platoons of PAC and over 150 police constables, sub inspectors were deployed there. Villagers maintained peace.”

Title: In a first, IIT Hyderabad students can take up six-month internship
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

IIT Hyderabad

HYDERABAD: For the first time in the history of Indian Institutes of Technology (IITs), IIT Hyderabad has decided to allow its students to take up a six-month internship beginning from the academic year 2020-21.

Director of IIT-H, BS Murthy, said that the proposal was passed by the senate, which comprises of all heads of the departments and senior faculty members of the institute, recently. He said it will be implemented from August 2020. Until now, students are allowed to do only summer internship in IITs.

“Time and again students have complained that the summer internship is not just enough for them to get industry exposure. So, we have decided to allow them to take up a six-month-long internship,” said Murthy. He said that an option to opt for the internship will be given during the sixth semester to interested students.

The IIT-H director said they are also mulling awarding six or seven credits to internships and the remaining credits of the sixth semester will be adjusted in remaining semesters.

He said they are planning to give a one-year sabbatical to students who want to pursue their ideas in the near future. He said that the proposal is yet to be placed before the senate. “The one-year sabbatical will most likely be offered to second year BTech students. Initially, we will ask them to pursue their idea on the campus and funds will be allotted, if needed, by the institute. Subsequently, based on merit, we will allow students to take a sabbatical,” told Murthy to TOI.

Title: ‘Pak-made’ fake Rs 2,000 notes with face value of Rs 24 lakh seized
Content: MUMBAI: A man who arrived on a flight from Dubai on Sunday morning was arrested for carrying fake Rs 2,000 notes with a face value of almost Rs 24 lakh. The notes were of high quality, incorporating seven of nine security features.The accused told the police that they were printed in Pakistan and sent to Dubai, with India intended as the final destination. The denomination, when issued in 2016, was touted as highly se cure, but RBI said in October that no Rs 2,000 note was printed in 2019 as NIA had found high-quality fakes.The passenger, Javed Shaikh (36), a Kalwa resident, had been to Dubai and Bangkok in the past and may have brought in many such consignments. Police are questioning him about who the present consignment was meant for.“An average person will not be able to identify the fake notes. Shaikh walked away at the airport’s security check. He was caught at the bus stop outside the international terminal,” said joint commissioner of police (crime) Santosh Rastogi, who did not rule out a terror link. He said Shaikh was caught because of a CIA tipoff.“The counterfeit currency was smartly stuffed in one of his trolley bags. The notes were scattered inside a cushion, which was stuffed into a gap between the bag’s wall and a cloth liner. It took us over an hour to locate the money,” Rastogi said.“A scanner identifies notes if they are kept in bundles. It’s the edges of the bundles that get detected. As opposed to this, Shaikh was carrying the notes in a scattered format, making machine detection difficult,” Rastogi said.On the quality of the notes, a crime branch officer said that the two security features that weren’t copied properly were ‘optically variable ink’ (ink that changes colour with changing angles) and ‘see-through register’ (hidden features that are seen only if a note is held against light).In Video: Mumbai: ‘Pak-made’ fake notes with face value of Rs 24 lakh seized

Title: 7,394 cases settled in Ytl National Lok Adalat
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Yavatmal: The National Lok Adalat, organized on the directives of Supreme Court and high court, evoked good response with 7 ,394 cases getting settled here on Saturday. The cases. involving over Rs12.54 crore, have been settled with mutual understanding.

The adalat was organized under the banner of District Free Legal Services Cell under the guidance of chief district and sessions judge Kishor R Petkar.

There were 1,287 long pending and 6,107 pre-litigation cases for consideration of the judging panels in various courts. The cases related to various departments such as revenue, Bembla irrigation project compensation, cooperative and nationalized banks, MSRTC, MSEDCL LIC and several others were put up during the adalat.

Talking to TOI here, secretary of the District Free Legal Services Cell Justice MRA Sheikh said the lok adalat is helpful for litigants as it saves their time and money. This activity has also enabled the judiciary to minimize its burden of pending cases, he added.

Bar Association president Jitendra Baradkar, lawyers, district administration, police department, concerned agencies and judges apart from employees of the courts cooperated with the cell to arrange the camps, said Justice Petkar.

Title: All UP jails to have radio station by 2021, says DG (prison)
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Meerut: The UP director general (prison administration and reform services), Anand Kumar, recently inaugurated an in-house radio station in Meerut district jail, making it the 26th of 70 jails in UP to be equipped with a fully functional radio station operated by jail inmates. Senior departmental officials claimed all 70 jails in the state will have similar radio stations by end-2021.

Apart from playing songs on request, the radio jockey also reads out information on legal and human rights help for inmates. Announcements related to court hearings of individual inmates and other recreational activities inside prison are also made on radio.

“Lots of inmates suffer from depression. We thought to have something that will provide some entertainment which can help them fight depression to some extent. We’re involving inmates to run the station,” DG (prison) Kumar said.

Unlike normal radio stations, which work on a particular frequency, customised public address systems are used in jails. A room is allotted for the radio jockey and the station, which includes relay and amplifiers. Speakers are mounted in every barrack. Inmates can put in written requests for songs, which the radio jockey plays after announcing the name of the inmate who made the request.

“We’ll also organize lectures on legal and human rights, and provide interface with experts who could suggest legal remedies. In some jails, we have roped in help of professional radio jockeys, who have come to jail and imparted training to interested inmates to sharpen their skills,” added Kumar.

Title: Kolkata Temperature: Chill to stay a few more days in Kolkata
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Met officials have ruled out the possibility of rain as of now, saying the mercury will plunge further by anot... Read More

KOLKATA: With the sun emerging out from the cloud cover , the mercury went down a notch below the normal mark on Sunday. Met officials have ruled out the possibility of rain as of now, saying the mercury will plunge further by another two or three degrees by Monday.

The cloud cover, drizzle and light rain in some places in the past few days dragged the day temperature down while pushing up the minimum temperature. The minimum temperature had shot above 17°C on Saturday. It receded to 15.6°C on Sunday, which was one degree below the normal mark.

“The chill-bearing north- westerly wind has started breezing in. The mercury will fall further on Monday. At present, there is no major weather system that will disrupt the path of the northwesterly . Hence, the chill will persist for the next few days,” said GK Das, director (weather) at Regional Meteorological Centre Kolkata .

Two cyclonic circulations — one over Bihar and the other over Vidarbha — had brought the hope for rain on Friday and Saturday. But the city was spared of downpour, though the sky remained overcast. According to Met officials, the clouds that reached the city sky were of medium height and the absence of convection caused little rain. “For now there is no weather system that can bring rain in the city,” said Das.

With the dry and cold northwesterly reaching the city from Sunday evening onwards, the mercury could touch down the 13°C mark by Monday and go slightly further by about a degree on Tuesday.

Title: Niti Aayog bats for local batteries
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Hyderabad: Urging electric vehicle manufacturers to stop importing batteries from China, Niti Aayog member VK Saraswat on Sunday advised startups in the e-mobility sector to come together and build them indigenously. Speaking at the launch of ‘EPluto 7G’, an electric scooter manufactured by PURE EV, an IIT-H incubated start-up, Saraswat said the Niti Aayog was planning to set up gigawatt tower factories where companies could make batteries indigenously. tnn

Title: Speeding cases saw a rise in 2019, reveals data
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Madurai: Speeding cases saw a rise in 2019, a recent data released by Madurai police has revealed. The city police registered as many as 8429 cases for speeding in 2019 and collected a whopping Rs 30,63,900 from the violators.

Police officials said that they strictly monitored various traffic violations and speeding was one of the common ones. Based on instructions from the city police commissioner S Davidson Devasirvatham, traffic police as well as cops in charge of law and order have been keeping a tight vigil against youths involved in speeding, since it is a major cause of accidents.

A police officer said that ever since equipment for issuing spot fine was provided the number of cases booked for all kinds of traffic violations have increased. Stringent implementation of traffic rules will has also help curb road accidents, which is visible in the reduction of number of road accident deaths. Compared to 217 deaths in 2018, there were only 183 deaths in 2019.

Boards displaying speed limits has been installed in most of the city roads to caution commuters. Earlier, only a few roads had such boards. Speeding and not wearing helmet contribute to most of the road deaths in the city.

Title: Rail, road, metro: RRTS station to connect three modes at Delhi's Anand Vihar
Content:
A new addition to the hub is going to be the underground Anand Vihar station of the 82-km long Delhi-Meerut RR... Read More

NEW DELHI: Anand Vihar in east Delhi is one of the city’s biggest transport hubs with the presence of a railway station, two Delhi Metro corridors and two inter-state bus terminals on either side of the Delhi-Uttar Pradesh border. A new addition to the hub is going to be the underground Anand Vihar station of the 82-km long Delhi-Meerut Regional Rapid Transit System (RRTS) corridor, which will also seamlessly integrate these different modes of transport.The National Capital Region Transport Corporation (NCRTC), which is building India’s first RRTS corridor, said a key aspect of the planning was the integration of its stations with other modes of transport such as metro train network, bus terminals, airports and Indian Railways through walkways, lifts, escalators, foot bridges and underpasses.An NCRTC spokesperson said, “Anand Vihar is one of the busiest public spaces linked by several modes of public transport. Lakhs of people, among them senior citizens and children, use these transport modes daily, often with heavy luggage. The lack of adequate integration leads to unsafe road crossing and numerous level changes, making the journey unsafe, time consuming and inconvenient, and ultimately forces people to shift to private vehicles.”Of the 22 RRTS stations on the Delhi-Meerut corridor, four are underground, with just the Anand Vihar station among the four in the Delhi stretch of the corridor. The underground station will have some unique features, according to NCRTC. “Only one level will be below the ground,” the spokesperson disclosed. “The platform will be underground but the concourse will be at the ground level.”He pointed out that a typical underground Delhi Metro station was constructed two levels under the ground, with the platform usually located at a depth of 20 metres. In the case of Anand Vihar RRTS station, however, the station will be located just eight metres below ground, and the cut-and-cover method will be employed to construct it.“The construction of this station will be technologically complex as RRTS trains will pass underneath the Delhi metro Blue Line (Dwarka-Vaishali),” the spokesperson said. But he also said that the station design would allow safe, convenient and faster movement of commuters from Anand Vihar RRTS station to the public transport modes and vice-versa. The spokesperson claimed, “Such a design is not only commuter-centric, but will significantly reduce the construction cost of the station.”The idea is that the station design will allow commuters to avoid having to step on the roads while moving from one mode of transport to another. This will be a comparatively safer, more comfortable and hassle-free travel experience for commuters.The spokesperson also said, “Around 11.5 km of the Delhi-Meerut corridor will be underground, of which 5.8 km from the elevated New Ashok Nagar RRTS station to BEL, Ghaziabad, will be in Delhi,” he said. NCRTC has floated the tender for the design and excavation of underground passages by tunnel boring machines in the Delhi segment.

Title: Coronavirus in Hyderabad: Two new suspect cases in Hyderabad
Content:
Representative image

HYDERABAD: Two new suspected cases of Novel Coronavirus (2019-nCoV) were reported at the state-run Gandhi hospital on Sunday. The nine other suspected cases, which were reported on Saturday, have tested negative for the dreaded virus. Both persons had recently returned from China.With the latest set of reports, a total of 70 people so far have tested negative for the virus.
