These people, who were previously suspected to be infected, are still being monitored closely by state health authorities, and will remain in home isolation for 14 days.Apart from these 70, another 72 people have been kept in quarantine at home, and are being monitored. They have, however, not been tested for the virus so far, as they had not shown any symptoms such as fever, cough, cold or breathing problem, which are associated with the disease.“All of the suspected cases continue to be under observation of the health department. Teams from the Integrated Disease Surveillance Programme are monitoring them each day and ensuring that they remain in quarantine till 28 days,” said Vijay Kumar, state nodal officer for Corona.

Title: No route charts, seats in bus shelters mainteined by agencies
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Trichy: The private agencies that were entrusted with the task of maintaining the bus shelters in the city by the Trichy City Corporation are turning a blind eye towards the upkeep and the needs of the bus passengers.

Across the 65 wards of the city corporation, there are more than 200 bus shelters. Besides those, few other bus stops were built and maintained by the MLA constituency development fund. Of which 167 shelters have been handed over to private advertisement agencies for maintenance.

In return, the agencies were given the rights to display advertisement hoardings in the bus shelters for a price. While some of the bus shelters are maintained well, the bus stops near schools continues to be in bad shape.

The Cantonment and Palakkarai localities, home to private offices, banks and schools are deprived of a proper bus shelter . While advertisement hoardings atop the bus shelters are brightly illuminated, the seats of the shelters are either broken or missing. Route charts of city buses are also absent. “Newcomers to the city are not aware of the bus stop names. The civic body should ideally name the bus stops for the convenience of passengers,” S R Kishore Kumar, advocate wing, Makkal Needhi Maiam, said.

As the advertisement agencies focus only on the illuminating the hoardings, which brings them revenue, they ignore providing other basic amenities.

Some of the bus shelters in Palakkarai and Williams Road have broken steel chairs, forcing passengers, mostly school students, to stand outside. The bus shelter at Melapudur lacks both the stone bench and steel chairs.

“We will strictly insist the advertisement agencies to provide seating arrangements or we will cancel the agreement with them,” a corporation official said.

Title: Sewage continues to flow into Vaigai despite wall: NGO
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Madurai: Despite assurance from the city corporation to block the sewage flow into river Vaigai by constructing a wall along the bank, an NGO found the river still being polluted by the effluent from the same source in a field survey on Sunday.

M Rajan, co-ordinator, NGO Vaigai Nathi Makkal Iyakkam, said that 20 members of his team conducted a study on the riverbed from Vilangudi to Viraganoor along the riverbed and found sewage flowing into the river. “We saw the sewage discharged via large pipes running through the newly constructed walls at Aruldosspuram and near the Thiagarajar Arts college,’’ he said.

The NGO said that it saw sewage flow into river in six places, after it was discharged from Government Rajaji Hospital. It kept flowing into the river. “They now claim to have stopped it. However, the hospital has no treatment plant, and the site where the effluence was earlier found is now dug up. You can still see water and sewage there. We suspect the sewage is being discharged through an underground pipe,” said Rajan. He said the discharge of sewage into the river will remain unresolved without a proper action plan. They have decided to submit a report on their Sunday’s finding to the Madurai District Collector T G Vinay on Monday.

A committee appointed by the Madras high court had also confirmed that sewage was indeed being discharged into the river. Meanwhile, Madurai corporation has started work on the Sewage Treatment Plant at Alwarpuram, which is expected to solve the problem completely.

Title: Happy Barodians turn the road into a stage
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Vadodara: Sundays have become truly ‘sunshinedays’ in Sanskarinagari — with eager Barodians assembling at the crack of dawn on the Sayajibaug Road to either showcase their talent or explore hidden possibilities.

A street play was enacted this Sunday explaining the benefits of solar rays and conserving energy while en-rapt audience cheered on. It was an energetic beginning to the Happy Streets organized by The Times of India as citizens turned up in large numbers.

While some jived to Zumba and Bokwa beats, kids rode bicycles, skated and played badminton. Amid all these, another group took to performing Bhavai.

Some boxed and some clicked selfies, while a few women learnt self defence techniques. Joint police commissioner K G Bhaati, who visited Happy Streets, appreciated the initiative and even advised the citizens to follow traffic rules.

Title: Pay-parking in parts of Panaji from February 15, likely to be round-the-clock
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Representative image

PANAJI: Pay-parking for two- and four-wheelers along nine stretches in the state capital is expected to commence on Saturday and is likely to be implemented 24x7, including on Sundays and public holidays.

Signage displaying parking rates per hour have already been erected around the city, including on 18th June Road, around the Church Square, around Garcia de Orta, around the old secretariat and in the Campal residential area.

The public will be issued computerised receipts that will mention the date, time and number of their vehicle. “There will be no manual ticketing. This way, we have a proper accounting system in place from Day 1,” the contractor , Sohan Juwarker, told TOI. He also said he has handed over Rs 1 crore to the Corporation of the City of Panaji (CCP) towards a bank guarantee and security deposit for the three-year pay-parking contract.

While the agreement between the CCP and the contractor is yet to be signed, the corporation is confident it can roll out pay-parking in Panaji on February 15. “The terms of the agreement stipulate that the contractor will implement pay-parking on February 15. We will sign the agreement at the beginning of this week,” mayor Uday Madkaikar told TOI.

Fifty workers have been engaged in collecting pay-parking fees . Police verification of their antecedents is under way.

Discounted monthly and yearly passes will be issued to those interested, including shop owners. “We have fixed the rate for monthly passes at Rs 150 for two-wheelers. The rate for four-wheelers will be decided in the next few days,” Juwarker said, adding that an app is being developed to make the pass system paperless.

Once charged, parking fees will be considered valid for any other parking location within CCP’s jurisdiction for that time slot. Government vehicles will be exempted from paying for parking.

Title: Hyderabad: New speed guns can generate instant challan
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

A newly installed speed meter with cameras at Tank Bund to identify motorists who are overspeeding

HYDERABAD: After a recent analysis revealed 21 persons were killed due to over speeding, the city traffic police acquired six high-end speed guns to add to the five existing ones.

Police said the high-end laser speed guns are also capable of generating an e-challan on the spot. “We are going to use these speed guns in black spots or places that have wide roads to keep a check on people who are over speeding,” said additional commissioner (traffic) Anil Kumar.

Meanwhile, Cyberabad Traffic Police caught as many as 273 persons between February 7 and February 9 during drunk and drive checks.

Title: 3 city colleges qualify for south India football
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Trichy: Three city colleges have qualified for the quarterfinals of 7th South India level inter-collegiate football tournament also called Jamal Mohamed trophy that commenced here on Sunday.

The three-day-long knockout tournament is scheduled to be held at the Jamal Mohamed college ground till February 11, 2020. Participated by a total of 12 arts and science college football teams from Tamil Nadu and Kerala, qualifier round was held on the inaugural day.

Four colleges including three city-based colleges namely St Joseph’s College, National College, Bishop Heber College and HH The Rajah’s College from Pudukkottai qualified for the quarterfinals by beating the football teams from Thanjavur, Kariakudi, Tiruchendur and Ramanathapuram.

The four teams will face four other college teams including Loyola College, Chennai, Jamal Mohamed College, Trichy, PSG College, Coimbatore and MES College, Kerala that has already qualified for the quarterfinals round on bye. TNN

Title: Sambar deer falls into well, rescued after 2 hours
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Trichy: A four-year-old male sambar deer that fell into a 16 foot-deep well near Manikandam of Pudukottai district was rescued on Saturday.

The rescue operation, which lasted for over a couple of hours, left a couple of forest department personnel injured. However, the animal was captured and safely released into Pachamalai reserve forest.

The incident happened on Saturday morning. The locals alerted forest department about a sambar deer falling into an open well in an agriculture farm behind the office of block development officer in Manikandam.

The forest department team along with volunteers reached the spot and pulled the deer out of the well using ropes. After the deer was rescued from the well, it ran into a nearby canal and was taken out of the canal after a brief rescue effort.

Trichy forest range officer, R Gunasekaran, who was leading the rescue team, said that it was a tedious task as the deer was weighed over 200 kg. “We decided to release the deer in Pachamalai forest,” said Gunasekaran. “Usually success rate of rescue mission is very low in case of spotted deer as these are very timid and often die out of shock during rescue. However, sambar deer are ferocious like bulls. Once we covered its eyes, it was quiet and we could translocate it to Pachamalai hill,” said honorary district animal welfare officer, G Ramakrishnan from animal welfare board of India (AWBI), who was part of the rescue.

There were not many sambar deer recorded in the recent time in Manikandam area. Besides, Thuvarankurichi reserve forest is the nearest forest to Manikandam at about 40 km.

While the forest officials, too, were puzzled over its appearance in Manikandam, range officer said that it could have travelled from Pudukottai or Sivagangai forest and entered Thuavarankurichi forest.

Title: Forest dept for relocation policy to deal with man-animal conflict
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Panaji: Speedy compensation, tiger conservation awareness and efforts to formulate a relocation policy for people living near forest areas, are some of the measures the state forest department is going to adopt to deal with the man-animal conflict in Goa.

“There is a Dhangar community residing in the areas where the tigers frequent, and they only own cattle for their livelihood. So obviously they will attract tigers. We need to develop a relocation policy so that the people benefit more by coming to the town area,” state’s chief wildlife warden, Santosh Kumar said.

“The compensation process is also being sped up so that they receive the money within two to three days. Thirdly, we have to sensitise people about tiger conservation,” he said.

The forest official further informed that the tiger nails that were found have been sent to forensic labs outside Goa. “The matter will go to court after we file a chargesheet based on the reports we receive,” Kumar said.

Following the death of four tigers in Goa within a span of less than a week, the department is maintaining round the clock vigilance.

“We’re monitoring the situation and trying to work with people so that we can minimise the man-animal conflict as well as attacks on cattle,” said principal chief conservator of forests, Subhash Chandra.

Title: 2 Tangedco staff arrested for taking bribe in Ariyalur
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Trichy: Directorate of vigilance and anti-corruption (DVAC) in Ariyalur nabbed two employees of Tamil Nadu Generation and Distribution Corporation ( Tangedco ) for demanding and accepting bribe for obtaining electricity connection on Saturday night.

Sources said that a farmer, identified as Dharmalingam of Karkudi in Ariyalur, approached the Tangedco office in Suthamalli seeking electricity connection to operate a borewell in his agriculture field.

Though the farmer paid a sum of Rs 2.45 lakh to Tangedco, two employees of Tangedco, identified as one assistant engineer Rajiv Gandhi and a foreman Sarvanan with Suthamalli Tangedco substation, sought Rs 10,000 as bribe to facilitate the electricity connection.

Unwilling to pay the bribe, the farmer Dharmalingam approached DVAC Ariyalur and registered a complaint. As per the directives of DVAC, the farmer on Saturday night handed out a few chemically laced currencies to the two Tangedco employees. Subsequently, the duo was caught red-handed by the DVAC sleuths. The accused employees were remanded under judicial custody on Sunday.

Title: Cannot afford to lose coal block again: CM
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Panaji: While admitting that Goa lacks the fiscal space to pay the performance guarantee for the Dongeri Tal-II coal block in Madhya Pradesh, chief minister Pramod Sawant told Goa Industrial Development Corporation (GIDC) that the state cannot afford to lose out on the coal block for a second time.

Sawant asked GIDC to explore “various options” to raise the funds required to develop and mine the coal block. GIDC now plans to either take a loan or ask the mine developer operator (MDO) to make the payments on behalf ofGoa. “As far as performance security and other financial commitments are concerned, GIDC may explore various options. In any case, GIDC cannot afford to lose the coal block allocation,” Sawant wrote in his file notings.

Goa is running out of time to pay the performance guarantee for the coal block, with Coal India limited (CIL) serving an ultimatum to GIDC to make the necessary payments within the next three months. “One thing is certain, if we delay again, they will cancel the allotment ,” industries minister Vishwajit Rane said.

According to the industries department, the capital cost to develop the coal mine is Rs 500 crore while Rs 196.5 crore has to be paid upfront as performance security.

GIDC sought the funds from the finance department which rejected the proposal due to lack of funds. “There is no fiscal space available under State Guarantee Act to provide performance guarantee. Grant of guarantee of Rs 196.5 crore is a potential risk adding to our liabilities,” the finance department said.

The allotment of Dongeri Tal-II coal block is for the purpose of sale of coal and not for power generation and GIDC could stand to benefit from the revenues generated from the coal block.

GIDC has already received the mine plan and mine closure plan. The environment clearance (EC) for open cast, mining lease and consent to establish have been obtained, but a detailed report on the mine’s potential has yet to be prepared.

“A proposal for appointing monitoring committee to monitor the development of coal block and a screening committee for evaluation of the consultant is under consideration of the government. A consultant and a MDO has to be appointed at the earliest,” Rane said.

Title: Legal eagles guide law, science students
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Justice (retd) Z K Saiyed

Vadodara: Adopting an interdisciplinary approach in education, city-based Parul University (PU) blended science and law streams to provide practical solution to some of the lacunae in the criminal justice system.

University’s applied science faculty organised an expert lecture on the ‘judicial perspective of investigation and evidence’ on Saturday. It was delivered by one of the most notable legal luminaries of the state, justice (retd) Z K Saiyed.

Justice Saiyed, former Gujarat high court judge, shared his insightful perspective on forensic handwriting expertise as well as on the significance of post-mortem and inquest panch-nama, strangulation, among various other topics.

Over 150 law and forensic science students attended the lecture, where Saiyed shared his expertise on various landmark judgments, which he had delivered over time on this subject, along with other concepts pertaining to test and investigation of samples examined by forensic laboratories and cross examinations.

Additionally, a book titled ‘Rule of law and the conscience balance in Ethiopia’ authored by PU’s PhD law student Wolle Abegaz Yesuf was also unveiled by the retired judge and university’s dean of law Dr Akil Saiyed.

The varsity has been engaging with various notable experts within the field of law including justice Ravi Tripathi, justice K A Puj in the past too to help students learn more. “Hosting personalities of such an esteemed stature, who have made vast contributions to our nation’s legal fraternity is of vital importance for us as a university” said PU’s president Dr Devanshu Patel.

Title: Delhi: Nod to expand waste plant at Okhla draws ire of locals
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

The ministry has allowed the plant to increase its generation by 7 MW

NEW DELHI: Going back on its previous directions, the Union ministry of environment and forest (MoEF) has now allowed the Okhla waste-to-energy plant to increase its power generation from 16 MW to 23 MW by amending the environmental clearance the plant had received in 2007.

The latest documents, which have been accessed by TOI, show the environment ministry has allowed the plant to increase its generation by 7 MW “without increasing the municipal solid waste (MSW) intake and without installing any additional equipment.” “..The ministry hereby amends the environmental clearance dated 21.3.2007 and 9.5.2007 for increase in power generation from 16 MW to 23 MW without increasing MSW intake and without installing any additional equipment..” the order states.

Additional conditions have also been imposed on the plant. No further expansion will be permitted beyond the 23 MW power generations capacity at the site, considering its proximity to the Sukhdev Vihar residential colony, which is less than 100 metres away.

Other conditions include online emissions monitoring for all parameters and that the plant should be run in automatic mode to achieve stable operating conditions. “Online emission monitoring equipment for all parameters provided in the guidelines for continuous emission monitoring systems shall be installed and connected to CPCB and DPCC servers,” the order stated.

However, locals say that meeting the increased power demand without increasing the waste intake is not possible, stating the ministry has completely disregarded the report by the expert appraisal committee (EAC). “EAC had stated that the calorific value of the waste is below 1,000 kcal per kg, which is far below requirement. How can the plant now produce more electricity with less waste?” said Vinayak Malik, general secretary, RWA, Sukhdev Vihar. “In its report, EAC also called for expansion only at the operator’s second site at Tehkhand and not at present site because of its close proximity to residential areas. This direction has also been violated.”

In September 2019, the ministry had observed a number of violations at the plant, stating it was not only handling more unsegregated waste per day than approved, but it is also managing the entire process at one location instead of the two allotted to it. The order, dated September 4, had also stated that the plant had increased its capacity to 20 MW against the 16 MW approved, meaning more refuse derived fuel is being processed and at higher emission levels. The order had directed the CPCB to carry out an ecological damage assessment study and to monitor dioxins and furans from the fuel gas once a month.

The environment ministry had also stated that CPCB would decide a compensation amount to be deposited by the project proponent for “restoration of natural resources and pollution control measures”.

Title: West Bengal: Bus kills pillion rider, driver held
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Representative image

KOLKATA: A 45-year-old man riding pillion on a bike along Canal East Road in Narkeldanga was run over by a bus carrying a group of wedding guests on Sunday.

According to the police, Md Nehal, a resident of MN Chatterjee Road, was wearing helmet but it was crushed due to the impact of the accident. Nehal was taken to NRS Medical College and Hospital where he was declared dead on arrival.

Police said the bus had hit the bike from behind. As Nehal fell down, his head was crushed under the wheels of the bus. Though the driver sped away after the accident, cops tracked him later. They arrested the driver and impounded the bus.

Title: Wadettiwar again pushes for lifting of Chanda liquor ban
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Yavatmal: Liquor mafia has thrived in Chandrapur district ever since prohibition was imposed there and even police have failed to curb illicit liquor smuggling as a formidable lobby is at work, said relief and rehabilitation minister Vijay Wadettiwar on Saturday.

The minister was addressing a press conference after visiting two hamlets in Yavatmal district — Bhandari (Nath) dominated by Nathjogi community and Bhamb (Raja) where majority of Wadar community members reside.

“The ban has actually proved counterproductive in Chandrapur as it has led to mafia activities leading to unhealthy competition causing threat to life and property of the people,” said Wadettiwar, hinting at pushing for lifting of the liquor ban from the district.

Commenting on NCP minister Jayant Patil backing the demand for declaring Yavatmal as a dry district, Wadettiwar said if prohibition is imposed, the flow of illicit liquor will increase followed by its sale at exorbitant prices.

Earlier, addressing the residents of the hamlets, Wadettiwar said a new policy for improving the living standard of vimukta bhatkya jamati (nomadic tribes) in the state will be formulated soon. The minister also assured the gathering that the state would solve the housing problem faced by villagers.

“I am aware that the roaming Nathjogi community members are deprived of domicile certificate and hence they are denied benefits of several welfare schemes including Gharkul under which the state has promised to build houses for the marginalized sections,” he said and assured the community of removing this lacuna soon.

Expressing concern over the conditions in which the nomadic tribes are living, Wadettiwar urged them to send their children to school as without education there can never be any progress for the community. He also promised to reserve seats for children from the community in English medium schools.

“Providing roof over heads alone will not improve the living standard,” he said. Youth from both Nathjogi and Wadar communities should be encouraged to go for self employment using new technology, he added.

The minister was accompanied by principal secretary JP Gupta, assistant secretary Gavit, deputy commissioner Vijay Salve, Devanand Pawar, Narayanan Shinde, Jitendra Moghe, Rahul Thakre, Anil Ade, tehsildar Dheeraj Sthul, sarpanch Chandrakala Shinde and others.

Title: Encroachment causes sewage to spill on road in Sastha Street
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Madurai: At least 50 houses in Sastha Street in Pandian Nagar in ward 29 of Madurai corporation have been affected by overflowing sewage water caused by encroachment in the adjacent canal and lack of maintenance. This is not the first time sewage water has entered homes in this area. People say that they have brought the issue to the knowledge of corporation officials but has not been set right.

Syed Ahamed Basha from Yagappa Nagar said although there is underground drainage system in Tahsildar Nagar and Yagappa Nagar, the sewage generated from these areas are not pumped to Sakkimangalam sewage water treatment plant. “Instead, sewage collected from UGD is let into an outlet channel from Vandiyur tank, which joins the Vaigai River. With the channel blocked due to encroachment and lack of maintenance, sewage flowing in it enters into the residential area,” he said.

G Selvam, a resident from Pandian Nagar said that sewage flows over a mud road, hindering vehicular movement in the area.

“Officials should remove encroachments alongside the canal, which chokes movement of water and construct retaining wall so that sewage does not flow into residential area. We have taken the issue to the officials umpteen number times, but it has only fallen into deaf ear. When we approached the assistant engineer last year, he assured of taking up the work after the completion of general election. But, the AE got transferred and our struggle continues,” he said.

With the children and elderly falling sick often, residents strongly believe that health issues are caused by the stagnating sewage water around their houses. Another resident said that they are often mobilizing money themselves to clear the stagnating water using septic tank cleaner vehicles, but it is only a temporary solution, they said. Madurai corporation commissioner S Visakan said he has asked officials to check the issue take appropriate measures.

Title: Leopard numbers down 90% in 120-200 years: Study
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Bengaluru: A recent study revealed the leopard population in India has declined 75% to 90% over the past 120-200 years and blamed human intervention for it.

The findings come at a time when big cats are facing various threats, including road kills, poaching and habitat loss in several parts of the country.

For the study conducted by Bengaluru-based Centre for Wildlife Studies and Dehradun’s Wildlife Institute of India, researchers used genetic data from leopards sampled from across the Indian subcontinent to investigate population structure and patterns of demographic decline. They also checked the demographic history of each identified subpopulation and compared genetic decline analyses with countrywide local extinction probabilities.

Researchers collected faecal samples and identified 56 unique leopards using a panel of 13 microsatellite markers, and merged this data with already available statistics on 143 leopards.

“Coalescent simulations with microsatellite loci revealed a possibly human-induced 75-90% population decline 120-200 years ago across India,” the study concluded.

It revealed four distinct leopard subpopulations corresponding to the Western Ghats, Deccan Plateau (semi-arid), Shivalik and Terai region of the north Indian landscape, with high genetic variation. Scientists deduce these genetic clusters were formed due to restricted gene flow along major habitat-type differences between these biogeographic zones.

The research was conducted by authors Supriya Bhatt, Suvankar Biswas and Bivash Pandav of Wildlife Institute of India, Krithi K Karanth (CWS) and Samrat Mondol (WII) and has been published in the journal Life and Environment.

Krithi Karanth, chief conservation scientist, said the study results are both interesting and alarming. “Using two different methodological approaches, we have established that even one of the most adaptable big cats in India has experienced decline in population structure and distribution,” she noted.

This study team suggested leopards be given similar attention like tigers in India. It also emphasised the importance of similar work on wide-ranging and commonly perceived as locally abundant species as it’s possible that they may show population decline, especially in the context of the anthropocene (current geological age).

Title: Soon, you can buy verified, safe milk from the vendor
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Madurai: Food safety officials are planning to streamline milk vendors in the district, who sell in loose, by bringing them under Verified Milk Vendor scheme, an initiative of the Food Safety and Standards Authority of India (FSSAI). The scheme, which has already been rolled out in Gujarat, is aimed at addressing issues of quality and safety of raw milk supplied directly to customers by unorganised milk vendors.

FSSAI chief executive officer Pawan Kumar Agarwal briefed food safety officials from Tamil Nadu who took part in a meeting in New Delhi recently in this regard and instructed them to start the spade work for implementing it.

The officials said while large milk suppliers have been brought under their fold, the new initiative will help streamline raw milk vendors who have been outside their ambit. Although the number of raw milk vendors has come down ever since packet milk supply began, they are still operating in good numbers. In a city like Madurai, the raw milk suppliers are present in considerable number in the city itself. Many residents rely on such vendors due to the doubts about the quality of packet milk.

Designated officer for food safety in the district, Dr M Somasundaram, told TOI that they will roll out the scheme soon. To start with, they are planning to cover 100 vendors from the city and outskirts. The vendors will be registered with them and given identification cards of the food safety department. They will be constantly monitored, the quality and safety of milk checked periodically using lactometer and samples sent to designated labs.

People can rest assured on the quality of milk purchased from such verified vendors, he said. Reports had emerged recently showing that milk samples tested by the food safety department contained cancer-causing Aflatoxin M1. It is suspected that the carcinogen could have entered the cattle’s body through fodder. Somasundaram said they will check for the quality of fodder provided to cattle using equipment available for the purpose.

Title: Post-graduate youth loses Rs 14,000 to online job fraud
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Nagpur: A postgraduate youth, who had recently completed Master of Science (MSc), was duped of Rs 14,000 by a trickster on the pretext of securing a job for him in a pharma company in July last year.

According to sources, Husban Khan, 23, a resident of Ayyappa Nagar, had registered himself on Naukri.com and uploaded his resume on the website.

After a few days, Khan received a call from a person who offered him a job at Sun Pharmaceutical. The caller told Khan that his resume is good for the job, but he will have to go through online interviews and other procedures.

The caller initially asked Khan to send Rs 2,000 to his account as registration charges. After Khan had sent the money, the caller arranged an online interview following which he was informed being selected for the job.

The accused later asked Khan to send Rs 7,000 for completing other formalities, which the job seeker complied with. As Khan suspected something fishy, he called the accused and demanded the money back. Khan told the accused that he doesn’t want the job now. The accused convinced Khan to send Rs 5,000 more saying after that the entire amount deposited by him will be refunded.

In the hope of getting the money back, Khan deposited Rs5,000 in the bank account provided by the accused. After the money was deposited, the accused switched off his mobile. On realizing he has been duped, Khan approached cyber complaint cell (C3) of city police and filed a complaint.

After primary probe, C3 transferred the complaint to Mankapur police station where a case of fraud has been registered. Police are now trying to track down the owner of the bank account in which the money was deposited.

Title: Bangalore Accident: Lamborghini rams traffic police chowki in Bengaluru
Content:
Lamborghini sports car involved in the accident.

BENGALURU: Two men at the wheel of their luxury sports cars created chaos at Mehkri Circle and CTO Junction on Sunday. Two persons were injured and five vehicles, including the luxury cars and a traffic police chowki, were damaged in the two freak accidents.A Bentley car (TS 09 UC 9) speeding from Hebbal hit three vehicles, including an autorickshaw under Mehkri Circle underpass on Ballari Road at 2.30pm. The driver fled the spot leaving his Bentley behind.Praful Kumar, an engineer, and Abdul, an auto driver, sustained injuries in the accident. The Bentley belongs to a private company. “We have summoned the company representatives on Monday, M Narayan,” DCP (traffic-east) said.In the other incident, a brand new Lamborghini crashed into a traffic police chowki at CTO Circle opposite Cubbon Park Metro station at 5.15pm. There was no police personnel at the chowki at that time.Declining to divulge the car driver’s name, Cubbon Park traffic police said they have registered a case of rash and negligence driving against him. Police said the luxury car seemed to be a new one as it still had no registration plate.In Video: Bengaluru: Luxury car crashes into police post

Title: Eight held with illegal weapons
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Representative image

JODHPUR: Eight persons were arrested and 11 illegal weapons were found on them by police here on Sunday. The weapons included pistols, revolvers, country-made pistols and 17 live cartridges.

Police said the accused were arrested while they were trying to sell the weapons.

Sources said police got a tip-off about one Nehpal Singh roaming in Sardarpura in search of a customer for the weapon.

“We spotted him and arrested him from near a pan shop. He was found with two pistols and 4 live cartridges,” said an officer.

During interrogation police learnt that seven of his aides had been roaming in different areas of the city with the weapons and cartridges.

The officer said the gang identified itself as 0044 gang. The leader of the gang, Nimbaram, is currently lodged in Jodhpur Central Jail. He was arrested by Chittorgarh police some time ago.

Singh, who has half-a-dozen cases registered in different police stations under different sections of IPC, claimed that he had obtained the pistols and cartridges from Nimbaram.

“We have initiated an investigation into the matter and hope to bust the huge illegal and country-made weapons trade,” the officer said.

Title: Telangana’s crop production in 2019-20 highest since state formation
Content:
Picture used for representational purpose

HYDERABAD: Telangana saw its highest production of agricultural crops since formation at 1.3 crore metric tonnes for the year 2019-20, according to the directorate of economics and statistics. The statistics department attributes the rise in production to an increase in area under cultivation due to irrigation projects such as Kaleshwaram and increased rainfall. The year also saw the highest year-on-year growth in food production, a rise of 42% or 37 lakh metric tonnes over the previous year.Except turmeric, many major crops have seen a rise in production. According to the statistics department estimates, turmeric production dipped by 14,000 metric tonnes with a total production of around 3 lakh metric tonnes.Chilli production saw a rise of 24,000 metric tonnes with total production estimated to be around 3.28 lakh metric tonnes. Oil seeds also saw a significant rise in production with an estimated total production 6.6 lakh metric tonnes, an increase of 42,000 metric tonnes over the previous year.As per the statistics department, paddy and cotton are the major contributors to production numbers. Paddy has seen an increase in per-acre productivity with the state estimated to have produced 66 lakh metric tonnes of rice.Cotton, the second-most important crop in the state, was estimated at 48 lakh metric tonnes in terms of production, a rise of 13 lakh metric tonnes over the previous year.The directorate of statistics will soon be forwarding its report to the Centre.

Title: Central agency to conduct beach auditing at Kappad
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Kozhikode: The Centre for Water Resource Development and Management (CWRDM) will conduct beach auditing at Kappad as part of improving cleanliness on the beach.

The beach auditing will focus identifying the key source of waste and the major waste particles found on the beach.

The beach auditing project is part of the educational and awareness programme planned as part of the Blue Flag Certification Programme. The ministry of environment and forest has entrusted CWRDM to carry out awareness and educational programme among students, tourists and residents on the importance of proper waste management on the beach.

“We will collect details about what are the types of waste found on the beach and who are the sources of waste,” said Dr P S Harikumar, senior principal scientist at CWRDM who is coordinating the beach auditing and other activities at Kappad Beach. The types of waste generated and how to reduce waste generation will all be studied, he added.

The plan is to collect data for the audit through questionnaire. The tourists, residents and others will be made part of the audit.

The audit will also collect details to gauge how aware the residents and tourists are about the importance of cleanliness and waste management. Shop keepers will also be made a part of the audit.

“We are planning a number of awareness and educational programmes for the residents of Kappad and nearby areas,” said Dr Harikumar. Awareness for school students, youths and others is also part of the programme, he said.

To mark the beginning of the awareness programme for Blue Flag Certification process, Kerala State Council for Science and Technology and CWRDM on Sunday carried out beach cleaning activity at Kappad. Over 100 students from various schools took part in the drive.

They also organized painting competition and quiz programme for school students from the area.

In order to qualify for the Blue Flag Certification, a series of stringent environmental, educational, and safety and accessibility criteria must be met and maintained. The programme is also part of the national campaign aiming to keep trash out of beaches and oceans to raise awareness on cleanliness of environment.

The national and international teams are expected to visit Kappad soon to review the cleanliness condition. Cleaning and other activities are already ongoing at Kappad and we are now focusing on the educational side, said Dr Harikumar.

Title: Reflexology pathway, scary house and more at revamped Domlur park
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Bengaluru: An open theatre, a scary house, a reflexology pathway and much more. All these aren’t features of a new mall in the city, but a public park coming up in Domlur, east Bengaluru .

Kanakadasa Park, spread over two acres, also has unique seating arrangements themed after fruits like apples, bananas and watermelons. To keep the kids engaged there are installations of frogs, deer, peacocks, etc.

“There are public parks in the city themed around one or two special features. But I wanted to bring many features in one space,” said Lakshminarayan CR, corporator of Domlur ward. “We have spent Rs 2 crore to renovate the park, including pooling in some CSR funds,” he added.

The corporator said the reflexology pathway is specially designed to stimulate acupressure points in the feet. “The walkway is about 10 feet wide and can easily accommodate more than 300 walkers,” he explained.

Ravi Prasad, a local, said residents are excited about the inauguration of new features at the park. “A bench in the shape of a huge apple scaling to a height of 4 feet is interesting,” he added.

The park will also have installations of Disney characters, which will also serve as selfie points. Kalyani L, another Domlur resident, said they are happy to see the park get a revamp. “Though some renovation work had started in 2015, it didn’t take off. Later it became a hub of anti-social elements. It’s good that the public space is being reclaimed now,” she added.

A senior official said the park also has a sustainability factor. “There is a biogas plant and the electricity generated from it will be used to illuminated the walkways. A few final touches remain, after which the park will be thrown open to the public,” he added. The facility also has a parking lot, which can accommodate about 50 cars and over 100 two-wheelers.

Title: Demolished encroachments back on Annarayuni lake, locals losing hope
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Hyderabad: Months after encroachments on the Annarayuni cheruvu , on the outskirts of the city, were demolished, fresh encroachments are being planned, say residents. They say that unless lakes are fenced and watchmen appointed, the water bodies have will always remain vulnerable. On Saturday, residents confronted a man on a tractor who was trying to ‘clean up’ the lake in Keesara so that construction work could be carried out. The lake currently does not have any water.

“We have been working on the lake (protection) for four years and have begged officials to rejuvenate it. Every time officials say they don’t have funds,” said Prashanth Mamidala, an activist, adding: “Forget rejuvenation, mere protection of the lakes boundaries is becoming a challenge.”

Highlighting that despite municipal minister KT Rama Rao giving a positive response on the issue of rejuvenating the lake, nothing had progressed on ground. “Encroachments keep on happening. Why is it that we should beg so much to get things done?” Prashanth said.

In July 2019, a structure on the full-tank-level (FTL) of the lake was demolished after multiple complaints. However, it was back up again by December and still stands. “We have to keep tweeting the MRO Keesara who responds very rarely,” said Srinivas Podduri, a local.

Speaking about the promises made by political representatives, another resident, Vijay Shekar said: “Before the municipal elections, MLA and MPs promise that they will ensure the lake is cleaned up but once the polls are done we are back to square one.”

Irrigation officials, meanwhile, stated that work on ‘priority lakes’ is still pending and there were not enough funds to complete the rejuvenation process for all lakes in one go.

Title: Bengaluru: No Aadhaar? You may not get to rest in peace
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Representative image

BENGALURU: Make sure you have your Aadhaar card nearby before you breathe your last. For, staff at some BBMP crematoria and graveyards are insisting that Aadhaar of the dead be produced, if you have to be laid to rest.

However, the Supreme Court has made it clear that Aadhaar is mandatory only where citizens are availing benefits of government welfare schemes.

Last week, Rajesh K (name changed), a resident of Vijayanagar, lost his 75-year-old aunt. When the grieving family took the body to Sumanahalli crematorium, Outer Ring Road, for the last rites, they were in for a rude shock. “The staff there said the slot had to be booked online and insisted that we produce my aunt’s Aadhaar card and that too the original,” he told TOI.

“Amid all the grief, their demand stumped us. My aunt’s Aadhaar card was missing and we didn’t have its photocopy either. We went to a nearby cyber café to generate the e-aadhaar, but it didn’t work as the SIM of the registered mobile number had been blocked due to some reason. We somehow managed to activate the mobile number and get the e-aadhaar as proof. It was a traumatic experience,” said Rajesh.

The civic body maintains as many as 12 electric crematoria and 46 burial grounds across the city.

Ä staffer at Sumanahalli crematorium said they ask for Aadhaar as everyone has it now and they think it’s the most reliable identity proof.

When TOI randomly dialled several crematoria and burial grounds, many staffers said they are OK with Aadhaar (original or photocopy). “We ask people who come to book slot for cremation to ensure they mention the Aadhaar number during online booking and show us the original or photocopy of the Aadhaar letter or card,” said a staffer at the crematorium in west zone.

However, a staffer of Hebbal crematorium said they ask for Aadhaar, but if it’s not available, they accept any ID proof.

Prakash KV, a resident of Mallathahalli, said staffers at crematoria insist that relatives mention the Aadhaar number of the dead as identity proof.

Title: Hyderabad Rain: Rain drags mercury down, temperature dips by 9 degrees Celsius in 24 hours in Hyderabad
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

The city experienced its third wettest day in February in the past 10 years

HYDERABAD: Following the sudden spell of rain on Saturday evening, the city saw a sharp drop of nine degrees Celsius in the maximum temperature within 24 hours.

The maximum temperature in Hyderabad dipped to 23.4 degrees Celsius from 32 degree Celsius by Sunday evening.

However, the India Meteorological Department (IMD), Hyderabad said the low temperatures are unlikely to sustain for a longer, and it will be back to hot and humid after two days.

The city experienced its third wettest day in February in the past 10 years after it received an average rainfall of 4.1mm in 24 hours till 8.30am on Saturday evening. Light rains continued in the city even on Sunday.

As per IMD data, the city received highest rainfall of 20.2mm on February 21, 2011 followed by 12mm on February 18, 2013.

The sudden showers brought down the mercury levels below 30 degree Celsius after a long dry after a long dry spell. According to Telangana State Development Planning Society, from 8.30am on Saturday to 8.30am on Sunday, Nagole and Maruthi Nagar in Saroornagar circle and Rajiv Nagar in Kapra circle received highest rainfall of 30.2mm followed by 27mm in Jahanuma in Falaknuma circle, 26mm in Habsiguda in Uppal circle among others.

Parts of city such as Bandlaguda, Mythri Enclave in Trimulgherry, Chandrayangutta Bahadurpura experienced waterlogging. The change in weather conditions was attributed to a cyclonic circulation over southern parts of Odisha in association with a trough extending up to south Telangana.

Several districts such as Karimnagar, Nalgonda, Nizamabad, Hanmakonda also received moderate rainfall resulting in sharp drop in mercury levels. According to the IMD, Hyderabad, the maximum temperature dropped by 8.4 degrees Celsius in Ramagundam to 24 degrees Celsius. This was followed by 7.2 degrees Celsius drop in Nizamabad and Hanmakonda, where the temperature dipped to 25.5 and 24.8 degrees Celsius respectively.

Meteorologists forecast that rainfall activity is likely to continue for the next two days across Telangana and Andhra Pradesh. “Amidst rains, maximums of Telangana are likely to drop by three to four degrees Celsius due to increased cloud cover and subsequent rainfall. On the other hand, the night temperatures are expected to settle above normal for the next few days,” read a weather report issued by Skymet, an independent weather forecasting agency.

By February 13, rains are likely to vacate the region completely following which no major rainfall activity will take place.

Title: Eight held with illegal weapons
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Representative image

JODHPUR: Eight persons were arrested and 11 illegal weapons were found on them by police here on Sunday. The weapons included pistols, revolvers, country-made pistols and 17 live cartridges.

Police said the accused were arrested while they were trying to sell the weapons.

Sources said police got a tip-off about one Nehpal Singh roaming in Sardarpura in search of a customer for the weapon.

“We spotted him and arrested him from near a pan shop. He was found with two pistols and 4 live cartridges,” said an officer.

During interrogation police learnt that seven of his aides had been roaming in different areas of the city with the weapons and cartridges.

The officer said the gang identified itself as 0044 gang. The leader of the gang, Nimbaram, is currently lodged in Jodhpur Central Jail. He was arrested by Chittorgarh police some time ago.

Singh, who has half-a-dozen cases registered in different police stations under different sections of IPC, claimed that he had obtained the pistols and cartridges from Nimbaram.

“We have initiated an investigation into the matter and hope to bust the huge illegal and country-made weapons trade,” the officer said.

Title: Taxi driver dies in Verna road accident
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Vasco: A taxi driver from Taleigao died, and a family of four was injured in an accident at Verna junction on Sunday morning. The deceased Rusell Fernandes, 20, was driving the family to Margao when his vehicle crashed into an oncoming trailer truck while trying to overtake a car.

Fernandes was taken to the Hospicio, Margao, where he was declared dead.

The passengers Valentin Costa, 48, and Sandra Costa,46, and their children Alino, 13 and Alrico, 9, were taken to GMC for treatment.

Leader of opposition Digambar Kamat said there was almost one fatal accident on Goa’s roads each day and urged the government to take immediate steps like restricting the movement of heavy vehicles during the day to ensure commuters’ safety.

“The roads have become death traps. Road dividers, reflectors and speed breakers are all damaged or faulty. It’s not safe to drive ,” Kamat said.

Title: Chief minister must start process for Madurai AIIMS enrolment: MP
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Madurai: Chief minister Edappadi K Palaniswami should initiate the process for enrolment of students in the All India Institute of Medical Sciences which is expected to be established by 2023, Madurai MP Su Venkatesan has said. Many other states which are also getting AIIMS have already started the process and a delay would result in Tamil Nadu students being deprived of an opportunity to study there, he told reporters here.

Planning for the AIIMS in Madurai was being done in coordination with the Japan International Cooperation Agency (JICA). If the institute is to be started in 2023 the process of student enrolments should have started by now. For establishing a medical college with hospital, a temporary building and link with a 300-bedded hospital were necessary. Madurai had scope for this and it should be started without further delay. Admission notices had been issued for the new AIIMS in Mangalagiri in 2018, Bibi Nagar in Telangana in 2019 and for Jammu AIIMS the notice was to be issued this August. The Jammu and Madurai AIIMS are expected to start functioning in 2023, but TN has not taken any step towards the admission process, he said.

The chief minister and health minister should appoint a special officer for the AIIMS establishment process as AIIMS and National Institute of Pharmaceutical Education Research were necessary for spearheading Madurai’s development, he said.

Asked about Union government’s announcement that a site museum would be established in Adhichanallur, he said it looked like a definite move to divert attention from Keeladi which had revealed the ancientness of the Tamil civilization that had thrived on the banks of Vaigai. “What will they showcase in the Adhichanallur site museum when the detailed excavation was conducted 70 years ago and the report on the latest 15-year-old excavation is yet to be released,’’ he said. TNN

Title: TNGCTA wants full-time research director at BDU
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Trichy: The Tamil Nadu Government College Teachers Association (TNGCTA) has demanded appointment of a full-time research director at the Bharathidasan University as it is hampering research activities..

The university had taken multiple steps to speed up evaluation of PhD thesis and award of degrees without delay by creating a separate research wing in March 2018. “But many such measures on part of the university did not yield much results as it has not appointed a full-time research director,” said P David Livingstone, secretary, TNGCTA Trichy zone.

“Research director (in-charge) S Muthusamy is also heading the chemistry department of the university and only comes to the research section in the evening which is resulting in delay. Despite automation of the research sections, many of the PhD scholars and guides are asked to come in person to clarify many trivial issues,” he said.

A government college faculty member had allegedly applied for research guideship in 2018. While she was qualified for guideship at that point, the university delayed the award of guideship for two years. Now the university is deny guideship to the faculty citing new UGC norms.

“It is unfair on part of the university to delay the award of guideship in 2018 and ask the faculty member to fulfil the requirement based on the recent orders of the UGC,” said Livingstone

Speaking to TOI S Muthusamy, said there may be exceptions, but all measures are being taken to fast track the research section. I am working in the section till late evening to clear files.

On the appointment of a full-time research director, Muthusamy said that university has taken steps and appointment will be made soon. “We have taken up the matter with vice-chancellor P Manisankar on many occasion but nothing has been done so far. Therefore, we have decided to carry out protest if the VC continues to remain a mute spectator,” said Livingstone.

Title: Undertrial not allowed to see her husband’s body; son in jail too
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Relatives brought the body till gate of the jail, but were denied entry

VADODARA: In a cruel twist of fate, a woman undertrial in Vadodara Central Jail was denied a last glimpse of her dead husband before his last rites on Saturday. The couple’s only son too is serving a sentence in the same jail. The casual labourer from Wadhwana village in Dabhoi taluka died alone at his home on Saturday afternoon, as his wife and son are in jail on rape charges.

While the relatives of the deceased tried their best to help Rauji Rathodiya ’s wife Leela and son Sukhdev see his mortal remains, and brought the body to the gate of Vadodara Central Jail, officials did not let them enter owing to lack of knowledge of legal procedures.

The villagers arrived at the jail with just an application seeking permission for the duo see the body. But the jail sentry turned down their request and asked them to leave immediately.

“We had a letter drafted by a lawyer requesting my aunt and cousin to see my uncle’s body. But the jail officials did not even accept the letter and asked us to leave,” said Rathodiya’s nephew Arjun.

He added that they waited at the jail gates from morning till evening and when nothing moved the jail officials, they took the body back to Wadhwana and performed the final rites.

A jail inmate can seek interim bail from a court to attend the funeral of his or her family member.

“The villagers had come with a rough application letter and so we had to turn them away. They did not follow any legal process,” explained jail superintendent V R Patel.

Title: IOC-run petrol pump soon on district prison premises
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Kozhikode: The district prison here will get a petrol bunk run by the Indian Oil Corporation soon. The project is part of the prisoner welfare project of the state government.

The plan is to deploy prisoners and those who complete their jail term at the petrol pump. Kerala so far has four similar pumps in prisons.

The project was first introduced at Poojappura Central Jail. Later the project was extended to other prisons including Kannur, Thrissur and Open Jail at Cheemeni in Kasaragod.

A discussion regarding the project was held at district prison on Sunday during the launch of a series of welfare and employment projects for the prisoners. Director general of prisons and correctional service, Rishi Raj Singh inaugurated the prisoners’ welfare projects on Sunday.

While the land for the petrol pump and the staff will be given by the prison’s department, the installation of the pump and other activities will be done by the Indian Oil Corporation.

The plan is to set up a petrol pump that operates round-the-clock. Officials with the IOC also took part in the programme at Kozhikode district prison on Sunday.

Rishi Raj Singh also released the cloth bags prepared by the women inmates of the prison. There is also a plan to develop the cloth bag making unit and the official received the sewing machine sponsored by Peruvayal service cooperative bank.

The inauguration of vocational training programme for the prison inmates including training in LED bulb making, steel fabrication, aluminium fabrication were also inaugurated on the day.

The Prison DGP also distributed certificates to those who completed the vocation training programme previously.

The release of mural painting was also done at district prison. Two mural paintings-one sponsored by Lions Club of Calicut Diamond and the second by Fine Arts College Students, were released.

DIG of Prisons North Zone M K Vinod Kumar, V Jayakumar, district superintendent of Prisons, T Rajesh Kumar, welfare officer Kozhikode district prison and others were present.

Title: Hyderabad: Paint mixer bursts in garbage bin, 1 hurt
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

The injured ragpicker was shifted to Gandhi Hospital

HYDERABAD: One person was injured following an explosion inside a garbage bin at Musheerabad ’s Harinagar on Saturday.

Officials rushed to the scene to ascertain if the blast had occurred due to explosives. After analysis, police found out that a paint box had caused the blast.

Forensic officials at the scene confirmed that it was a half-used paint mixer that had exploded.

“There were no explosives in the container. It was a paint box. The injured person, a rag-picker, has been shifted to a hospital,” said a police official.

The injured person is undergoing treatment at Gandhi Hospital. Police said that there were two such boxes in the garbage bin, one of which exploded when the man had tried to open it.

Title: Hinganghat Latest News: Hinganghat burns survivor continues to be critical
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Ankita Pisudde

NAGPUR: The 24-year-old Hinganghat burns survivor , Ankita Pisudde, continued to be on ventilator on Sunday at Orange City Hospital and Research Institute (OCHRI). She had been admitted there on February 3 after being brought with almost 40% burns from Hinganghat.

Sources from the hospital said the condition of Pisudde, a contributory botany lecturer, was critical with fluctuating oxygen levels in her blood. Though the team of doctors had managed to stabilize her blood pressure, her oxygen level continued to remain a cause of grave concern.

Pisudde had been set afire by Vikesh Nagrale near her college, after she refused to speak to him and also reported his advances to her father. Nagrale, now in Wardha jail, is learnt to have told police that he did not like Pisudde complaining to her father about his attempts to speak to her. The accused, who was nabbed by Nagpur rural police, is married and has a child.

Title: Maha tourist dies after somersaulting
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Panaji: A tourist from Satara, Maharashtra died of a suspected head injury after attempting a somersault at Baga beach on Sunday.

Drishti, the government-appointed lifeguarding agency, said that Balu Shinde, 40, was part of a group of eight males who were playing on the shore.

At around 11.30am, he landed on his head while attempting a somersault and was knocked unconscious.

A Drishti official said that Shinde's vitals were found to be normal, however, he had difficulty breathing. Shinde was rushed to the Mapusa district hospital where he passed away, the official said.

Title: 28 kg ganja seized from river bed
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Thanjavur: Police recovered 28 kg of ganja buried in the Cauvery river bed near Kumbakonam in Thanjavur on Sunday. Two people have been arrested by the police in connection with the incident.

According to police, the accused have been identified as S Vignesh, 26, a resident of Valayapettai in Kumbakonam, S Vellaiyan alias Rajkumar, 37, of Panathurai near Kumbakonam. Police are looking for a third accused Arunkumar, 25, of Mission Street in Elumichangapalayam.

Based on the accused statements, the police team took them to Cauvery river bed near Valaivupettai in Kumbakonam and unearthed 15 gunny bags of ganja.

Police produced the two before the Kumbakonam court and lodged them in prison under judicial custody. Meanwhile, the police have intensified their search operation to nab the third accused who is on the run, police said.

Title: Mid-day meal mess due to SHGs chosen by edu dept: Headmasters Association
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Nagpur: After almost two days of guarded approach over the Hudkeshwar school food poisoning case, the Nagpur chapter of Headmasters Association (HA) has accused the education department and civic authorities of messing up the midday meal (MDM) scheme. Madhusudhan Mude , president of HA (Nagpur district), said some officials are probably sabotaging the MDM scheme for kickbacks.

Mude said that the MDM scheme must be run only by big centralized kitchen set ups that have a proven track record of supplying thousands upon thousands of meals each day. “Only under such a set up can we have constant monitoring of how the food is cooked, packed and delivered,” he said.

He alleged that in many schools MDM contracts given to big national-level not-for-profit organization had been cancelled. “My school is one of them. Akshay Patra was serving midday meals here but the contract was cancelled and given to a local self-help group. The economics of it means that these ultra small units won’t be able to provide high quality food and still churn out a profit. And cutting corner means compromising on quality,” said Mude.

He confirmed to TOI that the education department had been informed about the poor quality of MDM being served by self-help groups. “We have complained more than once but nobody in the department is ready to listen. It means that someone in the department is getting commission to ensure status quo,” said Mude.

HA office bearers are planning to now present a memorandum to the department for completely doing away with contracts to local self-help groups and to bring in the bigger players. Mude said, “The big organizations like Akshay Patra and Annamrita have a huge set-up in various cities and are like a well-oiled machine when it comes to MDM. Their kitchens are state-of-the art, cooking preparations standardized and packing materials are also of high quality. If the department is serious about safety of children then they will revert the contracts to the bigger units.”

Education activist Shahid Sharif said there have been complaints about quality of food served by self-help groups earlier too but no action was taken. “The Food and Drug Administration will be releasing its report on Monday about the food sample taken from the Hudkeshwar school. But we have come to know that there is definitely some problem with the sample that was tested,” said Sharif.

Title: Protect windowpane oysters at Cortalim, NGT tells govt
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Panaji: The National Green Tribunal ( NGT ) has directed the expert committee of the Goa Coastal Zone Management Authority ( GCZMA ) to look into the error in its report, which denies the presence of windowpane oysters on the Cortalim coast, and take adequate mitigation measures for the protection and conservation of the protected species.

Counsel Rahul Choudhary representing the NGO, Federation of Rainbow Warriors, told the tribunal that there was a factual error in the report of the committee pertaining to windowpane oysters, where the conclusion and recommendations of its report state that there are no window pane oysters around Cortalim, when they actually do exist.

The GCZMA, at its meeting on February 5, decided that the expert members would conduct a fresh physical inspection along the construction of the Zuari bridge, where the federation has stated PWD work is ongoing in violation of CRZ clearance.

The authority found that the construction work on the Agasaim and Cortalim side of the bridge is fraught with irregularities. It observed that construction debris and earth dumped on the western and eastern sides of the old Zuari bridge fell partly within the CRZ-1 area of the river and lying within the no-development zone (NDZ) of the Zuari.

“As per the CRZ regulation, no dumping of earth or land-filling is permissible within the NDZ area. It is understood that the NH 17 work is not yet complete and is still ongoing, so the material will be lying within the area for some time, but will be removed as told by PWD — which is permissible as per a circular dated February 25, 2015 from the Union ministry of environment, forests and climate change,” the GCZMA stated in its meeting.

It recommended that the PWD be instructed to manage waste dumped along the northern bank of Zuari river on the Agasaim side, which is also not permissible. “The respondent should be told to manage the waste properly by installing a waste disposal mechanism at site or by engaging a contractor for its management,” the authority recommended.

The GCZMA further said that the open sewerage system at site is a serious concern. So, the PWD should be strictly directed to close the stinking sewer immediately, which is not permissible within the NDZ area. “Instead, they should provide mobile toilets for the labourers and PWD should be directed to initiate action for replanting of mangroves, which have been cut during the course of road / bridge construction,” the GCZMA said.

Title: 10th century Chola sculptures found near Trichy
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Trichy: Three sculptures, allegedly from the Chola era, were identified by epigraphists during an explorative study near Chemmedu of Kolli hills in Namakkal district. One among them is the sculpture of Jeyshta deity, supposedly dated back to 10 century CE.

They stumbled upon the sculptures on the outskirts of Karayankattuppatti village where they had been carrying out a study on tribal life and culture. The chola sculptures of deity Mahishasuramardini, which were also found, are estimated to be of 12th century CE.

“Jeyshta is the elder sister of goddess Lakshmi. Also known as Muuttadevi, this deity is mentioned in the ancient Tamil literature Thirukkural where she is called as Thavvai and Mamugadi,” said R Kalaikkovan, director of Dr M Rajamanikkanar Centre for Historical Research.

Seated on a bench with both her legs down with a flower medallion fixed to her head gear, she is adorned with Karanda makuta, palm leaf kundalas, charappali, bangles, rings and swarna vaikaksha.

Her right hand is in abhaya and the left hand is kept on the thigh. Her son Nandhikesvaran also known as Manthan and her daughter Agnimatha are seated in suhasana in two raised pedestals seen one on each side of her. Her son with the face of a bull has a staff in his right hand and his left hand is kept on his thigh. One of the Mahishasuramardini sculpture is in a standing posture with her feet resting on the head of the defeated and killed buffalo demon Mahishan. Holding bow and arrow in the front hands and sword and shield in the back hands, a beautiful deer is standing behind her with its face to her right. “Absence of the usual objects - the chakra and the conch - in the back hands of this image is significant and differentiates it from the urban counterparts,” said R Akila, who was part of explorative study.

In the other sculpture, the hands of the deity are in abhaya (bestowing protection) and dola (simply hanging on the side). The back hands of this icon as in the normal Durga images with conch and chakra. “Commonly the right hand of the deity is used to show the abhaya mudra whereas here it is with the left hand,” said Kalaikkovan.

Title: No end to parking woes in Walled City, residents livid
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Illegal parking has made driving through the roads impossible

JAIPUR: Parking woes in Walled City has become a never-ending problem. While authorities blame congested lanes for the mess, residents say lack of proper administration was the reason.

There are many lanes in Walled City but illegal parking has made driving through the roads impossible. Haldiyon ka Rasta, Gopalji Ka Rasta, Nahargarh Road, Baba Harish Chand Marg and Khajane Walon ka Rasta are a few such examples.

Vikas Kohtari, former councillor from Walled city, said roads get congested from early morning. “There is a severe parking crisis in Walled City areas. Though it has been a heritage city by UNESCO, parking has forced people to move out of here. Residents are slowly opting to leave their ancestral havelis and live in Jaipur Greater where they can move freely,” said Vikas.

According to rules, none of the businessmen in the city is allowed to park vehicles in the market. But people hardly follow the norms and cars can be seen parked in the market right from the morning.

Kailash Mittal, vice-president of Johri Bazaar Market Association, said it is easier to park illegally by monthly paying contractors. “These contractors will charge a monthly amount from the businessmen and any one can park their vehicles for more than two hours. Traffic police don’t even tow their vehicles,” said Kailash.

Title: Soon, CCP to maintain EDC Patto Plaza
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Panaji: The economic development corporation (EDC) has in principle decided to hand over the logistics of its Patto Plaza to the corporation of the city of Panaji(CCP).

When this is done, CCP will be responsible for the maintenance of roads, footpaths, streetlights and pay parking in the complex. The existing pay parking contract for Patto Plaza will end on March 31.“We will have to retender the pay parking contract,” Panaji mayor Uday Madkaikar said.

The move, he said, came after the North Goa Collector notified all roads as public roads. Currently, CCP only collects garbage from Patto Plaza, while EDC manages the complex. The EDC reclaimed and developed the 1.8 lakh sqm in 1985 to make it a model commercial hub and also implemented a pay parking scheme in the commercial area.

Title: Guilt-ridden man hangs after friend’s daughter dies in accident
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Nagapattinam: A 45-year-old man was found hanging in Nagapattinam district on Sunday a day after his friend’s daughter died in a road accident while he was taking her to school on a two-wheeler. The deceased man, a flower vendor, has been identified as Veeramani of Pookara Street in Velankanni.

On Saturday, Veeramani’s friend Mathiazhagan requested him to drop his daughter, M Mahara Jothi, 16, at her school as she had missed her regular bus. Jothi was a Class XI student at a private school in Nagore.

While Veeramani was on way to drop her at school, an SETC bus hit his two-wheeler at Paravai on the East Coast Road. The accident happened when Veeramani tried to cross the ECR without noticing the bus, onlookers said. The bus driver's rash driving was also a reason for the accident, according to the Velankanni police.

Jothi and Veeramani sustained injuries and were rushed to Nagapattinam Government Hospital. However, Jothi died on the way to hospital while Veeramani sustained minor injuries in the incident.

Though he returned home after being treated as an outpatient in the hospital, he appeared depressed apparently bogged down by guilt as he felt that he was the reason for Jothi’s death. On Sunday morning, he went missing from his house.

When his family members searched for him at various spots, they were shocked to find his body hanging from a tree in nearby North Pogainallur village. Veeramani is survived by his wife and two sons. Velankanni police arrested bus driver Madhankumar and further inquiries are on.

Title: GRH employee sacked after being found to be ex-prisoner
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Madurai: A female daily wage worker employed at Government Rajaji Hospital (GRH) was sacked after complaints arose that the woman has been employed despite being released from the prison only around four months ago.

The woman, Gowri, was employed as a daily wage worker at the Department of Surgery at GRH, shortly after being released from prison. Though initially there were rumours that she had previously been sent to jail regarding her involvement in a case related to child kidnapping at GRH, the hospital dean Dr Sangumani J denied the rumours.

“After we received complaints from daily wage workers, we came to know that the woman had only shortly been released from jail in a case related to her private affair. We later held an inquiry as well regarding her appointment and removed her from service,” he said.

The dean also said that an inquiry was held in the presence of a professor from the Department of Surgery and that Gowri herself admitted that she was indeed released from jail four months ago.

“The appointment of daily wage workers happens at the levels of Resident Medical Officer (RMO) and Sergeant on a daily basis. There has also been no evidence of any wrongdoing by senior officials. As soon as we found the complaint valid, we removed her. The matter has been put to rest,” added Dr Sangumani.

Title: Coronavirus spells trouble for electronics, toy sellers
Content:
(Representative image)

NEW DELHI: A crisis stares in the face of consumers as traders have put on hold import of Chinese products, including electronics, automobile parts, toys, mobile phone parts, fabrics and other materials, for the next two months.The traders said that due to the outbreak of coronavirus , manufacturing units in China have suspended production. It has become difficult for businessmen to visit the country for checking the quality of consignments due to travel restrictions.Manish Khandelwal, a furniture trader at CR Park, claimed that till December he visited China every month. “Even my clients came here till last month, but news of coronavirus caused panic among them. I need to visit the country regularly to check for new varieties, quality of products, negotiate prices and finalise the consignment. But I don’t think it is going to be possible to visit China soon,” he added.Umesh Seth, an automobile parts dealer at Kashmere Gate, said many businessmen suffered losses during the ongoing Auto Expo as Chinese manufacturers didn’t turn up. “Traders from far flung areas come to place bulk orders at the expo. Even I had to cancel my tickets,” he added.Low price, availability in bulk and variety are some of the favourable features of Chinese goods in India. The price of the same products manufactured in India are much higher, so people prefer to buy them even when there is no warranty, said traders.Vinay Khandelwal, a trader of mobile accessories at Gaffar Market, said, “I have been in contact with my supplier. He told me that labourers are not turning up for work because of the sudden rise in coronavirus cases and deaths. These units were expected to open from February 8 with the completion of the extended Lunar New Year holidays. However, looking at the situation, I don’t think they will start operations soon.”Confederation of All India Traders secretary general Praveen Khandelwal said traders importing Chinese products mostly keep stocks for at least two months. “The impact of short or no supply will be seen in April. In Chandni Chowk alone, around Rs 1,000 crore of materials are imported from China every month. Traders in other markets, like Lajpat Nagar, Rajouri and Gaffar Market, also regularly import Chinese products.”

Title: Coronavirus in Kerala: Coronavirus has severely affected tourism sector: Kerala tourism minister
Content:
Kerala tourism minister Kadakampally Surendran

THIRUVANANTHAPURAM: Admitting that novel coronavirus (nCoV) has dealt a severe blow to the state’s tourism sector, tourism minister Kadakampally Surendran said on Sunday that a meeting of the state tourism advisory council will be convened soon to chalk out a new marketing strategy to overcome the crisis.“The scare following the positive confirmation of nCoV cases in the state has of course affected the inflow of tourists, which calls for chalking out of a new marketing strategy. We took similar initiatives after the two consecutive monsoon floods, which ravaged the state, and post-Nipah virus outbreak to revive the sector,” the minister told reporters.Though the industry heaved a sigh of relief after the state government withdrew the declaration of nCoV infection as a state-specific disaster a couple of days ago, mass cancellations of hotel bookings and tour packages have already done the damage, stakeholders had pointed out.Meanwhile, responding to widespread criticism on the 20% cut in the 2020-21 budget outlay for tourism sector, especially on the allocation for marketing (which he was giving more thrust now), the minister said this happened due to the ‘specific nature’ of this year’s budget. “But, there’s no need for any concerns as there will be timely support through additional allocations as per requirements,” he said.The allocation for tourism marketing is Rs 63.4 crore in 2020-21 budget against Rs 82 crore earmarked in 2019-20. This was despite Kerala State Planning Board’s (KSPB) recommendation to focus more on marketing destinations and varied tourism products of the state, instead of infrastructure development.Held as a pioneer in marketing tourism among Indian states, Kerala, over the years, has been exploiting the potential of information communication technology for luring tourists from both international and domestic markets. But, the state has not yet come up successfully with a USP (unique selling proposition) for its authentic products like folk artforms, which, according to officials, require regular promotion on global platforms.As per the 2020-21 allocations, the activities under marketing scheme include international and national promotional campaigns, branding and partnerships.
