An amount of Rs 9.75 crore has been earmarked for international and national marketing events, including participation in trade fairs and organizing B2B meets, while Rs 8.25 crore is allotted for international and national campaigns, including print, TV, cinema halls and OOH (out of home advertising).Other activities under marketing include website development and web-based marketing activities (Rs 7.5 crore), social media and digital campaigns including national and international ‘Blog Express’ (Rs 6.8 crore), conducting FAM trips for tour operators, potential travel writers and journalists (Rs 6.75 crore), production and revamping of publicity materials (Rs 6.5 crore), sponsorships, financial assistance to various fairs with tourism potential and awareness advertisements (Rs 6.25 crore), focused public relations activities in international and domestic markets (Rs 6.1 crore), promoting MICE, monsoon tourism, adventure tourism and branding of tourism information centres (Rs 5.5 crore).

Title: 10 die of electrocution as bus touches live wire in Ganjam
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Berhampur: At least 10 people died of electrocution and 20 sustained injuries when a bus came in contact with a low-hanging high-tension wire and caught fire near Mandrajpur village, under Ganjam district’s Golanthara police station limits, on Sunday.

The private bus was carrying around 40 passengers, most of whom were from Dankalpadu village. They were on their way to Chikarada village to attend an engagement ceremony when the bus came in contact with the 11-kv line.

Transport minister Padmanabh Behera blamed local electricity officials for the tragedy and has asked the Ganjam district administration to launch a probe into the incident. Southco is the power distribution firm that operates in the area.

“The deceased sustained 80%-90% burns,” Radhamadhab Tripathy, principal of MKCG Medical College and Hospital, where the passengers were initially taken, said. “Eight of the injured were referred to the SCB Medical College and Hospital, Cuttack, after their condition worsened,” Ganjam district collector Vijay Amruta Kulange said.

Tripathy said the injured sustained 30%-40% burns. “We have constituted a team of doctors to treat the injured,” Tripathy said.

The bodies have been handed over to their relatives after conducting postmortem at MKCG. The deceased have been identified as U Debraj Reddy (11), Santoshini Sahu (12), B Taraneya (57), B Rameya (55), Ch.Tulasiamma (37), B Kanamma (40), B Achulu (35), K Kamaraju (50), B Mohini (30) and K Sanju (20). Debraj died on way to SCB Hospital.

“Among the other victims admitted at SCB hospital are five women and two men. Their condition is critical,” said Bhubananda Maharana, emergency officer at the Cuttack-based hospital

Chief minister Naveen Patnaik expressed grief and sorrow at the loss of lives and announced an ex-gratia of Rs 2 lakh each for the next of the kin of the deceased. He also said the injured would receive free treatment.

This is the second time in a fortnight that passengers were killed in a bus-related accident in Ganjam district. Earlier on January 29, nine passengers were killed when a bus fell off a bridge near Taptapani Ghati.

Sources said the bus left Dankalpadu village at about 12.30pm and the incident happened around half-an-hour later. The bus driver, while trying to give way to a two-wheeler, came in contact with the wire. “Some of the passengers got down from the bus and tried to rescue others. We immediately cut the power supply and tried to help those trapped inside the bus,” Damburu Reddy, a villager from Mandrajpur, said.

Firefighters and local police also helped rescue the injured. At least five ambulances were pressed into service to shift the injured to the hospitals. “The driver of the bus is yet to be identified. He may be among those injured,” a local policeman said. Police said they would register a criminal case against those responsible for the incident.

Local people claimed they had asked officials of Southco, the power distribution firm in the area, to raise the height of the low-hanging wire. “Despite repeated requests, Southco officials did not take us seriously,” Ch Sudhkar Reddy, sarapanch of Ekasingh panchayat, under which the incident happened, said.

Title: Shacks resort to club vibe to draw crowds
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Panaji: As evening sets in, the relaxed vibe at shacks along the Calangute and Baga stretch morphs into high-octane music energy with DJ’s blaring speakers and groups burning the dance floor with their moves.

In a case of necessity being the mother of innovation, shack operators, who are battling reduced footfalls and increased competition, have resorted to using music and dance to lure single Indian men to their establishments.

If shacks are unable to make business on food or deck beds when the crowd is thin, they are at least able to sell alcohol to the men, who come in to dance, and cover some cost, a shack operator at Baga said.

The tables and chairs are moved to the beach to make space for dancing. “Some shacks even plant two to three young women on the dance floor to draw in groups of single men loitering on the beach,” a shack operator said.

This ploy can attract a crowd of 50 or more men, most of whom enjoy dancing to Indi-pop music. “If I play English music they will ask to turn it off,” a shack operator from Baga said.

“If the shack has a good music system and DJ in a tow, dishing out songs as per audience demand, it can make good business for the night. One particular operator at Baga has a music system costing above Rs 10 lakh,” another operator said.

Agreeing, the shack operator from Baga said that the crowd will not step in if there is no music.

In the last few years, most shacks in this belt have invested in music systems worth anything between Rs 3 lakh and Rs 5 lakh. Hiring a DJ is a matter of affordability as they charge Rs 1,000-plus per night.

“They (DJs) come at a higher price during the Christmas week and New Year. I don’t have a DJ,” an operator at Baga beach said. The stretch has over 100 shacks where the trend of shack-by-day-club-by-night has caught on with the same enthusiasm as it has at Calangute.

“Foreign tourists avoid these beach stretches due to noise,” one operator said. No action is taken against loud music, he said.

Another factor that works in the favour of shacks at Baga is the presence of popular clubs like Tito’s and Mambo nearby.

“Male tourists who do not want to pay the stag entry fee, but want to enjoy themselves dancing, land up at the beach,” the shack operator said.

Shacks erected close to the entrance of the beach are likely to draw more people. However, location is no guarantee for good business and many shack operators have men working on commission to bring in clients.

“There will be one or two such boys attached to each shack, who will wander around the beach to get customers. They work on commission basis,” a shack operator at Calangute beach said.

A four to five per cent commission is paid on the bill raised for guests brought in by the person.

Arun R, who works at a beach shack in Calangute on commission basis, is feeling the pinch of a not so good tourism season this year. Arun, who is from Karnataka, said he normally earns more than Rs 30,000 a month by way of commissions, but that this year his earnings have dropped.

Some shacks along the beach stretches of Calangute, Candolim and Baga also have additional attractions like large screens where they show cricket and footfall matches.

“Everything is being tried to keep guests hooked and loosen their purse strings on food and beverages. So, if a neighbouring shack has anything new, I can’t be sitting tight. This is competition,” the shack operator said.

Title: RHB moots plan to sell shops on discounted rates
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Jaipur: After the Rajasthan Housing Board ( RHB ) sold its residential properties on discounted rates, a proposal has been floated to dispose of shops and commercial properties along the same lines.

For this, RHB has identified more than 300 properties in 10 cities including Jaipur, which will be sold at a discount rate between 25 % to 50 %.

Majority of the properties are in the slab of 25 per cent exemption, however, there are four shops in Bharatpur, which have been kept up to 50 per cent exemption. An official said, Jaipur has the highest number of shops. The board will dispose of these shops and commercial plots that are located in different sectors of Pratap Nagar and Indira Gandhi Nagar at a discount of up to 25 per cent.

There are a total of 223 shops in both these areas, of which 61 shops are in Pratap Nagar area, while the remaining 162 in Indira Gandhi Nagar. Other than this, the board will sell shops available in residential colonies in Tonk, Dausa, Sawai Madhopur, Bharatpur, Alwar, Bikaner, Nagaur, Bundi and Jodhpur cities. This decision to dispose of shops in exemptions was taken in the board meeting held in Januaray.

Like previous auction, the board will this time too adopted reverse bidding method for auctioning. An official explained, “Reverse bidding method means a person who has put up a bid to buy house on minimum discount rate will win the auction. Supposedly, one person plans to buy a house at 40% discount and another at 30% discount. The board will sell the flat to a person who is asking for less discount. Residents will be given a month’s time to submit their bid.”

During the real estate slump , the RHB had earned Rs 166 crore by selling 1,011 flats and houses across the state. Buoyed by the success, the RHB plans to continue with the auctions.

Title: Clear dues or no RTE admission: Pvt schools to state
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Jaipur: The consortium of private schools in Rajasthan has warned the state government that they will not admit any student under Right to Education (RTE) Act this year until their dues are cleared.

At present, around four lakh students from economically weaker section are studying under RTE in various private schools in the state. As per the Swayamsevi Shikshan Sanstha Sangh Raj, an organisation for private schools in the state, they have not received the payment since 2018 for the RTE students.

Kishan Mittal, president of the organisation, said, “The year is about to end, but the payment for the students for 2018-19 and 2019-20 sessions hasn’t been received. Whenever we question the state government, they give us an excuse of lack of funds. The state government receives funds from the Central government, then where have they spent all the money.”

In 2017, the Rajasthan government was paying every private school around Rs 17,000 for each student, which was later changed to Rs 13,700 in 2018 and then in 2019 it was further cut to Rs 10,500. And for the last two years the government hasn’t paid that money either, he added.

Kishan said that a student who was studying for a fee of Rs 17,000 is now studying for Rs 10,500, which, too, is not paid by the state government on time.

“We have to face losses due to the late payments. When we are following the government guidelines, then why can’t the government pay us on time. There are more than 32,000 schools in our organisation and the decision was taken unanimously at a meeting organised on Sunday. This is a serious issue which should be taken up by the government on priority or we will not admit any RTE student this year,” Kishan said.

Title: Delta area will be converted into ‘protected agri zone: CM
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Trichy: Farmers of delta districts welcomed chief minister Edappadi K Palaniswami’s promise that the Cauvery delta region would be converted into a ‘protected agricultural zone’, celebrating the announcement by bursting crackers and distributing sweets.

The celebrations came after the chief minister’s promised the delta region would be converted into a protected agricultural zone’ at function in Salem on Sunday. Farmer leaders hailed the announcement saying the government must take immediate steps to enable its implementation. The government must pass an ordinance and urge the union government to publish in its gazette.

Farmers of Neduvasal, the village that was the centre of hydrocarbon protest, urged the state to pass a resolution in the ensuing budget session. KK R Lenin, founder and president of the movement against destruction, said the initiative might restrict the union government from exploring oil wells on agriculture land not in the sea.

“As per the contract awarded to Vedanta groups, they may execute explorations on the sea by using horizontal pipes towards seashore. The government should ensure that it should not happen,” he said. Swamimalai S Vimalnathan, secretary of Thanjavur district Cauvery farmers protection association, said that it was former chief minister J Jayalalithaa who proposed the scheme and the present chief minister has endorsed it. “The government should withdraw entire cases registered against those who protested hydrocarbon exploration,” he said.

Farmers’ wing of Tamil Manila Congress headed by its state organizer, Puliyur A Nagarajan, said that delta farmer’s 25-year due demand has been fulfilled. When the union environment ministry exempted hydrocarbon exploration activities from the rigour of environmental impact assessment (EIA) and public consultation through public hearings, how chief minister’s announcement would become a reality? asked N Veerasekaran, state spokesperson for Bharatiya Kisan Sangam. “However, if the chief minister would make it a reality, that would be a benefit to the entire farming community,” he said.

Title: 57-year-old woman’s organs help save four lives
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Representative image

NEW DELHI: A 57-year-old woman, who was admitted to Venkateshwar Hospital in Dwarka after suffering a brain hemorrhage and was later declared brain dead, donated her organs for transplant. Her heart, liver and two kidneys were used to conduct transplant and save the lives of four people with organ failures.

A Venkateshwar Hospital official said the deceased’s liver and one kidney was used to for transplant at their centre, while her heart and another kidney were given to Max Saket and Artemis hospital in Gurgaon, respectively, for conducing the life-saving procedures. “All transplants have been carried out successfully and the patients are stable and recovering well,” said the official.

While a living donor can donate only a kidney, a portion of pancreas and liver to his or her immediate blood relative, individuals declared brain dead can help nearly a dozen. Multiple organs and tissues can be harvested, including heart, kidney, lung, liver and pancreas, for transplantation, say doctors.

Title: Sambar deer falls into well, rescued after 2 hours
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

TRICHY: A four-year-old male sambar deer that fell into a 16 foot-deep well near Manikandam of Pudukottai district was rescued on Saturday.

The rescue operation, which lasted for over a couple of hours, left a couple of forest department personnel injured. However, the animal was captured and safely released into Pachamalai reserve forest.

The incident happened on Saturday morning. The locals alerted forest department about a sambar deer falling into an open well in an agriculture farm behind the office of block development officer in Manikandam.

The forest department team along with volunteers reached the spot and pulled the deer out of the well using ropes. After the deer was rescued from the well, it ran into a nearby canal and was taken out of the canal after a brief rescue effort.

Trichy forest range officer, R Gunasekaran , who was leading the rescue team, said that it was a tedious task as the deer was weighed over 200 kg. “We decided to release the deer in Pachamalai forest,” said Gunasekaran. “Usually success rate of rescue mission is very low in case of spotted deer as these are very timid and often die out of shock during rescue. However, sambar deer are ferocious like bulls. Once we covered its eyes, it was quiet and we could translocate it to Pachamalai hill,” said honorary district animal welfare officer, G Ramakrishnan from animal welfare board of India (AWBI), who was part of the rescue.

There were not many sambar deer recorded in the recent time in Manikandam area. Besides, Thuvarankurichi reserve forest is the nearest forest to Manikandam at about 40 km.

While the forest officials, too, were puzzled over its appearance in Manikandam, range officer said that it could have travelled from Pudukottai or Sivagangai forest and entered Thuavarankurichi forest.

Title: Land acquisition: Social impact study soon
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Malappuram: The social impact study for the land acquisition for the development of parking area of Karippur International airport will begin soon in view of the protest against the land acquisition from the part of land owners.

A Kottayam based private organization is expected to submit the social impact study report within one month.

The authorities are planning to acquire a total of 15.5 acres in the premise of entry gate of the airport to set up ample parking areas. Authorities will acquire land with a width of 100m and length of 700m. The state transport department will hand over the acquired land to Airport Authority of India (AAI) for further development works.

But the local-level protest against the land acquisition process is still continuing. A group of land owners had staged blockade in front of the Kondotty village office in protest against the move to acquire the land. In view of protest, district collector is likely to convene a meeting in the coming days to discuss the issue with local protest.

Earlier the revenue authorities faced a similar protest when they started acquisition procedures of 137 acres in Pallikkal panchayat and the authorities launched a social impact study of the land acquisition in the area, aiming to address the issues of the local people who will be directly affected by the land acquisition.

It was in October 2016, that the government issued an order granting administrative sanction for 485.3 acres for the long-pending works of airport development. As per the order 248.3 acres would be acquired from Pulikkal, Kondotty and Nediyiruppu villages for the development of the runway of airport and 80 acres would be acquired from the same panchayat for rehabilitation of evictees. 137 acres would be acquired from Pallikkal village for the development of airport terminal.

Title: Grand agri expo begins in Chanda
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Chandrapur: “The rising number of farmer suicides is a cause for serious concern. Collective efforts are urgently needed to deal with the agrarian crisis,” said former MP and senior Congress leader Naresh Puglia.

At the Shetkari Mahosav held at Chanda Club ground, Puglia slammed the pathetic attitude of agriculture officers towards issues pertaining to the farm crisis prevailing in the state. “Officials need to visit farms to understand the hardships faced by farmers. Irregular rainfall and poor prices of agricultural produce have intensified the crisis,” he said.

Lauding the Kunbi Samaj Mandal for organizing such an innovative programme, Puglia said farmers definitely stand to gain from it.

A free heath check up camp was also organized with a team of 70 doctors rendering their services. Puglia inaugurated the agriculture expo in the presence of senior leader, Adv Babasheb Wasade, Zilla Parishad CEO Rahul Kardille, additional SP Prashant Khaire and district superintendent of agriculture, Dr Uday Patil. Thousands of farmers thronged the stalls at the expo to get information about the latest technology and equipment.

Title: In a first, drug dealer on Darknet nabbed
Content:
Representative image

NEW DELHI: For the first time, Narcotics Control Bureau (NCB) has arrested a vendor selling psychotropic drugs on the Darknet to students and businessmen and seized around 22,000 tablets from him. The arrested man, Deepu Singh, is a hotel management graduate from a private university in Noida.The operation is significant because Darknet markets and vendors are extremely difficult to track because the network provides complete anonymity to the buyer and seller. Anonymous connections are achieved by using end-to-end encryption. At times, agencies track down the receiver of consignments using their sources in courier firms, but the seller, almost always, manages to hoodwink them.Rajesh Nandan Srivastava, deputy director general of NCB, said the psychotropic drugs were being sold by the accused in the garb of erectile dysfunctional drugs, fitness supplements and health products. The drugs were not only being shipped across the country, but also to USA, UK, Romania, Spain and other European countries through courier.Singh was allegedly selling drugs on two Darknet markets — Empire market and Majestic Garden — and had over 80% positive reviews, indicating that he was operating for long and had a wide range of customers.“The network was spread across India, Singapore and USA. Global post offices and international courier services were used as logistics for illicit trade. The payments gateways of cryptocurrency (Bitcoin, Litecoin) were used by the operators to conceal transactions from law enforcement agencies,” zonal director KPS Malhotra said.After getting a tip-off, Darknet markets were accessed and vendors were profiled by NCB sleuths by analysing suspicious parcels evading KYC norms, Malhotra said. Singh was found to be a major player. His listings were found in one of the biggest and reliable markets. He was using various international couriers and global post office to ship the contraband.A few days ago, NCB officials intercepted a suspicious parcel from Air Cargo Logistic Centre located near New Custom House, Delhi. Singh was tracked using advanced surveillance techniques and nabbed from Lucknow.During investigation, police found past seizures of 33,000 tablets linked to this network. Singh revealed that he came in contact with a person in 2018 who was engaged in internet pharmacy and offered him a part-time job. Soon, Singh made his own network. The vendor accounts on Darknet (Empire Market) were managed by his associate, who is at large. The associate used to take the orders and send the details of the shipping address and quantity. Singh collected the stock of psychotropic drugs from various cities.Explaining Darknet, Malhotra said, “It is a black market operating via The Onion Router or Invisible Internet Project selling drugs, cyber arms, weapons, counterfeit currency, stolen credit card details, forged documents, unlicensed pharmaceuticals, steroids and other illicit goods.”

Title: Health minister announces ‘Navjaat Suraksha Yojna’ for neonates
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Jaipur: Aiming to bring down infant mortality rate (IMR), the health department is formulating a policy ‘Navjaat Suraksha Yojna’ for care of neonates. While attending a conference of kangaroo mother care at JK Lon Hospital in Jaipur on Sunday, health minister Raghu Sharma said that the health department will soon bring a policy for infants, who are born with low birth weight, malnutrition and those who are premature babies.

The new scheme for neonates will help in bringing down the infant mortality rate further. Aiming to improve healthcare facilities for neonates, the health department has decided to include kangaroo mother care in ‘Nirogi Rajasthan’ initiative of the state government.

“Aiming to prevent deaths of neonates, we will organise training programmes for kangaroo mother care in the state. We have 77 master trainers in kangaroo mother care and they will go to district and block level to train the healthcare staff,” said Sharma.

The health department is promoting the technique claiming that it provides continuous skin-to-skin contact between mother and baby and exclusive breastmilk feeding to keep the baby healthy.

In the state, the infant mortality rate is 35 deaths per 1,000 live births. According to the National Family Health Survey 2015-16, the IMR in the state was 41 deaths per 1,000 live births. The health department is aiming to bring down IMR further by formulating a ‘ Navjaat Suraksha Yojna’, Nirohi Rajasthan and initiatives like kangaroo mother care.

SMS Medical College principal and controller Dr Sudhir Bhandari said that kangaroo mother care is a natural incubator.

The health department is promoting it as it does not require separate funds. “It is a low-cost technique which is highly practical and has potential to save millions of new-borns without any burden on healthcare cost. This technique is still underutilised and if utilised properly, can save many lives. We have been using the technique for the past few years at JK Lon Hospital and now we have trained doctors and nurses in the past three days here at the hospital came to take part in the conference,” said Dr Ramesh Choudhary, associate professor (paediatrics), JK Lon hospital.

“It is just like putting a child in warmer, which is a mechanical care, but it is a humanised care with better results,” said Dr Choudhary, who was part of organising team of the conference on kangaroo mother care (KMCCON 2020).

Title: Spurious milk sale: 3 arrested
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Jaipur: Jaipur Rural police arrested three persons and seized a stolen tanker carrying 24,000 litres of milk in Phagi police station area.

Police also recovered the instrument used for breaking the seal of the tanker apart from two drums of milk which had been taken out of the tanker.

“For the last six months, we have been conducting an operation to catch those who are involved in selling adulterated goods, including milk and fuel. The Amul dairy tanker seized on Sunday was supposed to go Manesar. We caught the accused when they were in the process of taking out the milk after breaking the seal of the tanker,” said Shankar Dutt Sharma, SP, Jaipur Rural.

The three accused were identified as Raj Jat, 25, Maan Singh, 41, and Dharam Raj, 19.

According to officials, the modus operandi followed by these accused was that first they would break the seal and take out the milk. Following this they would add water in the tankers to maintain its quantity. They would add three times water in milk which they have already taken out of the tanker and then sell it in the market.

“The drivers of the milk tankers are hand in glove with dhaba owners and others in selling the adulterated product in the markets. The onus is on the milk companies and suppliers to test the milk when it reaches the processing units, but that is not being done. Also, the tankers are fitted with GPS and the companies must track the movement of the vehicles and check if there are any unwarranted stops. It is not the job of police to check such activities, the companies must take initiatives on their own to prevent adulterated goods being sold in the markets as they are posing a risk to the consumer’s health,” the official added.

Title: Sports complex plan at Pratap Nagar shelved
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Jaipur: The proposal to develop a sports complex in Pratap Nagar on Rajasthan Housing Board (RHB) land has been shelved.

Urban Development Housing (UDH) minister Shanti Dhariwal has directed to hold the project after the Jaipur Development Authority (JDA) proposed to develop the stadium in Chop village on Delhi road.

The RHB had earlier proposed to develop a sports complex on a 133-bigha land in Indra Gandhi Nagar extension. In the complex, the board had proposed to include a cricket stadium, basketball, volleyball and badminton courts, a swimming pool, archery and shooting ranges of international standard.

A senior official source said, “Priority is to develop a stadium at Chop on the directions of the UDH minister.”

As the land on which sports complex was proposed fall under the ecological zone , the RHB has planned to prepare the detailed project report (DPR) of the complex. Work, however, will be initiated after receiving direction from the state government.

Sources said the JDA had earmarked around 35 hectares in Chop village on Jaipur-Delhi national highway for developing a new stadium.

The land was identified after receiving a letter from the Rajasthan Cricket Association (RCA).

According to a senior JDA official, during the previous Congress tenure, the civic body had allotted nearly 18.16 hectares to RCA in Chop village in 2012. However, the then BJP government cancelled the allotment in 2017 claiming that the academy did not adhere to the terms and conditions.

An official source said, “The state government has directed to revoke the cancellation. It has also identified adjoining 17 hectares to develop a stadium.”

Sources said according to the previous agreement, the land to RCA was allotted with a condition that the academy will hand over the club house (situated in SMS stadium) to JDA. However, the RCA refused to honour the agreement.

The RCA proposed to develop a capacity to seat 30,000 people for an approximate budget of Rs 500 crore in the first phase. The stadium was to also have a multi-cuisine food court and a sports medical university.

Title: Hidden agenda in rising state lottery prices: Chandy
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: Former chief minister Oommen Chandy has alleged hidden agenda in increasing the prices of state lotteries from Rs 30 to Rs 40.

“The agenda is to invite other state lotteries and thereby increase the revenue of the state through this. Already there is a favourable verdict from the high court for other state lotteries to do business in the state. Hence by increasing the prices of state lotteries, the other state lotteries will thrive in Kerala ,” said Chandy.

Already the state lottery business is facing severe crisis. Now with the increase in prices, the other state lotteries will be sold much cheaper than our lotteries. This will also affect lakhs of people who are totally dependent on the lottery business. When the prices are increased, the business will be affected and sales will come down. Mizoram lotteries are priced much lower than our lottery. They are waiting for a chance to come back to the state to do thriving business.

The LDF government has always taken a soft stand towards other state lotteries and hence the state will soon witness this once again. It was the UDF government which banned other state lotteries, said Chandy. TNN

Title: CR collects Rs18.32 crore fine in 10 months
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Nagpur: The Central railway (CR) has collected Rs18.32 crores in fine from passengers travelling without or irregular tickets and also unreserved luggage in 10 months from April last year to January 2020, which is a rise of 17% as compared to penalties slapped during the same period last financial year.

In January, the CR’s fine collection was Rs1.69 crore which too is an increase of 16.4% for the same month in 2019.

The CR authorities, in a press release, underlined that increase in actions from 3,42,802 lakh between April 2018 and January 2019 to 4,09,512 during the period between April last year to January this year. This is 19.5% increase in actions taken under the supervision of divisional railway manager (DRM) Somesh Kumar, senior divisional commercial manager Krishnath Patil and asst divisional commercial manager HK Behera.

The CR’s crack down on the ticketless riders was stepped up in 2019 and there is no let up this year too. During the period between April last year to January this year, CR’s special drives had resulted in detection of 72,311 cases of ticketless travelling in which fine of Rs4.23 crore was collected.

Title: Citizens enjoy classical ragas, santoor at Brahmanaad
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Nagpur: Classical vocalist Sugandha Laturkar from Chennai showcased finer details of Hindustani classical singing at the ‘Brahmanaad’ event organized by South Central Zone Cultural Centre on February 9 on Sunday morning. The magical strains of the santoor also reverberated through the hall later with Pandit Valmik Dhande bringing the morning to an end with a flourish.

Nothing matches the soothing sound of sargam and alaap in the crisp early morning, which gives a fresh start to the day and triggers emotions that captivate music lovers. Listening to the mellifluous morning recitals has become a part of routine for music lovers in the city on first Sunday of every month.

Clad in a deep purple sari, Laturkar spread magic with her high-pitched vocals and ragas, which left the audience asking for more. She began her performance with a alaap and presented a bahaduri todi in rupak taal, ‘Mahadev devnapati parwati pati’. Then she chose a beautiful bandish in raag Ahilya Bilawal, and presented a bandish ‘Ja re ja re ja kagwa’. She later presented an engaging tarana in raag Vibhas, ‘Tarwa ginat mein toh rain gawai’. She ended her classical recital with a nirguni spiritual bhajan ‘Sadho yeh tan baat tambure ka’.

Each raag and tarana went perfectly with the serene atmosphere of the morning hours. The programme was organized inside the SCZCC hall this Sunday, to protect the audience from chilly breeze, and the threat of showers, but made the experience warmer and cosier for music lovers.

Laturkar was accompanied by husband Vinay on the tabla, Shrikant Pise on harmonium, and Ankita Samdale on tanpura, giving perfect support of instrumental music to her melodious voice.

After the hall had been soaked in the classical recitals, the much awaited performance of the morning was staged by famous santoor player Pandit Valmik Dhande. His fingers on the santoor spread magic, soaking the audience in blissful music. He chose classical ragas for the morning and left the audience impressed.

Dhande presented raag Parmeshwari and ended his instrumental performance with raag Bhairavi. He was accompanied by Ram Khadse on the tabla.The duo kept the audience glued to their seats. The programme was anchored by Shweta Shelgaonkar.

Title: CCP’s lease contract for mkt tenants ready
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Panaji: Corporation of the City of Panaji ( CCP ) will hold a special meeting this month to decide on many contentious issues, including the long-pending signing of a 30-year lease with tenants at the municipal market and the relocation of confiscated food carts.

The meeting to finalise the signing of agreements with tenants was scheduled for February 5, but was postponed after CCP’s legal team wasn’t ready with the new draft lease agreement. “The final agreement, valid for 30 years, is now ready. We will approve it at a special meeting this month,” mayor Uday Madkaikar said.

With no agreements signed, the cash-strapped corporation hasn’t been receiving any rent money from shop owners in the market since the first phase was constructed in 2003, and the second phase in 2007. Ironically, sopo fees (a charge for space occupied by vendors) are collected regularly from fruit, vegetable and flower vendors in the market.

Last month, CCP commissioner Sanjit Rodrigues blamed the corporation for entertaining objections from the market association, and for the association wavering between signing a lease or a leave-and-license agreement with CCP.

Madaikar said permission for the confiscated food carts to continue operating, their relocation will also be decided at the special CCP meet. Seventeen food carts at Don Bosco and 23 carts from Miramar continue to be confiscated for not maintaining hygiene.

Title: Two admitted to isolation ward in Koz
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Kozhikode: Two persons who arrived from novel coronavirus-hit countries were admitted to Kozhikode Beach General Hospital here on Sunday. The beach hospital dispatched their swab samples to the NIV lab at Alappuzha Government Medical College Hospital. The beach hospital authorities have informed that two of them were admitted with mild fever.

With the admission of the two persons, the total number of persons in the isolation ward at beach hospital has risen to three.

The health department authorities have also kept 11 persons who arrived to Kozhikode from coronavirus-hit countries on Sunday under home quarantine. With this, the total number of persons under home quarantine in the district has risen to 389.

District medical officer Dr V Jayashree said that out of the 24 swabs dispatched for test so far, 21 of them tested negative for novel coronavirus infection.

Meanwhile, only seven patients are under hospital-based surveillance in Thrissur district where the first nCoV positive case in the country was detected. Out of the seven patients, three are at medical college hospital, two are at the general hospital at Chalakkudy, one is at the general hospital at Kodungallur and one at a private hospital in Thrissur city. TNN

Title: 16 killed, 64 injured in road accidents during rains last yr
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Nagpur: Sixteen people were killed and 64 injured in 66 road accidents that occurred during rains in 2019 in the jurisdiction of the city police commissionerate.

Around 89.57% of the 1,007 road accidents happened when the weather was clear. These facts came to the fore after a study carried out by Nagpur city traffic police to gauge the impact of the weather on road accidents.

In 2019, traffic police started investigating road accidents comprehensively. Details of the weather conditions were also taken into account.

Until 2018, while registering cases of road accidents, the police mentioned only few details like the name of the victim, time and the spot. But 2019 onwards, every police station in the city has started filling reports in an 18-point format.

The study included time, day and place of the incident, details of the vehicle or vehicles involved, traffic rule violation (s), vehicle make, type of accident (fatal, grievous or minor), type of road (national or state highway or service road), nature of road (narrow, turning, slope, speed breaker at intersection, pothole ridden, puncture or none) and other factors like the state of the vehicle and environmental conditions like smog, rain, darkness or sunlight.

The traffic police recently completed its analysis on the weather’s impact on road accidents from January 1 to December 31 in 2019. The accident analysis of clear skies as well as the monsoon indicates that motorists are more careful on roads during rainy days.

Instances of rash and negligent driving increase during clear weather. As many 902 road accidents, including 207 fatal, took place when the weather was clear. These accidents claimed 224 lives and injured 941. Nearly 66 accidents occurred due to rains and claimed 16 lives. According to the study, four accidents happened due to the foggy weather that killed one person and injured three.

Weather —A—F—K—I

Sunny/Clear—902—207—224—941

Rainy—66—16—16—64

Fog—4—1—1—3

Others—35—9—9—34

A= Accidents, F=Fatal Accidents, K=Killed, I=Injured

Title: Kozhikode tops in H1N1 cases in Kerala in 2019
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Representational Photo

KOZHIKODE: Kozhikode district had the maximum number of H1N1 patients in Kerala in 2019, reveals the data published by the state health department.

It’s for the second consecutive year that the district has topped in reporting maximum number of H1N1 cases and deaths in the state.

According to health department authorities, the state had reported a total of 853 H1N1 cases and 45 deaths from January 1, 2019 to December 31. Out of these, 142 cases and seven deaths were reported from Kozhikode district. In 2018 too, the district had the highest number of H1N1 cases in the state, 161 cases and six deaths.

The experts in the field have opined that the effective surveillance mechanism established in the district from the grassroots level to district level following the Nipah virus outbreak was the reason for the timely detection of H1N1 cases. The health department authorities have opined that they have put in place an effective surveillance mechanism covering each local self-government bodies in the district after the 2018 Nipah virus outbreak, treat each case of fever and other symptoms with utmost care and collect swabs from suspected patients. This has resulted in the accurate detection of the H1N1 cases.

H1N1 district nodal officer Dr C J Michel said that the number of H1N1 cases decreased in Kozhikode in 2019, compared to 2018. “The district medical officer here has put in place an effective surveillance mechanism to ensure the daily reporting of the communicable diseases after the Nipah outbreak. Even private hospitals provide data daily in case patients with suspected symptoms of H1N1 approach them for treatment. The health field staff of grassroots level immediately reports the disease on it detection to avoid further spreading,’’ he said, adding that continuous health awareness and screening programmes by the health department covering all schools, high risk and vulnerable groups have also helped in the timely detection of the cases.

Title: Exploring Alavi Bohra culture
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Vadodara: Nearly 50 heritage enthusiasts walked through the narrow bylanes of the old city to explore Alavi Bohra heritage in the city on Sunday evening.

The walk organised jointly by the Heritage Trust, Vadodara and Alavi Bohra community gave the participants have an opportunity to have a look at the old Mohalla culture which dates back to almost 550 years in and around old city.

The walk that started from the main masjid of Badri mohalla included a tour to houses that are 75 years to 90 year old but are still preserving the essence of the Bohra culture. The participants not only got an opportunity to see how Bohra topis are weaved by a family but some of them even purchased some as memoirs of the walk.

Later, the heritage enthusiasts got an opportunity to dine in Bohra style as they were served Bohra cuisine, both vegetarian and non-vegetarian, on ‘thaals’. The heritage walk, second such attempt after 2015, this time focused on ethnic eating style.

Title: GHMC lags behind in collecting taxes from advertising agencies
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

The GHMC has also approached the court against the advertisers

HYDERABAD: The Greater Hyderabad Municipal Corporation (GHMC) has failed to collect Rs 92 crore in taxes from advertising agencies across the city. As per the norms, the GHMC is mandated to collect Rs 6,000 per annum as tax for the advertisements displayed on RTC buses. However, records reveal that four years of the contract, which is for five years, have already been completed.

Activists allege that the GHMC has been ignoring its statutory obligation of taxing ad agencies. “I have complained to the authorities regarding the posters but in vain. GHMC should answer why they are not collecting the pending advertisement tax,” said Shyamsunder Goud, president, Telangana Vanarula Parirakshana Committee.

Besides ads on buses, lollipop hoardings on central medians have also been put up illegally. Agencies that used to secretly operate at night are now erecting them in broad daylight, said sources.

According to sources, after the contract of an ad agency expired in 2011, the agency approached the court and got a stay order and put up additional lollipop hoardings in violation of norms. As per GHMC records, since 2011, ad agencies have not been paying taxes.

The GHMC has also approached the court against the advertisers. A source in GHMC said that the advertisement agencies are backed by politicians.

Title: Artificial grounds at Delhi's Siri Fort Sports complex will ruin green areas: Plea
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Delhi high court

NEW DELHI: Delhi high court has put on hold Delhi Development Authority’s (DDA) bid to build synthetic football and hockey grounds in Siri Fort Sports complex , after a member of the facility challenged the move.

In his plea, the member — who also lives nearby — argued that the construction of artificial grounds for the sports will entail destruction of green areas of the complex and cutting down of grown trees.

When the court sought to know DDA’s stand, the authority, which runs the sports facility, gave an undertaking that it won’t cut any trees till the next date of hearing.

The petition by Sudhir Gupta complained that without consulting the members, users and players of the complex, DDA had suddenly begun construction for the artificial grounds.

The plea says that such a move will destroy and damage the greenest part of the entire complex, “which will involve uprooting or cutting innumerable trees all around the natural mud jogging track.”

Urging the court to stay the revamp plan, the petition informs the court that DDA’s bid will also involve conversion of lush green grass football and hockey grounds into artificial synthetic grounds by cutting the trees, bushes and shrubs “and in the process damaging and destroying the huge green patch, also known as the lungs of South Delhi.”

Gupta’s plea points out that the existing set-up of the sports facility is unlike other football grounds, which are professionally used and don’t usually have any trees or bushes of any kind.

“In the Siri Fort Sports Complex, the grounds are surrounded by beautiful mud track with hundreds of trees. The jogging track is used by large number of its members. In fact, after Lodi Gardens, it is the most popular green jogging track,” the petition underlines, saying it needs to be protected and maintained as a legacy.

Alleging that DDA’s decision has been taken in a “totally arbitrary and unfair” manner, the petition says the authority neither shared the kind of process and raw material that they intend to use for the two fields nor consulted the members of the complex who are stakeholders and directly concerned with the conversion of the turf.

If allowed to go unchallenged, such a move violates not just the petitioner’s fundamental rights but also violates other constitutional and statutory right to enjoy pollution free environment, Gupta’s plea says.

Title: CCI launches probe into cotton sales in Andhra Pradesh
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Picture used for representational purpose

GUNTUR: The Cotton Corporation of India (CCI) has launched an investigation into allegations about irregularities in purchase of cotton from farmers.

A team of vigilance officials from Cotton Corporation of India’s New Delhi office are visiting cotton purchase centres in the district and inspecting the records. Sources said the vigilance team has unearthed irregularities by field staff and is looking at the possible role of senior officials. The CBI had booked criminal cases against a few senior officers two years ago.

Sources said the CCI and marketing department officials had connived with ginning millers to procure stocks from unauthorized purchase centres by rejecting farmers’ stocks. With the CCI officials refusing to procure the stocks citing technical reasons and procurement norms, farmers were selling their stock to middlemen at throwaway prices. The middlemen sell the same stock to the ginning mills who in turn offer it to the CCI. The CCI officials, however, have completed purchase in the name of farmers to pay higher sums.

While middlemen and ginning mills buy cotton from farmers between Rs 3,500-Rs 4,000 per quintal, the Cotton Corporation of India is purchasing it between Rs 5000-Rs 5550 per quintal, the minimum support price (MSP) fixed by the Centre.

Sources allege that middlemen and officials are pocketing nearly Rs 1,500-Rs 1,600 per quintal. Curiously traders bought stocks at Rs 6,000 per quintal, above the MSP, as fresh crop arrived in the market in December. The prices then dipped below MSP resulting in distress sale by farmers.

The fall in prices in the open market is believed to be the result of a conspiracy by middlemen, ginning millers and officials. Traders stopped buying from farmers by the time the peak procurement season commenced in the first week of January.

Although the farmers rushed to the CCI purchase centres, they could not sell the stocks due to several hurdles including failure to get e-crop booking certificate, high moisture level and length of the lintel.

Taking this distress among the farmers to their advantage, middlemen bought stocks below Rs 4000 per quintal and sold the same to the Cotton Corporation of India at MSP with nearly Rs 1,500 profit. “Our officials will ensure quality of the stock. It is the responsibility of the marketing department to give us the list of genuine farmers. We are here to support the farmers,” said Cotton Corporation of India general manager K Maheswara Reddy.

Title: Government plans rice cards for BPL families to end PDS misuse
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Picture used for representational purpose

AMARAVATI: In a bid to end diversion and recycling of rice distributed through Public Distribution System (PDS), the government will issue rice cards for BPL families . About 19 lakh ration cards are expected to be weeded out from the existing list. The district administrations are gearing up for the distribution of new rice cards to the eligible families.

Interestingly, rice cards were delinked from Arogyasri and other government welfare schemes.

After studying the ration scheme in the last six months, the government found that about 10 lakh cardholders were not drawing ration regularly. Besides, many ration dealers were found resorting to malpractices by purchase of rice from the cardholders and selling the same stock to the millers.

The government also noticed that huge quantities of PDS rice was sold in the black market and recycled to public at higher prices. While the government is giving rice to the BPL families at Rs.1 per kg, the millers are selling the rice at Rs.15-20 per kg in open market. Hoteliers and street vendors are buying the low quality PDS rice from the millers as the fine variety rice is available only between Rs.45-Rs55 per kg.

“We carried out a survey to identify the eligible families for disbursement of rice cards. The old concept of ration card is over now,” said civil supplies minister Kodali Srivenkateswara Rao (Nani). He said that lists have been published in village and ward secretariats and the government has taken feedback from people. He said they have received objections from two lakh people and is conducting verification. The minister said that no eligible family would be denied ration.

The government had relaxed norms to get rice cards even after delinking it from Arogyasri and fee reimbursement cards. The government is issuing separate cards for Arogyasri and fee reimbursement schemes.

Since the ration card was the only criterion for all BPL schemes in the past, several people had secured ration cards although many of them were not drawing the ration. The government is expecting that the new concept of rice cards would bring the irregularities to an end.

“We will issue new ration cards within five days of filing an application in the village and ward secretariat,” said civil supplies commissioner Kona Sasidhar .

He said that the administration will launch the household distribution of rice in one assembly segment in each district from April and cover all the 175 constituencies by August. Sasidhar said that the government will supply quality rice through rice cards to all BPL families.

Title: 12-year-old boy electrocuted in Hyderabad
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Representative image

HYDERABAD: A 12-year-old boy was electrocuted to death after he came in contact with a live wire while scaling the compound wall of Film Nagar Cultural Center (FNCC) on Sunday.

Banjara Hills police said that the deceased, a Class 6 student and resident of Durga Bhavani colony near FNCC, entered the FNCC premises by scaling the compound wall to collect a few tennis balls from the tennis court.

While he was leaving the premises by climbing the compound wall, he came in contact with the high-tension wire. Police rushed to the spot and disconnected the power supply after an FNCC staff member noticed the boy in trouble and alerted the police. However, the boy had died.

“One of the FNCC staff members noticed smoke emanating from a live wire and a boy stuck to it from far away, after which he alerted the police,” sub-inspector Ravi Raj told TOI, and added that the boy entered FNCC with the support of a locked gate at the rear side of the compound wall. “While returning, he took the support of a table, which was kept at the tennis court, to scale the wall. The boy had come to steal the balls from the court,” the SI said.

Police said that the compound wall was well-constructed and the electricity department officials have sealed the area around the transformer near the wall.

The boy’s father had passed away several months ago and his mother works as a maid. Police have registered a case under Section 174 (suspicious death) of CrPc.

Title: CLC state convention held in Vizag
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Visakhapatnam: The Civil Liberties Committee ( CLC ) on Saturday conducted a state convention in the city. Around 120 representatives from 13 districts participated in the convention. Various issues pertaining to the state were discussed. The new general body was also elected.

Some resolutions were unanimously approved by the State House of Representatives of the CLC. They asked for repealing of Citizenship Amendment Act. They also opposed any privatization move of the Visakha Port Trust. The CLC opposed the government’s acquisition of land allotted to poor people for land use for capital construction in Vizag and demanded the GO issued for that purpose to be withdrawn immediately.

Further, the CLC demanded that the government should provide free medical services to the kidney ailments victims in Uddanam area and provide relief to affected families. They also demanded uranium mining should be stopped in the Telugu states. The government should take immediate steps to prevent farmers’ suicides in the state, especially in Rayalaseema region and forest rights of adivasis should be protected.

Title: Man attacked by elephant in CTR
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Nainital: A man was attacked by an elephant while he was riding a bike in Gujjar Basti inside the Corbett Tiger Reserve (CTR). The manmanaged to escape with some injuries to his waist and legs.

It was only when other Van Gujjars came to the man’s help and scared the animal away that he was able to save himself, CTR director Rahul said. “He had fallen in the bushes, screaming. Several others heard him and scared the animal away,” said Rahul. The incident accentuates the man-elephant conflict that has been escalating of late in areas near CTR.

Title: New technique helps save 80-yr-old heart patient
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Jodhpur: An 80-year-old heart patient had his heart blockages removed by using Intravascular Shock Wave Lithotripsy technique, a technique introduced in the country recently. According to Sanjeev Sanghvi, HoD (Cardiology), MDM Hospital is one of the few hospitals in India, which have used this technique. Barely a day before this, similar procedure was administered in Indore.

Sharing the details of the case, Sanghvi said that patient Chandra Shekhar Bohra had come to the hospital with a complaint of panting while walking and pain in the chest.

“When we examined the patient, we found three blockages in his coronary arteries after angiography but there were multiple limitations that made it difficult to administer either angioplasty or bypass surgery as all blockages were calcified,” said Sanghvi.

Without breaking the calcium deposit, even the stents would not have entered the blocked arteries and even if they entered, they would not have dilated properly, rendering the procedure worthless.

Sanghvi said that usually elderly patients have more calcium deposit and intervention at higher age is always a risk. “So we decided to use the all-new technology , the Intravascular Shock Wave Lithotripsy, to de-calcify the arteries before proceeding with stent installation. We successfully conducted the entire procedure in 45 minutes,” said Sanghvi, adding that three stents have been installed in the patient in the blockages and the patient is recovering fast.

Associate professor (Cardiology) Pawan Sarda said that the balloon in this technique carried an ultra-sonic transmitter, which emitted Sonic Pressure Waves, which broke the calcium deposit in the arteries.

“This technique breaks calcium, making stent implantation easier and stents are properly expanded,” he said adding that the team of doctors conducted the procedure without any external assistance.

He said that this technique was first introduced in the US in June 2017 and had come to India on January 11 this year.

Title: Mumbai: In testing times, coaching centres join hands to share faculty and expertise
Content:
Representative image

MUMBAI: Coaching campuses , like many other businesses, are passing through testing times. With their backs to the walls, they have come up with a new model for tuition classes.A dozen tutorials have joined hands in a mega Mumbai experiment to share faculty , experience and expertise, thus birthing ‘Edumentors’ out of the crisis. The core mission of these 12, who serve different parts of the city, is to share the big bill of faculty pay so that they do not have to cut corners. “We share our faculty and notes, our stationery supplier is the same and so is the man who furnishes our classes with tables and benches. The interior designer is the same. Coming together and sharing has been a celebration,” said Govindraj Chettiar , one of the directors of Raju Sir’s Academy .The experiment is spreading. In Thane, Logical Academy, Excel Classes and Karnavat Coaching , which were all running three commerce self-financing courses with small batch sizes, joined hands to offer one course each. “Instead of cutting costs and running courses for 10 or 15 students, we decided to divide the market. Now each of us only takes one course. Students wanting to study BMS come to Karnavat, Logical Academy only teaches BAF and Excel picked the BBI programme,” said Sachin Karnavat.With a tagline, “Let’s merge to emerge”, the Maharashtra Coaching Classes Owners’ Association (MCCOA) seems to have found a way out of the crisis. “Of the 98,000 coaching classes in Maharashtra, 40% are operating at a loss or are just managing to break even,” said president Sachin Karnavat.Now, consolidation is paying off. Four classes in Dombivli have broken down the walls of rivalry and prudently realigned. Amol Damle of Samarth Classes, Anand Subramanium of A’s Academy, Virchand Maisheri and Vijay Gawas came together to jointly offer tuitions for class XI, XII and CA and CS courses.It’s not a rosy picture yet. With student enrolment plummeting, discounts are the order of the day. “Almost 90% of the classes are not getting the sticker price of their courses though most have not upped fees from last year,” said Narendra Bambwani, former MCCOA secretary. Fees at his Reliable Classes are down 25%. The reasons are many. Some students don’t join a class for the first term and sign up only for the final term, others turn to app tutorials. “Also, it is now easier to pass because of internal tests and the emphasis on objective questions. The choice in question exams has increased. Students in many subjects are asked to answer three questions of six,” added Bambwani.The hyper competition in the market, with the introduction of digital platforms, has disrupted the tutorials business. “When parents come for admission, they demand discounts and if we don’t budge, we lose the student to a cheaper competitor or a home-maker who is running private tuitions out of home,” said Prajesh Trotsky, consultant to several coaching classes.Unemployment has proved a double-edge sword for the business. “The ones without jobs are starting tuitions to teach and earn. And those with children are not sending kids to classes because of unemployment or poor pay cheques. Then, some students are moving to tech and online tutorials. Schemes like ‘pay-for-XII-get-XI-free’ abound in the market,” he added. Every student enrolled is a battle won and some are willing to go to any extent to get them.

Title: Collect feedback from complainants, says Kerala DGP
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Kerala DGP Loknath Behera

THIRUVANANTHAPURAM: In a welcome move, the police department will soon introduce a system through which people can give their feedback to senior police officers on the action taken by police based on their complaints.

State police chief Loknath Behera has directed all district police chiefs to randomly chose 10 people everyday from among those who file complaints before local police stations under their jurisdiction and speak to them directly over the phone. This move is expected to increase efficiency of the local police when dealing with case. It is also expected to improve the behaviour of policemen towards complainants as it would allow the latter a chance to share any bitter experience they had while visiting police stations.

In a statement issued on Sunday, Behera said that all district police chiefs must randomly choose 10 complainants from their limits and speak to them. Similarly, the deputy inspectors general in charge of ranges and inspectors generals in charge of zones must also call 10 complainants every day. Behera and the additional director general of police (Law and Order) will also be doing the same. Henceforth, people are requested to provide their phone number too along with the complainant in order to effectively implement this system. The new system will come into effect as the state government will declare police stations as service delivery centres.

The DGP said that thousands of complaints of various nature are received at police stations across the state every day. Efforts are on to digitize details of these complaints following the lines of Crime and Criminal Tracking Network in which digital records of active cases are made available to all police stations. Once the system of real-time digitization of complaints is realized, it will be easy for senior officers to accesss these datas on their fingertips and contact the complainants. Collecting feedbacks from the complainants on a daily basis will help the department assess the quality of services provided through police stations and also introduce necessary changes in their functions if needed, Behera said.

Once the system of real-time digitization of complaints is realized, it will be easy for senior officers to accesss these datas on their fingertips and contact the complainants. Collecting feedbacks from the complainants on a daily basis will help the department assess the quality of services provided through police stations and also introduce necessary changes in their functions if needed, Behera said.

Title: Collect feedback from complainants, says Kerala DGP
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Kerala DGP Loknath Behera

THIRUVANANTHAPURAM: In a welcome move, the police department will soon introduce a system through which people can give their feedback to senior police officers on the action taken by police based on their complaints.

State police chief Loknath Behera has directed all district police chiefs to randomly chose 10 people everyday from among those who file complaints before local police stations under their jurisdiction and speak to them directly over the phone. This move is expected to increase efficiency of the local police when dealing with case. It is also expected to improve the behaviour of policemen towards complainants as it would allow the latter a chance to share any bitter experience they had while visiting police stations.

In a statement issued on Sunday, Behera said that all district police chiefs must randomly choose 10 complainants from their limits and speak to them. Similarly, the deputy inspectors general in charge of ranges and inspectors generals in charge of zones must also call 10 complainants every day. Behera and the additional director general of police (Law and Order) will also be doing the same. Henceforth, people are requested to provide their phone number too along with the complainant in order to effectively implement this system. The new system will come into effect as the state government will declare police stations as service delivery centres.

The DGP said that thousands of complaints of various nature are received at police stations across the state every day. Efforts are on to digitize details of these complaints following the lines of Crime and Criminal Tracking Network in which digital records of active cases are made available to all police stations. Once the system of real-time digitization of complaints is realized, it will be easy for senior officers to accesss these datas on their fingertips and contact the complainants. Collecting feedbacks from the complainants on a daily basis will help the department assess the quality of services provided through police stations and also introduce necessary changes in their functions if needed, Behera said.

More than 300 birds were identified by the participants at different venues.

Title: Delhi: More facilities, less wait at new AIIMS OPD block
Content:
Masjid Moth campus

NEW DELHI: More than 50 years after its establishment, All India Institute of Medical Sciences (AIIMS) is all set to undergo the biggest infrastructural overhaul. The Raj Kumari Amrit Kaur OPD block on the main campus will be relocated to the new building at Masjid Moth , located about half a kilometre away from the main campus.TOI recently visited the upcoming eight-storey facility where workers could be seen giving final touches and fixing the fitments.“The old OPD block had outlived its utility. It wasn’t able to cope with the patient load. Therefore, the institute decided to build a new one. It is a truly modern building with disabled-friendly services, such as separate counters for the specially abled and a ramp for wheelchairs and trolleys, among others,” said Dr Arti Vij, chairman, media protocol division, AIIMS.Vij added that the new block would be made operational in two phases. The first phase, starting February 10, will involve shifting of OPDs for general medicine , endocrinology and orthopaedics, among others. In the second phase, a fully-automated core lab with capacity to handle over two lakh tests daily will be made operational.“There are nine lifts for patients in the new block, three for staff and one for equipment. Also, there is a queue management system, which will be enrolled in the second phase,” said another official.Over 8,000 patients from across the country visit the AIIMS OPD daily. Currently, the OPD services are run from Raj Kumari Amrit Kaur OPD Block, which came up in 1950s. It is overcrowded and patients are often found squatting on the floor. The new block is designed to serve better, an official said.“The new building will have a dedicated lab for OPD patients to increase the number of tests and decrease waiting time. It will also have a waiting area, minor operation theatres and resuscitation facilities on each floor,” said the official.The doctors at the hospital said that shifting outpatient department services would help decongest the main hospital and allow for better management of inpatient facilities. “The existing OPD may be utilised to expand emergency medicine and other inpatient departments, depending on the need assessments,” said a senior doctor.In addition to the OPD block, the Masjid Moth campus in south Delhi will also house the upcoming mother-and-child and surgical blocks. The authorities said both the buildings were ready and furnishing and equipment installation under way. All these projects, he added, were conceptualised long ago and the construction work started between 2014 and 2015.

Title: Constitution, Gandhi and Bharat Nirman parks to come up in Bikaner varsity
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

The Bharat Nirman Park at the varsity will have statues of national heroes like Swami Vivekananda, Chandrashek... Read More

JAIPUR: Taking cognizance of the rising unrest among university students over different issues, the Maharaja Ganga Singh University (MGSU), Bikaner, has established a constitution park.

While work on Gandhi Park and Bharat Nirman Park is under progress, aiming to educate students on the Constitution and to re-introduce national ethos and values to them.

The university has claimed to have taken first-of-its-kind initiative in the country for having three unique parks.

The MGSU is one of the country’s biggest (in terms of land) university spread in 1,183 acres. The Constitution park welcomes you with a signage taking you through circular walkways with important articles of the Constitution carved on black plaques. The plaques have the preamble, fundamental duties, directive principles, roles of important people in drafting of the Constitution along with important portions. The park came up on a sandy land. It concludes with an Ashok Stambh right behind the 100-feet tall national flag. The park is almost ready with work in its final stages.

“The way university students are engaged in heated debates over CAA, NRC and other issues. It becomes important for us as an institute to tell them what is right and wrong in the light of the Constitution. This exercise will keep students informed, which will eventually help in taking right decisions,” said Bitthal Bissa, deputy registrar of MGSU.

The Bharat Nirman Park will have statues of national heroes like Swami Vivekananda, Chandrashekar Azad, Bhagat Singh and Subhash Chandra Bose. The park is 100 metres in length and 50 metres wide with all the information on these heroes. Every statue will be erected on a five-metre platform. The most ambitious project is to create Gandhi Park. “The aim is to take Gandhiji beyond his statue. This park will have Gandhiji’s important visits like round table conferences in London, important movements—Satyagraha, Civil Disobedience and his role in the freedom movement. It will be in pictorial and illustration formats,” Bissa said.

Title: Coronavirus: Navy officer from Doon, chef from Tehri admitted in AIIMS
Content: Dehradun: Two patients — a 34-year-old Navy officer and a 38-year-old chef from Tehri Garhwal — are the latest to have been admitted to AIIMS Rishikesh with symptoms of suspected coronavirus Providing details, Harish Thapliyal, public relations officer, AIIMS Rishikesh said that the naval officer, who is a resident of Dehradun, had travelled from Taiwan to Tianjin in China by ship recently.“He stayed in the ship from January 22 to January 24, and then boarded a return flight from Bangkok to Delhi. He travelled to Dehradun on the same day and started developing dry cough with sore throat, nasal discharge, and nasal blockade on February 6, which is barely 10 days after his visit to the ship,” said Thapliyal.Doctors at AIIMS found that the patient, brought to the hospital on Saturday night, was also complaining of fever since the past three days and was having chills. However, he had no history of breathlessness, chest pain, nausea or vomiting.“We are suspecting coronavirus infection in the officer. We have sent his reports to a test lab in Pune along with the samples of a 38-year-old man from Tehri Garhwal who works as a chef in Shanghai city in China and had come back to India on January 5,” Thapliyal said.Talking about the details of the second patient, Thapliyal said that he is working in China since 10 years and was brought to the hospital with complaints of fever and sore throat.“He has no history of visits to crowded market places preceding two weeks during his stay in Shanghai city and no history of contact with any known sick persons there. But we have sent his samples, too, for testing just to be 100 per cent sure that he has not been infected,” said the PRO.Since January, AIIMS Rishikesh has received seven suspected coronavirus cases. While the reports of initial three cases were negative, another person was kept in the isolation ward for observation for some time and later discharged, and his samples were not sent. The hospital is still awaiting the reports of an 11-year-old who was admitted last week, along with the two cases whose samples were sent for testing on Sunday.

Title: AP sets big incentives for industry in draft policy
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Vijayawada: The draft Industrial Promotion and Export Promotion policy 2020-25 of the AP government has forecast a substantial increase in incentives to Rs 4,638 crore from the Rs 2,431 crore of incentives offered during the 2015-2020 period.

The draft says that the total interest subsidy during its lifetime is expected to be Rs 595 crore compared to the 314 crore in 2015-2020.

Similarly, the investment subsidy is expected to be Rs 2,315 crore in 2020-25 compared to the Rs 1,026 crore in the earlier policy.

Power cost reimbursement is expected to increase to Rs 520 crore from Rs 356 crore, while sales tax reimbursement is expected to touch Rs 1,059 crore from Rs 642 crore. Incentive under the “Others” head is set to increase to Rs 149 crore from Rs 94 crore.

As per the breakup cited in the draft, the “overall incentive outflow from the state” is estimated at Rs 674 crore in 2020-21, Rs 779 crore in 2021-22, Rs 904 crore in 2022-23, Rs 1052 crore in 2023-24 and Rs 1,230 crore in 2024-25, taking the total to Rs 4,638 crore in the five-year period of the policy’s run. The state expects the incentives given to industry would result in direct employment to 2,48,482 people, while the total investment is estimated at Rs 38,119 crore in the 2020-25 period. According to the draft, each Rs 1 crore of investment is expected to create seven new jobs.

The draft says that the inflow to the state during the 2020-25 period is expected to be Rs 3,896 crore, including Rs 858 crore through State GST due to tax on capital expenditure and Rs 3,039 crore through State GST due to sales accrued to Andhra Pradesh.

Most of the investment subsidy is expected to be offered to the MSME sector. The policy aims to increase the growth of manufacturing from 13.5% to 20% of the Gross Value Added.

Referring to AP’s policy of reserving 75% of jobs in the private sector to “locals”, it says that units that employ more than the mandated 75% “locals” would be given a one-time cash incentive of Rs 3,000 per employee for the initial two years.

The policy says that the focus for investment would be the Agritech, agro-based and food processing, aerospace and defence, pharmaceuticals and chemicals, textiles and apparel, electronics and auto and auto components.

Title: With new feature, criminal data of repeat offenders just a click away for T police
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Hyderabad: Accessing old records of repeat offenders was easier said than done in the past. This wouldn’t be the case anymore as the state police will now be able to refer to the criminal antecedents of the accused at the time of filing the First Information Report (FIR).

Police have linked the crime database of the state with the Crime and Criminal Tracking Network and Systems (CCTNS) FIR registration page, which will enable the investigation officers to prepare a stronger case against repeat offenders.

Earlier, police could get certain details of the accused’s criminal history only at the time of arrest and after the accused’s fingerprints were recorded in the database. “Mostly, antecedents of property offenders are checked,” said an IT cell official. Due to this lacuna, offenders who had a history of offences against women and children, causing bodily harm and road accidents, used to secure bail easily as the investigation officers were usually unaware of the accused’s criminal history.

In cases where the details of the accused are known at the time of filing the FIR, the new feature that runs in the background will alert the police officer entering the details of the FIR about the criminal history of the accused. “We have been building a database of repeat offenders in the state. If the accused in a road accident case has a history of similar cases, the system will show a pop-up and the investigation officer can mention the details in the remand report. This way, the accused will not be able to secure bail easily. Also, investigation can be carried out in a better way and a strong case can be made against the accused,” said DGP M Mahendar Reddy.

The feature is being tested on a pilot basis in Telangana and the background search starts as soon as the police officer filing the FIR clicks on the ‘known offender’ option. Particulars such as the name of the accused, his/her father’s name and address can be searched in the police database. “Investigation officers have been instructed to mention the criminal history of the accused while sending remand reports to courts,” the DGP said.
