Title: Finance Commission may suggest a Rs 15,000 crore welfare fund for jawans
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Representative image

NEW DELHI: The 15th Finance Commission is likely to recommend setting up of a Rs 10,000-15,000 crore fund for welfare of jawans killed or injured in combat. The move is part of the panel's discussions on a separate allocation for defence, a task that was given to it later.

"We were the first (Finance) Commission to visit Ladakh, we saw some very moving presentations on the Kargil war and we recognise that sacrifices by young men for India's protection must be recognised and we need to have some institutional arrangement, like a large corpus for Jawan Welfare Fund . If the corpus is reasonable, then the proceeds from that can go towards welfare of families and jawans. We need to make sure that there is no duplication because almost every state government and the Centre have funds. We need to pool these resources," 15th Finance Commission chairman NK Singh told TOI.

The panel has set up a task force under Singh to look at various aspects of providing resources for defence and the proposed Jawan Welfare Fund will be part of that. Apart from the finance commission chief, secretaries for defence, home and expenditure will be members.

"We're getting different assessments for defence forces and paramilitary. We need to try and make sure that we don't excessively centralise it and create a robust one for defence and internal security because they are being governed by two large ministries," he said.

Title: Fake Currency in Mumbai: How Mumbai police caught flyer with 'Pakistan-made' Indian notes
Content:
The notes seized were of high quality, incorporating

MUMBAI: A man who arrived on a flight from Dubai on Sunday morning was arrested for carrying fake Rs 2 ,000 notes with a face value of almost Rs 24 lakh. The notes were of high quality, incorporating seven of nine security features .The accused told police they were printed in Pakistan and sent to Dubai, with India intended as the final destination. The denomination, when issued in 2016, was touted as highly secure, but RBI said in October that no Rs 2,000 note was printed in 2019 as NIA had found high-quality fakes .The passenger, Javed Shaikh (36), a Kalwa resident, had been to Dubai and Bangkok in the past and may have brought in many such consignments. Police are questioning him about who the present consignment was meant for. “An average person will not be able to identify the fake notes. They look genuine. Shaikh walked away at the airport’s security check. He was caught at the bus stop outside the international terminal,” said joint commissioner of police (crime) Santosh Rastogi, who did not rule out a terror link.He said Shaikh could be caught because of a CIA tip-off . “The counterfeit currency was stuffed in one of his bags. It took us over an hour to locate it,” Rastogi said.“We identified him because of his white jeans. It was around 9.30am. He was waiting for a BEST bus... The notes were scattered inside a cushion, which was stuffed into a gap between the bag’s wall and a cloth liner,” he said.The format of the notes’ arrangement was the reason why they couldn’t be detected by baggage scanners. “A scanner identifies notes if they are kept in bundles. It’s the edges of the bundles that get detected. As opposed to this, Shaikh was carrying the notes in a scattered format, making machine detection difficult,” Rastogi said.On the quality of the notes, a crime branch officer said that the two security features that weren’t copied properly were ‘optically variable ink’ (ink that changes colour with changing angles) and ‘see-through register’ (hidden features that are seen only if a note is held against light).The team that busted Shaikh was the crime branch’s unit 8. Led by DCP Akbar Pathan, it included ACP Sangeeta Patil, and senior inspector Ajay Joshi.Shaikh has been booked under IPC sections for common intention, criminal conspiracy, and counterfeiting. During interrogation, he said he went to Dubai just five days ago, and for the first time. “But we don’t believe this,” said Rastogi.In Video: Mumbai: ‘Pak-made’ fake notes with face value of Rs 24 lakh seized

Title: Agency tribals raise alarm over land grab for mining, tourism
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Tribal groups in Agency areas of Visakhapatnam district have raised an alarm over cases of land belonging to tribals being taken over by people from the plains.

Ramarao Dora, convener of the Adivasi Reservation Parirakshana Porata Samithi, alleged that people from the plains are taking over land owned by tribal people in Anantagiri, Araku and Lambasingi to build infrastructure for tourism. “Several tent projects have been set up in the three places, which are used for prostitution,” Dora said on Sunday, adding that apart from affecting the local ecology, tourism projects and illegal mining are leading to an exodus of tribal people to the plains.

“We have been pleading with the government to take action against commandeering of tribal land in reserved areas because it has affected the livelihood of tribal people. We have also written to the President, the Prime Minister and other senior officials in New Delhi to take action against encroachment of tribal land, but nothing has been done so far,” Dora said.

An Adivasi Aatmagaurava Sabha will be held by tribals in Paderu in the district on February 12. Over one lakh people are expected to attend the event, Dora said.

On the reservation of seats for tribals, Dora said, “Of the 12 ZPTCs in the Agency, the government has reserved four for Backward Classes and the rest for the open category. There is no seat for Scheduled Tribes.”

Title: Guv directs varsities to change curriculum
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Jaipur: State varsities are set to change their curriculum making it more employable from the upcoming session, incorporating new developments in science, economics and history.

The state-funded universities are forming a committee to execute these changes with the industry experts in real time. So far, the change in the curriculum took place every three years and in phases. The move came after the governor house directed all the state-funded universities to change their curriculum in a meeting with the vice-chancellors on Friday.

Rashmi Jain, vice principal of Maharani’s College, said she has received a letter from the Rajasthan University VC’s office to take steps towards changing the curriculum. “It is a welcome step taken by the governor. The change in curriculum is a mammoth task which is done by the board of studies. We have leass than three months remaining to change the curriculum, which makes the task very daunting. But if everyone resolves, it will be done,” Rashmi said. The changes must be made keeping in mind the employability.

Experts said degree courses cannot become employable until research modules, skill-based learning and practical studies or training is added. “Adding all these elements in one phase is not possible. It has to be done repeatedly for some years with consistent revision,” said Puneet Sharma, an educationist.

The governor house also directed the universities to introduce semester system in BA Honours degree. “No doubt, semester system is far better than the usual system, but the former requires more resources like teachers, labs and classrooms. The semester system has bi-assessment system in an academic cycle while the usual system has only one,” Rashmi said.

Title: Bravehearts to be honoured at investiture ceremony
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Dehradun: The Golden Key division of the Western Command under the Indian Army will be organising an investiture ceremony in Dehradun on February 18 in which Army personnel will be honoured for their bravery and gallantry. The awards will be presented by Lt Gen RP Singh, General Officer Commanding-in-Chief, Western Command, an Army spokesperson said.

During the occasion, a total of seven Vashisht Seva Medals, 32 Sena Medals for gallantry and 2 Sena Medals for distinguished service will be presented. In addition, 16 elite units of the Western Command will be presented the Western Command Appreciation Award by the General Officer Commanding-in-Chief, Western Command, the spokesperson added.

Title: Nachinola to get garden under MPLAD scheme
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Saligao: The Nachinola panchayat took a resolution to develop an open space outside the children’s park into a recreational garden under the MPLAD (MP’s local area development) scheme at the gram sabha held on Sunday. The meeting was presided over by sarpanch Pooja Mayekar and panchayat secretary Dhiraj Govekar.

Amit Naik raised concerns over incomplete drainage in ward no 2 due to which the drains overflow during the monsoon, inconveniencing residents. The sarpanch assured the gathering that they would conduct an inspection.

Another local, Avinash Azgaonkar, complained about the empty beer bottles which are dumped on the shoulders and pavements along the streets, posing a nuisance to pedestrians. He also raised the issue of a kiosk that was given persmission by the panchayat, which was proving to be an obstruction to roadside parking, which was, in turn, obstructing traffic movement.

He demanded an inspection and asked the panchayat to shift the kiosk to prevent traffic issues. The sarpanch said the police has been asked to increase patrolling in the area to prevent the dumping of beer bottles.

Title: Maj Gen Rajendra Singh Thakur new U’khand GOC
Content: Dehradun: Major General Rajendra Singh Thakur is set to take over as the General Officer Commanding (GOC) of Uttarakhand sub-area from Monday.Major General Thakur is an alumnus of NDA, Khadakwasla, and was commissioned in the Army in 1983, according to a communique by the Army. Till now, Major Gen Thakur had been serving in Army Air Defence headquarters of Southwestern Command.

Title: More police parades in public places soon
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: In a bid to attract more people, especially the youth to police force, the state police authorities have decided to conduct parades, and display performances of police brass band and dog squads in public places regularly. The decision is inspired from the massive public attention the police could garner when they conducted the Republic Day Parade at Beach Road in Kozhikode on January 26.

In a statement issued here on Saturday, state police chief Loknath Behera said that henceforth the weekly parades of police personnel attached to local police stations and battalions must be conducted in public places so that general public can view it. Similarly, the police brass band troupes are also directed to conduct at least one public performance per week. The district police chiefs are also directed to conduct a show of performances of the dog squads for the public at least once in a month.

Behera said that such public parades and display of performances would help reduce the gap between the police and youths. This would also encourage the youth to work hand-in-hand with the police on schemes such as Janamaithri Community Policing in which the participation of the public is very essential.

There are also discussions to conduct Independence Day and Republic Day parades of local police in places that are more accessible to the general public.

Title: Budget session at Gairsain likely from March 2
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Dehradun: The budget session of Uttarakhand assembly is likely to be held at Gairsain from March 2.

Sources said that the 5-day session would end on March 6.

The session would commence with the governor’s speech and would be followed by the tabling of state budget in the assembly.

Later each department would table its budget individually. Notably, the BJP government had not held a single assembly session at Gairsain last year.

Opposition Congress had strongly raised the issue in the state assembly in the last session in Dehradun.

Even outside the state assembly, senior Congress leaders, including Harish Rawat, had slammed the government on the issue saying that “2019 was the first year since 2014 that a session was not held at Gairsain. This is against the spirit of Gairsain and the people of Uttarakhand.”

CM Trivendra Singh Rawat had earlier announced that the next session would be held in Gairsain.

The state government is expected to make the official announcement on the budget session after the cabinet meeting on February 12.

Title: Woman kidnapped after family feud
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Visakhapatnam: A 35-year-old woman was attacked and kidnapped under Gopalpatnam police station limits here on Saturday.

According to police, Guthi Lakshmiand her husband Guthi Nagaraju were residents of Ellapuvanipalem in Gopalapatnam. On Saturday evening, five women and two men attacked and dragged Guthi Lakshmi into a car. She was released on Sunday morning.

Cops said Lakshmi is Nagaraju’s second wife. According to family members of the accused—relatives of Nagaraju’s first wife—Nagaraju neglected his first wife after marrying Lakshmi. The accused kidnapped Lakshmi, hoping Nagaraju would return to his first wife.

Cases of kidnap and assault were registered. The accused are yet to be arrested.

Title: Pinarayi Vijayan: Govt can pay building rent too: Kerala CM to school management
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Pinarayi Vijayan

ALAPPUZHA: Chief minister Pinarayi Vijayan said that aided school managers should not try to threaten the state government.

“Since the state government is paying salary to the teachers of aided schools, the government can also give rent for the school buildings, if the managements wish to rent out the schools to the government. If situation demands, the government is also willing to take over aided schools,” said the chief minister. He was speaking at the valedictory function of Kerala School Teachers’ Association state meet.

“The state budget proposed to plug loopholes in Kerala Education Rules (KER), so that the practice of aided school mangers making unjustifiable appointment of teachers is curbed. Some aided school managers have come out against it. As per the budget, new posts can be created in aided schools only with the concurrence of the state government. It has put a stop to the practice of managements creating a new post when the number of students increases in a division in aided schools. Managers had demanded that the government should take over school buildings and said that they only needed rent. If the state government can pay the salary of aided school teachers, it is capable of meeting the rental charges of the buildings too. They should not try to threaten the government by saying this,” the Vijayan said.

He added that some people are seeing the education sector with a business mind. “They are trying to exaggerate the number of students. It will not be permited,” he said.

In another function, Vijayan said that his government would construct at least one housing complex in each district for the landless and homeless under the next segment of LIFE Mission.

He was speaking after handing over the keys of 121 houses sponsored by Ramoji Film City and constructed by Kudumbashree members for the flood victims at a function held at here on Sunday.

The chief minister said that Ramoji Film City constructed the houses spending Rs 7 crore. “The state government is not only aiming to build houses for the poor but also provide employment for them. Apart from it, the government is also ensuring care for elderly and patients,” he said.

Title: Anomalies in Aerostat system & UAV purchase order led to cancellation
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Hyderabad: The Andhra Pradesh police’s attempt to purchase Aerostat, an aerial surveillance equipment and an unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) from Israel has landed the then top cops in N Chandrababu Naidu ’s regime in trouble.

The aerial surveillance equipment, used by agencies like the US Customs and Border Protection, was meant to keep an eye on Maoists and red sanders smugglers. An enquiry by the current Jaganmohan Reddy government found procedural irregularities and involvement of the company owned by the son of the then additional DGP (intelligence), AB Venkateswara Rao .

In April 2017, the AP government issued GO No. 741 allowing DGP N Sambasiva Rao, additional DGP (intelligence), AB Venkateswara Rao, deputy conservator of forests special task force for red sanders protection BNN Murthy to visit Yavne in Israel in April 2017 for a practical demonstration of Skystart 180 Aerostat System. An Israeli company, RT LTA Systems, a subsidiary of Aeronautics, is the manufacturer of both Aerostat and the UAV worth around Rs 45 crore.

Despite objections raised by senior IPS official, Nimmagadda Surendra Babu, a member of the purchase committee, the police department went ahead with the procurement process. In November 2017, Venkateswara Rao visited Israel for an International Cyber Security Seminar.

On December 7, 2017, the AP home department issued a GO granting permission to procure Skystar 180 Aerostat and Orbiter 3 through State Trading Corporation of India. During this period, two police chiefs have changed, but Venkateswara Rao kept pushing for the purchase of the equipment.

Another senior IPS official, Nalini Prabhat had raised concerns regarding the procurement as to why there is no live demonstration of the equipment in India and raised objections on its efficacy. Meanwhile, the then DGP RP Thakur received an anonymous complaint that the Akasam Advanced Systems, that is dealing on behalf of the Israeli company is owned by the son of Venkateswara Rao.

Following this, RP Thakur cancelled the purchased order. The equipment was never bought, and there was no monetary loss to the government in the whole process. However, the Jagan government that took up the issue, found severe procedural irregularities and have suspended the officer as there was an intention and attempt to buy the equipment. The government is also contemplating proceeding against the incident under the Prevention of Corruption Act by roping in the Anti-Corruption Bureau.

According to Ministry of Corporate Affairs records,Venkateswara Rao’s son Aluru Chetan Sai Krishna had incorporated a company named Akasam Advanced Systems in Vijayawada on July 11, 2017, three months after Rao’s visit to Israel. The key allegation is that Akasam was involved as an Indian dealer of Israel-based company called RT Inflatables. A search on the web shows a company by the name of RT LTA Systems, but there is no trace of a company called RT Inflatables.

AB Venkateswara Rao has denied any involvement of his son or himself in the process. Sources close to him said that Global Tender was called in to find out the exact price of the equipment and State Trading Corporation was roped in to deal with the purchase.

Sources close to Venkateswara Rao said all correspondence was conducted from DGP office and Intelligence department was only the user agency. Tenders were cancelled thrice as they received only one bid. During this time, an Araku MLA was murdered by Maoists in the agency area. Sources said that then DGP had issued orders after the MLA’s murder. “DGP RP Thakur cancelled the order after senior officials raised objections. AB V Rao's family is not involved,” a source said.

Title: International Yog Festival to see star-studded line-up
Content: Dehradun: The International Yog Festival organised by the state government is scheduled to be held at Rishikesh from March 1 to 7. The festival, in which The Times of India group is partnering with the state government, has been scaled up to a much larger level this year, and will witness the presence and participation of many leading figures from the spiritual and yoga world. Among the gurus and guides that will grace the event are Sister BK Shivani of the Brahma Kumaris, international life coach Gaur Gopal Das, and Junapeethadishwar Acharya Mahamandaleshwar Swami Avdheshanand Giri.Besides, yoga teachers from across the country will conduct sessions at the festival. The festival will also witness a daily aarti on the banks of the Ganga at Rishikesh followed by a cultural event which will see performances by renowned singers Anuradha Paudwal, Pt Rajan-Sajan Mishra, Pt Ritesh-Rajnish Mishra, Susmit Sen Trio and Prem Joshua among others.The official logo of the festival was released by Art of Living founder Sri Sri Ravi Shankar at the Art of Living Ashram in Bangalore in the presence of Iva Ashish Srivastava, managing director of Garhwal Mandal Vikas Nigam (GMVN) which is organising the event at the Ganga Resort in Rishikesh.While launching the logo, Sri Sri Ravi Shankar conveyed his blessings and hoped for a successful conduct of the festival. “I congratulate the people of Uttarakhand and the government for hosting the festival at ‘yog nagri’ Rishikesh. I am sure an event like this will go a long way in further developing Rishikesh into a world destination for propagation of the benefits of yoga,” the spiritual guru said.

Title: Extra coaches on 4 train services
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Hyderabad: To accomodate wait-listed passengers, four train services running from Secunderabad to Shalimar and Vizag will be augmented with additional coaches this month. Secunderabad – Shalimar AC Superfast Express will be enhanced with two extra AC III-tier coaches and two AC III-tier coaches will be added to superfast express trains between Secunderabad and Vizag. TNN

Title: Hyderabad: Gold worth Rs 1 crore seized from four women at RGI Airport
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

File photo of RGI Airport

HYDERABAD: Customs officials at RGI Airport seized 2.5kg smuggled gold worth Rs 1 crore from four women passengers who arrived from Jeddah on Sunday.

At the customs check area in RGI Airport, officials screening passengers who arrived from Jeddah in Air India flight (AI 966) intercepted the women after they noticed suspicious objects in their undergarments.

“The four women had concealed gold in their undergarments. While some were carrying broken gold biscuits, others were carrying gold chains and bangles. The seized gold is of 24 karat purity,” said a customs official.

The four women are not related to each other. “Two of them went to Saudi Arabia on Umrah pilgrimage and the other two had gone there on personal visits. None of them has history of frequent visits to Saudi Arabia or Dubai,” said a customs official.

According to customs officials, the market value of the seized gold is about Rs 1 crore.

Cases were booked against the four offenders and based on the quantity of the gold seized from each of them, two accused were arrested. tnn

Title: New classification of Saligao rejected
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Saligao: The state’s government’s notification under which Saligao has been declared as an urban area dominated Sunday’s gram sabha . Locals unanimously resolved to reject the notification.

Villagers also demanded to know the status of the expansion plan of the garbage treatment plant, which they had earlier opposed. Sarpanch Shraddha Borkar said they are still waiting for data collected by experts. Assuring villagers that the panchayat “is with the people”, Borkar said the panchayat would write to the chief minister again, opposing the plant’s expansion.

The budgetary provisions for several developmental works were also announced. The secretary said the panchayat has been allocated nearly Rs 14 lakh under the 14th finance commission for many of these works.

Former sarpanch Eknath Oraskar pointed out that no allocation had been made for sports infrastructure and a village library and suggested that the budget be revised to include the same.

A villager, Mario Cordeiro, highlighted the badly-maintained light poles near the Saligao junction. The sarpanch said they would write to the electricity department asking that these be repaired urgently. The sarpanch was also requested to act against heavy trucks passing through the no-entry zones in the village during peak hours.

Another villager, Bola Ghadi, suggested that signboards be erected in the vicinity of the Lourdes Convent school cautioning motorists to drive safely.

Title: Barge carrying 600 tonnes of rice sinks
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Kakinada: A barge carrying 600 tonnes of broken rice capsized near Kakinada Anchorage Port on Sunday. The crew onboard escaped unhurt. Cops said the barge had to stop midway when the weather changed causing it to sink . Losses amount to Rs 1.35 crore.

Title: Plastic recycling plant inaugurated in Haridwar
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Haridwar: Chief minister Trivendra Singh Rawat on Sunday laid the foundation stone for a plastic recycling plant at SIDCUL in Haridwar, the district’s first such facility which has been built with a grant of Rs 3 crore from the Union Ministry of Panchayati Raj. The CM said it will be operational in around eight months. Union minister of Panchayati Raj Narendra Singh Tomar was also present at the inauguration.

CM Rawat said that setting up the plant was a step in the direction of realizing Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s dream of a clean India. Tomar said that apart from contributing towards cleanliness, the plant will also generate employment.

“Not only political leaders and film artistes, elected leaders of panchayat bodies are also doing their bit to contribute towards the cleanliness campaign,” said Tomar at the event. He also congratulated the government on making Uttarakhand free of open defecation.

Later in the day, the CM inaugurated an eight-day interstate cooperative exhibition at Rishikul ground, on occasion of the 100th anniversary of Haridwar district cooperative bank. In the evening, Rawat also inaugurated a two-day workshop of representatives of three-tier panchayat bodies at Patanjali Yogapeeth.

Speaking at the Rishikul exhibition, the CM said, “Several measures are being taken by the government to boost farmers’ income. These include granting licences for the khandsari industry, setting up plants to make ethanol from sugarcane, schooling farmers to make maximum profit on minimum investment. The aim is to help them double their income by 2022.”

Tomar said that a budget of around Rs 3 lakh crore had been allocated for rural development and agriculture and schemes like Kisan Udan Yojana had been formed to help farmers export their produce.

Title: Kochi police on the lookout for ‘foreign’ mobile thieves
Content:
Images of the accused posted on the Facebook page of Kerala Police

KOCHI: Taking their investigation to the social media, the city police are closing in on two thieves, apparently foreign nationals, who steal high end mobile phones from shops in the district.Since the only clue about the accused were the visuals from a CCTV camera, police sought the help of their 1.3 million followers on Facebook and posted a video of the crime, seeking tips about the accused. It was on Friday night, the police posted the video of two seemingly white men nicking a mobile phone from a shop at Chembumukku in Thrikkakara. One among the duo was seen talking to the salesman, distracting him, even as the other leans over the counter and nicks a mobile phone. He can be seen keeping it in his bag before leaving the shop. Two days on, police have been getting calls from across the district and nearby towns.Police, however, are yet to get to the accused. In some cases, the callers either misidentified the accused while in other cases the accused managed to give police the slip.In one tip received by the police, a theft attempt was reported at a mobile phone shop at North Paravur. Police got information that the accused had asked the way for Vypeen from the area.Based on this input, police have strengthened surveillance in Vypeen area where tourists frequent. “There is a temple festival going on at Cherai and the police have been asked to stay vigilant. Checking for the accused duo is being held in this area as well,” said an officer. Another tip call, according to sources, came from Koothattukulam where the caller identified two persons similar to those in the video, however, these persons were later identified to be two Rajasthan natives.Police said the accused are repeat offenders who roam the state posing as tourists. “We have identified two-three cases from across the district and it seems like the same duo have committed the crime. Their modus operandi is also the same. One among them distracts the person manning the shop while the other makes the loot. Their target mostly are mobile phone shops,” said a police officer.Police also sought the help of WhatsApp groups of mobile phone shop owners to spread the video of the crime and seek tips about the accused. “When we shared the video on WhatsApp, we got CCTV visuals of a theft from Chavakkad in Thrissur. The men in the video looks similar and their modus is also the same. It is hard to track them as we don’t know their whereabouts,” said a police officer.Police said they have approached the Foreigner Regional Registration Office (FRRO) as well. “We have sought the help of FRRO and are trying to get the passport details of the accused. With the help of the public, we may be able to catch them sooner,” said an officer.Tips can be directed to Thrikkakara police station: 0484-2428665 SHO: 9497980424 or the ACP: 9497990071.

Title: Crime against women: 230 cases remain undetected
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Representative image

PANAJI: Around 230 cases of crimes against women , including cases of rape, molestation and outraging of modesty —have remained undetected in the state, over the past five years.

Goa police said they were trying to solve the undetected cases. “From time to time, directions are given to all the investigation officers to conduct thorough and speedy investigations and to make sincere efforts to detect the cases,” chief minister Pramod Sawant in a written reply tabled in the state legislative assembly.

There are two police stations for women in the state— one at Panaji (North Goa) and the other, a women and child protection unit, at Margao (South Goa), Sawant said.

Goa police have registered cases of rape, kidnapping, molestation, eve-teasing, marital abuse, dowry deaths and immoral trafficking of women, among others. While chargesheets have been filed in many cases, based on evidence, most of the cases are pending trial. Some cases have been closed by the police , due to lack of evidence.

Goa police have made arrests in several cases of crime against women in the past couple of years. Police had arrested three Indore-based men for gangraping a 20-year-old woman at Betalbatim beach. The three raped the woman, filmed the act, and demanded money in exchange for not making the video public.

A 22-year-old chef from Kuwait and native of Kolhapur, Joseph Das, was arrested for molesting a 17-yearold German girl at Ourem beach in Canacona.

The police had arrested nine tourists from Pune for allegedly attempting to outrage the modesty of a minor girl at Calangue beach. The nine men also assaulted the girl’s minor brother and created a ruckus before they were arrested.

Title: Chirag wins bronze in Iran tourney
Content: Dehradun: Uttarakhand’s Chirag Sen has won a bronze medal in the 29th FAJR Badminton International Challenge held from February 4 to 8 in Shiraz, Iran.Sen was defeated in the semi-final round of the men’s singles where he had to compete against Belgium’s Maxime Moreels.The Almora born player gave a tough fight to his Belgium opponent before going down by 21-16, 18-21 and 21-23. The gold medal was bagged by China’s Xiaodong Sheng who defeated Moreels by 21-17 and 21-12.In the quarter-final stage, Sen had defeated Iceland’s Kari Gunnarsson by 21-14 and 21-8. Prior to that in the pre-quarterfinal round, the 21-year old shuttler had defeated Iran’s Amir Jabbari by 21-11 and 21-17.BS Mankoti, secretary of Uttarakhand State Badminton Association, said, “Chirag has won several national championships in the domestic circuit. The FAJR tournament is an invitational tournament in which players look to improve their rankings and Chirag has succeeded in doing so as he won a bronze medal. His focus will now be to improve his world ranking furthermore.”Notably, Sen’s current world ranking in singles is 121.

Title: Kochi: ‘Preterm baby was legally aborted, disposed illegally’
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Representational Image

KOCHI: The police team investigating the case of the abandoned body of a preterm baby which was found in a bucket in Perandoor Canal at Elamakkara on February 2 has found that it was a case of abortion and that the body was “unscientifically dumped” in the canal by someone who was supposed to dispose of the medical waste.

According to top police sources, the investigation found that the baby was legally aborted in a city hospital and the police have taken the statements of the parents. The police said that they are probing to find the person who dumped the body in the canal after the hospital handed over the body as medical waste post abortion. Meanwhile, the police refused to divulge the identity of neither the parents nor the hospital.

“We confirmed that the baby was aborted at the advice of the doctor after they found out about its abnormal growth. As the baby’s age was less than 25 weeks, which is the permissible limit for abortion, no action will be taken against the parents. We are yet to confirm how the hospital has managed the disposal of the body, which is medical waste. The probe is currently on to find the person who did that,” said a police officer.

The bucket with the body was spotted by children who were playing near the canal on Makkaparambu Theeradesha Road. The water current brought it to the edge of the canal and when they saw it, they mistook the body for a doll and picked up the bucket. But when they realized it was a body, they called elders in the area and they alerted the police.

Title: Calicut University researchers invent slow-release fertilizers
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Calicut University (File Photo)

KOZHIKODE: Researchers at Calicut University have come up with an eco-friendly solution to a long standing problem faced by farmers of having 70% of nitrogen fertilizers, mainly urea, getting wasted before plants can absorb them.

Urea which makes up for around 50% of total nitrogen fertilizer consumption worldwide, is susceptible to nitrogen loss to the environment due to its fast and premature decomposition nature. It has also been causing environmental damage due to agricultural runoff of massive levels of fertilizers to water bodies often resulting in harmful algal blooms in waterways.

CU researchers have now developed a slow-release fertilizer composite by giving a glassy/crystalline coating to urea using sugar acetates (sucrose octaacetate (SOA)) by processing it in a CO2 solvent medium.

P Raveendran, professor of Chemistry and Dean (Faculty of Sciences) at CU, along with researcher Anu Antony of the varsity Chemistry department have jointly made the invention. Raveendran said that while urea takes around 15 minutes for total decomposition, the slow-release composite of urea and sugar acetates takes upto 90 hours for decomposition.

The SOA-urea composite prepared in CO2 medium forms an amorphous glassy solid which results in immobilization of urea, leading to slow-release to the soil.

The new fertilizer composite has a simple, green and non-hazardous preparation process as all materials used in the process, including the SOA coating material and CO2 solvent, are inexpensive and environmentally benign. “The slow-releasing fertilizer composites ensure efficient nutrient uptake by reducing loss of nutrients via leaching, runoff, volatilization etc., and thereby improving crop yield and reducing the amount of fertilizer needed,” said Raveendran.

He said that apart from urea, the technique can be applied to other fertilizers including ammonium nitrate , potassium nitrate , calcium nitrate etc.

According to researchers, a major drawback associated with the application of urea as a fertilizer is its fast and premature decomposition causing inefficient absorption of nitrogen by the plant.

In the initial stages, plants require only a very small amount of the nutrient. However, the demand for nutrients increases during the upcoming stages of growth. Leaching, surface runoff and vaporization of urea further lower the amount of urea present in the soil for uptake by the plants in their growing stages and about 40 to 70% of nitrogen escapes to the environment and only the remaining small amount of nitrogen is left for the uptake by the plants.

Also, the new invention will prevent fertilizer burning plants due to fast release of urea that can adversely affect the growth of the plant. Researchers have filed patent application for the new invention.
