In the initial stages, plants require only a very small amount of the nutrient. However, the demand for nutrients increases during the upcoming stages of growth. Leaching, surface runoff and vaporization of urea further lower the amount of urea present in the soil for uptake by the plants in their growing stages and about 40 to 70% of nitrogen escapes to the environment and only the remaining small amount of nitrogen is left for the uptake by the plants.

Also, the new invention will prevent fertilizer burning plants due to fast release of urea that can adversely affect the growth of the plant. Researchers have filed patent application for the new invention.

Title: Kanaka Durga flyover to be inaugurated by March 31
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Vijayawada: Krishna district administration says it has focused on completing the Kanaka Durga flyover works and inaugurate it in a huge way, at the earliest. District collector A Mohammed Imtiaz, who is monitoring the works of the flyover, said that they want to inaugurate it by March 31. Officials said they have already completed the works of the Benz circle flyover and have started trial runs.

The Kanaka Durga flyover project is a dream project for the residents of Bhavanipuram, Gollapudi, Vidhyadharapuram and One Town areas who are frequently faced with severe traffic jams. The Telugu Desam party-led government had begun the works of 2.3-km, six-lane flyover and 2.9-km-long road widening from VMC office junction to Bhavanipuram.

Though work on the flyover began in November 2015, the project got delayed due to poor funds and the project’s complicated design. The project missed the deadline five times when the TDP government was in power.

Following special interest in the project from chief minister YS Jaganmohan Reddy the deadline of December 31, 2019 was fixed.

But once again, project works missed the deadline and the state government took the issue seriously. Collector Imtiaz, who is inspecting the project every week, said the project works were about 90% complete.

“We are keeping efforts to complete the project works soon and permit traffic from March. A minor portion of works is pending and the agency has already started landing works. We are confident we won’t miss the deadline this time,” Imtiaz said.

Meanwhile, citizens are happy with the pace of project works and requested the district administration to focus on developing connecting roads. “We have waited for almost five years for the Kanaka Durga flyover to be complered. We are happy that the project works have gained pace at least now. Officials should also develop connecting roads before permitting heavy vehicles through the flyover,” said Kaja Nageswara Rao, a cloth merchant from One Town.

Title: Enthusiastic tourists participate in desert fest
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Jaisalmer: The desert festival on Sunday saw a large number of participants at the Paliwal village of Kuldhara . The participants and tourists were enthusiastic to see the Rangoli competition on the theme of ‘Beti Bachao Beti Padhao’.

There were other competitions organised at Dedansar Ground on city outskirts. These competitions included tug of war, matka race, camel polo, camel race, kabbadi etc. In addition to this there were tattoo show by the BSF, air warrior drill show by the Indian Air Force and performance by Army band.

The occasion saw participation and attendance of dignitaries like GOC Major General Rakesh Kapoor and other seniors Army officers, MLA Rooparam, zila pramukh Anjana Meghwal, divisional commissioner B L Kothari, tourism director Bhanwarlal Sharma, district collector Namit Mehta, SP Kiran Kang and others.

The winners and participants of various games and events were felicitated.

Kanu Charan of the BSF, Nakhat Singh Hada and Meere Khan won the first, second and third prizes, respectively for camel decoration competition. The winner of the Shaan-e-Marudhar competition was Surendra Singh of BSF with Gordhan Singh as the runner-up and Reshmaram at the third position. The tug-of-war saw the foreign tourists winning hands down in both male and female categories. The Indian Camel Polo Association team won the camel polo while the Jaisalmer Kabbadi team won the game of kabbadi.

The Panihari pot race for foreign tourists was won by Jenny from England, followed by Lauren from Canada and Riyaz from Israel. Their Indian counterpart event was won by Seema followed by Renuka Vaishnav on second position and Baby coming third.

Title: Mass vaccination drive in VZM to guard against filariasis
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Visakhapatnam: Medical authorities in Vizianagaram will take up a mass vaccination drive against filariasis in association with the malaria control department from February 10 to 12.

The drive will provide tablets to more than 2.4 million people in the district and is geared toward making Vizianagaram filariasis-free. East Godavari and Vizianagaram districts are among the two most affected by the disease in Andhra Pradesh.

There are at least 4,000 confirmed cases of filariasis in the district. Dr S Ramani Kumari, district medical and health officer (DMHO) told TOI, “We are not sure of the actual spread. Symptomatic cases show that there are 4,000. But the actual number of people affected or those carrying the disease are unknown.”

The DMHO as well as the district malaria control department agree that Vizianagaram town, Parvathipuram and Salur are the most affected. A Sambamurthy, district malaria control officer said, “Vizianagaram has a number of water tanks that are very old. The conditions are similar in Parvathipuram and Salur where water bodies are dirty. These are breeding grounds of the culex mosquito which is a vector for passing on filiriasis.”

Title: 265 players take part in Auli events
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Dehradun: The National Skiing and Snowboarding Championship saw many events and participation of 265 players comprising 12 teams in Auli on Sunday. As many as 10 states and two additional teams representing the Armed forces namely the Services Sports Control Board (SSCB) and Indo-Tibetan Border Police also took part in the event, which will end on Monday.

On Sunday, several events took place, including senior and junior categories. The women’s Slalom event saw Sandhya Thakur (HP), Aanchal Thakur (HP) and Varsha Thakur (HP) bagging the first, second and third positions respectively. While the men’s Slalom event saw Arif Khan (J&K), Rajat Thakur (HP) and Devender Gurung (SSCB) bagging the first, second and third positions respectively. The under-16 girls Giant Slalom event saw Vardha (J&K), Palak Thakur (HP) and Bharti Bhujwan(Uttarakhand) bagging the first, second and third positions respectively.

Many states such as Bihar and Karnataka participated for the first time.

Title: Govt assures job for victim’s brother
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Nagpur: Leaders cutting across the political spectrum expressed grief over the demise of Ankita Pisudde, who succumbed to burn injuries here on Monday. Right from governor Bhagat Singh Koshiyari to chief minister Uddhav Thackeray and deputy CM Ajit Pawar, many condolences to the family.

While the governor called for introspection by citizens over the “unfortunate incident”, the CM assured that the case against her assailant Vikesh Nagrale would be tried in the fast track court. Thackeray also informed that the government had already appointed noted lawyer Ujjwal Nikam to fight her case.

“The entire society is agitated today. Women are progressing in all walks of life. They are assuming newer responsibilities and tackling challenges efficiently. In order to further hasten their progress, society must bear a positive attitude towards them,” Koshiyari said.

Home minister Anil Deshmukh assured a job to a member from her family, probably her brother. He held discussions with Nikam and the Wardha SP in the morning and asked them to prepare a strong case. He also assured full help to the family after the news of her death emerged in the morning.

While terming the 25-years-old teacher’s death as a blot on the entire state, Pawar called for stringent punishment to the accused, which would act as a deterrent in society.

Demanding stringent punishment for her stalker Nagrale, who threw petrol and set her afire, leader of opposition Devendra Fadnavis said he would pray that the deceased’s family members get strength to come out of the shock. He requested the government to ensure justice for her.

Pressing for capital punishment for Pisudde’s assailant, PWD minister Ashok Chavan said the entire state was in a state of shock and there was resentment against the accused. “In such cases, the trials should be run on fast track basis and accused should be sentenced to gallows as early as possible.”

Revenue minister Balasaheb Thorat assured the government was standing with the victim’s family and would make every effort to ensure justice. “The Hinganghat incident is a shame for the entire state and the government will take responsibility to prevent such incidents. We’re also considering bringing in stringent laws to ensure that such incidents shouldn’t be repeated. Attempts were made to save the young victim by giving her the best medical treatment, but unfortunately we couldn’t save her. The government and the Congress party are with the family in their difficult time,” he said.

Expressing disappointment over the young victim’s death, human rights activist and lawyer Smita Singalkar said the incident displayed an urgent need to change the society’s mindset towards women. “It’s high time to work on men’s mentality, who usually don’t like to hear ‘no’ from women and they construe it as a setback to their superiority. The attitude to seek revenge develops after this. Parents, society and the government machinery should come together to make schoolchildren aware of this aspect right from the beginning. Every woman has a right to accept or reject a proposal,” she said.

Title: Conversion to Christianity by inducement should be punishable offence: RSS general secretary
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Suresh Joshi

PANAJI: National general secretary of the Rashtriya Swayamsevak Sangh (RSS) Suresh ‘Bhaiyaji’ Joshi, on Sunday said while RSS does not oppose conversion to Christianity, it is opposed to conversions by way of exploitation and inducement of the poor, illiterate and the backward. This practice should be made punishable by law, Joshi said at a public interaction in Goa.

He also said that political opposition of BJP by any Hindus should not be seen as opposition of Hindus.

The top RSS functionary said that not just mass conversion, but even individual conversion was wrong. “Forceful conversion or by inducement, we say, should be made a punishable offence. There is no restriction on those who are going to Christianity on their own,” Joshi said, even as opposed the dishonesty of conversion by inducement.

“There are many cases across the country of those operating under the guise of NGOs. If you want to work in the area of water conservation, then why are you building a church in the village,” Joshi said while replying to a question from the audience.

In response to another audience question, he said that any opposition of Hindus by Hindus is only limited to the political stage. “You have written in your question that Hindu has become enemy of the Hindu community, meaning BJP. Hindu community does not mean BJP. Opposition to BJP should not be seen as opposing Hindus. All these political fights will continue. It should not be linked as opposition of Hindus...Opposing Hindutva is political. Supporting Hindutva is also, at times, political. I feel that Hindutva and Hindus should rise above this,” Joshi said.

He also said that without the concept and sentiment of a ‘rashtra’, the country will remain nothing but a piece of land, and that is how it is being wrongly viewed by some, as a mere geographical entity.

“Why are those born who are willing to give up everything and sacrifice for this motherland, if this is a lifeless land? Those who think Bharat is just the Himalayas, its mountains and its rivers, have not understood Bharat. Then they think that if there is a piece of land where not even grass grows and we have lost it, let it go. But it is not a lifeless piece of land. That is why I say that only praying to Bharatmata will give this country the strength and energy,” Joshi said, adding that just as a human being has atma (soul), the country too has a soul and that has been named as ‘rashtra’.

Joshi also said that a Hindu can never be communal because Hindus are not a community. “Those who worship one god, have one manner of worship, and believe in one book are considered a community. Since Hinduism doesn’t fit into this description, Hindus are not a community. Hindus, therefore, cannot be communal,” Joshi said.

The RSS has never stopped any non-Hindu from joining the organisation. But they will have to believe in Bharatmata. “We will not change our ideology or have a separate programme tailored from them,” Joshi said.

Title: JS raises corruption charges against Durga temple mgmt
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

File photo of devotees at the Kanaka Durga temple

Vijayawada: Jana Sena on Sunday raised corruption charges against Sri Durga Malleswara Swamy Varla Devastanams management and said executive officer MV Suresh Babu was holding on to the post despite the high court orders.

Jana Sena spokesperson Pothina Venkata Mahesh made allegations of corruption against endowments minister Vellampalli Srinivas for allowing Suresh Babu to continue as an executive officer.

“Kanaka Durga temple is the second largest temple in the state after Tirumala Tirupati Devastanams but the apathy of the state government is hurting sentiments. The state government transferred IRS officer Koteswaramma as executive officer of the temple and in her place posted Suresh Babu, who is not eligible for the position. I have challenged this appointment in the high court. Despite a row of government orders issued to regularise his service, the high court said that Suresh Babu is ineligible for the post,” Mahesh said.

“Suresh Babu was given two promotions in three months, which is against the guidelines of the endowments department,” Mahesh alleged.

“The temple income has come down to Rs 2 crore per month in recent times ever since Suresh Babu took charge as executive officer. The temple’s expenses have also increased. Temple authorities cancelled the milk tender for Rs 42 per litre and allocated a new tender to the same vendor for Rs 44 per litre. Temple authorities are at liberty to waste the money donated by the devotees and minister Vellampalli Srinivas is indirectly supporting these acts,” Mahesh alleged.

“The chief minister should immediately post an IAS cadre official as EO and order a probe into the illegal contracts and tenders called for by Suresh Babu,” Mahesh demanded.

Title: For a patriarchy fix, many young Tamil Nadu women opt for hymen reconstruction surgeries
Content:
Representative image

CHENNAI: A couple of months ago an uproar over reports of fake virginity products sold on Amazon India led to the e-tail giant taking down the merchandise. While not surprisingly, newer varieties of these synthetic blood-containing, self-dissolving cellulose capsules continue to be sold on websites of Indian pharmaceutical companies, there seems to be an equal, parallel demand for another virginity ‘restoring’ service — hymen reconstruction surgery or hymenoplasty — in Tamil Nadu.The surgical procedure with the aim to cause bleeding in women during post-nuptial intercourse (a common myth associated with the bride’s virginity), hymenoplasty surgeries in Chennai have in fact existed for as long as cosmetic surgeries, as a part and parcel of that specialisation. As a Chennai-based plastic surgeon says, "Although it may stem from cultural reasons, for us, it is the same as repairing any ruptured tissue — like a torn earlobe or a cleft lip."But for many young women living under the fear of social stigma and shaming, hymen reconstruction is a prerequisite for a good married life. Among the recent patients that Dr Karthik Ram, chief cosmetic surgeon at Chennai Plastic Surgery, had was a 26-year-old woman from Trichy, who wrote to them enquiring about the procedure ahead of her wedding. "She had been looking for a safe place to get it done, and realised that travelling to Chennai would keep it confidential and simple," he says. "We don’t usually probe our patients for reasons, but try to talk them out of it first. And this woman told us that her previous relationship ended, and her new family was conservative, so she couldn’t take a chance," he says.While cosmetic surgeons say they make it a point to reiterate to their clients what has for years been underlined by gynaecologists — that an intact hymen is not an indicator of virginity — their clinic’s websites are quite straightforward about the purpose of the service. Some call it ‘the restoration of virginity’ while others attribute it to "cultural factors" and protection from the "shame and humiliation the woman may face if she’s discovered not to be a ‘virgin’ after marriage".The conservative patriarchal mindset, which puts women on a pedestal by pandering to an ideal of purity and innocence, essentially encourages their objectification. "We must understand that for young women signing up for the procedure, its gravity goes beyond medical reasoning. They’re scared and insecure, because they can’t at that point, be tutoring their fiancés about the myth behind the hymen. They just want to be safe," says another surgeon offering the service.In Coimbatore and Srirangam, hymenoplasty has been finding takers in young middle-class women hailing from conservative families and facing risk of humiliation. "Most are women aged between 20 to 25 years. We recommend they come to us about two weeks before their wedding. Some are those getting married for the second time," says Dr Ram.The surgery is typically a minor one lasting less than an hour and healing too is fast, taking no more than two weeks at most, say surgeons. "Initially, hymenoplasty fell under the range of surgeries intended at reversing the process of aging — repairing a tear following a difficult pregnancy, or restoring of the fat tissues in the vaginal region. But over the years, with its medical or aesthetic reasons becoming unfounded, it has been put under the umbrella of ‘cosmetic gynaecology’," says the Chennai-based surgeon.While in Chennai, takers are still few, a doctor says a good number of her hymenoplasty clients have also been women from the Middle East, where stigma is severe. "I’ve also had older teens who have survived sexual abuse coming to us with their parents who fear their children will face trouble after marriage if their hymens are not restored," she says.Pointing out that this trend perpetuates a narrow-minded attitude and puts unrealistic pressure on young women, senior gynaecologist/obstetrician Dr Priya Selvaraj says young men and families needed to be educated most. "Medically, the hymen by itself is a membranal structure that can partially, completely or very thinly cover the vaginal outlet. It can tear while doing heavy sports activity or tampon use. Also, due to its variable structure — appearance, elasticity and the extent to which it covers the vaginal opening — it cannot be used to ascertain whether a woman has had sexual intercourse or not," she says. "Therefore, an intact hymen or even bleeding for the first time during intercourse, are not signs of virginity at all."

Title: ‘No head of religion can get in way of governance’
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Panaji: It is wrong for any religious body to issue a statement that will bring about a communal divide, transport minister Mauvin Godinho said on Sunday, reacting to the statement issued a day earlier by the archbishop of Goa and Daman, Filipe Neri Ferrao, against the Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA). Ferrao had appealed to the Centre to “immediately and unconditionally” revoke the CAA.

“No head of a religious body has the right to interfere in the governance of any state or country and especially make a comment that will bring about an opposition on communal basis. They should not be seen even indirectly as inciting some sort of communal tension,” Godinho said, adding, “The intention behind it may be very good. But one should be very careful.”

Commissioner for NRI affairs Narendra Sawaikar, in a series of tweets on Sunday, said the opposition to CAA was unfounded. “Why should Archbishop oppose #CAA? when SC is hearing & will decide a challenge to the law. 14 year Catholic girl is fighting for justice in Pakistan. Crores of people are supporting CAA. Unfounded opposition,” he tweeted.

In another tweet, he said, “Archbishop says that #CAA shld be withdrawn as it is being opposed. My question is why? When crores of people are supporting #CAA, including Goans. #StopSpreadingFalsehood.”

Meanwhile, ports minister Michael Lobo on Sunday said the archbishop, in his capacity as a religious head, has been issuing statements to guide his faithful and that no politician should comment on it. He also said that the Pope gives messages about his views on many issues to the world and similarly, Hindu religious heads, too, give clear messages to their community.

Title: YSRC MLA chalks out plan to develop 20 Gurazala villages
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Guntur: Gurazala legislator Kasu Mahesh Reddy has prepared a plan to develop 20 villages in his constituency as model villages.

After studying the conditions and taking feedback from mandal-level officials, Mahesh Reddy has selected 20 villages to give a complete makeover in the next few months. He has held discussions with engineers from panchayat raj, rural development, rural water supply and other allied departments to ready an estimate to take up various development works in the villages.

“We are planning to make model villages with roads, drains and drinking water, including RO facility. We will ensure that no civic grievance is left unaddressed in these villages,” Mahesh Reddy said.

The MLA said they would expand the programme to other villages in a phased manner after completing the work in the first phase. He said that there was no dearth of funds for taking up the works. He said that they would also distribute house sites to all the eligible poor in the model villages.

Recalling the success of his experiment in making Narasaraopet town with 100 percent cement concrete roads when his father Krishna Reddy was legislator of the constituency in the past, Mahesh said that he was planning to upgrade civic facilities in Gurazala constituency.

He said that development works in phases would help them complete the projects. He said that they were planning to develop all the 100 villages in the constituency as model villages by 2024.

He said that chief minister YS Jaganmohan Reddy had announced a government medical college to his constituency and cleared comprehensive water grid project for Palnadu. “We have achieved two big projects—medical college and water grid—within six months of coming to power. We have also kept our promise of upgrading Dachepalle and Gurazala as municipal towns,” said Mahesh Reddy. He said that he would resume Jagananna Palle Baata, a walkathon, in the villages after local body elections.

Title: Street vendors get ID cards in VZM town
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Visakhapatnam: District collector and special officer of Vizianagaram Municipal Corporation M Hari Jawahar Lal distributed identity cards to 1,388 small vendors operating in Vizianagaram town. The cards were issued under the Mission for Elimination of Poverty in Municipal Areas (Mepma) and will help vendors ply their trade and avail loans from banks.

Speaking on the occasion, the collector said the cards will provide vendors with a financial security net and allow them to expand their scale of operation. He added that the cards will ensure that vendors are not discouraged from plying their trade.

Vendors can also air their grievances with the municipal authorities, the collector said, adding that frequent monthly meetings would be held with vendors to resolve their issues. The collector also stressed the need to ensure that streets are kept clean and that this should be the responsibility of the vendors.

The collector added that more vendors are being identified for ID cards under Mepma.

Title: Kerala govt prepares Brahmapuram plant for fresh ‘lease’ of life
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Trouble mounting: The waste dumping yard at Brahmapuram

KOCHI: Even as work on the proposed waste-to-energy plant at Brahmapuram has started, the state government has kicked up a new controversy by deciding to replace the concession agreement with a lease agreement and revoke the Kochi corporation council’s decision in this regard.

The local self-government department issued an order in this regard on January 16.

A concession agreement is entered into by a government body and an agency allowing the latter to operate a business subject to certain terms. A lease agreement between lessor and lessee allows for use of an asset or land. This enables the lessee to raise funds by mortgaging the properties with banks.

Kochi corporation and GJ Eco Power Pvt Ltd had signed a concession agreement to set up the plant in February 2016. Later, the agency approached the local body to convert it into a lease agreement, which the corporation rejected outright. This forced the agency to approach the government and the state-level advisory committee (SLAC), which met in December 2018, asked the civic body to accede to the agency’s demand. But the health standing committee decided not to consider the proposal of the agency and the corporation council, convened in April 2019, ratified it.

The corporation secretary relayed the decision of the council to the government. But the department revoked the decision and asked the corporation to implement the direction of the SLAC under section 58 of the Kerala Municipality Act 1994.

The corporation reached an agreement with the agency in February 2016.

“The contract says nothing about a lease agreement and that’s why the corporation rejected the agency’s proposal. If the current concession agreement is converted into lease agreement the agency can raise funds for setting up the plant. The government has asked us to take a decision in this regard at the council meeting. The mayor is on an official trip to Dubai and is expected to return by February 15. The council will discuss the matter after that,” said deputy mayor K R Premkumar.

With the local body reaching lease agreement with GJ Eco Power Pvt Ltd, the 20-acre property in Brahmapuram will have to be leased out for 20 years.

“The ownership right on the land will remain vested with the lessor. The concession agreement signed in 2016 is a licence to use land. It has no mention of leasing out land. Only a portion of the agreement regarding land use needs to be changed. When the concession agreement was signed officials were ignorant about the lease. Now the government is coming up with six more similar plants. Under the lease agreement, only the equipment set up on the land can be mortgaged. Since we received all the required permits, the agency had started groundwork at the site. The lease agreement is only for raising funds for setting up the plant. Pilling work will start after February 18 soon after KSEB removes a tower in the area,” said a GJ official.

Title: Highest number of road accident deaths, but Tamil Nadu reluctant to slap high fines
Content:
Experts said steep fines, as proposed in the new MV Act, would check chronic violators

CHENNAI: Tamil Nadu has implemented only a handful of changes proposed in the new Motor Vehicles (Amendment) Act, 2019. However, despite leading the country in the number of road accident deaths (12,216 in 2018), the state is hesitant to slap higher fines on violators, as proposed by the amended law, fearing opposition.Transport minister M R Vijayabaskar, in an earlier interview to TOI, had said the proposed fines were “abnormal” and would be reduced considering inputs from various stakeholders.A team comprising officials from the state transport department and traffic police studied how other states have implemented the new Act and submitted a revised fine slab. The file is pending with chief minister Edappadi K Palaniswami since September. The government had conducted a couple of meetings to discuss the same but no decision has been taken.“We have recommended a 10% to 20% increase in fines (compared to existing fines as per old MV Act,1989) for many offences, including speeding, driving without helmets and driving uninsured vehicles,” said a transport department official.The new Act proposed a fine of Rs 5,000 to Rs25,000, or three years imprisonment for some of the offences.Some of the very few changes introduced by TN include removing minimum age required for commercial driving licences, mandatory driving tests while renewing expired driving licences and few online vehicle registration procedures.Transportation activist K Kathirmathiyon said the government delayed implementation of fines keeping local body polls in mind. “But what is stopping them now? Further delay will defeat the entire purpose of the Act. Hefty fines alone will deter motorists from violating traffic laws,” he said.Other experts said the state was gearing up for elections in about a year’s time and this could be one of the reasons why the government has put the new rules in the cold storage.Road safety researcher M Radhakrishnan said before introducing any new law, the state has the responsibility of holding public hearings and spreading awareness among people. The failure to do so was the main reason to hold back the new Act. “The police came out with announcements on new fine structure even before ensuring that they have necessary equipment to collect penalty from violators,” he said.As per the new Act, driving licence and vehicle details of repeat offenders, booked for major offences identified by the Supreme Court committee on road safety, would be uploaded on Centre’s VAHAN portal. This requires handheld devices but all enforcement authorities are not equipped with them.“Forget about educating people on hiked penalty, even the basic requirements for imparting driving lessons to people are not fulfilled by driving schools. The Motor Vehicle Rules in the Act says a 5,000sqft area is needed for conducting driving classes for people. None of the driving schools has this,” said V S Suresh, a Madras high court advocate.The public has other reasons to worry about besides hefty fines. S Dinesh, a resident of Taramani, said, “Even when the fine amount is Rs 100 to Rs 500, traffic police demand bribes. Can’t imagine how they will start chasing down us when penalties become Rs 10,000 or more.”

Title: Chennai Metro News: Chennai Metro rail has no rule to penalise men boarding ladies coach
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Frequent announcements are made at all stations warning men not to occupy the ladies coach but there are no sq... Read More

CHENNAI: It has been nearly five years since the first metro line opened in the city but Chennai Metro Rail Limited (CMRL) is yet to have a penalty policy in place to curb men travelling in a ladies coach. While a metros in Delhi and Bengaluru have implemented strict rules and slapped fines on violators, male commuters travelling in ladies coaches in the city’s metro trains continue to go unchecked.

Frequent announcements are made at all stations warning men not to occupy the ladies coach but there are no squads or police personnel to check these compartments periodically. “We do not have rules to make men travelling in ladies coach an offence. So we cannot penalise them,” an official said. “In other metros like Delhi, it is based on instructions given by the metro rail organisation,” the official added.

One of the reasons for not penalising commuters, according to sources, is poor patronage. Metro trains here have an average daily patronage of 1.16 lakh while the estimated patronage is nearly 7.76 lakh.

CMRL operates a four-car train and has one coach with a capacity of nearly 312, exclusively for women. The four cars are linked without any partition unlike suburban trains which have either separate compartment or are partitioned with an iron sheet.

Male commuters would restrict themselves to the two common coaches earlier when the patronage was low, as they had ample space to sit even during rush hour.

But now, after the patronage has reached a daily average of 1.16lakh, women commuters have started complaining that male commuters walk into their coach both during rush hour as well as in non-peak hours when other coaches are not crowded. “Women in Delhi are aggressive. They chase away men walking into the ladies coach. Here women barely show the courage to talk because others won’t back them up when they ask men to leave the coach. At times, elderly men occupy our coach and that makes it even more difficult for us to ask them to leave,” said Uma Chandran, a regular commuter from Shenoy Nagar to Ekkattuthangal.

In suburban trains, operated by Southern Railways, special squads conduct surprise checks and slap a fine of Rs 500 on those violating the rules.

CMRL officials said all metro follow Metro Railways Operations and Maintenance Act that details offence and punishment, which does not specifically mention about men travelling in ladies coach. “But that will change soon. Amendments are being made to the Act and all metros were asked for suggestions. One of the suggestions made was to make men travelling in ladies coach as a punishable offence. The amended Act is yet to be tabled in the Parliament,” a CMRL official said.

Title: Gehlot goes back on his promises: Poonia
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Jaisalmer: BJP state president Satish Poonia on Saturday said that there are many issues that need discussion in the assembly. He was speaking here to the media during his one-day trip. He also alleged that chief minister Ashok Gehlot goes back on his promises.

Poonia added that in the Congress manifesto it was stated that power tariff will not be increased for five years, but it was not to be so. “The chief minister had promised to give unemployment allowance but only 1.5 lakh people got it while 27 lakh are still waiting,” he added.

The BJP leader also alleged that the law and order situation is deteriorating. “Rajasthan did not have a full-time home minister and the CM who has this portfolio did not have time to take care of the situation,” he added.

Regarding the Congress’s decision to not implement CAA, he said that this is a law and it cannot be stopped from being implemented.

He said that assembly speaker CP Joshi has also said that Rajasthan will have to implement this law.

Title: Goa: Cops fail to file charges in 60 days, Nigerian gets bail in drugs case
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Representative image

PANAJI: A 29-year-old Nigerian national caught with narcotics on October 26, 2019, has been released on conditional bail after the additional sessions court found that the police did not file a chargesheet within the time limit of 60 days.

Kingsley Echezone Igweze staying in Siolim filed an application for default bail stating that no chargesheet was filed by Goa police’s anti-narcotics cell within 60 days and that the quantity of narcotics recovered from him was a variable one.

The court of additional sessions judge Kshama Joshi found that the chargesheet was filed on January 24, the day after Igweze filed his application for default bail.

The court order came two days after chief minister Pramod Sawant said that he had instructed the police department to take strict action against the drug peddlers operating in the state.

T George, counsel representing Igweze, relied on the recent order of the high court of Bombay at Goa passed on January 23 where the high court found that another Nigerian national Felix Odede was “entitled to bail by default” as the chargesheet in his case was filed beyond the 60-day period.

In its decision the high court held that the chargesheet has to be filed within a period of 60 days where the offence is punishable with up to ten years of imprisonment.

“In the present case, the applicant is alleged to have committed offence punishable under Section 21 (b) of NDPS Act wherein the punishment is with rigorous imprisonment for a term which may extend to 10 years and with fine which may extend to Rs. 1 lakh,” the court stated.

In Odede’s case too the chargesheet was filed on January 22, only after he moved the high court. The quantity of narcotics in his case was also of a variable quantity (6.635 grams of cocaine and 8.542 grams of MDMA) which entails punishment only up to ten years.

As per the decision cited the time limit for filing the chargesheet is 60 days and therefore, the applicant is entitled to be released on default bail on stringent conditions as laid down in the decision as the applicant is a foreigner.

In both cases the Nigerians were granted conditional bail on furnishing bail bonds of Rs 1 lakh and directed to deposit their original passport and visa with the investigating officer and not leave the state without prior written permission of the court.

Title: Andhra Pradesh: Tirumala gears up for Sri Lankan PM Mahinda Rajapaksa visit
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Mahinda Rajapaksa

TIRUPATI: Officials of the Tirumala Tirupati Devasthanams, in coordination with the district administration and Tirupati urban police wing, have made elaborate security arrangements for the two-day visit of the Sri Lankan Prime Minister Mahinda Rajapaksa , along with ministers A Thondaman and KN Devanand to Tirupati on Monday and Tuesday.

The entourage will arrive on Monday night and leave on Tuesday morning. The Sri Lankan PM and his entourage will offer prayers to Lord Venkateswara during the Suprabatham seva on Tuesday. tnn

Title: Chennai: NGT seeks report on illegal fish market in Chintadripet
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Chintadripet fish market

CHENNAI: Chennai’s iconic 203-year-old Chintadripet fish market is functioning from an unauthorised complex and has no trade licence, Greater Chennai Corporation told the National Green Tribunal (NGT) Southern Zone.

“If it is not legally permissible then what is the action taken to remove such illegal activity,” NGT questioned the corporation and Tamil Nadu Pollution Control Board (TNPCB) while giving them a month to submit a report on possible pollution at the site.

The petitioner S Ranjith Fernando said the fish market, run by a political leader, with 19 shops and spread over 9,600sqft was not maintained properly with no mechanism to dispose and treat water and fish waste. Odour from the market affected the surrounding air quality, he said.

The petitioner said vendors use nitrogen, phosphorus and potassium that will have an adverse impact on the quality of water and soil if discharged untreated.

Last December, TNPCB inspections revealed that waste generated while cleaning fish and prawn were manually collected and stored in plastic bins which were later collected by the corporation.

Water was let into sewer lines and bleaching powder was used to disinfect the area, TNPCB said.

The corporation said the market building had no approved plan and owners/occupants did not submit copy of the plan as directed by courts in the past.

“So it is to be treated as unauthorized construction. It is revealed that shop owners do not have licences... There was no maintenance of the building and it is not in good shape and condition despite warnings from sanitary inspectors to maintain hygiene,” the corporation added.

The fish market association represented by its head D Y Mohammed Saliha requested an alternate place to run the market.

The case will again be heard by NGT on March 18.

Title: Chicalim, Sao Jose de Areal oppose ‘urban area’ tag
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Vasco: Members of the Chicalim gram sabha , at Sunday’s extra-ordinary meeting, unanimously resolved to oppose the urbanisation of Chicalim village .

Claiming an ‘ulterior motive’, the villagers alleged that the local government has joined hands with the real estate lobby for their own gains, causing them to go against public interest.

They also demanded that local MLA and panchayats minister Mauvin Godhino addresses them and clears his stand on the notification of the government.

“Undeterred urbanisation with increased real estate development, will greatly harm Chicalim’s sensitive ecology, biodiversity and heritage,” activist and villagers Cyril Fernandes said.

In Sao Jose de Areal, too, the gram sabha rejected the state’s notification of the village as an urban area and unanimously resolved to remain a ‘rural area’.

The members further resolved that the village panchayat shall forward the resolution to the government, asking it to immediately drop the subject notification and retain all villages in the list as ‘rural areas’.

Title: Biometric-based boarding within 2 years at Cochin airport
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

A view of Cochin International Airport

KOCHI: In line with the Union government’s Digi Yatra progamme that envisages the digital processing of passengers at airports, the Cochin International Airport Ltd ( Cial ) plans to implement biometric-based e-boarding system within two years to offer its passengers a seamless, paperless and hassle-free transit through all major check points — terminal entry, security check, boarding gate, and aircraft boarding.

Cial authorities said that the system is aimed at improving passenger experience by reducing waiting time in queues as they can walk through e-gates swiftly. Also, it will augment access control of airport authorities as ticket counterfeiting could be checked completely through e-tickets with unique barcodes thereby preventing illegal entry into the terminal. Cial has invited tenders from qualified companies in this regard.

Under the system, the passengers will have to go through a one-time registration at the airport where they will be giving out their personal details, any one of the government IDs (Aadhaar, voter’s ID card, driving licence, passport etc.) along with their facial biometrics to the airport operators. The passenger will thus get a unique Digi Yatra ID which will be used at the time of booking. The data will be stored in the airport’s database under each Digi Yatra ID and will be processed to identify the passenger later whenever he uses the airport to fly to other places. This will make the passengers’ entry at all the checkpoints seamless and fast.

“E-boarding intends to strengthen access control, paperless boarding and reducing human intervention in identity check, is expected to be completed in one and half years. Physical examination of boarding pass and identity cards at multiple checkpoints is the most time consuming process at airports. As Cial’s passenger traffic is increasing, the rush at counters will be high and the system will be a solution to make the process fast,” said a Cial official.

All the e-tickets provided by airlines or ticket facilitator applications have a 2D/QR Barcode following the concept ‘One person, One Ticket & One Code’. So that each passenger, even in a group booking, will be issued with individual ticket having unique code, which is linked to the servers of airlines, security agencies, customs and airport authorities. Within seconds, the system can compare the details in ticket and ID and give clearance.

“The passenger only has to scan his boarding pass in mobile phone at a scanner placed at the security area for frisking. Once the machine approves the ticket and his identity through facial scan, CISF personnel will let him pass through a terminal placed at his end before frisking the passenger. In this method, those using fake tickets could be caught easily. At present, anybody can create a paper ticket and use an ID to enter the terminal. Once e-boarding is implemented only bonafide passengers will be allowed entry,” an official said.

Title: Saraswati river flowing underground in Rajasthan: Union minister
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Gajendra Singh Shekhawat

JAISALMER: Union jal shakti minister Gajendra Singh Shekhawat said Saraswati river is flowing under this part of the land and its existence has been proven.

“Scientifically it has been confirmed that Saraswati river is flowing beneath the ground. In addition, there are many streams that flow under the ground which directly connect the Himalaya glacier to the sea,” Shekhawat said.

Speaking about PM Narendra Modi’s dream project Namami Gange, he said work was going on mission mode. He said people during the last Kumbh Mela had felt it that Gangotri water in Haridwar could be used for consumption.

Discussing about stopping water to Pakistan, he said India and Pakistan had signed the Indus water treaty. PM had already announced that now it was not possible that terrorism and water could flow together. “All preparations have been done to stop the flow of water to Pakistan,” he said.

The Union minister said many technical studies were done in which the existence of Saraswati river flowing underground had been proved.

The minister said the Congress government in Rajasthan had cheated the farmers and did not waive off their loans.

“The youth are also feeling cheated as the promise of unemployment allowance has not been fulfilled. The state has also hiked power tariff. People have lost faith in this government,” he added.

He said the Congress had become irrelevant in the country.

Title: Goa: Abandoned, cured patients find unwilling home at asylum
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Officials say it’s almost impossible to trace residences of some patients

PANAJI: A peculiar problem at the Institute of Psychiatry and Human Behaviour (IPHB), Bambolim, has left the authorities scratching their heads — many patients do not go home even after they’re cured, and stay at IPHB till their death.

Many of them either have no family, or are abandoned by their kith and kin.

Information obtained under the Right to Information (RTI) Act reveals that as of December 2019, 76 patients have been residing in IPHB for over five years, and since 2013, 29 patients have died while at the institute. It is, however, unclear if they had been declared mentally fit, as the IPHB didn’t have the relevant records.

“It is not possible to trace patients as some of them are from outside the state and are unable to recall their home address after recovery,” an IPHB official said. The problem is more acute in the case of women patients, authorities say, as it’s practically impossible to trace their residences. Some of them — either abandoned or lost — don’t even remember their home state.

“Many of these patients had never before moved out of their house, let alone travelled,” said an IPHB official.

“Male patients fare better, and are at least able to recall some details like the name of their village or directions to their residence.”

The institute, which admits on average three patients a day, has 190 beds. In 2019 alone, it saw 1,104 admissions. Many of the institute’s patients with behavioural problems are picked up by police personnel and taken to IPHB for treatment. Some of these are brought in straight from Goa’s railway stations. “In these cases, the person is made to board a train and naturally, they disembark at the last station (Margao).”

In recent years, the internet has come to the aid of the authorities, who often use the resource to track the families of patients on the basis of sketchy details they provide. “However, our efforts don’t always bear fruit,” an official said. And when there’s no immediate family, “they continue to remain at the hospital”.

Meanwhile, the Goa government has proposed a “half-way home” to accommodate IPHB patients who have recuperated, or require more time to recover but are unable to go home for lack of family support or absence of family.

GMC dean S M Bandekar said that he is aware of the problem. “The chief secretary has approved the proposal for the half-way home,” he said. “Patients with no families, after their initial treatment, will be placed in the half-way home and looked after.”

In the past, 38 IPHB long-stay patients were discharged and housed at Provedoria, the government’s institute of public assistance.

Title: Establish a rapid response mechanism: Min to officials
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Vijayawada: The minister for panchayat raj and rural development (PR&RD) Peddireddy Ramachandra Reddy directed officials of the department to establish a Rapid Response Mechanism (RRM) in coordination with the energy department and Energy Efficiency Services Limited (EESL) to ensure all the LED street lights in the state are at 100% capacity all the time.

At a review meeting with the officials and all stake-holding departments on Sunday, Reddy said that the state government had transformed the governance in rural areas with the establishment of village secretariats. As all the services and grievances are being addressed in 72 hours through village secretariats, issues with LED light illumination should also be addressed within 72 hours.

To achieve this, Reddy suggested the EESL, a public sector undertaking of the union ministry of power to strengthen field level network for quick response to the complaints. “Even as EESL is making some fruitful efforts, it has to be improved further to reduce delays for which coordination with stake holding departments is required,” he said.

The officials of the energy department told the minister that measures have been taken to put in place a web portal to redress the complaints of street lights not working. Village volunteers will identify the issues at field level and report to village secretariat, where a ticket will be raised for deployment of quick response teams.

EESL officials told the minister that the LED street lighting programme taken up in Andhra Pradesh is presently the world’s largest programme. The EESL has made an upfront investment of Rs 800 crore to install 23.54 lakh LED lights across the state. The officials further said that they are planning to install another three to five lakh LED lights in the uncovered areas and extended colonies.

Installation of LED street lights is estimated to have saved 260 million units of energy per year that would translate into Rs 156 crore in monetary terms, according to the officials.

Title: New office-bearers for CII Trichy zone
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Trichy: The annual meeting of CII Trichy zone was held on Saturday to elect the new office-bearers. V Vasudevan, managing director of Sangu Chakra Hotels, was appointed chairman of CII Trichy zone for the year 2020-2021. Senguttuvan Duraisamy, the executive director and unit head, Kauvery Hospital, Cantonment, Trichy was appointed vice-chairman.

Title: 9 is number of choice for newly inducted Karnataka ministers
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Ten Innova Crysta cars are parked at Kumarakrupa guest house for the newly-inducted ministers

BENGALURU: Officials of the department of personnel and administrative services (DPAR) were surprised when a huge majority of the ministers inducted into chief minister BS Yediyurappa’s council of ministers last week demanded official vehicles bearing registration numbers either ending in nine or adding to nine.

"We’ve had ministers either asking for a specific number or not caring about it at all, but this is the first time a majority of new ministers were after one number - nine," a senior DPAR official said.

The ministers, however, said it had nothing to do with numerology or astrology. KR Pete MLA KC Narayanagowda’s vehicle bears registration number 2727. Sources say Narayanagowda had written to the department demanding a vehicle whose registration number adds to nine.

Hirekerur MLA BC Patil, who took oath along with Narayanagowda, has got a car with the registration number 0009. Patil insisted it wasn’t a collective decision by the defectors-turned-ministers nor was it designed.

"I chose the number thinking it is a lucky number. I did not contact any astrologer," he said, adding: "When I won the 2018 assembly polls with 555 votes, I bought a vehicle with the same number assuming it to be lucky. Now, I chose number nine, but it is not that I planned always to have it."

ST Somashekar’s Innova Crysta bears the registration 0045. "I never believed in numerology," the Yeshwantpur MLA and minister said. "How can nine be a lucky number for me? I have already suffered for six months. I certainly did not ask for any specific number."

But sources say the new ministers chose the number as they think their decision to shift parties in 2019 gave their political careers a major boost. Also, they were influenced by the fact that Yediyurappa proved his majority in the assembly on July 29, 2019.

Vijayanagar MLA Anand Singh has also got an Innova Crysta bearing the number 4999. "I feel 9 is now my lucky number. I have not contacted any numerolgist," Singh said.

Shivaram Hebbar of Yellapur constituency bucked the trend. He opted for 6000. Hebbar said he chose the vehicle because it was in good condition and not for the number.

Astrologer S Krishna Kumar, who is also director of the astrology course at Bharatiya Vidya Bhavan, said vehicle owners prefer registration numbers ending or adding up to 9 or 5. “In numerology, these two numbers are auspicious. Vehicles with these registration numbers are expected to bring good things to owners and also ward off bad things,” he said.

Title: Differently abled couples tie the knot
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Jaipur: About 47 differently abled couples tied the knot at 34th Royal Mass Wedding Ceremony held in Udaipur on Sunday. These couples took a pledge against dowry system by participating in the mass wedding. More than 30 couples have undergone corrective surgery treatment. The event was organised by Narayan Seva Sansthan. A couple — Ramu Kumari and Ganpat from Pratapgarh suffer from polio. They always wanted to settle in their lives but their disabilities were the biggest obstacle in finding a suitable partner.

During the ceremony, 47 couples got household items, sarees and blessings of thousands of people. The marriage was a celebration like any other wedding with photography, long marriage procession, videography, music, baggis etc.

Title: Rajasthan govt transfers 37 IAS officers ahead of budget
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

JAIPUR: The state government transferred 37 IAS officers in a major bureaucratic reshuffle on Sunday, the move coming days before the budget.

Ajitabh Sharma, who was principal secretary to the chief minister, was relieved from the responsibility at the CMO and given charge of energy and discoms at a time when the power utilities are making huge losses.

He will also hold additional charge as chairman of Rajasthan Energy Development Corporation Ltd and Rajasthan Renewable Energy Corporation Limited.

Recently, the government had approved an average 11% hike in power tariffs across sectors, excluding small and medium industry. The hike was highest for the agriculture sector at 18% followed by domestic consumers.

Kunji Lal Meena, who was in-charge of energy department and discoms, has been shifted to mines and petroleum department as principal secretary. The post was earlier held by Dinesh Kumar, who has now been appointed chairman and MD of Rajasthan State Vidyut Prasaran Nigam Ltd.

Senior IAS officer Sudhansh Pant, who was on central deputation, has been brought back as principal secretary, forest and environment department.

Naveen Jain has been made RSRTC managing director. He has been replaced by Neeraj Kumar Pawan as secretary of labour and employment department.

Title: Mind over matter: Soaring through skies to keep India safe
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

HYDERABAD: The Indian Peace Keeping Force (IPKF) was deployed in Sri Lanka and a transport aircraft was on a mission to take supplies from India to the country that was going through an internal strike. The aircraft was to return to India but it was noticed that a propeller had caught fire. Ravirala Jayasimha of the Indian Air Force (IAF) who was part of the crew reacted instantaneously. He jumped out of the cockpit and put out the fire. The propeller had suffered damage but the challenge was to fly it back to India.

“I made all mandatory checks and told pilots that we should be able to fly out. The plane could fly but there probably would be an issue if we faced turbulence. Since we could also depend on the second engine, I suggested that we fly and the pilot trusted me enough,” Jayasimha recalled.

But in the process of putting out the fire, Jayasimha suffered burn injuries on his hand. The scars have remained but he prefers to view them as proof of the courage he displayed.

Even as a child, Jayasimha was not used to giving up. Hailing from Nalgonda in Telangana , he joined school at the age of 12 in class 7 and soon topped his class. It was his headmaster who changed the way Jayasimha thought about life. The teacher gave him Rs 40 as a gift. “Does one get rewarded like this?” he asked the teacher innocently. “Achieve greater things and the rewards will come by themselves,” the teacher answered. In class 10, he topped the school. In Intermediate, he stood third in Andhra Pradesh .

Jayasimha’s journey with the Indian Air Force began as an Airman. But the journey wasn’t without challenges. They initially did not select him because of medical reasons. The malnutrition was evident. When he went for recruitment into the IAF, they told him that he would die on the running track itself as he was too weak to even run.“If I have to die, I might as well die doing that,” he told them. “You should have eggs and milk and come back for the test after three months,” they told him.

Jayasimha’s family was not economically sound and he could not afford that diet. He came back only to fail the test again. A conditional offer was made as he was sent for training to Chennai. Three months later, he passed the medical test. He excelled in the course and was assigned to the post of lead aircraft maintenance technician.

When Jayasimha was posted in Amritsar, a Cheetah Chetak helicopter developed problems. Just when the others had given up, Jayasimha took charge and carried out repairs to make it fit to fly. He went on to take the SSB exam that would put him in the officer rank. He not only made it to the Air Force Academy in Dundigal but also passed out as ground duty officer. Jayasimha rose in ranks to become a squadron leader in the IAF.

He went on to join the Defence Services Staff College at Wellington and acquired more degrees, including two MSC degrees and an MBA. He also has 14 Guinness world records to his credit in memory and mind education.

After quitting the IAF, Jayasimha started giving inspirational lectures and teaching mind management techniques to improve memory for students.

“An eagle can soar in the sky but it is not enough if it knows that it has wings. It has to take off,” he tells students as he talks to them about tapping into their true potential.

Title: SACON, bird enthusiasts to prepare bird atlas
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Coimbatore: The Salim Ali Centre for Ornithology and Natural History ( SACON ) along with bird enthusiasts have decided to create a bird atlas for the district. The atlas would document the bird diversity in the district.

Kerala is conducting bird-based surveys to document the scientific distribution of birds in the state. Following the same technique adopted by Kerala, bird enthusiasts have decided to prepare the atlas for the district.

“The enthusiasts had already divided the district into cells and sub cells. Every 3.3 square kilometer is considered as a cell and each cell has nine sub cells. The district has as many as 37 cells and 111 sub cells,” said a bird enthusiast who is involved in the study.

Explaining that they have been planning to carry out the survey on random basis, he said they have been planning to record the activities of bird at a cell for once in 15 minutes for four times from 6am to 11am on daily basis. tnn

Title: Green solution for temple waste
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Workers collect palm leaf waste from Ernakulathappan Ground

Kochi: Every year during the annual temple festival, the Ernakulam Siva Temple, like all places of worship, generates several tonnes of waste. Disposing them of is a problem for which they have to take the help of Kochi corporation.

But, this year, the problem transformed into solution as Pelican Biotech, which is in need of biodegradable waste for creation of soilless planting medium used to convert medians under the Kochi Metro rail into gardens, were in need of organic material to be used in four medians near Jos Junction. “On Wednesday, we collected around three tonnes of waste from the temple which would be used at medians near Jos Junction. Work on the decorative garden is being carried out with CSR funding from Cochin Shipyard,” said Pelican Biotech CEO C N Manoj. The waste comprised of elephant dung and remains of palm leaf fed to elephants brought to the festival.

Pelican Biotech is using biodegradable waste collected from various sources to transform 16 medians of Kochi Metro into decorative gardens. “The total length of medians would come to 160m and we would need 160 tonnes of waste,” said Manoj. Fifty percentage of the waste, which gets transformed into soil transplanting medium, has to be replaced every six months.

Ernakulathappan Kshetra Kshema Samiti president R Rajendraprasad said while waste generation on ordinary days mostly consists of garlands used on deities and tender coconut shells after abhishekam, more amount of waste is generated during festival. “Normally, we depend on the Kochi corporation but this year we decided to provide the waste to Pelican Biotech after they approached us,” he said.

According to Rajendraprasad, the temple administration has successfully introduced a ban on plastic inside the temple premises. “We can say that it is now 99% plastic free. We also had done a campaign to make Sabarimala pilgrimage green,” he said.

Title: CMC Colony housing unit residents’ woes worsen
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Coimbatore: Residents of CMC Colony housing unit are in a spot.

On one side, the Tamil Nadu Slum Clearance Board (TNSCB) is planning to demolish the dilapidated housing unit and start reconstruction work by March. On the other side, the Tamil Nadu Electricity Board (TNEB) has disconnected the power connection, which the residents had drawn illegally for the construction of temporary shelters that are being set up adjacent to the housing unit.

The move has hit the work of makeshift shelters, on which they have already invested Rs 50,000 each, and they won’t be able to vacate the housing unit without an alternate accommodation facility.

Ramesh, a 51-year-old sanitary worker, said, “The power connection was disconnected a week ago. But we can’t afford to delay the construction of temporary shelters. First of all, the housing unit could collapse anytime. Secondly, I have already borrowed Rs 50,000 by pledging bank passbooks and am not in a position to spend more.” His monthly salary is just Rs 9,500.

Now that the power supply is disconnected, the residents are forced to carry water in drums from public toilets for the construction work. The welding work has also been hit and they are now forced to use nuts and bolts to connect the pole joints. “We don’t know how strong the shelter would be. But we don’t have any other option,” Ramesh said. He, along with his family members, has been constructing the shelter on their own.

A total of 200 families are affected by the TNEB’s move. While a majority of them have stopped the construction of makeshift shelters mid-way, others are in a hurry to complete them.

Another resident, Ganeshan, said they were forced to stop the construction work as they could not drill poles and metal sheets to make holes in the absence of power supply. “There is also pressure on us to vacate the housing unit at the earliest. We don’t know what to do.”

The housing unit is almost 30 years old. TNSCB had intimated the residents its decision to reconstruct the housing unit a few months ago and asked them to vacate the place at the earliest. Subsequently, some of them had either moved to their relatives’ places or rented out a house. More than 200 families were, however, left with no other option but to construct temporary shelters nearby.

A resident, who has completed the work on the shelter, said that was not livable. “The heat is unbearable inside the shelter. The situation is difficult for everyone, especially children, who are not used to sleep without fans. We don’t know how long we have to bear this.”

When contacted, a TNSCB official said the TNEB had disconnected the power supply as that was drawn illegally. “The city corporation has now submitted an application seeking power supply for the residents and it is likely to be provided to them in a week. If the occupants vacate the housing unit this month, the reconstruction work would commence soon,” the official said.

Title: Race on in MVA for president’s post in township authority
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Pimpri Chinchwad: The race has heated up in the Maha Vikas Aghadi (MVA) for the president’s post of Pimpri Chinchwad New Township Development Authority (PCNTDA). The MVA government replaced the BJP-appointed Sadashiv Khade with the Pune divisional commissioner Deepak Mhaisekar.

The PCNTDA was set up in 1972 with a vision.

It is an autonomous institution meant to look into building of housing colonies for people and infrastructural projects that would be needed in the limits of the Pimpri Chinchwad Municipal Corporations areas. Nigdi Pradhikaran, Wakad, Thergaon, Bijlinagar, Moshi and Kalewadi were some areas of its jurisdiction.

The Fadnavis-led BJP government too did not appoint any politician to this post for over three years.

Later it nominated Khade on September 6, 2017 who continued in office even after the Maha Vikas Aghadi government came to power. The state government issued a government resolution on February 3 replacing him with Mhaisekar.

Now, there are strong aspirants for the post among all the three parties.

Not a single Congress candidate won the 2017 municipal elections so there is no Congress corporator among the 128 elected members of Pimpri Chinchwad Municipal Corporation (PCMC). If the Congress gets allotted the post of PCNTDA president, it will help the party get at least one big government post in the city.

Former MLA Vilas Lande, former mayors Yogesh Behl and Mangala Kadam, former opposition leaders Bhausaheb Bhoir and Datta Sane are among the main contenders from NCP for this post.

In the Congress some top contenders are Pimpri Chinchwad city unit president Sachin Sathe, former mayor Kavichand Bhat and Shyamala Sonavane.

District unit president Gajanan Chinchwade, city unit president Yogesh Babar, former group leader of corporators Sulabha Ubale are the main contenders for this post in Shiv Sena.

Sathe and Sanjog Waghire, president of Pimpri Chinchwad unit of NCP said, “The allotment of the state-run corporations and authorities(pradhikaran) among the alliance partners is yet to be decided. We would like it if the state unit of our party tries to get this post allotted to us.”

Title: Online database helps identify 1.31L fake ration cards
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

caption

Bhopal: Almost a month after the launch on ‘One nation, one ration card’ scheme, which includes MP, around 1.31 lakh people have been found to be registered at more than one location. As many as 50,000 people under below poverty line (BPL) have been deleted from the list and more are likely to follow, according to officials.

The new scheme is aimed at providing portability of Public Distribution System (PDS) entitlements. The mechanism aims to ensure that no person under BPL or person entitled to PDS is deprived when he or she moves from one place to another. Currently, the scheme is being implemented in 11states, including Madhya Pradesh.

The PDS software system was integrated between the 11 states. Data sharing revealed fake ration card holders to the tune of 1.31 lakh, according to district food controller Jyoti Shah Narvariya.

The Union government has given a one-year deadline till June 30, 2020, to states and Union Territories for rolling out the ‘One nation, one ration card’ system, under which beneficiaries can buy subsidised foodgrains from ration shops in any part of the country.

Currently, the 11 states under the scheme are expected to easily implement the PDS portability within their state as Point of Sale (PoS) machines have been installed in all ration shops. There are about 439 PDS ration shops in Bhopal. An estimated one lakh people in the division are labourers from nearby states or districts.

This facility will be of great help to a family or a person shifting from one state to another. The idea behind this initiative is that no poor person or family should be deprived of ration, for want of a ration card of that particular state. Apart from this, the new initiative will also help in weeding out fake BPL card holders. The new initiative is being implemented through IMPDS (Integrated Management of Public Distribution System), an online database.

Title: ‘A piece of Pune in Nashik through Happy Streets’
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Nashik: Over 1000 participants took part in the second edition of this year’s ‘ Happy Streets ’ organised by the Times group at Dindori Road on Sunday.

Deputy commissioner of police, Amol Tambe, was encouraged by the participation of people and called the event as a ‘ piece of Pune ’. “In the past 20 years, the city has advanced multifaced, which was to be seen at the streets today. There are many ideological exchanges taking place. The hope for innovative ventures for artists is also growing through such platforms,” said Tambe.

The half-a-kilometer stretch between RTO Corner and Kishor Suryavanshi Road at the Dindori area on the outskirts of the city was thriving with life and energy with people from all quarters.

The two-hours event which kick-started at 7 am saw equal participation from the female counterparts. Deputy Municipal Commissioner Archana Tambe appreciated the women for coming out in numbers.

“The women are always busy with family responsibilities. The opportunity to relish music and art is less for them. The initiative of ‘Happy Streets’ gave them an opportunity to take time out for themselves and get stress free,” said Tambe.

Many new activities like a magic show, quilling, charcoal painting, live music, cycling, etc were seen on the streets. Many new stalls were also seen at the Sunday event.

The most popular item was Zumba that kept the crowd swirling over Bollywood songs for two hours continuously. The dance-lovers had filled half of the area to dance on the roads.

People brought their bicycles, yoga mats, calligraphy stationery, rangoli colours, etc to embrace the congestion of free roads.

A 73-year-old Subhash Bhavsar showed stunts while riding his bicycle without holding hands. All the onlookers could not stop themselves from appreciating his balance. “There are two more Sundays left for this year’s Happy Streets. We will make sure that the citizens enjoy the most and begin the year with a lot of vigour and delight,” the organizers said.

The event will take place at Govind Nagar on February 16 and at Nashik Road on February 23.

Title: Students find answers to overcome exam stress, counsellors to rescue
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Nashik: While the SSC and HSC exams are just round the corner, Maharashtra State Board of Secondary and Higher Secondary Education have released a list of the contact numbers of counsellors who are available for the students to help them overcome their stress and other issues.

A total of 10 contact numbers have been provided by the board to assist the students during the board examinations. The counsellors are available between 8 am till 8 pm until March 23. The students have already started making the calls and seeking help for examination related issues.

“I have already received over 15 calls since Saturday. There is only a week’s time left for the students to write their examinations. Most of the students ask what they should do if they forget answers during the examinations,” a counsellor said.

Stress is common these days for the students as well as for the parents. “Not only students but parents also place a call to guide their children. Since there is less time left for the papers to begin, I advise them to revise only what they have studied to date so that they do not forget their answers,” said the counsellor.

The students from Pune, Nagpur, Aurangabad, Mumbai, Kolhapur, Amravati, Nashik , Latur and Konkan area can contact the counsellors to get rid of stress before or after an examination.

The board has requested the students and parents in its circular not to contact the counsellors to get the information regarding examination centres, seating arrangement or question paper as the information regarding this is available at the respective division offices.

“Students want to know how to boost confidence. Time management is another general question. We encourage the students to stop panicking during the examination if they do not know the answer to any question” another counsellor said.

Most of the counsellors hail from Pune and Mumbai, who are experts in their fields. The board has instructed the counsellors not to reveal their names but has released the list of the contact numbers.
