“However, some land belongs to the IAF which is needed for the airport as are plots owned by private landowners. In the last advisory committee meeting, we had talked at length about them. Once these issues are cleared, things will be in order,” he said.

Title: Consumer forum pulls up insurance company for failing to reviving cover
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Nashik: The Nashik district consumer forum has pulled up an insurance firm for its failure to extend the promised cover despite fulfillment of all formalities and ordered it to compensate the consumers Rs 15,000 for harassment, both physical and mental.

“The failure of the insurance company in extending the insurance cover despite completing the formalities by the consumers amounts to deficiency in service. Though there was no claim filed by the consumers and they were hale and hearty, the company has to compensate for the mental harassment faced by the consumers when they were abroad,” read a February 2 judgment delivered by a three-member forum.

Pious David (72) and Thalema Pious (68) residents of Nashik Road had been to Australia from November 3, 2017 on a tourist visa. Both had paid premiums of Rs 5,169 and Rs 5,789 to ICICI Lombard insurance company for a health cover of USD 50,000 during their stay till December 15, 2017.

According to the consumers, they had chosen to take the insurance cover from the company on condition if they were able to extend the same after completing the formalities.

“The clients paid the required premiums and went to Australia on tourist visa. For some reasons their stay abroad got extended and hence got in touch with the insurer requesting to extend the cover as well. They even completed all the formalities but the company simply refused extension for no valid reason,” MK Vaishnav, counsel for the applicants, said in the case registered with the forum on March 31, 2018.

“The complainants witnessed an accident in Australia where there was a huge casualty and was disturbed with the thought how could they deal with such medical injury if they were part of the mishap,” Vaishnav added.

In its reply the company through its counsel PP Pawar claimed that there was no medical claim filed by the consumers with it. Besides it was not biding upon the company to extend the cover. “Whatever has been said in the complaint is fictitious and hence the case may be dismissed,” Pawar had said.

“It is observed that the company has in its terms and condition stipulated the process for extension of cover which was followed by the complainant from abroad. The company by turning down the request without any valid reason has caused mental harassment to the consumers,” the forum said asking the company to pay Rs 10,000 as compensation for mental harassment and Rs 5,000 for physical harassment.

Title: Jaywalking no crime, 3 pedestrians die every day in Gujarat
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

AHMEDABAD: Jaywalking , or crossing the road without regard for approaching traffic , has become so commonplace in the city that it is no longer perceived to be a crime. Throwing caution to the wind, and putting their own lives and the safety of others at risk, Amdavadis walk across streets with impunity while vehicles are on the move. On the flip side, most zebra crossings meant for people to walk across the roads, are taken over by vehicles that stationed at red signal.

Road safety consultant Amit Khatri says, Nearly 65 to 70% of the pedestrian accidents are caused because of jaywalking. He says that till this date pedestrians are not being fined for being careless on the road, and not respecting street signs. “It’s a behavioural issue. Ear pods are plugged in, often people are seen talking on mobile phone while crossing the road,” says Khatri adding that Artificial Intelligence powered CCTV cameras can now recognize jaywalking. “The traffic police should be asked to locate such individual on the spot and fine them,”

According to the report, “Road Accidents in India – 2018” of the Union government, on an average, three pedestrians are killed in Gujarat every day in road accidents. As many as 1,170 pedestrians were killed in road accidents during the year 2018 in the state. The report found footpath encroachments played a major role in such incidents by forcing people to walk on the road space meant for vehicles.

Title: Delhi assembly elections: How eroding share of Congress may further boost AAP
Content:
File photo

NEW DELHI: A further decline in the prospects of Congress in Delhi, though not unexpected, seems to be powering AAP ’s success, as has been predicted by various exit polls. Most polls forecast zero seats for Congress though one has given it four, with a vote share of 8.8%.In 2015, Congress had a vote share of 9.8%. Psephologists don’t seem to believe that the party can match even that figure this time round. Unlike BJP, which mounted an aggressive campaign, the grand old party was largely missing in action. AAP claimed that a major chunk of late voting had gone in its favour even though BJP maintained that the reality was quite the opposite.Congress’ loss is being seen as AAP’s gain, as any vote-split would have helped BJP make deeper inroads.Sources said among a few constituencies where Congress ran a strong campaign were Kasturba Nagar, Gandhi Nagar, Seelampur, Mustafabad, Badli, Sultanpur Majra, Chandni Chowk, Hari Nagar, Dwarka, Kalkaji, Sangam Vihar and Kondli. However, with party bigwigs conspicuous by their absence for most of the campaigning, it was left for the candidates to fend for themselves. To their credit, many of them conducted door-to-door meetings and made extensive use of social media, besides holding small public meetings on their own, the sources added.But for most parts, the campaign failed to generate a lot of excitement. While BJP and AAP ran high-octane campaigns, Congress adopted a laid-back approach, with not many senior party functionaries hitting the ground in support of its candidates. In the last week of electioneering, several star campaigners, including Rahul Gandhi and Priyanka Gandhi Vadra and ex-PM Manomohan Singh and chief ministers of Chhattisgarh and Punjab CM, did address public meetings, but it all appeared to be too little too late.“Congress doesn’t appear to be very strong this time. When it was in office in Delhi, the party carried out a lot of development work,” said Hiten Sharma, a voter at Chanakyapuri. The party, too, chose to harp back on its past record, often invoking the tenure of three-time CM, the late Sheila Dikshit.While some candidates blamed the delay in distribution of tickets for the lackadaisical approach, others claimed that there was a lack of coordination from the central office. A candidate, requesting anonymity, said that the party had failed to back the contestants on the ground. While the more resourceful candidates could still power their campaigns, the newcomers fought lone battles.In contrast, sources in AAP said, the party had managed to project itself as an alternative to people who previously voted for Congress. “A large chunk of Congress voters shifted to AAP across various assembly segments. It will significantly increase our vote share and lead to the party breaking its own record of 2015,” claimed an AAP functionary. In 2015, AAP had won 67 of the 70 assembly seats.Even though Congress failed to match the electioneering blitzkrieg of AAP and BJP, the chief of the party’s Delhi unit, Subhash Chopra, claimed they would surprise everyone with their performance when the results finally came out.

Title: Cold is back and so are diseases
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Bhubaneswar: The return of cold wave after a spell of rain and the prevailing inclement weather have led to outbreak of diseases. Cough, cold, respiratory diseases and bronchitis are affecting a large number people.

Many are also suffering from ailments like asthma, body ache, joint and muscle pain and skin diseases. Doctors said precautions like avoiding exposure to cold, maintaining personal hygiene and keeping distance from affected persons can keep people away from diseases.

“Influenza is a winter disease and people generally suffer from common cold, running nose, sore throat and cough in this season. With the drop in temperature, viruses get active in the atmosphere as a result more people, especially children, elders and those with history of asthma and chronic diseases, fall sick,” said Dr C B K Mohanty, director of medical education and training (DMET).

Several parts of the state experienced rain and thundershowers for the last few days with bone-chilling wind making a comeback. Both day and night temperature has dropped significantly. The Met office forecast cold wave conditions will prevail in coastal and interior districts for some more days.

On Sunday, Koraput and Sundargarh recorded 10 degree Celsius, the lowest minimum temperature in the state, while the minimum temperature in Bhubaneswar was 15 degree Celsius, an IMD source said. The state witnessed a sudden fall of temperature. “Due to this, cold and cough affected my child. Children are going to school, getting exposed to cold wind and are falling sick. It has become a big problem as final exams are starting from tomorrow (Monday),” said Shrabani Mishra, mother of a 10-year-old son. Doctors also advised eating of healthy food.

Children with low immunity generally fall ill during winter. “Apart from common cold, fever and cough, many kids also complain of tonsil infection due to exposure to cold wind and by taking cold drinks and ice cream in this season. Kids also get stomach flu in winter and complain about abdominal pain, diarrhoea, excessive flatulence, vomiting and fever,” said senior paediatrician Dr S S Mohapatra. Hospitals across the city said the number of patients complaining flu-like symptoms has increased in the last one week.

“Winter is the season of flu and bad weather aggravates it to serious conditions. Besides, this is the season when cases of swine flu and pneumonia are reported,” said Dr Dhananjay Das, deputy superintendent of Capital Hospital here.

The weather condition is hazardous for people with history of asthma and respiratory diseases. Doctors advised patients not to take them lightly and avoid self-medication.

“Many people take common cold very lightly and take medicine of their own. Parents must ensure their children cover ear, nose and neck when they are going out,” said Dr Swarupananda Mishra, ENT specialist.

Title: Pune: Three steal domestic LPG and sell it for commercial use, booked
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

The incident occurred on Friday night in Indiranagar in Bibvewadi. Police found about seven cylinders stored i... Read More

PUNE: The Bibvewadi police on Saturday booked three men, including the brother of a sitting corporator, for mishandling LPG cylinders, which resulted in an explosion that left one person injured.

The incident occurred on Friday night in Indiranagar in Bibvewadi. Police found about seven cylinders stored illegally in the house that was damaged in the explosion.

The injured person, Rajaram Bhawarlal Bishnoi, alias Raju, is a 29-year-old resident of Upper Indiranagar . He sustained 30% burns and is getting treated at Sassoon General Hospital, said sub-inspector P M Waghmare of the Bibvewadi police station.

Fire brigade officials said the explosion occurred around 11.30pm on Friday in a small house located in a slum pocket. The entire house, in which the cylinders were stored, caught fire as a result. Two fire tenders rushed to the spot. The firefighters safely removed the cylinders from the house, and rescued Bishnoi and took him to the hospital. The house was damaged in the incident.

Sub-inspector Waghmare said the seven cylinders had no supporting documents. “The cylinders should be in the custody of the LPG agency or with the authorized personnel,” he said.

Waghmare said their investigation has revealed that the three suspects were involved in illegal trade of the LPG cylinders for the past few months.

“One of the three suspects owned the house and rented it to the other two. One suspect is employed by a LPG agency as a delivery boy for the Bibvewadi area,” Waghmare explained.

The delivery agent would steal cylinders meant for the domestic use from the agency and take them to the house. “Bishnoi and another man were employed in the house. The delivery boy also used to bring empty cylinders meant for commercial purposes,” Waghmare said.

“The two workers used to take remove gas from the domestic cylinders with the help of a machine and transfer it to the commercial cylinders, which they sold to different eateries and other establishment,” Waghmare said.

Cylinders for domestic use are subsidized by the government, while commercial cylinders are more expensive, police said.

“They had to break the seals to steal gas from the domestic cylinders. The delivery boy would reinforce the seals and deliver them to households. This way, they also cheated many families,” Waghmare said.

In his statement, Bishnoi told police that on Friday night, there was a brief power outage in the area, when they were transferred the gas. “When the power supply resumed, there were a few sparks, which caused a cylinder to explode,” Waghmare said.

The three suspects have been booked under the sections 188, 285, 287, 338, 436 and 420 of the Indian Penal Code. Police have also invoked provisions of Essential Commodities Act and The Explosives Rules, 2008.

Title: MEMU train from Deolali station soon
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Nashik: The Bhusawal divisional railway that has flagged off the fourth Mainline Electrical Multiple Unit (MEMU) said that it will soon start the promised Deolali-Bhusawal MEMU train . However, the railways refrained from setting up a deadline for the project.

The Bhusawal division on Saturday night flagged off the Bhusawal-Badnera MEMU service. It was inaugurated by local MP Raksha Khadse.

Divisional railway manager Vivek Kumar Gupta said, “It was the fourth MEMU train started in Bhusawal division and the first from the headquarters. We would be focusing on starting one between Deolali ( Nashik ) and Bhusawal soon.”

The MEMU rake has Linke Hoffman Busch (LHB) coach platform and is quite safe and comfortable for longer rides, railway authorities said, adding that MEMU trains will have rest-room facilities as well.

The Bhusawal-Badnera (Amravati) MEMU train that was flagged off from Bhusawal will operate on a regular basis start from the divisional headquarters at 6.30 am and will halt at 24 stations before reaching Badnera Junction at 11.25 am. In the return journey, the train will depart from Badnera Junction at 1.30 pm and reach Bhusawal at 6.55 pm.

Title: ‘We are targeting over Rs 5L-cr in investments in third edition of Make in Odisha conclave’
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Though the third edition of Make in Odisha conclave is months away, preparations have started in right earnest. State industries and micro, small and medium enterprises (MSME) minister Dibya Shankar Mishra provides a glimpse of the government’s plan during an interaction with Sujit Bisoyi

Odisha is gearing up for the third Make in Odisha conclave this year… What are the plans?

The state government has successfully hosted two editions of Make in Odisha conclaves. Many of the proposals received during the two conclaves are under various stages of implementation. Countdown has already begun for the third edition, which will be even bigger. We hope to get positive response from the investors this time as well. Our target is to attract investments worth more than Rs 5 lakh crore in the third edition of the conclave.

The government had held national and international roadshows ahead of the 2nd edition of Make in Odisha. Any such plans this time?

The exercise has already began with two roadshows in Bengaluru and New Delhi to showcase the state’s business ecosystem in different sectors. More events, including international roadshows, are on the anvil. We are planning a mega show in Delhi (date yet be finalised) which will be attended by the chief minister ahead of the conclave’s third edition. The aim is to reach out to maximum investors to showcase our business ecosystem and growth potential.

What do you think are Odisha’s biggest advantages?

Over the past two decades, our government has been committed towards developing infrastructure like road, railways and port. The state now has three deep sea ports while some more are under construction. The state has rich mineral resources, skilled manpower and land bank. Above all, we have a stable government that takes firm decisions. All these factors make Odisha the most favoured investment destination in the country.

The state and Centre are working together on most issues now. Do you think it will have a positive impact on the state’s industrial growth?

Our CM has always stressed that interests of the state are paramount. We believe in constructive cooperation with the Union government. Whatever cooperation we need from the Centre to further develop the investment climate in the state, we will ask for it. I am hopeful that the Centre will also extend full cooperation on all fronts. What is the government’s vision to boost MSME sector?

If you have seen our six priority areas or focus sectors, we have mostly focused on downstream and ancillary industries. This will hugely boost the MSME sector in Odisha, which has the potential to create enormous employment opportunities. Growth of MSME sector will largely help in growth of state’s economy. To facilitate the small and medium industries, the state government has created sector-specific industrial clusters in different parts of the state. Besides, we have formulated policies with attractive incentives.

Odisha had roped in Japan as country partner for second edition of the conclave…

We sincerely feel that any international partnership is always welcome. Japan will always be there as one of our potential partners. As far as country partner for the third edition of Make in Odisha conclave, the discussion is on at different levels. We will get a clear picture after a few months.

Odisha is yet to get any significant response as far as foreign direct investment is concerned…

A long-term exercise is needed to get international investment. We are on the right track. Going by the response received during the recent roadshows in Guangzhou, China, and Singapore, I can say that Odisha is being considered as a potential investment destination. We are optimistic that the state will get more foreign investments in the years to come.

Where does the state stand in respect to investment intents received during the previous two conclaves?

Many of the intents have been converted into actual investments after dedicated teams were formed to follow up with the investors, who had evinced interest. We had received 84 and 202 proposals in the first and second editions, worth Rs 6.26 lakh crore. Of these, we have so far approved 120 proposals worth more than Rs 2.5 lakh crore. Many of these projects are under various stages of implementation.

There have been frequent agitations related to land acquisition…

There is hardly any agitation now against land acquisition for industrial projects. In fact, the state government has expedited the land acquisition process for some big-ticket projects.

Title: Living under stress? Umang helpline will come to your rescue
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Bhopal: To avoids adolescents making risky choices, combating stress, battling fear psychosis and assisting them with general adolescence problems, a helpline — Umang — became operation in the city from Sunday.

Umang offers a glimmer of hope to adolescents undergoing dilemma, trauma and anxiety.

An adolescent facing any such problem can make a call on phone number 14425 for seeking counselling on the issue putting him/her under stress.

A press communique released by the district administration said that the helpline would not only counsel students facing examination stress, nervousness at the time of examination result, but will also address other issues common at an adolescent age such as inferiority complex, substance addiction, suicidal thoughts, or problems faced in selection of subjects for further studies.

The communique stressed that trained counsellors would be deployed to address issues raised on the helpline. A friendly behaviour on their part with the person on the other side of the helpline would be ensured, and secrecy would be maintained about identity of the caller. Counselling would be carried out to a caller even if he does not disclose his name or personal details. If required, follow-up calls can also be made on the toll-free helpline number.

Principals of all the private and government-run high schools and higher secondary schools have been asked by the district administration to apprise students of their school on the helpline number, so that they are able to share their problems relating to examination stress or other issues and get a proper counselling.

They have also been asked to put up information about “Umang” on their school campus, so that students are able to take advantage of it and results of their school also improves.

Title: Apply for blockchain course before Feb 11
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: The entrance examination for admission to blockchain ABCD course , conducted by Kerala State Development and Innovation Strategic Council ( K-DISC ), will be held on February 15. Applications can be submitted online at https://abcd.kdisc.kerala.gov.in before February 11.

Engineering and science graduates and working professionals are eligible to apply for the accelerated blockchain development (ABCD) programme, which offers huge employment potential.

The entrance examination will cover topics such as numerical ability, logical reasoning and computer science basics. It will be held at the centres of the ICT Academy in Ernakulam, Kozhikode, Thiruvananthapuram and Thrissur. The registration fee is Rs 500. The candidates should also remit Rs 1,000 as course advance fee. It will be reimbursed to those who fail to qualify in the entrance examination. Women candidates who score 60% are eligible for 100% scholarship and others will get 70% scholarship on the course fee. Classes will begin in the last week of February. For more details, contact 0471-2700813 or 8078102119.

Title: City-based woman duped of Rs 51L
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Nashik: An online fraudster, pretending to be based in London, duped a city-based woman to the tune of Rs 51 lakh over a period of one-and-a-half year. A complaint in this regard was registered with the cybercrime police station.

Police said that the fraudster first won the victim’s trust and asked her to transfer money in his bank account from time to time. However, after she realised that she was being cheated, she approached the cybercrime police with a complaint.

Police said the 43-year-old complainant, a school teacher by profession, got acquainted with a person on a social media website in November 2018. The suspect told her that he was based in London. Later, the teacher and the concerned person often contacted each other on social media website, phones calls, etc.

As days passed, the conman won the trust of the woman after which she started sending him money.

Devraj Borase, senior PI of the cybercrime police station said that the conman who used to speak and chat with the victim only in English used to assure the latter that he would come and meet her in India.

A few months back, the conman told the victim that he had sent a gift to her address. A couple of days later, he told her that the gift was stuck with the customs department and that he would need some money to clear the article from the aforesaid department.

The woman paid a huge sum of money to the conman. Borase said that the woman sold her jewellery and also used her savings to give money to the conman with the hope that he would come to India and meet her.

However, after the woman had spent Rs 51 lakh on the conman, she realised that she was being cheated. Upon realising her mistake, she discussed the matter with a friend. The woman that realised that she could be taken for a ride by the unidentified man after which she lodged a complaint with the cybercrime police station.

The police said that similar cases have occurred with several people in the past.

Title: Bengaluru: 2 Iranians held for robbing cash from showrooms
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Illustration used for representational purpose.

BENGALURU: RMC Yard police arrested two Iranians who allegedly stole money from car showrooms by diverting cashiers’ attention in Bengaluru, Udupi and Mangaluru .

The accused would approach the cashiers, asking for change for Rs 2000 notes to divert their attention and flee with cash from the showroom. Saeed Rostami, 26 and his friend Saber Hossein Eghbalzadeh, 35, are both residents of Tehran and in India on tourist visa.

The duo landed in New Delhi on January 16. Later, they arrived in coastal Karnataka before reaching Bengaluru on February 1. The same day around 4pm, the two visited Trident Automobile Pvt Ltd’s service centre in RMC Yard. They went to cashier Kiran and sought change for Rs 2000. One of them dropped the note and Kiran picked it up for him. Meanwhile, Kiran also noticed there was no change in his cash box and informed the duo accordingly. “Kiran later realised Rs 44,000 was missing from the cash box. He verified CCTV footage and found the two visitors stole the money when he bent down to pick up the Rs 2000 note,” a police officer said.

Kiran filed a theft and cheating case against the men. RMC Yard police suggested Kiran circulate the footage at other car showrooms and service centres as they had heard about similar incidents being reported from Udupi, Mangaluru and other places in Bengaluru. “Sharing of CCTV footage helped us nab the suspects. They visited a showroom near Cauvery junction on Ballari Road on February 6. The staff noticed the duo and realised they were the same guys, who had stolen the money at RMC Yard and informed us,” said police.

Title: Non-NCERT books in CBSE schools ruffle feathers
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Bhopal: Madhya Pradesh Parents’ Association has expressed displeasure over the Directorate of Public Instructions order to CBSE schools to send them a list of non-NCERT textbooks prescribed by them.

The members of the MPPA said, the DPI is giving the private schools liberty to prescribe books by private publishers — which are unnecessarily more expensive than the NCERT.

“The Madhya Pradesh education department had passed an order in 2018 stating that all private CBSE schools should use NCERT books ... and in turn not force parents to buy expensive books by private publishers. The orders clearly state that the schools found guilty of prescribing books by private publishers in place of NCERT books can lose their NOC and recognition. But even two years later, this order has not been implemented,” said Prabodh Pandya, secretary of MPPA.

Citing examples of several noted private schools affiliated to the CBSE board in Bhopal, Pandya said, “I have the lists of all the books prescribed by the private schools. They are only using NCERT books for Hindi and Social Studies and have prescribed books by private publishers for all other subjects. Why?”

“The orders by DPI further give the schools the liberty to prescribe books by private publishers. The education department is not asking them clearly to follow the orders issued by it in 2018 and still beating around the bush by quoting the CBSE by-laws that state schools 'may' prescribe books by private publishers, but should give preference to NCERT books? The Delhi high court has also given a decision on this matter and the state's orders are also available”, Pandya said.

The members sent a letter to the Madhya Pradesh education minister Prabhuram Choudhary regarding the matter on Sunday.

Commenting on the issue, education minister Prabhuram Choudhary said, “We have asked all the schools to provide us the information of the books they are prescribing in the school curriculum. Schools cannot pressure parents to purchase extra books and will have to follow the rules laid down by the education department of MP. If we get a complaint regarding the same, we will take strict action against the school.”

Title: KWA adalats in all dists before Feb 28
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Palakkad: Kerala water authority ( KWA ) will organize adalats in all the districts before February 28 to address complaints of consumers.

Minister for water resources K Krishnankutty has issued the directions to KWA to organize the adalats, KWA officials said.

The complaints can be filed with the respective sub-division assistant executive engineers before February 22. The date of adalat in Palakkad district will be announced shortly, they said.

The adalats will help in ensuring drinking water supply to consumers, including the government and other offices. It will also aim to save the water lost in pipe bursts, leakages, digging of roads, etc.

The complaints of excess bills, faults in water-reading meters, bills charged during the non-supply of water and during the non-functioning of water meter, excess water charges due to delay in the conversion of building construction connection to domestic connection, fine on delay in payment of water bill, etc, could be addressed during the adalat that will help both KWA and the consumers, the officials said.

Title: 21 pistols, 50 cartridges seized in Delhi
Content:
This story is from February 10, 2020

Representative image

NEW DELHI: Hours before Delhi started voting on Saturday, Special Cell tracked down a huge cache of weapons and ammunitions brought to the city to disrupt law and order. The consignment, containing 21 pistols and 50 live cartridges, was brought to Delhi by two smugglers from Madhya Pradesh, who have been arrested.

The carriers were identified by the police as Pritam Singh (20) and Santoshi (50) from Morena in MP. Police are looking for the receivers and suspect that gangs of northeast Delhi and UP had ordered the weapons. The carriers claimed they had no details about the identity of the receivers and the kingpin of the racket had told them that they would be contacted by them once they reached the location of delivery.

The operation was conducted by a team led by ACP Lalit Mohan Negi and Hriday Bhushan, who have been tracking three arms supply modules from MP for the last one year. “Gangs are indulging in supply of illegal weapons to the criminals of NCR. Keeping in mind the upcoming Delhi assembly elections and in order to cut this supply of illegal fire arms and ammunitions to the criminals, intensive efforts were being made to track and arrest the illegal arms traffickers,” said Pramod Kushwaha, DCP (Special Cell).

The team received information that two carriers involved in interstate illegal firearms trafficking would be coming to northeast Delhi’s Dilshad Garden to supply these weapons.

A trap was laid and the accused were arrested with 21 pistols, including 11 semi-automatic pistols of .32 bore and 10 single shot pistols of .315 bore. They were also carrying 20 cartridges of .32 bore and 30 cartridges of .315 bore. A case was registered against them.

During interrogation, Santoshi revealed that he had been arrested and sent to jail in a case of brawl and met arms traffickers inside the prison.
